DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th item on Stormie Jones to UPDATE with Jones' condition worsening
DOC.TEXT: Transplant recipient Stormie Jones developed hepatitis in her second transplanted liver and was in serious condition Tuesday, doctors at Children's Hospital said. The 13-year-old girl flew here from her home in White Settlement, Texas, on Saturday to be tested after experiencing fatigue and a change in her liver enyzyme levels. Hospital spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said Stormie's condition was downgraded from fair to serious Tuesday after tests confirmed she had hepatitis, an infectious inflammation of the liver. Stormie made medical history in 1984 when she became the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient. The operation took place on Valentine's Day at Children's Hospital. Hepatitis damaged Stormie's first transplanted liver, which was removed in February. The girl received a second liver in February of this year, also at the Pittsburgh hospital. Last month she suffered a mild episode of liver rejection and returned to Children's for tests. Doctors adjusted the dosage of her anti-rejection medication.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Policemen, Judge Murdered; Car Bomb Deactivated
DOC.TEXT: Apparent hired assassins killed another seven policemen Wednesday in Colombia, and a judge handling drug trafficking cases was shot to death, authorities said. Three of the policemen were shot to death on the streets of the northwestern city of Medellin, headquarters of the world's largest cocaine gang, a spokesman with the police department said in a telephone interview. The Medellin cartel has unleashed a bloodbath against Colombian policemen, especially in that city. The three deaths Wednesday in Medellin brought to 132 the number of policemen killed in that city in 1990. The cartel has said it will pay about $4,300 to gunmen for each policeman killed in Colombia. Drug traffickers and government security forces have been locked in a deadly war since last August's slaying of a presidential candidate who advocated extradition of drug suspects to the United States. The police in Medellin meanwhile deactivated a car bomb Wednesday carrying 1,000 pounds of dynamite, the police spokesman said. The dynamite was in a taxi and was armed with a fuse and detonators, the policeman said. The taxi was in a parking lot only about a half-block from the city government's administrative office building. It was the second car bomb deactivated in Medellin in a week. In the last 10 months, the traffickers have responded with 283 terrorist acts, including one on a domestic airliner, that have killed 274 people.

DOC.HEAD: House Rejects Homosexual Protection Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday rejected legislation to protect homosexuals from harassment after an ugly debate in which one lawmaker labeled colleagues bigots and others called gay men and lesbians perverts. The House defeated the measure 118-80. Its sponsor, Rep. Babette Josephs, a Democrat, said after the vote she was unsure what move to take next, but vowed not to let the issue die. Under the measure, the same state law that gives special protection to religious, racial and ethnic groups would have been extended to include homosexuals. The bill would have extended the tougher penalties for bias crimes to protect people who are thought to be homosexual. ``We have a growing and serious problem of violence against people perceived to be gay or lesbian,'' Ms. Josephs said. ``The problem is real, pervasive and growing.'' In one of the most impassioned speeches of the debate, Rep. Thomas Murphy Jr., said he was disturbed by discussion and jokes around him on the House floor slamming homosexuals. ``This is bigotry in action. You don't have to go a local bar or sports stadium to hear bigotry, you can sit on the House floor and listen to it,'' Murphy said. ``Your snickers say you're bigoted. You don't condone a different lifestyle.'' Opponents of the bill criticized not only the measure, but also homosexuality. ``I feel in my heart and in my gut that to pass this bill is wrong,'' said Rep. Howard Fargo, a Republican. ``It's wrong to do anything legislatively to promote sexual perversion. It's wrong to do anything legislatively that would lead to the further deterioration of the traditional family and its values.'' Supporters said the issue was not one of morality, but of law and order. One group lobbying in favor of its passage, the Pride of Philadelphia Election Committee, which supports gay rights candidates, had distributed a pack of letters from supporters including Gov. Robert Casey's administration. Rep. Karen Ritter, a Democrat, said Pennsylvania had the most homosexual-related murders in the nation last year. ``We are not providing special treatment to perversion as has been suggested. Bigots who are unsure of their own sexuality have already singled out homosexuals for special treatment through violence,'' Ms. Ritter said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Recover Stolen Masterpiece
DOC.TEXT: Police have recovered a painting by 18th-century master Giambattista Tiepolo that was stolen from a Venice church last week. Police were investigating another theft Tuesday when they found Tiepolo's ``The Martyrdom of Saint Bartholomew'' in a house near the Church of San Stae. A search of the home of Stefano Frizzon, 30, turned up items linked with the robbery of the painting, the Italian news agency ANSA said. Under questioning, Frizzon said he stole the masterpiece to sell it to support his family, the agency said. Frizzon led police to the painting, tightly rolled in a plastic bag and hidden in the home of an unsuspecting neighbor, the report said. The picture had been cut from its frame Thursday night. Police said the burglar climbed through a window in the church, which did not have an alarm system. The painting suffered minor damage, but can be restored, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Queen Elizabeth Sees Site of Oldest Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Queen Elizabeth II and her husband Prince Philip took a bus ride into Iceland's rugged interior to see the historic site of the world's first Parliament. The drive on Tuesday from Reykjavik, the capital, to Thingvellir where Iceland's legislature, the Althing, was founded in 930 A.D. was the highlight of the three-day state visit which began Monday, the first by a British sovereign to Iceland. The royal couple took a lengthy walk down a rocky ravine to the Lawspeaker's Rock, where in ancient times an elected chieftain presided over the assembly. The royal couple _ both passionately fond of horses _ also visited a stud farm that breeds the sturdy little horses of Iceland, which are known for their a gait that gives riders a comfortable seat.

DOC.HEAD: Government Publishes Catalogue of Stolen Art
DOC.TEXT: In a major effort to crack down on art thefts, France has published the first catalog of art works stolen from its national collections. The authors of the catalog found that most recent thefts were from museum storage rooms, not exhibit halls, and were probably inside jobs. It lists 200 works stolen between 1979 and 1989 from museums throughout the country. Five hundred copies of the catalog are being distributed to police, museum and customs officials, art dealers, auctioneers and experts in a new effort to track down stolen art and crack down on resale on the international market, according to Andre Treps of the Interior Ministry. Written by museum curators Jacqueline Munck and Vincent Pomarede and published Tuesday, the catalog urges art professionals to take a more forthright approach to the problem. ``Too often, people in charge of the art collections after a theft feel guilty and have an understandable desire to cover it up,'' the curators wrote. Many French museums do not like to discuss art thefts and blame the media for ``falsely drawing attention to security problems,'' they wrote. The report, however, said that despite increased media coverage in recent months, there has been no upsurge in thefts. Many museum officials may be uncomfortable with other findings published in the catalog _ such as the fact that 57.5 percent of the art works stolen from museums were taken out of storage rooms, and the thefts were probably inside jobs. Only 40 percent of the works were actually removed from exhibition walls, the report said. ``Stealing works from storage is a very peculiar crime, usually committed by a guard or office worker, not for financial gain, but usually out of spite or the desire to have a souvenir to keep,'' the report said. The catalog lists the stolen works in alphabetical order, provides photographs of each work, says when and from where it was stolen, and gives pertinent information on the artist. The catalog, published by the Department of National Museums and the Interior Ministry, is to be updated on a regular basis.

DOC.HEAD: APPLE CRUNCH: Hudson Valley Growers Face Their Troubles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Nine generations of Cosmans, six generations of Clarkes and four generations of Crists have worked the land of the Hudson River Valley. Sometimes, their apple orchards have been bountiful; sometimes, they have not. But generally, they have kept their problems to themselves. It is a measure of their fears for the future that they sought out reporters from the city to tour their farms and hear about their troubles. ``The last two or three years, apples have not made money,'' said Steve Clarke from Prospect Hills Orchard Inc. in Milton. Consumers, and farmers, worry about chemicals. Farmers can get more money selling their land to developers than farming it. Competition from the Northwest and abroad is squeezing their apples off store shelves. And bad weather and pests, of course, never go away. How do growers survive? ``We go from year to year and look at the future and hope we're going to be here,'' Larry Cosman said at his Mount Airy Farm in the hamlet of Middle Hope, where he grows 250 acres of apple trees. ``I think the odds are kind of against us in the sense that progress will prevail sooner or later and push out some of the farms,'' he added later. Not that the farmers are railing against progress. ``We brought you up here to show we don't have our heads in the sand,'' said grower Jeff Crist. Farmers are adapting by getting closer to consumers, like the pick-your-own orchards at Clarke's farm, and with dwarf trees, which can be planted more densely and pruned and picked more easily. They also are starting sales organizations that market fruit from a group of farms, and are selling directly to restaurants, at farm markets and stands, and abroad. ``Ten years ago, it was enough to know what was going on in the confines of your orchard. It's not enough anymore,'' said Mike Moriello of New Paltz, trying to be heard over Joe Porpiglia's water dump, which washes apples and sends them down to the waxer. Not all have adapted. Some have sold their land, lot by lot. ``It's like they're treading water,'' said Elizabeth Ryan, who owns a 35-acre farm with her husband and is compiling oral histories of valley farmers. ``In the '60s and '70s, farmers sold their land, but they sold it to farmers. Now they sell it to big real estate,'' said Porpiglia, 60, as he looked out at farms that have been redeveloped for houses. ``For sale'' signs are interspersed among the apple blossoms. Farmland preservation is fashionable, but Crist's wife, Joy, said that just saving land is not the point. ``The emphasis needs to be on supporting and strengthening the farm business,'' she said. That means more research and development, a good, steady labor force, and enough farmers so there's competition among businesses that support farms. ``I don't see a lot of good, active farms going out of business,'' she said. From the early 1800s, growers in the Hudson Valley shipped many fruits by sloop south to New York City and points beyond, including to South American countries now sending apples to the United States. When Larry Cosman was a child, wholesale buyers from New York City would travel the valley, haggling with each farmer on his route. In a 1938 booklet prepared for an apple blossom festival, growers noted they had ``the best market in the world close at hand,'' partly because city consumers cherished the fruits of upstate farms. Cosman's father sold Happy Bee Apples, with cheery, old-fashioned stickers plastered on wooden boxes. Most went no farther than metropolitan New York. In the 1930s, Ryan said, there were 500 farms in Ulster County, on the Hudson's western bank. In 1990, there are fewer than 200 family farms all along the valley, from New York City to Albany, a 140-mile stretch. In 1986, Cosman, 43, abandoned Happy Bee, because he didn't have the volume to market his own label. Now his apples, a dozen varieties from 40,000 trees, are Hudson Valley apples, like his neighbors'. ``Sometimes you talk about it and get a little choked up,'' he said. ``It's a family name. ... It's part of you. Farming is not really a job, it's a lifestyle. And most farmers live, eat and breathe what they're doing.'' But the bottom line must prevail over sentiment. ``It's an international business,'' Cosman said, and the Hudson Valley growers had to market their fruit together to compete with similar labels for Michigan and Washington state apples. Though exports remain a small slice of the U.S. apple business _ 13 million 42-pound bushels in 1988 _ the Cosmans sometimes export 75 percent of a crop. Foreign climes seem very far away during a walk along Latintown Road in Ulster County. McIntosh and lesser-known types of apple trees spread out on all sides, looking as if nothing could touch the serenity. But Alar did. ``If you grow apples, that changed your life forever,'' Ryan said. ``On an emotional level, it was a terrible upset. ... All those guys in Washington told us it was safe, and we believed them. We wanted to believe them,'' said the Cornell-trained pomologist, or fruit specialist, who did not use Alar on her farm. Alar, also known as daminozide, is a growth regulator that slowed maturation and improved color and storage, making it easier to manage harvests. But even in February 1989, when the Natural Resources Defense Council issued its report linking Alar and cancer, few growers were using it, said Ulster County extension fruit expert Warren Smith. Nevertheless, apple prices and sales fell. Growers still are trying to recover from losses estimated at $100 million. Like consumers, Cosman said, farmers have a hard time figuring out which experts to believe. But they respond to consumers and to costs, Moriello said, and for chemicals, the cost has gone up 30 percent to 50 percent in recent years, even though he's using less. Smith said all the valley's apple growers use integrated pest management, a system that combines ecological, non-chemical methods and natural predators with chemicals, ideally fewer and fewer of them. ``We have never recommended calendar spraying when other options are available,'' he said. ``Would you take an aspirin if you didn't have a headache?'' For these growers, migranes are reserved for coping with apple prices. Though supermarkets were selling apples for up to 99 cents a pound, Mike Moriello said he was paid 19 cents a pound wholesale. Preliminary figures for 1989 show Washington state alone growing 119 million bushels for eating and processing, a glut that many growers say combined with the Alar scare for a disastrous year. Michigan was second with 23.8 million bushels, and New York third with 22.9 million. Farmers who made it this far intend to survive. ``We have whittled away our farm population to 2 percent,'' Ryan said. ``The people who are in agriculture now are the people who really want to do it. They're very insightful. They balance an extreme number of risk factors that they don't control, unlike a lot of other businesses. ``There is one saying in the farm community: `These are the greatest gamblers in the world.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Latest Japanese Export Is Apples
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Apple Orchards
DOC.TEXT: The Toyotas on American roads and the Sonys in American rec rooms may soon be joined by Fujis in American lunchboxes _ a Japanese-bred apple that seems to be the fruit of the future. Growers say Japanese bud wood grafted onto trees in the central Washington apple belt produces an apple that is crisper, tastier and more durable than Red Delicious, the industry standard since the 1920s. The Fujis also are bringing much higher wholesale prices _ not a minor consideration after three consecutive years of poor prices that have caused many growers to reassess the heart-shaped Red Delicious. ``There will be more change in the apple industry in the state of Washington in the next 10 years than in the last 30,'' said Brooke Peterson, a Washington State University tree fruit extension agent in Yakima County. He likened Washington apple growers, who produce 60 percent of the nation's crop, to U.S. automakers who were ``so big and so successful for so long'' that they failed to respond to the Japanese challenge. ``All of a sudden they are nipping us in the heels,'' he said. As a result, growers must produce a better and more diversified product, he said. Currently, 70 percent of Washington's apple crop is Red Delicious. ``We're in a revolution in supplying the public with an apple more satisfactory to their needs,'' said Grady Auvil, a legendary grower from Orondo who pioneered Washington production of the tangy Granny Smith a decade ago. Auvil, 84 and still out in his Columbia River orchard every day, is planting only Fujis on his 500 acres now. ``Twenty to 30 percent of the time the Red Delicious arrives to consumers in poor condition,'' Auvil said. The Fuji, first bred in Japan 35 years ago, has a longer shelf life, and shrivels on the outside before it softens inside, Auvil said. Too often, consumers complain of biting into a good-looking Red Delicious that is mealy. Tastes in apples change just as tastes in clothing, music or other products change, some growers say. Where consumers once clamored for bright red colors and the heart shape, now they are demanding better taste. The oblong-shaped Fuji has dull red stripes over a greenish-yellow base. Red Delicious apples cover more than 120,000 of the state's 160,000 acres of apple orchards. Trees take several years to bear fruit, so it will be some time before a flood of Fujis hits supermarkets, said Chuck St. John, a spokesman for the Washington Apple Commission. He also said it is much too early to write off the Red Delicious. ``It is not an inherently bad apple. Otherwise consumers wouldn't buy it,'' he said. ``We can grow Red Delicious and Golden Delicious better than they can be grown almost anyplace else in the world.'' The Red Delicious first was produced in a Midwest orchard in 1870 and was transported to Washington soon after. By 1915, the state was the nation's leading apple producer. But growers are struggling. Two seasons ago, the crop was severely damaged by excessive heat, and last year's sales and prices were hurt by the Alar scare. This year, the record crop of 78 million 42-pound boxes of eating apples has been bringing prices beneath the cost of production. Where boxes of Red Delicious sell for about $10 per box wholesale, Fujis sell for up to $40, said Jeff Main of the Market News Service in Yakima. Market News Service does not officially record Fuji prices, because there are so few available, he said. But it is likely that will change in the next three or four years, he said. The Fuji craze is reminiscent of the rush to plant Granny Smiths a decade ago. That tart apple now accounts for 5.5 percent of the state's crop. When Granny Smiths debuted, they, too, brought much higher prices. Now they are bringing about $15 per box, still better than Red Delicious. Auvil predicts Red Delicious will go the way of the Winesap in the next 30 years, and will be replaced by the Fuji. ``It is the one sweet apple you can always deliver with good quality if it starts the trip in good quality,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Cracks Down on Dissidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Worry about domestic economic turmoil and the global crisis of communism is causing authorities to get even tougher with dissidents and people they don't trust, Vietnamese and Western sources report. The crackdown has included arrests, tightened surveillance and suppression of the only legal dissident group, the Club of Former Resistance Fighters. At least half a dozen foreigners have been detained since April and two Americans accused of anti-government activity were deported. Sources said conservatives appeared to have gained the upper hand over those in the Communist Party leadership who favor economic and other reforms. ``There is a tremendous sense of insecurity'' in top party ranks, said a source with access to many officials. ``There is a tightening up, and everybody is more cautious and afraid to say anything. They don't acknowledge it, but you can see it in their faces.'' On June 16, Hanoi radio said the Interior Ministry counterintelligence force and police, in coordination with the armed forces, had ``promptly cracked down on many troublemaking and sabotage activities.'' Security forces ``caught 30 persons violating Vietnamese law and discovered over 200 foreigners entering the country illegally,'' the radio reported. It said they ``destroyed five underground reactionary organizations and captured tens of their members,'' and seized publications ``with reactionary contents.'' Many people ``have taken advantage'' of international organizations investing in Vietnam to infiltrate and spy, according to the broadcast. Thirty of more than 100 enterprises involved in joint ventures with foreign companies were found to be operating illegally, it said. Hanoi radio said the crackdown was connected with major anniversaries, an apparent reference to the 15th anniversary April 30 of victory in the Vietnam war and the centenary May 19 of the birth of independence leader Ho Chi Minh. Authorities feared protests on both days, but none materialized. Sources say dissident activity in Vietnam is minimal and the actions reflect ``paranoia'' over the possible loss of political and economic support from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Another factor, they said, was the bold challenge by pro-democracy demonstrators last year in China. A Hanoi radio report May 23 claimed the CIA had subverted Eastern Europe and was trying to do the same in Vietnam by circulating leaflets and employing tourists, overseas Vietnamese, minority ethnic groups and Catholics. Many non-Communist nations halted aid to Vietnam after its invasion of Cambodia in December 1978. Washington also forbids commercial dealings, but businessmen from other Western countries have flocked to Vietnam in the increasingly open climate of the past two years. The crackdown appears focused on Ho Chi Minh City, a southern commercial center that formerly was Saigon, capital of South Vietnam. For the first time in numerous visits to Vietnam in recent years, a reporter's papers were searched before his flight left, by a uniformed man introduced as ``a cultural officer.'' When asked the reason for the search, the man merely chuckled. A government employee who was to help the journalist through customs appeared nervous and left early. Two well-connected sources, who demanded anonymity, said they believed the tightening was temporary and did not mean an end to ``doi moi,'' the Communist Party's 3{-year-old economic ``renovation'' program. They added, however, that it might last until a national party congress expected in mid-1991. Most of those detained were either close to the party or members of it, the sources said. The Hanoi radio report said some ``confused and utopian'' party members had aided the alleged CIA sabotage campaign. An early sign of trouble in the party was Tran Xuan Bach's expulsion in March from the ruling Politburo after he supported greater democracy. Security forces also feared the decentralization of the economy and some political affairs had increased public discontent, the sources reported. Farmers demanding land reform marched in Ho Chi Minh City last year. It was the first known street demonstrations under Communist rule. Students have held campus protests of poor conditions at the universities. Hundreds of people protested at the city hall, demanding repayment of money they invested in a perfume company that used liberalized rules to create a pyramid scheme. Smuggling, corruption and crime have become major issues. Authorities decided the presence of foreigners would complicate matters and tightened visa rules in late April, a Vietnamese official said privately. Western businessmen said officials who once pleaded for investment had slowed things down and were preoccupied with ideological matters. In interviews with The Associated Press, authorities said there were no mass arrests. No more than 10 Vietnamese were arrested with businessman Mike Morrow, one of the Americans deported, said Nguyen Son, vice chairman of the information and ideological department in Ho Chi Minh City. Gen. Tran Cong Man, vice president of the Vietnamese Journalists Association, said there have been no mass arrests, ``but many people were warned.'' Morrow said his interrogators were convinced he was a spy and that the United States was trying to ``create a Tiananmen in Vietnam,'' a reference to the Beijing pro-democracy demonstrations crushed a year ago. The American, who was held for three weeks before deportation, said those arrested with him included Do Trung Hieu, a respected intellectual who belongs to the Communist Party. Miriam Hershberger, an American teacher in the capital, Hanoi, was deported June 5 for allegedly trying to incite student unrest. Both Americans were considered sympathetic to the government, as was Chan Tin, one of two Catholic priests detained in May and accused of preaching anti-communism. Like Hieu, he was a leader of wartime opposition to the U.S.-backed government of South Vietnam. The Club of Former Resistance Fighters is made up of southern war heroes and revolutionaries who criticize the party's postwar performance but have not questioned its leading role. In March, the club's two leaders were expelled, apparently on orders from the authorities, a source reported. He said the club approved a resolution in January criticizing the government and demanding more political reform. Nguyen Son, the Ho Chi Minh City party official, denied the report. He said the club's executive board expelled the leaders after they ``wrote and distributed documents calling for protests against the government.'' Son said one of the men, Ta Ba Tang, was under ``temporary detention'' and the other, Nguyen Ho, was at home. He did not make clear whether Ho was under restrictions. A British journalist who reported the club's actions after interviewing Tang and other members was detained briefly and several of his Vietnamese contacts were reported arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Lavish Ceremony Planned as Japan's Prince Weds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Kiko Kawashima is a college student living in a small apartment with her parents, but come Friday, Japan's modern-day Cinderella will call a palace her home. In Japan's first royal wedding in six years, the 23-year-old Miss Kawashima is to wed Emperor Akihito's youngest son, Prince Aya, who is 24 and second in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne. The wedding will be lavish _ the government has allotted nearly $1 million _ and filled with traditions dating back more than 1,000 years. But to a nation that only last year buried Emperor Hirohito, whose 62-year reign spanned a turbulent period of militarist expansionism and economic reconstruction, the wedding also is being hailed as the first taste of a new era. As far as the clearly smitten Japanese media are concerned, Prince Aya could not have chosen a better mate than ``Kiko-san,'' who is only the second commoner to marry into the imperial family. Aya's mother, Empress Michiko, became the first in 1959 when she married Emperor Akihito, who was then crown prince. Akihito ascended the throne immediately after Hirohito's death on Jan. 7, 1989. Most of Japan's major television networks will broadcast live coverage of the ceremony and related events. The wedding is scheduled to begin at 10 a.m. and will be followed by several other ceremonies, so television coverage will likely last well into the night. Along with the countless comparisons to Cinderella, Miss Kawashima has been dubbed the ``Apartment Princess'' because of her relatively humble abode _ faculty housing on the campus of Tokyo's Gakushuin University. At Gakushuin, Miss Kawashima is working on her master's degree in psychology. Her father, Tatsuhiko, teaches economics there. The former peer's school boasts much of the imperial family and former nobility among its alumni. It is where Miss Kawashima and her prince met in 1985, when he too was a Gakushuin student. Since the engagement of Aya and Miss Kawashima was formally announced in September, flocks of reporters often have staked out the Kawashimas' three-bedroom apartment. They have tagged along as Miss Kawashima did her final pre-wedding shopping, and even as she made a rare appearance at a bowling alley. Her score was reportedly about 100. Though the Japanese and their media generally treat the monarchy with great deference, photographing Miss Kawashima's mother hanging the family laundry out to dry is apparently acceptable, as is broadcasting it to millions of television viewers. Aya, who returned Thursday from two years of zoology studies at England's Oxford University, has managed to avoid most of the media blitz. Palace officials say the somber, 15-minute wedding will begin with the sound of shrill classical Japanese music. The young couple, attended by several chamberlains, will slowly walk down a corridor to a wooden shrine at the Imperial Palace. After Aya makes his vows to the sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the imperial family descended, the couple will sip rice wine to seal their marital bond. Later in the day, they are to visit Akihito and Michiko to announce their marriage. In keeping with tradition, the emperor and empress will not be among the guests invited to the ceremony itself. The guest list, however, does include such dignitaries as Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and the heads of the judicial and legislative branches of government. The emperor is to bestow upon Aya a new title to mark his marriage and creation of an independent household. Aya's given name is Fumihito, but Japanese only rarely refer to him by that. Following three days of receptions, and three more days to rest, Aya and Miss Kawashima will travel to the Grand Shrines of Ise, the central place of worship for believers of Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion. Before returning to Tokyo, where they will pay their respects at Hirohito's mausoleum, they also will visit the tomb dedicated to Japan's first emperor, Jimmu, who according to legend began his reign in 660 B.C. Police plan to mobilize 9,000 officers to guard against leftist attacks, and the public will have little chance to see the royal couple in person. But a short ``parade,'' from the Imperial Palace to the Akasaka Palace where the emperor and empress reside, is planned.

DOC.HEAD: Critics See Only Slight Easing in Uproar Over Flag Burning
DOC.TEXT: Senators who defeated a constitutional amendment against burning the American flag say the uproar may have eased slightly in recent weeks but the issue remains a sore point with many voters. ``It's still a tough issue,'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., said Tuesday after the Senate's 58-42 vote for the measure fell nine votes short of the two-thirds margin required. He said the dispute has ``opened a wound in this nation,'' but voters are seeing ``that the fabric of American society has not been threatened by flag burners ... and in the end I think that's what turned this debate.'' On the roll call, 38 Republicans voted for the amendment and seven opposed it. Among Democrats, 20 were for it and 35 against. The vote was largely symbolic because the amendment, which had President Bush's backing, also fell short of the necessary two-thirds vote in the House last week. Democratic leaders attacked it as an infringement on freedom of speech. The Senate pushed ahead with a vote on the amendment even though House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., had said he would not schedule a new vote in his chamber regardless of how the Senate acted. Sponsors said they would keep campaigning for the amendment nevertheless. ``We'll see what happens in the days and weeks and months ahead,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. He said Americans were pained to see protesters show disrespect for the nation by burning the flag and had been counting on Congress to settle the issue once and for all with a constitutional amendment. ``In the heartland of America, some folks just can't understand what Congress is up to,'' Dole said. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said the issue was ``so important that it should be sent to the states where the American people can decide whether they want to protect the flag.'' Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., another amendment supporter, said, ``Americanism cannot survive unless it has nationalism ... Americanism must have sacred symbols.'' Critics of the proposed amendment said the Senate vote was designed primarily to put them on record on an emotionally charged issue in a way that could be used by conservative challengers in fall election campaigns. ``Stirred by fears of sound bites and 30-second spots, members of Congress who should know better are expressing a willingness to sacrifice the Bill of Rights for what they hope will be a benefit in the polls,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., said his mail had turned against the amendment. And Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said heavy debate over the issue in recent weeks may have changed some minds. ``The more people learn about this, the more they hear discussion and hear all of the ramifications, the less likely they are to go for the amendment,'' he said. Kerrey said after the vote that it ``doesn't feel like a victory, it doesn't feel as good as it ought to'' because ``a wound has been opened in America, a real wound.'' The highly decorated Vietnam veteran said many veterans feel strongly about the measure and as a result of his opposition ``they are disappointed, they are disillusioned.'' In the debate leading to the vote, the Senate rejected three rival plans. It killed, 93-7, a plan offered by Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., that would have allowed Congress to ban desecrating the flag in various prescribed ways, such as trampling or mutilating. The Senate rejected, 90-10, a plan by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to strip the Supreme Court of its power to decide flag desecration cases. Helms said it was needed to combat ``these kooks ... these loonies who burn the American flag.'' And it rejected, 51-48, a proposal by Bumpers that would have outlawed by statute any flag burning that could lead to a breach of the peace. Bumpers said the amendment, as it came to the floor, was too broad and would cover too many harmless uses of the flag.

DOC.HEAD: Things Are Tough All Over _ Trump's on an Allowance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Trump, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: No more $1,500 ringside seats, or $200 dinners at Le Cirque. Forget the stretch limo; hail a cab. Helicopter? Take the bus, babe. Hard times are here for Donald Trump, a man on a bank-enforced allowance. Granted, this is no ordinary budget _ reportedly $450,000 per month, $5.4 million a year, or $14,794.52 a day, enough to make the average guy drool. The allowance is part of a deal with Trump's bankers to keep his financial empire afloat. But this will mean some sacrifices by a man not used to making them. The millionaire developer reportedly spent $583,000 on his extravagant lifestyle in May, money above and beyond the $841,000 maintenance on his yacht and the $246,000 upkeep on his private plane. There are those who believe Trump can make the necessary sacrifices to scrape by on his stipend. ``Donald Trump has always lived and worked the lifestyle of the rich and famous, and it will continue under the new circumstances,'' predicted Robin Leach, host of that syndicated TV show about the lifestyles of the you-know-who. There's also good news from the authors of ``New York on $1,000 A Day'' (which would leave Donald $13,794.52 a day to work with): ``New York ... the possibilities are endless. The solutions are only as limited as your own imagination.'' Now imagine these money-saving tips, Donald, provided free of charge: _No more chopper service to Atlantic City. A Domenico Tours bus can pick you up at Broadway and 69th Street (just a 15-block walk from Trump Tower). Bonus: $10 in change and a $2.50 lunch coupon upon arrival at the Trump Plaza. Plus a $5 voucher good in September in case things get worse. _Forget dinner at Le Cirque ($150 and up for two) or 21 ($70 for two, entrees only). They were once among Ivana's favorites, but they're a little too pricey now. Two hot dogs and a soda from a pushcart go for $2.75. _Cut back on your phone bill. In ``Trump: The Art of the Deal,'' you detail making more than 100 calls per day. How many calls do you really WANT to return these days? _Pack up the $1,800 Brioni suits and start buying off the rack. Stop seeing Broadway shows at $55 a ticket and head to the Bronx, where Yankee Stadium bleacher seats are a mere $4.50. _Get out of the boxing business before you end up like bare-chested promoter Butch Lewis _ losing your shirt. Trump, writing in his book, demonstrated there were some areas where he's frugal. The Donald doesn't drink, which means no unsightly bar tabs, and he rarely eats lunch _ just ``a can of tomato juice'' most days, he said. But life on a budget will be bothersome. Trump acknowledged as much in ``Art of the Deal'' when he observed, ``If there's one thing I've learned about the rich, it's that they have a very low threshold for even the mildest discomfort.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sidney Poitier will play Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall in a $10 million ABC miniseries, ``Separate But Equal.'' The four-hour production to be filmed in South Carolina beginning in August will center on a landmark school desegregation case of the 1950s, director George Stevens Jr. said Tuesday. Marshall, then an attorney for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, argued the case for better schools brought by black residents of Summerton, S.C. The case eventually was consolidated with four others that were decided in the 1954 Supreme Court decision Brown vs. Board of Education. In that decision, the high court found school segregation unconstitutional. The movie will air in April.

The rap group 2 Live Crew, whose ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album was declared obscene in South Florida, will parody the Bruce Springsteen hit ``Born in the U.S.A.'' as ``Banned in the U.S.A.'' Springsteen was comfortable with the lyrics and agreed to use of the parody, spokeswoman Marilyn Laverty said Tuesday. Jack Thompson, the lawyer who led the campaign that got the 2 Live Crew album declared obscene, objected to the parody. ``Mr. Springsteen, you're now harmful to the women and children who have bought your albums,'' he said in a letter. 2 Live Crew's attorney, Alan Jacobi, said the parody is due out next month. It has no sexually explicit lyrics, he said. Three weeks ago, U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez Jr. ruled ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' obscene in South Florida.

Helen Gurley Brown was given a Mercedes Benz and a chrome replica of a 1960s manual typewriter at a bash celebrating her 25 years with Cosmopolitan. The 68-year-old editor in chief credited her husband, film producer David Brown, with much of her success and danced the Charleston at the Monday night party, said Lisa McConkey, a Cosmo spokeswoman. Among the 250 guests were Beverly Sills, Barbara Walters, Don Johnson, Jane Pauley, Peter Jennings, David Frost, Mike Nichols, Diane Sawyer, James Woods, Merv Griffin and Ivana Trump. Mrs. Brown parlayed her 1962 best seller, ``Sex and the Single Girl,'' into a magazine proposal to Hearst Magazines and, eventually, Cosmopolitan.

Screaming fans gave singer Donnie Wahlberg of the New Kids on the Block a tumultous sendoff from the hospital where he recuperated from injuries suffered in a fall on stage. About 200 fans, mostly teen-age girls, greeted the 20-year-old Wahlberg as his bodyguard escorted him out of Saratoga Hospital on Tuesday after a two-day stay. Wahlberg signed autographs and hugged and kissed fans. ``Oh my God! Oh my God! Oh my God! Oh my God! He kissed me!'' said Loren Ferrara, 13. She said she had waited 11 hours to see the singer. Wahlberg gashed his chin and suffered cuts on his chest, arm and mouth when he fell through a trap door during a concert Sunday at Saratoga Raceway. He is expected to return to the stage Thursday in Hoffman Estates, Ill. The New Kids have recently topped the pop charts with the songs ``Step by Step'' and ``Hang Tough.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version moving on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Track star Carl Lewis admits in his new book that he was given money by Nike while competing for the University of Houston _ a violation of NCAA rules. In ``Inside Track, My Professional Life in Amateur Track and Field,'' the six-time Olympic gold medalist disclosed that his orginal contract with the athletic shoe manufacturer was for $5,000 with provisions for bonuses. Later, it was renegotiated into a four-year deal with a base figure of $200,000 plus bonuses for winning Olympic gold medals, achieving top rankings in the 100-meter dash and long jump, and setting world records. Lewis was not a student during the last three years of the renegotiated deal. Nike spokeswoman Liz Dolan said Tuesday the company knew it was violating National Collegiate Athletic Association rules when it signed Lewis while he was a student. ``We thought Carl deserved the support at a time when athletes didn't have the means to support themselves while training,'' she said. ``We were happy to support one of America's most promising athletes.'' Dolan said Nike's relationship with Lewis began in 1981 when he approached the company.

DOC.HEAD: Mel Torme, Cleo Laine Perform at JVC Jazz Festival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: The double bill of singers Mel Torme and Cleo Laine was what a jazz festival concert should be _ both performers on stage all evening, doing something special. Too often, two performers perform separately, before and after intermission, and the audience gets the same show it would hear at a nightclub. At Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night during the JVC Jazz Festival, the two superb jazz singers performed duets and traded solos. What made the evening even more exciting were the innovative arrangements by John Dankworth, who also led a six-piece band and played clarinet and saxophone. Songs from Broadway shows plus some other songs embodied the concert's theme, ``Broadly Broadway.'' The performers started with ``Lullaby of Broadway.'' Then Torme, with vocal warmth and swinging lightly, sang ``When There's a Shine on Your Shoes.'' Miss Laine went from low and sexy to really wailing on ``Taking a Chance on Love.'' Torme sang a fine medley from ``Guys and Dolls'' and ``Soliloquy'' from ``Carousel,'' the latter an interpretation which seemed more concerned with pretty top notes than content. Torme played piano on one number and drums on another with a show-off attitude which seemed not to rattle Miss Laine's secure stage presence. She was singing at her peak, with rare phrasing and enunciation. She made ``With Every Breath I Take'' from ``City of Angels'' mysterious, and ended in the stratosphere, impressed with ``Fine and Mellow.'' Torme, who looked slim and trim, sounded fine and mellow on ``Bye, Bye, Blackbird,'' which Dankworth flavored with just enough saxophone noodling. The two singers scatted together, making ``Lady Be Good'' exciting, joined for ``I Wish I Were in Love Again'' and put ``I Loves You Porgy'' and ``Bess You Is My Woman Now'' into a smooth, beautiful duet. Four hundred of the seats were priced at $250 and included a jam session by Torme, Miss Laine, Dankworth and other performers afterwards at Michael's Pub, as a benefit for Carnegie Hall.

DOC.HEAD: How Flag-Burning Issue Plays in a Georgia Congressional District
With PM-Flag Burning, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Freshman Democratic Rep. Ben Jones is treading carefully as he explains to the folks in his generally Republican district why he helped lead the fight against the constitutional amendment banning flag burning. But so far, the flag has not become the hot campaign issue some Republicans predicted, and even Jones' GOP challenger is being careful in his criticism of Jones' vote. Georgia's 4th Congressional District includes Atlanta suburbs and rural outlying areas. It is mostly affluent, and until last year its congressman was Republican Pat Swindall, who had one of the most conservative records in the House. But under a perjury indictment, Swindally lost a bid for a third term in 1988 to Jones, an actor who played Cooter in television's ``Dukes of Hazzard.'' Jones has experience with touchy subjects. He was the first to raise his alcoholic past in his two campaigns against Swindall. He also tackled the flag vote directly, bringing it up Monday in a talk in his hometown of Covington. ``Leadership means you will have tough choices and sometimes will be very lonely,'' Jones told about 60 community, business and government leaders at the Leadership Newton County meeting. Nobody likes flag burners, Jones said, but a constitutional amendment would be an overreaction to a ``handful of malcontents.'' Members listened attentively to Jones and gave him mixed reviews, said Bobby Myhand, the non-partisan group's chairman. ``Some people agreed with him and some didn't,'' Myhand said. With Swindall appealing his perjury conviction, the Republican banner is being carried by state Rep. John Linder. The national GOP has targeted Linder for financial support. Linder blamed the defeat of the flag-burning amendment on ``remnants of the `Me Generation''' in the House. ``I think Jones has been voting like a left-winger since he's been in there,'' Linder said. Lindner said the vote would be an issue, but not the only issue, in a district with an estimated 78,000 veterans out of about 400,000 potential voters. Thus far, Linder has limited most of his criticism to answering questions about the vote, rather than bringing up the subject. ``I'm not going to wrap myself in the flag,'' he said Tuesday after a fund-raiser in suburban Atlanta with Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. Jones and Rep. John Lewis, D-Atlanta, were the only members of Georgia's congressional delegation to oppose the amendment in last week's vote. The proposal would have given Congress and the states power to prohibit flag desecration. Atlanta-based pollster Claibourne Darden said Jones' vote won't help him in the November election. ``It was a stupid mistake. We're not dealing with right and wrong here; we're dealing with stupid and smart,'' Darden said. ``Ben's a gunslinger. He shoots from the hip, and consequently he makes mistakes. But that also makes it interesting.'' Elliott Levitas, the Democrat who in 1984 lost the 4th District seat he held for 10 years, said he doubted the flag-protection vote would determine the outcome of the race. ``A lot of people who would vote against Jones because of that issue would vote against him for three other reasons as well,'' Levitas said. DeKalb County Chief Executive Officer Manuel Maloof, a Jones supporter, said his stand on the amendment may help him. ``Knowing the district as he did and still standing up took the kind of courage you want to see in Congress,'' Maaoof said. ``It takes guts.''

DOC.HEAD: Voters Reject School Funding Plan
DOC.TEXT: A share-the-wealth plan for Oklahoma schools was soundly rejected in a special election Tuesday as voters in the eastern and western sections of the state split sharply over the issue. An aide to Gov. Henry Bellmon predicted a federal lawsuit would be filed challenging the disparity in Oklahoma's school funding system. ``Unfortunately we'll probably end up in federal court and the federal courts will write our funding laws instead of the people of Oklahoma,'' said the governor's chief of staff, Andrew Tevington. The proposal, listed on the ballot as State Question 634, called for redistributing on a statewide basis oil and property tax revenue that now goes to local schools. Some western counties with large oil reserves and utility facilities were voting against the plan by margins of more than 10-1. The measure was beaten badly in Oklahoma City, the state's largest city, and in most rural areas, but was favored by a large margin in Tulsa, the second largest city. Proponents of 634 said it was needed to end a situation whereby some school districts receive little more than $2,000 per student in funding and others get more than $10,000 per student. Bellmon had said the present system was ``not defensible'' and warned that Oklahoma could be subject to a lawsuit if it were not revised. In April, the state Legislature approved a $223 million school funding and tax measure that included pay raises for teachers, ending a statewide strike. Dan Brown, a financial consultant who led a citizen group that opposed State Question 634, said he thought the outcome showed a basic distrust of the Legislature. ``I think they are dissatisfied with the overall approach of the Legislature by trying to really force-feed Oklahomans,'' Brown said. ``They did not trust the Legislature to write a (school funding) formula that would be fair to all,'' Brown said. Voters also defeated three other state questions that would have changed how state school land money is handled, removed antiquated language from the state Constitution on school attendance and changed the membership of the state school board.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Spins About-Face on Taxes
With PM-Budget Talks Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: George Bush's taunting cry of ``read-my-lips, no-new-taxes'' proved to be a dandy political slogan but a woefully inadequate prescription for the economy. Slammed by huge budget deficits that kept getting worse, the president finally shut his mouth. To the delight of Democrats and the despair of Republicans, Bush conceded Tuesday that higher taxes would be required _ yes, required _ if there's to be any hope of getting the deficit under control. It was a major about-face for Bush, who had steadfastly argued during the presidential campaign and at the White House that higher taxes would rob the country of economic growth. Putting the best face on developments, the White House said Bush was doing what he could to put a spark in the sluggish budget deficit-reduction talks with Congress. Predictably, Democrats had a different interpretation. ``The charade is finally over,'' chortled Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J. ``The other shoe raised in the 1988 presidential campaign has just dropped,'' Torricelli said. ``George Bush has announced that he's raising taxes.'' Michael Dukakis, the Democrat who lost to Bush, lamented, ``I told the truth and I paid the price. Mr. Bush did not and we're all now going to have to pay the price for that.'' Republicans, mindful that they will have to answer to voters in November, staged a quick revolt against Bush's tax conversion. A letter circulated by Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., a member of the House GOP leadership, declared, ``Mr. President, we were stunned by your announcement. ... A tax increase is unacceptable.'' Ninety Republicans _ more than half of the 176 House GOP members _ hurried to sign the letter. The White House quickly began to backpedal to deal with panicky Republicans. Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, assured Republicans that nothing had really changed, that the president's statement ``doesn't mean anything new.'' But Bush's own words said otherwise. He said ``tax revenue increases'' would be necessary. A cautious leader, Bush changed his mind on taxes not in a sudden swoop but slowly, step by step. When he first took office, it appeared the deficit problem had peaked, stabilizing at about $150 billion before beginning to nose down. Bush held the line on taxes his first year, but then submitted a budget to Congress last January that proposed $13 billion in increases. He called them something else _ revenue enhancers and higher user fees. Instead of improving, though, the deficit crisis worsened, largely because of sluggish economic growth and higher-than-expected interest rates. The latest estimate, both from the White House and Congress, is that unless something is done, the deficit will soar past $200 billion when the cost of the savings and loan bailout is included. When budget negotiations began in the spring, Bush said everything was on the table. Did that mean he would go along with higher taxes? Bush refused to show his hand. Finally, after an unannounced breakfast meeting with congressional leaders on Tuesday, Bush released a statement removing his once-solid prohibition on tax increases. Republicans cried that Bush had robbed them of their best campaign ploy _ the same one he had used to beat Dukakis. Rep. Bill Schuette, R-Mich., who is using an anti-tax theme to try to oust Democratic Sen. Carl Levin, recoiled from Bush's statement. ``The president's recipe for deficit reduction includes a fatal ingredient _ tax increases,'' Schuette said. Agreeing with Bush's old philosophy, Schuette said a tax increase would be ``bad medicine for economic growth, stall out the economy and put people out of work.'' Democrats, of course, were delighted by Bush's change in course. ``It was a successful tactic in '88,'' said Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the Democratic congressional campaign committee. ``I think the president now has had a reality check,'' Anthony added. ``He's had advisers around him saying this country is going down on your watch.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since 1981 and is chief correspondent for The Associated Press at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Paris by Night in Couture Museum Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: What looks sexy in the evening? What do people want to parade in, and how rich do they want to appear? It has a lot to do with the tenor of the times. A stunning show at the Musee de la Mode Galliera that opened Monday and runs until October 28 gives an informative look at ``dream clothes'' for evening from 1850 through today. From the waist-cinching hourglass-figure frippery of the Second Empire through today's coat-of-mail armored mini by Paco Rabanne, the show demonstrates how women have presented themselves at their fanciest. The catalogue by the museum's head curator, Catherine Join-Dieterle, and her assistant, Valerie Guillaume, explains conventions and lifestyles behind dressing up through eight major fashion periods. With outfits from the museum's archives, other museums (including New York's Metropolitan) and major couture houses from Chanel to Lacroix, the show furnishes a close-up retrospective of some of the world's most opulent clothes, set dramatically in the museum's marble halls. There also are ensembles from the wardrobes of famous women: a yellow embroidered coat and gown by Dior for Princess Grace of Monaco in 1956; a jeweled satin strapless Dior worn by the Duchess of Windsor. ``Ball dresses were very important under the Second Empire of Louis Napoleon and Eugenie,'' said Ms. Join-Dieterle, introducing the show from its chronological start. ``There were also strict conventions, such as you had to wear bosom-revealing decolletes to a ball, but to the theatre or another function, chests and arms had to be covered, even by lace.'' She pointed out several beautiful gowns with hooped skirts that had practical, interchangeable jackets ``so the same outfit could be worn from late-day into the ball by switching the top.'' When the Empire collapsed, entertaining went back home, but clothes were no less rich, as shown by bustled models that Anglo-Saxons would identify as Victorian. From the Belle Epoque period up to World War I, young girls wore white, pink and lace. ``But changes were coming in tea-gown styles and pantaloons,'' said Ms. Join-Dieterle. ``At-home entertaining was very much the thing in the early part of the century, though women were beginning to go out to restaurants _ formerly reserved for coquettes or mistresses, rather than wives. And there were clothes for that too.'' She pointed out a window full of extravagant hats seen around town before 1914 _ ``usually worn to the theatre, and even provoking lawsuits since they kept people from seeing the play.'' Outfits for dancing the Charleston in the Roaring Twenties show the period as stylish but unsexy with high-necked, shapeless flappers by Patou, Chanel and Worth. ``But legs were being bared to the knee, and that was very daring at first,'' Join-Dieterle observed. Through the 1930s, and up to the latest collections, the show progresses with lessons in sociological-fashion trends like the 1950s return of the full-crinolined debutante gown. ``After the War's austerity, it was important to dress up again,'' said Ms. Join-Dieterle. ``It's obvious what women thought of dressing up in the late Sixties and early Seventies,'' she remarked. ``Not much.'' The evening wear from the early Sixties included a tiny mini-skirted yellow Ungaro suit, Mondrian-painting style dresses by Saint Laurent and Cardin, a micro-mini with cut-outs and feathers by Courreges. ``But the couturiers saw the un-dressed trend coming back before the student revolutions of 1968,'' Join-Dieterle said. Saint Laurent's black tuxedo evening suit looms in the room as a harbinger for what a woman can still wear out to a party without looking either over- or underdressed. The show also gives a nod to near-nudity with a Saint Laurent black chiffon and feathers from the Seventies, and to younger creators like Jean-Paul Gaultier with his brazen underwear look and Claude Montana, whose ropy fishnet tops a mannequin's bare bosom.

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Political Treaty at a Glance
With PM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at West Germany's proposed treaty for full political unification with East Germany, which would follow the July 1 merger of the two nations' economies. The political treaty is conditional on the successful resolution of talks between the two Germanys and the four World War II victors _ the Soviet Union, United States, Britain and France _ on the international ramifications of German unity. The parliaments of both German states would have to approve the proposed treaty, which contains three articles of union.

ARTICLE 1: One day after joint elections are held on an unspecified date in December, East Germany will approve a clause in the West German constitution that will allow it to become a part of West Germany.
ARTICLE 2: The territory now known as East Germany will become five states of a united Germany: Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-West Pomerania, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt and Thuringia.
ARTICLE 3: Germans in both parts of Germany will form a united nation.

The proposal also provides for: _the West German constitution to become effective in East Germany upon unity, with negotiations beforehand to decide on possible constitutional amendments or to make allowances for differing laws in the two regions.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Talks Seem Finally To Be Getting Serious
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The assembled schoolchildren hailed the declaration of the ``Year of Peace'' by tossing skyward 50 doves. The birds, which had been too tightly clutched through hours of delayed ceremonies and President Alfredo Cristiani's speech, flapped and flailed and crashed to ungainly landings on the national legislature's parking lot. But they eventually limbered their cramped wings. They took flight. Like the schoolchildren's flock in the June 1 ceremony, the difficult negotiating process intended to end 10 years of civil war in El Salvador has also had a tough time getting off the ground. But government and guerrilla negotiators on Monday ended a week of talks in Mexico that the U.N. mediator said produced unprecedented movement. Both sides expressed guarded optimism that next month's round could produce concrete accords to pave the way for a cease-fire before the year's end. The obstacles to a settlement are daunting and the climb is steeply uphill. Four efforts at negotiating peace between 1984 and 1989 broke down over mutual recriminations of intransigence. Yet, perhaps for the first time in the war, both sides appear definitively convinced that military resolution of the conflict is impossible and that there is no alternative to good-faith negotiation. ``It's the old question of whether the glass is half empty or half full,'' said guerrilla negotiator Salvador Samayoa. ``I prefer to see it as half full. And not because of mere optimism, but because conditions favor movement toward peace.'' In November, the rebels launched their biggest offensive of the war, trying to spark insurrection that would topple the government. Failing that, the offensive was designed to leave the insurgents entrenched in urban positions from which they could demand and obtain an expeditious negotiated solution. The huge push was beaten back after three weeks. The product of many months of preparation, the offensive failed to define the war's outcome. For its part, the government is being nudged toward a negotiated solution by a combination of factors. The guerrilla offensive, although ultimately unsuccessful, showed the military the rebels remain strong and motivated. Cristiani's Republican Nationalist Alliance wants to do well in legislative and municipal elections scheduled for March, and expects the mantle of peacemaker would produce significant electoral dividends. Perhaps most important, the U.S. government that has funded the nearly bankrupt government and war effort has served notice it will not continue providing large sums merely to maintain the status quo. The U.N.-mediated peace process addresses a seven-point agenda, the top item of which is the future role of the armed forces. The talks' eventual success hinges on accord on that subject, by far the most difficult. El Salvador is a small volcano-studded nation of 5 million on the Pacific Coast of Central America notorious throughout its history for lopsided distribution of wealth. The armed forces were for most of this century the key factor in ensuring that the few rich got richer while the many poor remained so. Relatively progressive younger officers staged a coup in 1979 with the stated intention of modernizing and democratizing the country. But the reform movement, assailed on one side by old-line rightist officers, degenerated into a bloody conflict with rebels wanting revolutionary change. An estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in the war. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, a leftist insurgent army of about 7,000 full-time combatants and perhaps twice as many part-time militia members, is battling a U.S.-funded force of 56,000 soldiers and militarized police. The FMLN contends that despite periodic elections and democratic trappings, the government is a civilian facade on military dictatorship. Though government officials describe El Salvador as a fledgling democracy, the armed forces enjoy a degree of power and privelege uncountenanced by any modern democratic system. The rebels demand ``demilitarization'' of Salvadoran society. Shafik Handal, leader of the rebel delegation in Mexico, said demilitarization includes disappearance of the insurgent army. But before the guerrillas demobilize, they demand first of all an end to military impunity. Although international rights organizations blame the armed forces for the slaying, outside of combat, of many thousands of suspected opponents, not a single officer has been convicted, or even tried, for a rights abuse crime. Handal and other guerrilla chiefs acknowledge that trial and conviction of all or even most offenders is utopian, and have centered demands for prosecution on four ``exemplary'' cases. The rebels say identification of those responsible for egregious abuses and their administrative removal from positions of command would suffice as punishment for those implicated in crimes other than the four symbolic cases. In addition to the purge, the rebels demand abolishment of militarized police forces they consider repressive and creation of a new police force under civilian command and control. Agreements on the dismantling of paramilitary organizations, drastic reduction in the number of military personnel and an end to forced recruitment are also rebel conditions for giving up the armed struggle. Oscar Santamaria, chief of the government delegation to the Mexican talks, told The Associated Press that the discussions produced advances that could pave the way for accords at the next round. Among elements contributing to chances for successful negotiations: The United States supports the removal of tainted and corrupt officers. Government officials privately concur that, once the war is over, police forces should be under a civilian portfolio rather than the Defense Ministry. And Cristiani has pledged to significantly reduce military strength once peace is achieved. If the military stumbling blocks are overcome, the other issues _ human rights, judicial and electoral reform, constitutional revision and economic accords _ could follow relatively easily.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Douglas Grant Mine has covered El Salvador for The Associated Press since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Low-Pain Tax Hikes May be Hard to Find
With PM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: The last time Congress and President Bush raised taxes for deficit reduction, they put the bite on banks, large corporations and defense contractors. The whole package _ enacted last November _ cost taxpayers about $8 billion a year. But because of its scatter-gun approach, nobody complained too loudly. As a result of Bush's announcement Tuesday that tax increases will have to be part of any significant deficit-reduction plan this year, congressional leaders and the president's advisers will be looking for the same kind of low-pain plan. But that kind of tax increase may be hard to find this year, simply because there is a limit to the number of ``loopholes'' that can be closed and corporate tax breaks that can be taken away. After all, President Reagan signed similar tax increases in 1987 and 1988. Many Democrats in Congress argue that the first target of any tax increase should be the rich. ``We ought to look at those groups who have profited from the tax structure of the 1980s,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, says. One proposal that has drawn wide attention would tax part of the earnings of the richest 600,000 Americans at a maximum rate of 33 percent. All their taxable income now is taxed at 28 percent, even though some earnings of those with less income may be taxed at 33 percent. Some lawmakers insist, however, that while Bush is backing away from his 1988 campaign pledge to oppose tax increases, he is set solidly against raising personal income taxes. Higher gasoline taxes? Bush specifically rejected that idea in the 1988 campaign and there is strong opposition from rural lawmakers. But it has considerable support in Congress because it would not only raise $1 billion a year for each one-cent increase but also assist in conserving energy. How about raising taxes on cigarettes and beverage alcohol? A higher cigarette tax is a good bet, in part because of health costs associated with smoking. But the tax on hard liquor already is considerably higher than on beer and wine, and there is some reluctance in an election year to risk offending ``Joe Sixpack'' and the wine-and-cheese crowd. The Congressional Budget Office annually draws up a list of tax increase options but makes no recommendations. Here are some of this year's candidates and what they would cost taxpayers in 1991: INDEXING: Delay for one year the annual mandated tax cuts designed to keep cost-of-living pay raises from pushing workers into higher brackets. $5.4 billion. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposed it as part of a plan to require most Americans to share the pain of deficit reduction. STATE, LOCAL TAXES: Allow deduction only of property and income taxes that exceed 1 percent of adjusted gross income. $700 million. MEDICARE: Extend the 1.45 percent Medicare premium (collected as part of the Social Security tax) to wages above $51,300, the present taxable maximum. This would affect the wealthiest 6 percent of employees. $3.5 billion. Bush has a separate proposal that is unpopular in Congress: require all state and local government workers to pay for Medicare; those hired before April 1, 1986, are now exempt. $1.2 billion. FRINGE BENEFITS: Impose a 3 percent tax on the value of employer-paid fringe benefits, except pensions. $2.6 billion. CREDIT UNIONS: Tax them just as banks are taxed. $400 million. ENVIRONMENTAL: Impose new taxes on a wide variety of pollutants. Rostenkowski proposed $3.2 billion from this source. BUSINESS MEALS: Allow a deduction for only 50 percent, rather than the current 80 percent, of the cost of business meals and entertainment. $2 billion. STOCKS: Impose a 50-cent tax on the sale of each $100 worth of stocks and other securities. $7.8 billion. MORTGAGES: Limit the interest deduction for home mortgages to $12,000 on a single return and $20,000 on a joint return. $600 million. AVIATION: Raise the 8 percent tax on domestic airline tickets to 10 percent, with similar increases for air cargo and fuel, as Bush has proposed. $500 million. ENERGY: Tax all energy at 5 percent of value. $14.2 billion. Or, tax all imported oil at $5 a barrel. $8.5 billion. ENERGY INDUSTRY: Repeal immediate deduction of certain intangible drilling costs, such as labor, claimed by oil and gas explorers. $500 million.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Senate Passes Tough Anti-Abortion Law Despite Veto Threat
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana Senate ignored a threatened gubernatorial veto in passing what would be the nation's strictest state abortion law _ a measure outlawing abortion even in cases of rape or incest. ``There's no indication at all that he's changed his mind about a veto,'' Gov. Buddy Roemer's spokesman, Rusty Jabour, said Tuesday. Roemer has said he would veto any bill that does not include exceptions for rape and incest. The bill would send doctors who perform abortions to prison for up to 10 years of hard labor. Women who obtain abortions would not be prosecuted. The House passed a version of the bill last week and was to get the measure again, possibly as early as today, to vote on amendments the Senate added to clarify that abortion would be allowed to save the life of the mother. The bill is designed as a direct challenge to the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling in Roe vs. Wade that recognized the right to an abortion. Abortion foes see the Louisiana measure as a way to get the court to reconsider. ``To find out that the Supreme Court really believes, we need a law that flies in the face of Roe vs. Wade,'' says Mike Cross, Senate sponsor of the bill. If Roemer vetoes the measure, anti-abortion forces said they will seek an override. The 104-member House approved the bill 74-27, four votes more than the two-thirds majority needed for an override. The vote in the 39-member Senate on Tuesday was 24-15, two votes shy of what would be needed for an override. ``We know who we have to work on,'' said Rep. Woody Jenkins, the bill's author. ``We know we have the governor's veto and we know we have the votes to sustain it,'' said Robin Rothrock, leader of an abortion-rights coalition. Sen. Ron Landry, a Democrat, offered an amendment to allow first-trimester abortions for rape and incest, but he lost 12-27 on one try and 13-26 on another. About 200 abortion opponents packed the balcony and either side of the Senate chamber during the sometimes emotional, 4{-hour debate. They broke into thunderous applause and cheers after the vote. Later, about 70 abortion rights advocates marched from the Capitol to the governor's mansion nearby, chanting pro-choice slogans. Jubilant abortion opponents gathered on the Capitol steps to congratulate Jenkins. During Tuesday's debate, several senators said the issue will be politically costly. ``There are men in this Senate who will vote _ on both sides _ who will be defeated because of their vote,'' said Sen. Fritz Windhorst, a Democrat from New Orleans who voted for the bill. Cross' opening statement drew heavily on House testimony from a geneticist, Jerome Lejeune of Paris, who contended that life begins at conception and that the fertilized egg already contains the genes to make a unique human being. He held up a 3-inch-long pink plastic model of a fetus and said, ``This is what this bill is all about today _ whether or not these little boys and girls are going to have a chance to live.'' But Sen. Sydney Nelson said parents must face agonizing decisions when faced with the impending birth of a defective child. He also said some children are never adopted. ``As a father and a lawyer and a Christian, I've reached the conclusion that this is not an appropriate bill for us to pass,'' Nelson said. The debate came one day after the U.S. Supreme Court upheld Minnesota and Ohio laws requiring minors to notify their parents or a judge before having an abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Anger, Defiance Reign In Liberian Countryside
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer recently spent a week traveling in rebel-held areas of Liberia.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A grisly sign of civil war stands at the shattered center of this remote Liberian town _ the skull of a government soldier, his scalp and half his face withering in the relentless sun. The head is impaled on a stake near a gutted armored personnel carrier that residents say was one of two that burst into town before dawn April 1. Rebels said they shot out the six tires of the vehicle, bearing the markings of the Liberian army's 1st Battalion Infantry, and immolated the half-dozen soldiers inside with firebombs. Surrounding buildings are riddled with bullet holes and the dirt road is still littered with empty cartridges. Survivors say about 60 of Kpaytuo's 1,000 residents were killed by marauding soldiers of the widely hated military of President Samuel K. Doe. It is the kind of carnage that could resume with the collapse of peace talks this week between representatives of Doe and Charles Taylor, leader of the National Patriotic Front rebels. Burned-out or abandoned villages, destroyed automobiles and looted homes and shops dot the inhospitable Liberian interior. The violence is part of the 6-month-old war between the rebels _ primarily of the Gio and Mano ethnic groups _ and Mandingos and the Krahns who support Doe, a Krahn. ``There have been many clashes in the country and we are suffering,'' said Thomas Karngbeae, a high school history teacher in Kpaytuo whose best friend was killed. ``They come to the villages to harrass and kill innocent people.'' In nearby Bahn, 125 miles from the Atlantic coast, the area around the town's center crossroads was flattened and burned. ``Most of our brothers and sisters were killed by Doe's soldiers,'' fumes Peter Vaye, Bahn's deputy military police commander. ``The Krahn soldiers burned our food storerooms, so we are suffering for food,'' says Vaye, his white clothes filthy with grime. Dozens of people were killed, he says. Karnue, an 85-year-old farmer wearing a tattered blue smock, remembers when the soldiers came to town that night in early April. ``They just drove in and burned houses,'' he said. He said four of his children died in the raid. Taylor, a former Doe administration official, led his insurgent forces into Liberia in December from neighboring Ivory Coast. The rebels are within 15 miles of Monrovia, and say they can seize the capital in 12 hours. Rebel spies are helping prepare the attack, says Commander Bobby Hayes, chief of rebel intelligence. ``Our men traveled to Monrovia and went downtown. We see there is very little to stop us.'' ``If ordered to attack we can take Monrovia in a day,'' says Tiagen Wantee, the Front's deputy battle group commander for the port of Buchanan, who says he was trained by Green Berets in the United States and the Special Anti-Terrorism Unit in Israel. ``We did not start this war to stay in Buchanan.'' The guerrillas are trained in Gborplay, a northern Liberian village scraped out of the rain forest near the border with Ivory Coast. By day the people of Gborplay work in nearby fields of corn, rice and cassava, a potato-like tuber, as wild parrots whistle and chatter overhead. They return home before nightfall _ there is no electricity _ when the fireflies come out among coffee bushes and jungle beasts begin their haunting calls from the surrounding jungle. Atrocities by Doe's soldiers have galvanized the largely Gio and Mano population of the north. Tales abound of Doe soldiers tying women and children to mattresses and setting them on fire. Sam Belleh, a Mano who trains rebel guerrillas in Gborplay, says he saw government soldiers murder his friend's wife, who was eight months pregnant. ``They cut her open and took out the baby. The baby was stabbed many times. I couldn't stand the sight and fled in the bush.'' Soldiers also threw young children into wells, Belleh said. He thinks about 800 were killed in that December attack at Saclepea, also in the north. Commando trainees, most barefoot, are put through exercises by John Teah, 29, a deputy training commander. Teah, in combat fatigues and wearing a large brass cross around his neck, also leads daily sessions of a beautiful chorus: half African ballad, half U.S. Marine Corps drill chants. ``Everywhere we go, people want to know, who we are,'' sing several hundred recruits, marching in place. ``So, we tell them: we are special commandos marching to the towns.'' Rebel recruits include 12-year-old Anthony Slersue, who carries a loaded machine gun slung from his shoulder. He says his older sister and brother were killed by the Liberian army. Christopher Nyeneken, 14, a Mano from Sannequellie, is learning to be a guerrilla ``to free Liberia. And because they killed my father.'' But life in the camp is tough; one young teen-ager tugged at a visitor's sleeve, saying, ``Sir, we are hungry.'' Their inexperience can have tragic consequences. During the battle for Buchanan last month Daniel Zuu was reaching for a machine gun reloaded by a 12-year-old when the youngster accidentally pulled the trigger, nearly emptying the magazine into Zuu's elbow. Zuu, 40, lost his left arm, but says that won't keep him from the war front. ``I will never retreat,'' he says stubbornly. ``I will never surrender.''

DOC.HEAD: Broiler Production Spreading From Traditional Areas
