DOC.TEXT: The nation's broiler belt hasn't changed much over the years, but the Agriculture Department says production is spilling over into other states. ``For example, Oklahoma and Missouri more than doubled the number of broilers they raised from 1980 to 1989, reflecting a spillover from adjoining Arkansas,'' a report said. ``Other states raising more broilers include Tennessee, South Carolina and Pennsylvania.'' But the broiler industry is still concentrated in 10 states, which accounted for 83 percent of the U.S. output last year. Most are in the South, which produced 4.8 billion birds in 1989, or 87 percent of the total. Arkansas was the leader with about 920 million broilers last year, followed by Georgia, with 812 million, and Alabama, with 750 million. Others states in the top 10 include North Carolina, Mississippi, Texas, Maryland, Delaware, California and Virginia. The report by Lee Christensen and Agnes Perez of the UDSA's Economic Research Service was included in the July issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``Although some of this spillover does not reflect major regional production shifts, further growth in traditional broiler areas is becoming increasingly constrained by environmental and economic pressures,'' the report said. ``High concentrations of broilers result in increasingly complex problems associated with waste management, water quality and animal disease.'' Also, as city sprawl develops near major broiler production centers, land prices and labor costs rise, thus adding to operating costs. ``Areas with underemployed resources, lighter population densities and fewer environmental pressures sometimes offer financial and other incentives to attract broiler complexes,'' the report said. Broiler production grew from 3.7 billion pounds, ready-to-cook weight, in 1960 to 17.3 billion pounds in 1989. This year's output is estimated at 18.6 billion pounds. ``Industry development in the broiler belt was pushed by local entrepreneurs and aided by the readily available and relatively low-cost work force,'' the report said. ``In addition, a warm climate helped reduce energy costs while growers used improved production technologies that adapted well to the South.'' As production grew, a large infrastructure of support developed, including slaughter and processing plants. The report said a 1989 industry survey of the 52 largest broiler companies showed that the largest four accounted for 45 percent of the total volume through 76 slaughter and ``further processing'' plants. The survey also found that the top eight companies accounted for about 60 percent of the volume in 105 plants, and that the largest 20 firms had 80 percent of the volume in 156 plants. Approximately 75 percent of the slaughter plants surveyed were in the top 10 broiler states, the report said.

Wind erosion eased its grip on the Great Plains this season because of improved moisture conditions in much of the region, according to a final survey by the Agriculture Department. Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said Tuesday that an estimated 7.8 million acres were damaged by wind in the 10 states that make up the Great Plains, down 45 percent from 14.3 million acres in 1988-89. The agency measures wind damage during a seven-month season that runs from Nov. 1 through May 31, when winds are usually the strongest and soils the driest. The survey covers 541 counties in the 10 states. ``Most of this decrease is the result of precipitation in Colorado and Kansas, where land damaged from wind decreased from 6.5 million acres last year to 463,000 acres this year for the two states,'' Scaling said. The greatest damage was in North Dakota, in its third year of severe drought, he said. The state reported 2.9 million acres damaged this season, compared with 2.3 million last year and a record 3.5 million acres in 1987-88. North Dakota accounted for more than one-third of the total wind erosion in the 10-state region. Kansas, after setting a record with 5.1 million acres damaged last year (largely because of a one-day storm that damaged nearly 4.8 million acres), reported only 190,000 acres damaged this season. The least damage was in Nebraska, with 130,000 acres damaged, compared with 192,000 last year. Officials said the record for land damaged by wind in the Great Plains was 15.3 million acres in 1954-55, the year that the agency began annual records. According to the survey, the state-by-state breakdown comparing wind-damaged acres in 1989-90 with damage in 1988-89, included: _Colorado, 273,731 and 1,403,655. _Kansas, 189,600 and 5,126,250. _Montana, 1,249,665 and 1,832,025. _Nebraska, 130,115 and 191,605. _New Mexico, 248,500 and 117,950. _North Dakota, 2,932,687 and 2,297,681. _Oklahoma, 136,800 and 111,930. _South Dakota, 601,830 and 678,550. _Texas, 1,668,000 and 1,979,626. _Wyoming, 407,550 and 552,680.

An additional $11 million has been reallocated to 46 states for the Agriculture Department's special supplemental food program for women, infants and children. About half the states were running out of money for the program, known as WIC. Higher food costs, especially for dairy and citrus products, were said to be the main factors. Officials said Tuesday the department regularly reallocates unspent and carryover WIC funds to states in need or in danger of running out before the end of the fiscal year. ``Many states have managed their WIC caseloads carefully enough that they aren't having any budgetary problems,'' said Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service. ``Others have had to economize ... by choosing less expensive but nutritious foods,'' she said. Nationally, the reallocated money will allow states to provide an additional 300,000 food packages to participants over the final three months of this fiscal year, Nelsen said. The funds will be available to states July 1 and will supplement more than $2 billion allocated for WIC in the current fiscal year that began last Oct. 1. More than 4.5 million women, infants and children participate.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela, Others Confront Issue of Violence in Rights Struggle
DOC.TEXT: Just as in the American civil rights movement a quarter century ago, the question of violence versus nonviolence in a struggle for human rights hung over Nelson Mandela's visit to Washington. The black South African leader received a thunderous ovation after a speech to a joint session of Congress on Tuesday, a reception that left him pausing in the aisle afterward to wave to members of Congress and the crowded gallery. Behind him, a white Republican, Rep. Chris Shays of Connecticut, slapped high fives with black congressmen. Rep. John Lewis, a Democrat from Georgia, couldn't help but feel a bit of astonishment at the scene. Lewis is a veteran of the civil rights struggle of the 1960s who remained dedicated to nonviolence despite 40 arrests and vicious attacks during the Freedom Rides and elsewhere. His last arrest, Lewis recalled after Mandela's speech, was in January 1966 outside the South African Information Center in New York City. He and other members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee were protesting South Africa's apartheid system and its imprisonment of Mandela. ``I never thought I'd live to see Nelson Mandela out of jail,'' Lewis said. Mandela, who spent 27 years imprisoned, made only slight reference to the use of violence as a tool in the black struggle against South Africa's racist system. He said ``those who care to worry about violence in our country, as we do,'' should look not at blacks who are denied full rights but at whites ``steeped in the ideology of racism.'' But the issue of violence remained a point of disagreement after Mandela's visit with President Bush and his meetings with members of Congress. Several lawmakers echoed Bush's call for Mandela to renounce violence, a step the black leader would not take. ``Mandela has been given plenty of opportunities to renounce violence. He has not,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich. ``I hope that's coming in the future,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. Lewis, who is black, said he also wanted Mandela to renounce violence. ``I would like to see a nonviolent revolution, a peaceful transition in South Africa,'' he said. ``There's been too much violence, too much bloodshed.'' Mandela's next stop on his U.S. tour is Atlanta, where he is to visit the burial place of Martin Luther King Jr., the museum that honors his life and the Ebenezer Baptist Church pulpit where he preached his message of nonviolent struggle against segregation. ``I hope by going to the South he will see what's happened in a region where there was discrimination, segregation,'' Lewis said. ``He will be in a region of the country that was a lot like South Africa just a few years ago. ``Without violence, we were able to turn the South into a New South,'' he said. ``Maybe being there will give him the will to try, as much as possible, to avert violence.'' Watching Mandela's speech from the House gallery was Jesse Jackson. In an interview afterward, Jackson accused Bush of hypocrisy for pressing the issue of nonviolence. He said Bush has used violence by invading Panama and by sending weapons to Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Angolan rebels. ``His use of the word `violence' was diversionary, from apartheid, just as his using the word `quotas' is diversionary from the issue of signing the 1990 Civil Rights Bill,'' Jackson said. ``If (South African President F.W.) de Klerk is not making the renunciation of violence the precondition (to negotiations), because he can't morally justify it, neither should Mandela have to do that,'' Jackson said. Mandela has advocated the use of violence only as a last resort, said Edwin Dorn, deputy director of the Joint Center for Political Studies, a black think tank. ``I'm perplexed at this administration's preoccupation with that subject,'' Dorn said. ``The administration has not shied away from the use of violence in other parts of the world.'' Rather than comparing the South African struggle over apartheid with the American struggle over civil rights, Dorn said a better analogy was to the U.S. civil war and the fight against slavery. Lewis said he did not believe Mandela's refusal to renounce violence damages his cause in the United States. He cited Mandela's calm demeanor and demonstration of no bitterness despite his own imprisonment. ``That's very in keeping with the philosophy of nonviolence, to be able to forgive and go on,'' Lewis said.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers' Union Leader Wins Democratic Runoff For Alabama Governor
DOC.TEXT: Teachers union leader Paul Hubbert won the Democratic nomination for governor in a caustic campaign against Attorney General Don Siegelman and will face Gov. Guy Hunt in November. The Democrats clasped hands in a show of unity after the runoff Tuesday, and Hubbert said, ``I think the nightmare of 1986 is over'' _ a reference to the party split that enabled Hunt to become Alabama's first GOP governor this century. ``For those misguided souls who think the Democrats are not together,'' Hubbert said, ``they've got another think coming in November.'' With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Hubbert received an unofficial 307,982 votes, or 54 percent, to 266,213 votes, or 46 percent, for Siegelman. Hubbert, 54, spent 21 years building the Alabama Education Association into a political force with 70,000 members ranging from janitors and bus drivers to teachers and professors. Making his first run for statewide public office, he led a six-candidate field in the primary June 5 but failed to win a majority, requiring Tuesday's runoff between the two top vote-getters. Siegelman, a 44-year-old Statehouse veteran, made a trip to Hubbert's victory celebration to pledge his support. ``A new battle begins tomorrow,'' he said. ``We will bring Alabama into the New South with a Democratic progressive governor in office.'' During the three-week runoff campaign, Siegelman attacked Hubbert as a special interest ``backroom operator'' who helped teachers at the expense of children. Hubbert accused Siegelman of running a racist radio commercial. Hubbert traveled with a mop and bucket in hand as he urged Siegelman to clean up the campaign. Hubbert also made joking references to Siegelman's use of marijuana in college. Hubbert said the negative ads and verbal slugging in the runoff won't hurt his campaign against Hunt, who won renomination against token opposition June 5. Hunt, a 56-year-old fruit farmer and preacher who was a little-known figure when he was catapulted into the governor's office in a 1986 landslide, predicted a tough campaign. But he added, ``I think by the time the summer's over, the people will know the difference between the candidates.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientific Results: A Bundle of Tiger Fur
DOC.TEXT: Scientific efforts to save the world's tigers finally yielded tangible results: a wiggly, yellow and black test-tube cub named Mary Alice. The 20-pound Bengal tiger, one of three cubs produced by in vitro fertilization, was introduced at the National Zoo on Tuesday. Mary Alice, the only cub that survived, was born on April 27 by cesarean section from a surrogate Siberian tiger. Her birth marks a milestone in efforts by zoos to save rare tigers from extinction using in vitro fertilization. Today, there are fewer tigers in the wild than in the world's zoos _ including only 31 black-footed cats, 21 sand cats and 12 pallas cats in zoos. ``This is a celebration of what we think is a great scientific achievement,'' said David Wildt, chief reproductive physiologist at the National Zoo. ``We can produce cubs by animals who are no longer fertile or have been apart for a long time.'' Natural feline reproduction in zoos hasn't been successful because most cats are picky about mates and sometimes refuse to breed naturally. Genetically desirable mates often are some distance away and transporting them is risky, said officials at the zoo's Center for New Opportunities in Animal Health Sciences. Of the 37 species of felines, all are threatened or endangered with extinction except the domestic cat. Since 1969, three subspecies of tigers have become extinct, center officials said. Animals are considered endangered if they are not reproducing quickly enough and if their numbers are declining rapidly. Scientists have been trying to adapt human artificial reproduction techniques to wild animals for nearly 10 years, said Robert Hoage, the National Zoo's public affairs director. Artificial breeding techniques have been successful in farm livestock. But adapting the procedures to conserve rare species has been slow, Hoage said. Ann Miller, a member of the zoo's reproductive physiology unit, said the breeding is at a snail's pace because ``scientists know so little about the basic reproductive characteristics of most wildlife species.'' But zoos have seen some success _ including an Indian desert cat born to a surrogate domestic cat using in vitro fertilization at the Cincinnati Zoo and a gaur calf born to a Holstein cow through embryo transfer at the Bronx Zoo. Intervention has prevented many tiger species from becoming extinct in the wilderness, zoo officials said. ``Sometimes people use the words _ captive and research _ as four-letter words,'' said Lee Simmons, director of Nebraska's Henry Doorly Zoo. ``This animal's relatives are captive in Siberia and other countries ... The habitats for many animals are in isolated enclaves.'' When natural habitats are destroyed, tigers are limited to a small roaming area that keeps them isolated from other tiger species. When they are isolated, tigers inbreed, and the species begins to die from reproductive problems, juvenile mortality and disease susceptibility, said Simmons. The National, Henry Doorly and Minnesota zoos have worked together on the tiger reproduction effort.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of Price Protections Cite Administration Support
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a protective U.S. sugar policy are citing Bush administration support for their stand as they seek a 10 percent reduction in sugar price levels in the 1990 farm bill. ``We're advocating a small reduction in price that the administration supports,'' Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., said Tuesday. Downey gave an early taste of the debate that sugar beet and cane farmers will witness when floor action on the farm bill begins next month. ``You have gotten away with murder and I don't blame you for wanting to continue it,'' Downey told a conference of the American Sugar Alliance. He and Rep. Willis Gradison, R-Ohio, faced off against Reps. Jerry Huckaby, D-La., chairman of the House Agriculture sugar subcommittee, and Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., in a panel discussion. Huckaby and Stangeland strongly support the program that keeps U.S. sugar prices higher than the world market, but Huckaby acknowledged that the administration is not as enthusiastic. He said he feared the administration saw the sugar program as something that could be traded away in exchange for concessions from other countries during international trade talks aimed at reducing subsidies worldwide. One of the arguments Downey and Gradison are using against the sugar program involves trade. ``How can we over a long period of time, as we move toward multi-trade agreements, sustain differences between agricultural and non-agricultural trade policies,'' said Gradison. The current sugar policy, which is extended through 1995 in the farm bill, holds domestic prices at 22 cents a pound, about 9 cents more than the average world price, by controlling the amount of sugar that can be imported from sugar-producing nations. Downey said sugar is not so unique a commodity that it has to be treated differently from other products whose prices ebb and flow with the market. But Huckaby and Stangeland contended that food differs from other items because is needed for human survival, giving the government a responsibility to regulate supplies and prices. ``We don't want feast or famine,'' said Huckaby. Furthermore, he and Stangeland said, price-distorting subsidies on sugar from Europe necessitate U.S. government protection of American growers. Stangeland said sugar-producing countries take what they need for themselves, sell to preferred customers and the highest rates possible and then dump the rest on the world market at low prices, often subsidized by their governments. Downey and Gradison said that by protecting sugar producers in the United States where sugar is not an ideal crop, the government is stifling economic development in countries that U.S. officials say they want to help. Forty nations are allowed to export to the United States and each has a limit on the tonnage they can sell here. Many of the countries are desperately poor, although they have excellent climates for growing sugar cane and could sell much more than their quota. ``It doesn't make any sense to not allow sugar imports from countries we are paying foreign aid,'' Downey said.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Claim Poverty, Poor Construction Worsened Toll
With PM-Iran-Quake
DOC.TEXT: Abbas Taghizaden pointed to his new home, a tent, up an arid valley from the town where more than half his neighbors died last week. ``I only have this and my land left, so I don't know how I can build a house. I don't know how I can live,'' he said. Many others were in the same position. Virtually all of Kelishom's mud brick houses collapsed in Thursday's earthquake, which killed up to 3,000 of the town's 5,000 people. Across northwestern Iran, the earthquake devastated scores of similar villages whose impoverished residents had relied on traditional building materials such as mud bricks. In larger towns and cities, residents said Tuesday that shoddy construction contributed to the high death toll. In Rasht on the Caspian Sea, for example, 60 people died when one of the city's most modern apartment buildings collapsed, neighbors said. Dozens of relatives watched Tuesday as huge cranes lifted portions of the crushed building, searching for the bodies of 24 people still missing. ``Some of my family are in there,'' said a young soldier. ``They haven't found them yet. Maybe they are alive, or maybe they are dead. I don't know.'' Many of the relatives and neighbors said officials had allowed the builder to add a floor _ and that led to the structure's collapse. Nearby, a 40-year-old factory stood without any visible damage. Much of the city's water supply remained out as workers repaired the main reservoir. ``There is so much corruption. This (the water system) should have withstood the earthquake,'' an architecture student said. Throughout the city, there was little damage to older buildings, even those made of fragile-looking brick. Newer, concrete buildings were seriously damaged. The worst-hit rural provinces were Gilan and Zanjan provinces, where 342 villages, towns and cities were demolished. Kelishom is in Gilan. ``Of the houses that are damaged, most were made of poor quality materials,'' said Gholam Reza Naghdi, one of two medical school volunteers in the village helping the injured. ``I think the reason for the huge damage was our poor economy. For that reason we need help from other countries.'' Some victims blamed the government. Others defended it. ``Since the current government took over, all we see is dying, dying,'' said a man who gave only his first name, Jalal. ``Some the government killed. Others died during the war with Iraq. Now more died in the earthquake. The economy is down to zero. I hope we can have some change.'' At Kelishom, a woman who lost eight members of her family in the quake expressed gratitude to the government for providing a tent and food. ``But it's cold at night,'' she said. ``I just hope that we will be able to move into our own houses again some day.''

DOC.HEAD: Computer Problems Delay Weather Service Data
DOC.TEXT: A pair of computer problems at the National Weather Service delayed delivery of weather information that newspapers use for their weather sections, a spokesman said. The problems Tuesday occurred in two separate banks of computers, one that receives raw weather data, and another that analyzes and transmits the data, Joe Irwin, a spokesman for the National Meteorological Center, said. The first problem cropped up at about 4 a.m., and it took until after 1 p.m. for the bugs to be ironed out and the systems brought back on line, he said. ``It was a bad day,'' he said as it ended.

DOC.HEAD: Zumwalt Blasts Government Attitude on Dioxin Dangers
DOC.TEXT: A former commander who ordered the spraying of Agent Orange in Vietnam says veterans aren't the only ones to suffer from the government's refusal to recognize the herbicide's trail of cancer and birth defects. Testifying Tuesday before a House Government Operations subcommittee, retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. said the government's attitude casts doubt on how honestly it is dealing with dioxin exposure in the environment. Agent Orange, used in highly concentrated form to remove crops and enemy cover, was contaminated during its manufacture with dioxin, an unwanted byproduct that the Environmental Protection Agency considers to be a probable cause of cancer. The federal Centers for Disease Control, however, says it cannot study the health effects of Agent Orange exposure on veterans because it is impossible to determine reliably who was exposed when jungles were sprayed to deprive enemy troops of cover. Veterans groups contend that military records can match spraying activities with troop movements. Agent Orange Zumwalt, who commanded naval forces in Vietnam, reported to Veterans Affairs Secretary Edward J. Derwinski in May that the government and industry ``intentionally manipulated or withheld compelling information on the adverse health effects'' associated with exposure to the ingredients of Agent Orange. Key among those ingredients is dioxin, although scientists at Tuesday's hearing said other contaminants may also be blamed for cancers, birth defects and other afflictions. ``... The flawed scientific studies and manipulated conclusions are not only unduly denying justice to Vietnam veterans suffering from exposure to Agent Orange, they are now standing in the way of a full disclosure to the American people of the likely health effects of exposure to toxic dioxins,'' said Zumwalt. He reiterated charges by outside scientists that two influential industry-sponsored studies on plant accidents used fraudulent data, and that scientists refuse to use animal data clearly showing a connection between dioxin exposure and disease. ``While dioxin apologists concede dioxin's carcinogenic effects on animals, they insist that humanity has a miraculous dispensation from the harmful effects dioxin wreaks on other species of the animal kingdom,'' he said. Derwinski retained Zumwalt last fall as an unpaid adviser to help resolve the Agent Orange question, which has been debated for two decades. Since Derwinski took over last year as head of the Veterans Affairs Department, compensation to veterans has begun. Without stating outright that Agent Orange exposure was the cause, the VA has decided to compensate the few thousand veterans with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and soft-tissue sarcomas, both rare forms of cancer. Zumwalt said in his report May 5 to Derwinski that based on his review of scientific literature, those two cancers and 25 other afflictions should be considered to be linked to Agent Orange. Derwinski chose Zumwalt because of his unique position. As a commander, he ordered the herbicide to be used. Among those serving in Vietnam at the time were Zumwalt's son Elmo, who later died of Hodgkin's disease and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Other witnesses said Tuesday that more attention needs to be focused on both key ingredients of Agent Orange, not just the one, 2,4,5-T, that was contaminated with dioxin. They said the other ingredient _ 2,4-D _ causes cancers and other ailments linked to Agent Orange. Evidence shows that 2,4-D was also contaminated with harmful compounds, some related to dioxin, they said. A so-called phenoxy herbicide, 2,4-D is sold over the counter to kill dandelions and other lawn weeds. Farmers use it against weeds in corn, wheat, rice and sorghum. The farm-chemical industry believes further research into 2,4-D is needed, but the ``weight of the evidence'' so far indicates the risk of harm is relatively small if it exists at all, industry spokesman Garry Hamlin said in a telephone interview from Indianapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,312.75, up 740.98 points, or 2.29 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Dog Recall Expands To Cover Nation
DOC.TEXT: J.M. Schneider Inc. of Ontario, Canada, is voluntarily expanding its recall last week of 22,000 pounds of frankfurters to include grocery stores nationwide, the Agriculture Department says. Officials said Tuesday the recalled franks are suspected to being contaminated by Listeria monocytogenes, which can cause listeriosis, a potentially serious disease. In an initial recall on June 22, the company and USDA said the franks were distributed to stores in unspecified states in the Northeast. ``However, further investigation revealed the franks were distributed in California, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio, Maryland and Texas,'' the department said. The product, labeled ``Schneider's Franks,'' is sold in one-pound plastic packages. The words ``Canada 35'' appear inside the inspection seal on the label. All bearing the ``Best before'' date of ``Jul 03'' are being recalled. ``Although no illnesses have been associated with listeria, several consumer complains are being investigated,'' said Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. Prucha said consumers should return the suspected franks to the place of purchase. None of the company's other products are involved in the recall. The problem was said to have been discovered May 31 in a routine USDA import reinspection in Buffalo, N.Y. Laboratory tests confirmed the bacterial contamination on June 20.
DOC.HEAD: Unexpected Price Rises Forcing Cuts in WIC Program
DOC.TEXT: Sharp food price increases and rebate reductions will force nearly a quarter of a million low-income pregnant women and children from a federal supplemental nutrition program, according to a survey. ``Between March 1990 and September 1990, the end of the current fiscal year, our survey found that at least 240,000 participants would no longer be served by the WIC program,'' Dennis Bach, president of the National Association of WIC directors, said Tuesday. Bach said at least 25 states already have begun reducing their monthly participation in the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC. The program provides needy women and children with vouchers redeemable at grocery stores for food, including milk, cheese, juices and cereals. Since May 1989 the Consumer Price Index shows that milk prices have risen 10.7 percent, cheese costs have climbed 12.7 percent and fruit juices and frozen fruit prices have risen 13.8 percent. Congress has appropriated $2.1 billion for the current fiscal year. Bach said an additional $72 million was needed to prevent the reductions. The House approved a fiscal 1991 increase of $235 million, including $85 million to maintain current services and $150 million for program expansion. But Bach said the $150 million ``could be eaten up to maintain current levels.''
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Heart Drug is Licensed by Du Pont
DOC.TEXT: A new treatment for life-threatening heartbeat irregularities is believed to be the first Soviet drug licensed by a U.S. pharmaceutical company and approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Officials of Du Pont Co. said the drug, which will be marketed under the brand name Ethmozine, is the most widely used in the Soviet Union to treat the heart condition known as ventricular arrhythmia. The drug appears to be safer than the eight others in its class for patients who have had congestive heart failure, company officials said. Side effects, which include nausea and dizziness, occurred in 10 percent to 15 percent of patients, said Wilmington, Del.-based Du Pont. Ethmozine, also known generically as moricizine, was one of three drugs studied by the National Institutes of Health in a clinical trial aimed at assessing the increased risk of sudden death in people who have an abnormal heart rhythm following a heart attack. The two other drugs, Tambocor and Enkaid, were removed from the trial and new restrictions on them were ordered by the FDA when researchers found that patients on the treatments were dying unexpectedly. The trial is continuing with Ethmozine along with placebos. About 800,000 to 1.2 million Americans are being treated for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmia, said Kurt Landgraf, worldwide director of Du Pont Pharmaceuticals. Arrhythmias are related to more than 300,000 deaths each year. The drug, developed in the Soviet Union in 1964, will be marketed by Du Pont under an agreement in which the Soviets will receive royalties of 4 percent on worldwide sales, Landgraf said. The drug will be available in the United States in September.
DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia to Open Borders to Volunteers
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia will become the third newly democratic European country to accept U.S. Peace Corps volunteers, U.S. officials say. Twenty-two specialists in English teacher training and English as a foreign language will leave for the Central European country later this year as the result of an agreement signed Monday in Prague by Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Peace Corps Director Paul D. Coverdell, the agency said in a statement released Tuesday. Another 40 volunteers are expected to be sent by mid-1991, the statement said. Teams of English language-teaching specialists left earlier this month to start Peace Corps programs in Poland and Hungary, the first established in former communist-ruled countries. Other governments in the region have made contact about having Peace Corps units in their countries, said corps spokeswoman Paula Kuzmich. More than 6,100 Americans serve as Peace Corps volunteers in 72 countries.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush-Taxes a0427
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the text of President Bush's statement on taxes Tuesday.
I met this morning with the bipartisan leadership _ the speaker, the Senate majority leader, the Senate Republican leader, the House majority leader, and the House Republican leader _ to review the status of the deficit-reduction negotiations. It is clear to me that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require all of the following: entitlement and mandatory program reform; tax revenue increases; growth incentives; discretionary spending reductions; orderly reductions in defense expenditures; and budget process reform _ to assure that any bipartisan agreement is enforceable and that the deficit problem is brought under responsible control. The bipartisan leadership agree with me on these points. The budget negotiations will resume promptly with a view toward reaching substantive agreement as quickly as possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Spot the Danger in Whirling, Chopping Blades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: 'Tis the season to be careful, lest lawn and garden work lead to lacerated feet and fingers _ or worse. Lawn mowers, electric hedge trimmers and other power tools greatly ease the burden of caring for the outdoors. But they also pose serious hazards for the unwary, the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission warns. Newer lawn mowers have devices that cause the blade to stop turning when the operator lets go of the handle, a system designed to prevent hand injury. But many older mowers remain in use, and owners of those machines can still lose fingers if they try to clean clogged grass of other problems while the motor is running. The solution is simple: Stop the engine before doing anything beneath the mower deck, even cleaning out a clogged grass chute. It can pay to disconnect the spark plug so the motor cannot accidentally turn over. And even with hanging guards, mowers can still run over feet if operators are not careful. The commission suggests always pushing mowers, trying to pull them toward you rarely, if ever. In addition to the threat of cutting off fingers and toes, the spinning blade can hurl such objects as small stones at high speed. The safety commission urges keeping children and pets away from the area being mowed to prevent them being hit by such items. Stop the mower before crossing gravel driveways. Gasoline-powered movers present the added hazard of burns. Adding fuel to a hot mower is extremely dangerous, say safety officials, who warn that it can suddenly catch fire, especially in the event of a spill. In addition the muffler and other mower parts become very hot and can cause severe burns if touched. Electric mowers have a cord for power that can be a hazard if accidentally cut, the commission adds. With walk-behind mowers, the safety commission suggests mowing across steep slopes, never up and down. Hedge trimmers aren't as dangerous as lawn mowers, but can pose their own set of dangers, the commission reports. The danger of being cut by the blades is obvious, of course. Those cuts seem to occur most often when people try to use trimmers with one hand. Before plugging in the trimmer, check the on-off switch. The commission reports that many accidental cuts occur when people plug the trimmer in while the switch is on and it starts running accidentally. Improper grounding or cutting the electric cord can also lead to electric shocks, the commission says. And officials urge that these machines not be operated around children and pets, which can accidentally trip an adult or may be injured by the tool as they are not aware of the danger.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Cuts Immigration Numbers, Lets Chinese Students Stay Four Years
DOC.TEXT: Chinese students fearing reprisals in their homeland will be allowed to stay in Australia at least four more years, but overall immigration quotas will be cut 10 percent as a result, officials said today. The joint announcement by Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Immigration Minister Gerry Hand followed a marathon Cabinet meeting Tuesday. The decision will affect nearly 20,000 Chinese students who arrived by June 20, 1989, a little more than two weeks after Beijing's bloody crackdown on its pro-democracy movement. Many of the students had expressed fears that they might be punished after they returned home. According to the statement today, future human rights conditions in China will dictate whether the Chinese students can stay beyond four years or gain permanent residence. The Cabinet decision slashed the maximum number of new immigrants from 140,000 a year to 126,000 to make room for the Chinese students expected to seek extensions on their stays in Australia. Ethnic groups did not want further restrictions on already-tight immigration levels. The announcement was likely to draw widespread criticism from the political opposition, students and leaders of other immigrant groups. The students originally thought they would be allowed to stay permanently, without condition, after Hawke announced June 6 that a separate immigration category would be created for them. He then muddied the situation by saying they could stay temporarily, but that none would be forced to go back to China. The category announced today will allow the Chinese to apply, beginning in August, for a special four-year residency permit. It will allow them to work and apply to have their families join them. ``Unless we were confident that the situation in (China) was such that human rights were no longer generally at risk, permanent residence would be granted to those who apply, subject to normal health and character checks'' after the four-year extensions expire, the government said today. The Chinese granted permanent residency would be part of the total number of immigrants allowed into this country of 16 million people, not a special, additional category. Cambodian groups were particularly incensed when Hawke said on June 6 that Cambodian boat people were seeking to better themselves economically and should not be granted refugee status. Although Hawke said the Cambodian immigrants would be sent home, immigration officials later said any requests for refugee status would be considered on a case-by-case basis. The political opposition has said the immigration claims of Chinese students also should be considered case-by-case and should not be given blanket protection. On June 3-4 last year, Chinese troops cleared central Beijing of pro-democracy protesters, killing hundreds of unarmed civilians. Thousands of activists were subsequently arrested. President Bush in November vetoed a congressional measure that would have permitted any of the 40,000 Chinese students in the United States to remain after their visas run out if they fear reprisal back home. Bush, fearing the measure would have further hurt U.S.-Chinese relations, instead signed an executive order in April saying Chinese students would not be forced to return home. Bush's order directs the attorney general to defer until Jan. 1, 1994, any deportation procedings against Chinese nationals who were in the United States on or after June 5, 1989, and whose visas expire.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Soar In Tokyo, Dollar Drops
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange soared Wednesday, while the dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 154.35 yen, down 0.88 yen from Tuesday's 155.23-yen finish. It opened at 154.33 yen and ranged between 154.00 yen and 154.45 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average climbed 740.98 points, or 2.29 percent, ending the day at 3,312,75. The index rose 447.58 points on Tuesday. Traders attributed the stock index's surge to the yen's recovery against the dollar, as well as to the start Wednesday of stock trading for settlement in July. Stock transactions for each month begin four days before the end of the previous month due to the time it takes to complete handling procedures. ``The yen's strength greatly contributed to reassuring market players and prompted active buying,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Currency dealers said the dollar's decline followed its overnight fall in overseas markets, where investors sold because of expectations of declining U.S. interest rates. The trend continued in Tokyo as Japanese institutional investors, mainly life insurance companies, bought the yen against the dollar believing a statement by President Bush would lead to lower U.S. interest rates, dealers said. In Washington on Tuesday, Bush said tax revenue increases must be included in any deficit-reduction package.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Holds Meeting to Decide Democratic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Politicians and academics meet Thursday to try to defuse a constitutional crisis by agreeing on a more democratic system that would challenge four decades of one-party rule. An opposition leader predicted violence could result if the National Affairs Conference fails to find a way to give more power to native Taiwanese, who have been dominated by the ruling Nationalist Party that retreated to this island from mainland China in 1949. President Lee Teng-hui called for the conference in March after widespread public demonstrations demanding the scrapping of the system that has preserved the Nationalists' lock on power. ``We would pay a very painful price should the conference fail to set the direction of reforms in accordance with public expectations,'' said Chen Yung-hsing, acting chairman of the nation's largest opposition group, the Democratic Progressive Party. He warned of violent demonstrations in case of a deadlock. The one-week meeting will be attended by 150 delegates, including 80 members of the ruling party and 16 representatives from the Democratic Progressive Party. Independent academics and politicians account for the bulk of the remaining seats. Although President Lee has not explicitly promised to follow recommendations made by the delegates, it would be difficult for him to reject a proposal that had broad support from conference members. The debate will focus on what to do with the 1947 constitution, enacted in China by the Nationalist government two years before it lost a civil war to the Communists and retreated to the offshore island now home to 20 million people. The Nationalists have since used the constitution as the legal basis for their political power. Claiming to still be the legitimate government of all China, the Nationalists have not allowed native Taiwanese to vote for a majority of seats in the national Legislature and the electoral college. Instead, the party froze in lawmakers elected on the Chinese mainland more than four decades ago. The Nationalists have acknowledged the need for change as the aging lawmakers from the mainland die off and the increasingly affluent native Taiwanese, who account for 85 percent of the island's 20 million people, demand more political power. The Nationalists are expected to propose changing the constitution so all members of parliament are elected in Taiwan. But the ruling party delegates appear divided over whether the electoral college should be replaced by presidential elections and whether the strong presidency should give way to a Cabinet-led government. The Democratic Progressive Party believes that just amending the constitution does not go far enough and wants to replace it with what they call a ``Great Charter of Democracy.'' Opposition delegates say the charter would provide for direct presidential elections and allow the people of Taiwan to determine whether they should drop reunification with mainland China as a national goal. But Taiwan independence is vehemently rejected by both the Nationalists and the Communist government in Beijing, which regards the island as a renegade province that must return to the fold. Perhaps that is why opposition party members suggest the issue of reunification be put off indefinitely. ``We respect the rights and wisdom of our next generation and will leave some room for them to settle the matter,'' said Huang Huang-hsiung, a conference delegate who heads the opposition party's constitution task force.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Arizona Wildfire
DOC.TEXT: A wildfire burning along a mountain ledge apparently jumped a fireline and killed five inmates and a prison guard fighting the blaze, authorities said. At least four other inmates and another person were injured, one critically, as the blaze burned 5,000 acres Tuesday in the Tonto and Coconino National Forests. Tanker planes and helicopters backed up about 1,000 firefighters and support personnel fighting the fire, which was ignited Monday by lightning. More than 500 homes were evacuated and shelters were set up in Payson, a community 90 miles northeast of Phoenix. The number evacuated was unclear, since many of the homes are recreational cabins and vacation homes. The six apparently were killed when winds and updrafts off the rim pushed the blaze past firelines, said Tonto spokesman Bob Celaya. The temperature reached 106 degrees on Tuesday in Payson. ``The fire literally seemed to have exploded,'' said Tonto spokeswoman Joyce Hassell. Many of the firefighters were pulled off the fire overnight. About 80 were assigned to fight the blaze early today, Ms. Hassel said. The inmates were among 18 or 19 prisoners and two officials the Perryville state prison assigned to the fire, said Corrections Department spokesman Mike Arra. The injured were taken to Maricopa Medical Center in Phoenix. One inmate was in critical condition with burns over 40 percent of his body and smoke inhalation, Arra said. A firefighter was in guarded condition, fire officials said. The others were being treated for smoke inhalation, Arra said.

DOC.HEAD: Armored Car Robberies
With PM-Armored Car Robbery
DOC.TEXT: The theft of $10.8 million from an armored car in Rochester, N.Y., puts it at or near the top of the list of large robberies from armored car services in the United States. Here is a list of some of the top robberies: _Dec. 12, 1982, two men broke into the Sentry Armored Car Courier Co. office in New York City. About $11 million disappeared, but authorities say only a fraction of that amount may have been taken by the robbers. Only about $1 million has been recovered, and investigators say some of the missing money may have been previously embezzled from the company. _Apr. 19, 1985, $7.9 million was stolen from a Wells Fargo depot in New York after four masked gunmen ambushed and disarmed four guards. _Sept. 12, 1983, a robber made off with $7 million from the Wells Fargo office in Hartford, Conn., after drugging and tying up a driver and office manager. _Nov. 24, 1983, two armed men held up a Wells Fargo armored car in Memphis, Tenn., stealing $5.2 million in cash, $750,000 in negotiable securities and checks, and $500,000 in bonds. _Oct. 20, 1974 robbery of $4.3 million from a Purolator Inc., building in downtown Chicago. _July 19, 1984, members of the neo-Nazi group, The Order, stole $3.6 from a Brinks armored car near Ukiah, Calif. _Dec. 19, 1978, thieves held up a Wells Fargo armored truck on Staten Island and got away with $2.25 million in bank funds. _March 19, 1982, robbers who impersonated FBI agents stole more than $2 million from a Purolator armored-truck collection center near Pittsburgh.

DOC.HEAD: Zhao Adviser Reportedly Released from Jail
DOC.TEXT: China has released from prison a key adviser to Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief for supporting some goals of last year's crushed pro-democracy movement, a newspaper reported today. Bao Tong had been private secretary to the former party chief as well as heading a party think tank on reform. The English-language South China Morning Post said he was released from maximum security Qincheng prison last month and is under house arrest in Beijing. The newspaper, quoting unidentified sources in Beijing, said an investigation of Bao's activity during last year's protests yielded no incriminating information. The paper claimed the failure to press charges against Bao was a setback for hard-liner Premier Li Peng. The report said authorities have yet to decide what to do with Bao. China's official media has said nothing about Bao's case. Amnesty International reported that Bao was arrested May 28, 1989, about one week before China's conservative leaders ordered the military to crush pro-democracy protests. Zhao, who was sympathetic to some of the students' demands for greater political freedoms, was dismissed from all his party posts June 24, 1989. He was accused of ``supporting the turmoil,'' a reference to the protests, and of splitting the Communist Party. Zhao is believed to be living under house arrest in central Beijing. He has not been seen in public since May 1989. Bao, director of the Research Center for Reform of the Political Structure under the Communist Party's Central Committee, reportedly acted as Zhao's liaison to students during the protests. One official evaluation of the protests reportedly labeled Bao and other intellectuals as ``black hands'' behind the movement. Since late last year, China has announced the release of more than 800 people jailed for their participation in the crushed democracy movement. Thousands more are believed still in jail, most without being charged or brought to trial.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Young Men Likelier Homicide Victims Than Other Nationalities
DOC.TEXT: Young men in America are more than four times as likely to be homicide victims as those in 21 other industrialized nations, and the reason probably is greater access to guns, researchers say. If the rate could be reduced to that of Scotland, the country with the next highest rate, more than 3,000 lives would be saved every year, said two researchers at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md. But a criminology specialist said Tuesday it may be unfair to compare U.S. homicide rates to those of other countries, as the study published today does. ``Comparisons carry the burden of different societies and legal systems, etcetera,'' James Wright, a Tulane University sociologist, said in a telephone interview Tuesday from his New Orleans office. Lois Fingerhut and Joel Kleinman said in the study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association that in 1987 there were 4,223 male homicide victims ages 15 to 24 in the United States, or 21.9 per 100,000. That compared to 22 victims, or a rate of 5.0 per 100,000, in Scotland; Austria's 0.3 rate was the lowest. Fingerhut and Kleinman said guns, the cause of 75 percent of U.S. deaths, might explain the differences. ``While there is no clear reason, we have to look at the availability of firearms,'' Fingerhut said in a telephone interview. France was second in gun homicides, at 54 percent. In Washington, Tom Wyld, a spokesman for the National Rifle Association, had no comment on the study. But Wright said the Swiss own guns and have almost no violence. ``They do emphasize responsible firearm ownership much more than we do,'' he said.' According to the NCHS study, only one of 14 homicides in Switzerland was by firearm. ``And, if you subtract all the firearm homicides, we're still killing loads more people than any other country,'' Wright said. U.S. homicides not involving firearms in 1987 outnumbered annual totals in all other countries combined 3-to-1, or 1,036 to 308, according to the study. Twenty percent of all U.S. homicides occur in the 15- to 24-year-old age group, the researchers said. ``In the United States, homicide is the leading cause of death among black males aged 15 to 24 years, and the third leading cause'' after autombiles and suicide among white males ages 15 to 24, the study said. California had the highest homicide rate, 22.0 per 100,000, for young men among the 25 largest states. Texas was next, with 20.9. Minnesota was lowest, with 1.9. New York had the highest percentage of firearm homicides: 78 percent of its homicides were committed with guns. Florida had the lowest, 64 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Fox in Top 10 for Second Consecutive Week
DOC.TEXT: The grousing ``Simpsons'' and the bickering Bundys of ``Married .. With Children'' continue to make TV history for Fox Broadcasting. For the second straight week, the Fox network claimed two top 10 programs, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings released Tuesday. A repeat of ``The Simpsons'' finished in a three-way tie for 10th place last week, and a ``Married ... With Children'' rerun landed in a three-way tie for seventh. Fox's sketch comedy ``In Living Color'' ranked 14th, the best showing thus far for the acclaimed show. During the previous week, the cartoon Simpson family finished third, the highest rating by a Fox show in the network's four-year history. Virtually all of the highest-rated programs were reruns. ``Cheers'' on NBC was No. 1. ``Roseanne'' on ABC was second, followed by ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Empty Nest'' on NBC. NBC's ``The Seinfeld Chronicles,'' which tied for seventh, was the only original programming in the top 10. NBC was still No. 1 in the overall ratings with a 10.3 average. ABC was second with a 9. CBS was last, again, with an 8.8. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. In the network news wars, ABC continued dominate with a 9 average. CBS finished second with 8.3. NBC had an 8.1. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 15.1; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 15; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 13.9; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 13.8; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 13.6; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 13.5; ``Coach,'' ABC, ``Married ... With Children,'' Fox, ``The Seinfeld Chronicles,'' NBC (three-way tie), 13.4; ``A Different World,'' NBC, ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, ``Designing Women,'' CBS, (three-way tie), 13.3.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Seeks Foreign Aid As Peruvians Line Up for Scarce Bread, Gasoline
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Alberto Fujimori flies to New York Thursday, seeking aid to help pull his country out of a crisis that has forced people to line up for scarce supplies of bread, gasoline and other essentials. Officials blame the shortages on panic-buying and the plummeting value of the inti, the country's currency, which makes imports more expensive. Meanwhile, the government must deal with $20 billion in foreign debt and 2,000 percent annual inflation. ``People whose gas tanks are normally half empty are trying to fill them up every night. Housewives who normally store one gallon of kerosene are storing five,'' Pedro Touzett, general manager of the state-owned oil company Petroperu, told a news conference Tuesday. In Lima, housewives stood in block-long lines to buy cooking gas. Children waited hours to buy fist-sized loaves of bread. Hundreds of taxis and buses idled near the few open gas stations. The inti lost value by the hour. On the free market it has been devalued by 48 percent in one week, and by 23 percent since Monday morning. The shortages come five weeks before Fujimori is to be sworn in. The agronomist, a political unknown at the start of the election campaign, defeated celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in a June 10 presidential runoff. When he travels to New York on Thursday, Fujimori plans to visit the United Nations to seek emergency economic aid to finance food imports. He will also travel to Washington to meet with officials of the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank. He hopes to re-establish ties with international lenders that were broken by his predecessor, Alan Garcia, who limited payments on the country's foreign debt. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, will then travel Tokyo for meetings with Japanese leaders. Japan has said it is willing to resume loans to Peru if the country can show a willingness to deal with its serious social and economic problems. In Lima, the shortages have only added to the problems of the capital's 7 million residents, who already suffer from daily blackouts, severe water rationing and runaway inflation. Touzett said the shortage of electricity had increased demand for cooking gas and gasoline to power private generators. The Petroperu chief said the power shortages also hampered fuel distribution because gas stations cannot operate their pumps and natural gas bottlers their machinery. The Bread Industry Association attributed the bread shortages to reduced wheat imports. Peru imports all but 150,000 tons of the 1.2 million tons of wheat the country consumes each year. ``Once more we beg the government to import on a bigger scale and to do so continuously,'' Gilberto Hinojosa Teves of the Bread Industry Association told reporters Monday. But economists say that many imports have been reduced because of a lack of foreign currency. The government has been selling silver and gold to raise money. The Central Bank reserves stand at $900 million, mostly gold and silver. Centrist politician Manuel Moreyra said Monday that the rapid devaluation of the inti was due to the government's ``unusual emission of bills as well as the uncertainty before political change.'' The country's problems have been compounded by a severe drought that has cut crop production and hydroelectric power, and attacks by Maoist-inspired Shining Path guerrillas on power lines.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says Leak Tests Same as Always
DOC.TEXT: NASA says it will run a fuel test on space shuttle Atlantis on Thursday to assure itself the rest of the shuttle fleet does not have hydrogen leaks like the one that has grounded Columbia. ``We believe that we don't have a generic-type of a flaw that should indict the rest of the hardware in the fleet,'' Jack Boykin, deputy manager of Johnson Space Center's orbiter projects office, said Tuesday. ``We want to prove that to ourselves beyond any reasonable doubt because there is a potential safety hazard to having a hydrogen leak.'' Columbia has been grounded by a tiny fuel leak that forced NASA to scrub its mission May 30 six hours before liftoff. Hydrogen is highly combustible. The shuttle was to have carried the $150 million Astro observatory. The leak is in the area where the orbiter is connected to the big external fuel tank. It is thought to be in a valve on the orbiter, NASA said. Up to 200,000 gallons of super-cold liquid hydrogen will be pumped into Atlantis' external tank on Thursday, about half the tank's capacity, to test its valve. The same test helped NASA locate generally the leak in Columbia. It's unclear whether NASA will launch Atlantis on a secret military mission in mid-July if the exact cause of Columbia's problems have not been determined by then. Boykin said, ``There are still folks in our community who aren't committed to that yet.'' The subject will be discussed during a flight readiness review on Thursday and Friday, he said. A launch date will then be announced. In repairs on Columbia, a 17-inch-diameter valve that carries liquid hydrogen from the external tank to the main engine was removed from the tank side, but no leaks were found. The problem consequently lies on the orbiter side, and the valve from the unfinished shuttle Endeavour will replace the bad component, NASA said. There is only one such valve on the orbiter side of the shuttle. The valve on the external tank side is jettisoned along with the tank minutes after liftoff, and a new valve accompanies every new tank. Columbia's hydrogen lines indicated leakage during a mechanical test in 1984 to check the valve on the external tank side, Boykin said. Seven other valves, including the one on Atlantis, also failed at that time. The valve on the external tank side of Columbia and the others that failed underwent yet another check. Each valve passed that test, Boykin said. Thirty-three of 64 valves made from 1980 to 1986, when the Challenger explosion temporarily halted production, leaked hydrogen during the mechanical test, Boykin said. Seventeen were within acceptable limits, he said. The remaining 16 went through the second test and passed, Boykin said. Nine went on to fly and performed well, he said. A similar test was performed with the valves on the orbiter side of the shuttles, and no problems were detected, Boykin said. The valve that apparently is leaking on Columbia was modified following the Challenger accident and has flown twice without any problems, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Bakes Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Much of the nation enjoyed fair weather early today, while temperatures in Phoenix fell below 100 after reaching a record-breaking 122 degrees. Heat advisories were posted for today and Thursday across the deserts of San Diego County, Calif. Temperatures in the inland valleys were expected to reach near 110 degrees, threatening orchards and vineyards. The western Plains and the Southwest sweltered on Tuesday, with temperatures reaching the 90s as far north as the upper Missouri Valley. Records for the day were broken from Los Angeles, where the temperature reached 112 degrees, to Lubbock, Texas, where it was a scorching 105. Authorities said they suspected three deaths in Phoenix and one in Los Angeles were heat-related. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 122 in Arizona at Buckeye, Gila Bend, Phoenix, Youngtown and Yuma and in Laughlin, Nev. The National Weather Service predicted it would be just about as hot today in the Southwest. Only slight cooling was expected by the weekend as a high-pressure system held fast over New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado and Utah. Today's forecast called for scattered thunderstorms across the Dakotas, Minnesota, Iowa, Oklahoma, northern Texas, southern Louisiana, Florida and northern New England. Showers were expected in northwestern Washington. On Tuesday evening, summertime thunderstorms rumbled over the lower Texas Gulf Coast, the lower Mississippi Valley, South Dakota, Iowa, western Wisconsin, Minnesota, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan. Showers and thunderstorms also developed over the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida, and were scattered over parts of Arizona, New Mexico, Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming and southwest Montana. DOC.HEAD: National Assembly Approves Ban On Smoking, Alcohol Advertising
DOC.TEXT: The National Assembly today approved a ban on all tobacco advertising and most liquor advertising starting in 1993. The law, approved on a 315-149 vote, forbids all direct or indirect advertising for tobacco products, including sponsorships of sports and cultural events. Legislators from wine-growing regions succeeded in excluding most wines from the ban on liquor advertising. All 270 assembly members of the governing Socialist Party backed the bill, as did 45 independents and centrists. The two main center-right parties adopted different tactics _ most members of the Union for French Democracy voted against the bill, while most members of the Rally for the Republic abstained. During a two-day debate on the bill, legislators defeated an amendment that would have banned sales of tobacco products to minors under 16 and adopted an amendment prohibiting liquor sales at service stations. According to the government, smoking causes 65,000 deaths and alcoholism 45,000 deaths each year in France. Health Minister Claude Evin, the bill's chief sponsor, said today's measure is ``without precedent in the history of public health.'' The bill is part of an anti-smoking campaign by the government. Cigarette prices are due to rise by 15 percent later this year, and the national railroad announced this week that smoking is to be banned on all of its commuter trains.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Apartheid must go, and it must go now. The masses of the American people are with us. Both Congress and the Senate of the United States are with us. President Bush and the administration are with us. Surely apartheid will go.'' _ African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, at the end of a three-day Washington visit.

``To find out what the Supreme Court really believes, we need a law that flies in the face of Roe vs. Wade.'' _ Sen. Mike Cross, on a bill passed by the Louisiana Senate that would outlaw abortion even in cases of rape or incest.

``In the heartland of America, some folks just can't understand what Congress is up to.'' _ Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, after a constitutional amendment against burning the American flag was defeated.

DOC.HEAD: Western Europe Moves Ahead With Plans for Political Union
DOC.TEXT: Plans for political union of a dozen West European countries have moved ahead, but it's still unclear what the final product will look like. Leaders of the European Community wrapped up a two-day summit on Tuesday by agreeing to open a special conference on Dec. 14 to sketch in the details. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is confident she has scotched grandiose plans for some kind of federal Europe. ``I think we have won on that,'' she told reporters. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey, host of the summit, said the leaders wanted to have ``a new, closer, much more integrated political relationship.'' There will be, he said, ``a much closer growing together politically.'' Some have suggested the community should turn itself into a federal United States of Europe. Others predict a more limited outcome. They foresee closer cooperation in foreign policy areas so the community can play a more influential role on the world stage. The European Parliament, the community's legislature, likely would be strengthened. It would have more say over the European Commission, the trading bloc's executive body. Mrs. Thatcher has opposed any moves that would transfer national sovereignty to new community agencies. To sharpen the debate, aides of the leaders have drawn up a list of questions that need to be answered before a political union can be formed. The five-page document said the overall goal is to strengthen the ability of the governments ``to act in the areas of their common interests.'' ``The unity and coherence of its policies and actions should be ensured through strong and democratic institutions,'' it said. The paper asked whether new powers should be transferred to the community from individual governments. It wondered how ``the notion of community citizenship'' should be dealt with and whether new agencies should be set up. The paper was drawn up after the leaders committed themselves at an Arpil summit, also held in Dublin, to a political merger by late 1992. Their decision was sparked by the political upheavals in Eastern Europe. The West European nations contend they must offer stability at a time of uncertainty in Eastern Europe. The special conference on political union will run parallel to a convention, starting Dec. 13, on fashioning an economic and monetary union. The conferences are needed to change the community's founding Treaty of Rome and set up any new political or monetary agencies. Officials want both conferences to finish their work and the nations to ratify any treaty changes by late 1992. That is the date when the nations already are set to create a European-wide market. To do that, they intend to get rid of the many trade barriers that bar the free movement of money, people and products. At their summit, the European Community leaders also called on all South Africans to renounce violence in a declaration that Britain said was directed squarely at Nelson Mandela's African National Congress. But the leaders of the trade bloc refused to ease sanctions against South Africa's white-led government, saying they need ``further clear evidence'' that changes to end apartheid will continue. Mrs. Thatcher said it was a ``great pity'' that the EC nations were ``unable to agree publicly to make a start now on easing sanctions.'' Unanimous support by the EC nations is needed to end joint embargoes imposed in 1986 that banned imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins. The summit also considered a West German and French demand for $15 billion in immediate aid to help the Soviet Union's deteriorating economy. Most of the other leaders opposed giving money to the Soviet Union with no clear idea of how it would be used. The community ordered its executive commission to undertake with the World Bank and other international agencies a study of Moscow's needs. Officials said they expected Italy, which takes over the community's six-month rotating presidency on July 1, to have Soviet aid proposals ready by fall.

DOC.HEAD: Army Private Convicted of Murdering Civilian During U.S. Invasion
DOC.TEXT: An Army private was convicted of unpremeditated murder of a civilian during the invasion of Panama. Investigators said she was shot during a gunfight staged to conceal the loss of a military pistol. Pfc. Mark McMonagle, 20, of Philadelphia, faced up to life in prison and a dishonorable discharge at sentencing today by the military panel that convicted him after an hour's deliberation Tuesday. ``They crucified him,'' said McMonagle's mother, Patricia. ``They sent him to Panama to give up his life, and they do this to him. There wasn't enough evidence to support the charges.'' Sgt. Paul Finsel Jr., 25, of Arkoma, Okla., also was charged with murder in the Jan. 25 shooting. His court-martial begins Friday. McMonagle, of the 7th Light Infantry Division from Fort Ord, admitted to an investigator that he went to a Panama City bar and brothel with Finsel, who lost his handgun when the two went into a back room to evade military police. Finsel convinced him that they should fake a firefight and say the gun was lost in the melee, McMonagle told the investigator. The two fired their rifles in the air, and soldiers nearby heard the shots and took up the fake firefight. Leila Diaz de Panay, 50, was shot in the abdomen while taking a bath in the courtyard of her home. McMonagle said he had seen a shadow and fired six times. ``What they did was a terrible, terrible thing. It's a hard thing to swallow,'' the prosecutor, Capt. Robin Johnson, said in her closing argument. Defense attorney Capt. Norman Allen argued that Finsel was ``belligerent, frantic, agitated'' and in trouble and that McMonagle simply followed his lead. ``If he made a mistake, that's a tragic mistake. ... We shouldn't offer up McMonagle as a sacrifice. (Mrs. de Panay) wasn't the only civilian who died,'' he said. The defense also offered affidavits from Panamanians in the neighborhood who said they heard gunfire coming from an apartment building. A third soldier, Pfc. Marc Gussen, 19, of Teaneck, N.J., who accompanied McMonagle and Finsel, testified for the prosecution. He pleaded guilty in April to firearms, alcohol and obstruction charges and was sentenced to two years in prison, demotion and dishonorable discharge.

DOC.HEAD: Industrialist Convicted for Helping Build Libya Gas Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with more background on trial, quotes from testimony. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A state court today convicted a 49-year-old West German industrialist of helping build a poison gas plant in Libya and sentenced him to five years in prison. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen was found guilty of violating export laws and tax evasion for his involvement in construction of the widely publicized plant in the Libyan city of Rabta, south of Tripoli. Hippenstiel-Imhausen admitted at his trial earlier this month that he helped build the chemical plant while he headed the Imhausen-Chemie company of Lahr, a southwestern city near Mannheim. The prosecution had asked for a prison term of 6{ years for Hippenstiel-Imhausen, calling him a ``merchant of death.'' He had faced a maximum sentence of eight years. Defense lawyers sought a briefer sentence, noting that the defendant had confessed. Judge Juergen Henninger sentenced him to five years. The ruling followed an 11-day trial, one of the most heavily publicized business trials in West German history. Hippenstiel-Imhausen said in court on June 13 that he had suspicions the project ``would be in conflict with West Germany's export laws'' but did not investigate because he ``didn't want to lose the business.'' West German law forbids the export of technology or material that could be used in conflict areas such as the Middle East. Libya has said the Rabta plant was intended for producing pharmaceuticals, but U.S. and West German officials have said it was built to manufacture chemical weapons. Hippenstiel-Imhausen testified that the Rabta project began in 1984 when a ``middleman'' contacted him about building a chemical plant to make ``pharmaceuticals and insecticides.'' He said he found out later that the $136 million project was to be in Libya and that his participation might violate West German law. Hippenstiel-Imhausen also admitted not paying taxes on $11.7 million on profits from his transactions. Allegations that several Western companies helped build the Rabta plant have triggered worldwide debate about toughening international export law enforcement. Hippenstiel-Imhausen is the only person to be charged in the case, though West German authorities are investigating 18 other people. Imhausen-Chemie was found to be the key supplier of equipment, construction plans and technical expertise to develop the Rabta project. Prosecutor Hans-Heiko Klein said Hippenstiel-Imhausen had delivered plans and documents, as well as providing material valued at $12 million. The defendant was arrested in May 1989 and kept in investigative custody since. His time in custody counts toward his sentence. On Tuesday, the ARD television network said Libya intended to build a second plant using the plans furnished by Hippenstiel-Imhausen for the first plant. It cited U.S. and West German intelligence sources for the information. The television report said two West German companies and a Netherlands firm were suspected of having ties to the project. According to the report, the Stuttgart prosecutor's office is investigating the allegations against the companies in West Germany. The Libyan scandal first came to light in December 1988, when the United States charged that West German firms were providing massive assistance for construction of a chemical factory capable of producing poison gas. West German government officials at first denied any of the country's companies were involved but later acknowledged the allegations were true.

DOC.HEAD: Broadway Approves Plan to Cut Costs and Ticket Prices
DOC.TEXT: Broadway theater owners, unions and producers have announced a plan to set aside three theaters where patrons would pay no more than $24 for tickets _ nearly half price. The plan announced Tuesday is aimed at stimulating the development of more productions and drawing theatergoers who can't afford Broadway anymore. Seats at most non-musicals cost $25 to $45. Under the plan, the three major Broadway theater owners _ the Shubert and Nederlander Organizations and Jujamcyn Theaters _ will each set aside one of its theaters for the productions, including dramas and comedies, but not musicals. The productions will be booked on a rotating basis, and the theater owner has the right to reject a play as well as to book a regular attraction and drop out of the rotation. Ticket prices will be reduced by cutting royalties, salaries and other costs by at least 25 percent. While orchestra seats will cost $24, seats in the balcony will be as low as $10, a price not seen on Broadway for years. The plan goes into effect Sept. 1 for an 18-month test period. The League of American Theaters and Producers said it will contribute $250,000 for administrative expenses and lighting in the three theaters.

DOC.HEAD: Shadyside Flood Death Toll Climbs to 24
DOC.TEXT: Searchers found a body in the Ohio River, bringing the toll to 24 dead in a flash flood two weeks ago. Nine people remain missing. The body of Jim West, 55, was found Tuesday at the Hannibal locks and dam. West's wife and mother also died in flooding here June 14, said Belmont County coroner's investigator Chuck Vogt. Vogt said the search for the missing is confined to the dam about 27 miles south of Shadyside. Of the missing, at least two were known to be in the area before the flooding. Authorities are not sure about the rest.

DOC.HEAD: Retiring Postal Worker Leaves $104,000 Worth of Vacation Pay
DOC.TEXT: Somewhere during a 37-year career, most people would take a vacation. Or maybe even use a sick day. Not Richard Lamica. ``There was a job to be done,'' he said. ``I didn't need vacation. Besides, the post office has been good to me all my life.'' After logging 76,960 hours at the U.S. Postal Service's Mountain View office, Lamica retired last week, leaving behind $104,000 worth of unused vacation time. He won't get the vacation money because he chose not to draw the pay over the years. ``He is an exceptionally nice fella,'' Postmaster Ken Baker said. Lamica, 55, began work at age 17, and except for a few days off in the 1960s to take the kids to Disneyland, he hasn't taken vacation. By the time he retired Friday, he had also racked up 410 sick days. Lamica was honored by city officials in April when he was selected grand marshal of the spring parade. On Monday, his first day as a retiree, Lamica said he wasn't sure what to do with himself. ``It feels strange,'' he said. ``It feels like I should be at work. This isn't going to be too easy.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Plenum Expected Friday to Decide on Congress; Platform Published
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party officials said today that the Central Committee will meet Friday to consider postponing next week's party congress, a policy-setting gathering of 4,700 delegates from across the country. Reformers fear that conservative foes of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's could dominate the gathering, split the party and undermine the Soviet leader as he tries to pull his country out of a deep economic and political crisis. The congress, scheduled months ago, is to begin Monday. But reports suddenly surfaced this week that it might be put off because of concerns that hard-liners may prevail. The reform-minded president of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin, told a news conference Tuesday that he favored postponing the congress until autumn to ``stabilize the political situation.'' A party official who spoke on condition of anonymity said today that party's 249-member policy-making Central Committee would meet on Friday. Yeltsin predicted there would be ``a real struggle'' at the Central Committee plenum over the congress timing. A postponement could prevent party hard-liners from capitalizing on their successes last week at a meeting of party members from the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic. The 2,700 party members at the Russian Federation meeting will constitute a majority of delegates to the national congress. Party congresses are normally held every five years. Delegates have the right to elect the party leadership and change the party's rules and program, though in the past power has always flowed from the top. Until Gorbachev came to power, the party was the country's leading political force. Now, Gorbachev has stripped it of its political monopoly as he seeks to transfer power to a more democratic government. The Communists have been blamed for the sorry state of the economy and have suffered major defeats at the polls.
