Gorbachev heads both the party as general secretary and the government as president, a post whose powers he has expanded, so he could lose the party post and still be Soviet leader. Despite the uncertainty surrounding the congress, the Central Committee went ahead today and published a ``program statement'' that the congress will discuss and be asked to approve. The program, spread across almost two pages of the Communist Party daily Pravda, takes a repentant tone about the party's blame for the country's ills. But it maintains that the country's main problem lay in the past distortion of socialism, not the ideology itself. ``False ideas about socialism as a society based on the state monopoly on property, and dictatorship led by the party-state brass in the name of the proletariat, led to tyranny and lawlessness and the alienation of people from property and authority,'' the committee said. The program backs many of Gorbachev's reforms already under way, including the transition to a market economy and the party's rejection of its former political monopoly. It also proposes more independence for party organizations in the 15 Soviet republics, and allows for the possibility of various platforms in the party without actually approving full-fledged factions. On the issue of whether party units should be removed from the KGB and army, the program says the party groups should be allowed to remain but be clearly separate from the basic power structure. The Russian Federation's parliament gave preliminary approval this month to a decree that would ban the party units in the KGB and army. It also forbade officials to combine a high party and government post. Yeltsin said Tuesday that the national party congress was the ``last chance for radical renewal of the party,'' and that he would suspend his party membership if he is dissatisfied with the results. The public debate over whether to postpone the congress contrasted sharply with carefully orchestrated meetings in the past. Along with the new program, Gorbachev is trying to bring new party rules to this congress. According to an early draft, they would slim down the Central Committee and expand the ruling Politburo, which has generally included about a dozen members and done all the party's most important decision-making. It would also be renamed the Presidium. Gorbachev's spokesman, Arkady A. Maslennikov, asked Tuesday by reporters about Gorbachev's position on the congress' timing, declined to comment and said the Central Committee would decide when the congress would be held.

DOC.HEAD: Sirhan Denied Parole For 13th Time
DOC.TEXT: SOLEDAD, Calif. _ A state parole board refused to release from prison Sirhan B. Sirhan, convicted of killing Robert F. Kennedy in 1968. Sirhan, 46, was told after a five-hour hearing at Soledad prison on Tuesday that he will not be eligible again for parole until 1992. Parole was denied ``because the prisoner committed a political assassination, which is unique in American history,'' said David Brown, one of three members of the Board of Prison Terms who presided over the hearing. Kennedy had just won California's Democratic presidential primary when Sirhan shot him in Los Angeles on June 5, 1968. Sirhan, a Jerusalem-born Christian Arab, later said he was angry at Kennedy for supporting the shipment of jets to Israel. Sirhan's death sentence was reduced to life in prison with the possibility of parole after the state death penalty was overturned. His first parole hearing was in 1975; Tuesday marked the 13th time parole has been denied.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first item to CORRECT typo in `congestive.'
DOC.TEXT: Gerard Appy, former executive director of Oregon Public Broadcasting, died Sunday at his home in Lake Oswego of congestive heart failure. He was 69. Appy was vice president of New York's WNET, one of the country's leading public TV stations, before being named executive director of the Oregon Educational and Public Broadcasting Service nine years ago.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota Town Remembers King of the Bubbly
DOC.TEXT: Bands played German waltzes and marches to honor Lawrence Welk, king of champagne music, as work began on the restoration of his farm where he learned to play the accordian as a child. Gov. George Sinner was among 100 people at the groundbreaking ceremonies Tuesday. He said Welk symbolizes the talent of the descendants of Germans who came to North Dakota 100 years ago. ``They are people who believe that artistic ability is at its best when it is for the common people,'' the governor said. Welk knew early on he wanted to be a musician and not a farmer, said Rosemary Schaefbauer, president of Welk Heritage Inc., which is coordinating the restoration of the home where Welk lived until he was 21. ``He disliked milking the cows, so he made it interesting by trying to do it in rhythm,'' she said. ``But the cows didn't like it. They would kick over the milk pail or slap him with their tails.'' Young Welk made a deal with his father. Lawrence would work on the farm until he was 21 if his father would buy him a $400 accordion. The deal complete, he struck out on his own in 1924. Welk formed a band three years later and got his start in radio at WNAX in Yankton, S.D. The band was known as ``The Honolulu Fruit Gum Orchestra'' and ``Lawrence Welk and his Hotsy Totsy Boys,'' and played at area ballrooms for several years in the late 1920s and early 1930s. In the late 1930s, the band traveled east to the William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh, where ``Champagne Music'' was born. Welk played in the Chicago area in the 1940s, and became a national television star in the late 1950s. His syndicated television show, still in reruns, is a favorite among North Dakotans on Saturday nights. The bandleader, now 87 and living in Los Angeles, did not attend the groundbreaking. But he sent a note of thanks. ``Little did I dream when I was growing up on the farm so many, many years ago that someday it would be restored and people would come and marvel at how life was lived in the early 1920s,'' Welk wrote. Welk's parents, Ludwig and Christina, arrived in North Dakota in 1893. The Welk farm in this town of 600 about 75 miles south of Bismarck had been vacant since 1966. The cost of the restoration project is estimated at $750,000, including $500,000 for a trust to maintain the museum after it opens. Welk Heritage Inc. has raised $150,000, including $80,000 from Welk's foundation in California. It hopes to collect the rest from grants and donations. Carpenters have finished rebuilding a granary and a buggy house, a summer kitchen and the outhouse on the farm. Renovation work is under way on the 25-by 28-foot sod house built by Welk's father at the turn of the century.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Goes Window-Shopping
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd item of PM-Mandela-Notebook to UPDATE with Mandela taking morning walk today
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela went window-shopping today, strolling past storefronts on busy Connecticut Avenue to the surprise of early-morning commuters. Only hours before his scheduled departure for Atlanta, Mandela left his hotel at 6:15 a.m. for a walk that took him from downtown to the city's DuPont Circle neighborhood. Along the way he stopped to look in store windows, and seemed surprised to find books with his photo on the cover in a bookstore window. Mandela arrived in lobby of his hotel in a New York Yankees warmup jacket and cap. He was greeted by Metropolitan Police officers who gave him a blue police T-shirt and a Washington Redskins cap. He changed into the new outfit in the lobby before starting his walk. Mandela also took a morning walk on Tuesday. Shortly before 7 a.m., he took a 25-minute hike, watched only by a handful of security officers, a couple of photographers, and a few surprised commuters who chanced across his path. His security detail raced to keep up with the smiling 71-year-old African leader, who wore the New York Yankees cap and jacket he had been given earlier at the New York stadium. Officers barked at each other and rushed at pedestrians _ including one man walking his dog _ to make hasty security checks. One city police officer paused long enough, however, to play tourist, taking out a small camera and snapping Mandela's picture.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Pledges $9 Million to Global Environmental Fund
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today urged an international conference to reduce the use of chemicals depleting the ozone layer, and she pledged $9 million to the world's first global environmental fund. ``We need to speed up action and set ourselves higher targets and shorter deadlines for reducing and eventually eliminating CFCs and halons,'' Mrs. Thatcher told the government ministers and officials from nearly 100 countries. ``Even if all the chemicals which damage the ozone layer were banned tomorrow, ozone depletion would continue to get worse for more than a decade. It would still take our planet well beyond the lifetime of all of us here to replenish the ozone already lost. ``That is the extent of the damage we have already done.'' CFCs, used in aerosol sprays, refrigerators, foams and cleaning solvents, destroy ozone gas scattered through the stratosphere about 30 to 50 miles above the Earth's surface. Scientists say that without the gas that filters out harmful ultraviolet rays, life in Earth would cease. Higher ultraviolet radiation damages the human immune system, causes skin cancer and cataracts, harms crops and disrupts sea life. Dr. Mostafa Tolba, executive director of the U.N. Environment Program, told delegates: ``Far too much is at stake to contemplate failure. We have no option but to succeed and inshallah (God willing) we will succeed.'' Tolba said the London meeting was ``establishing a new political movement to deal with the environmental crisis... a movement rooted in respect for the value of human life, the value of nature. We are not just writing a new treaty; we are writing a new chapter in international relations.'' During the three-day meeting, the officials will study proposals calling for a worldwide ban on a group of chemicals that threaten the planet's ozone shield. The conference also will discuss a proposal to create an international fund to help poorer countries pay the high price for ozone-friendly technology. Conference sources said diplomats were close to agreement on such a fund, which the United States opposed until two weeks ago. In a week of working sessions before the meeting moved to ministerial level, delegates tried to hammer out details for the fund proposal. But a number of tricky issues remain to be resolved by the ministers, including where the funds will come from. Many developing countries insist that the richer industrialized nations help the Third World pay the bill, estimated at $2 to $7 billion in the coming years, for converting to substitutes for chloroflurocarbons, or CFCs. Developed nations, led by the United States, want to shift their contributions from aid funds already allocated. The ministers appear likely to agree on a three-year down payment of $160 million, as suggested by Tolba. Another $80 million would be promised to China and India, to coax them into signing the 1987 Montreal Protocol on protecting the ozone layer. The ministers' work, if successful, will extend and strengthen the Montreal Protocol, already considered an environmental watershed. In September 1987, 56 nations agreed to halve CFC by 1996. Since then, scientific evidence on the destruction caused by the chemicals has prompted countries to move more quickly to eliminate them completely. Eighty-one nations decided in principle last year to ban them by the year 2000. Ministers will be debating whether to quicken the pace. The 12-nation European Community, along with the Nordic countries, Australia and New Zealand, wants to move up the ban to 1997. The United States and Japan are opposed. The ministers are likely to agree to ban halons and carbon tetrachloride, in addition to CFCs, by the year 2000. Both are used in firefighting. Scientific studies overwhelmingly show the ozone layer will not be fully restored unless all the severely damaging chemicals are banned worldwide and some of the less harmful substitutes are strictly controlled.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Group Demands Fiscal Accountability from Officers
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association's legislative body pledged to scrutinize the organization's finances because of questionable use by one former officer of hundreds of thousands of dollars. The AMA's 436-member House of Delegates voted Tuesday to require that members be told how much officials receive as pay and as other compensation. ``The board understands full well that the extraordinary financial transactions and their consequences have resulted in pain and embarrassment,'' said John J. Ring, of Mundelein, Ill., chairman of the board of trustees. ``For that, for our lack of knowledge at a time when we should have known, the board of trustees expresses its sincere regret to this House of Delegates,'' Ring said. The house rejected an effort to require reporting of all consulting contracts to AMA members. That proposal was submitted by the Louisiana delegation, which argued that the AMA officials need such oversight if their members' confidence is to be restored. But the AMA's newly appointed executive vice president, James S. Todd, said publishing the details of consulting contracts would put the association at a competitive disadvantage in attracting talent at reasonable prices, and inhibit the development of organization policies. The Board of Trustes submitted a report to the delegates outlining findings that James H. Sammons, the AMA's former executive vice president: _ Authorized the reimbursement from AMA funds of $353,826 for losses suffered by his money market account during the October 1987 stock market crash without disclosing the transaction to the board. _ Approved a loan of $267,710 for a condominium for the AMA general counsel, which ultimately the AMA foreclosed on at a loss of $76,672. _ Sold the AMA his home for $280,000, although the AMA ``was in possession of a single appraisal indicating that the value of the property was from $265,000 to $272,000.'' Sammons retired in February.

DOC.HEAD: Index of Leading Indicators Up in May
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 11th graf, The various..., to make index up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago sted 1.1 percent.
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge rose 0.8 percent in May, another indication the economy will skirt a recession this year, the government reported today. The Index of Leading Economic Indicators is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance. If the economy continues to grow through November, it will reach its eighth year of expansion. It already is the longest expansion in peacetime history. But today's Commerce Department report also contained an ominous note _ the largest negative contributor among the 11 forward-looking indicators was an index measuring consumer confidence. It was further evidence that Americans are becoming more cautious in their spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and which has helped fuel economic growth for 7{ years. But as consumer spending appears to pause, analysts point to business investment and overseas demand for U.S. goods as a major stimulus for continued, although weak, growth. The leading indicators were released as White House and congressional leaders were preparing to resume negotiations on a plan to reduce the fiscal 1991 deficit _ a reduction that would require continued economic growth. A recession would make that task much more difficult since it would mean a loss of jobs and incomes, diminished corporate profits and a drop in tax revenues. At the same time, the government would be called upon to increase spending on various benefits. In advance of today's report, a consensus of economists had expected the index to have risen 0.7 percent. Seven of the components were positive in May _ a longer average workweek, an increase in the price of raw materials, a larger amount of orders for consumer goods, higher stock prices, a decrease in the weekly unemployment claims, slower business delivery times and an increase in orders for new plants and equipment. In addition to the drop in consumer confidence, the other negatives were a decrease in the money supply, a smaller number of building permits and a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders. The various changes left the index at 146.2 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year ago. Many economists, who believe the nation's economy will continue to expand sluggishly during the remainder of the year, are growing more anxious over the slowing contributions of American consumers. The consumer confidence index was negative in January and February and unchanged in March. It posted a slim gain in April. Analysts have cited a poor job market and weak wage gains for the flagging consumer confidence. ``Consumer spending will remain weak,'' economists for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets wrote in their current Weekly Economic & Financial Commentary. ``Spending on services should rise solidly in the second quarter after posting a meager gain in the first quarter, but spending on goods will probably decline.'' Indeed, retail sales have fallen for three straight months through May, the first time that has happened since the summer of 1981 during the last recession. Retail sales represent about half of consumer spending. The Commerce Department also reported last week that overall consumer spending was flat in May, and said the April and March gains were weaker than first thought. And the Federal Reserve, in a survey completed by its district banks earlier this month, found ``very little growth, if not a decline, in real consumer spending for durable and non-durable goods this quarter from last.'' Many analysts say the Fed's tight-money policy designed to curb inflation has contributed to the economic slowdown by boosting interest rates. Some are calling for further relaxation of the Fed's grip on credit before the economy slips into a recession. A June survey of 51 prominent economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz., produced a consensus forecast of a weak 1.9 percent growth in the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services. The GNP rose 3 percent last year and 4.4 percent in 1988. But while consumers may be pulling back, recent reports indicate that the manufacturing sector may have bottomed out. Big-ticket durable goods orders, for instance, were up 3.9 percent in May, while industrial production posted a 0.6 percent increase. Nevertheless, the automobile and housing industries continue to be a drag on the economy, leaving exports one of the few bright spots. ``Because of weak domestic demand,'' the Merrill Lynch economists said, ``exports are likely to be the main source of growth in the second quarter and for the rest of the year.'' Meanwhile, the Commerce Department also said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators had slipped a revised 0.1 percent in April after a 1.0 percent gain in March. But even though the index fell in April, the revision was a slight improvement over the 0.2 percent decline originally reported last month.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Couple Decapitated; Son Charged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf `The bodies ... to UPDATE with missing heads found.
DOC.TEXT: A 27-year-old man was charged today with decapitating his adoptive parents with a saw, police said. The bodies of Anthony and Ann Camerlengo, both 73, were discovered Tuesday night in the basement of their home. The man's legs also were cut off. The couple's heads were found in a storm drain down the street early today. Thomas Camerlengo was charged with murder and weapons possession, police said. The couple's nephew, who lives next door, had notified police after going to the home to look for some belongings, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. The handle of a bow saw was found near the bodies, and a bloody blade was in the bathroom upstairs, Mohrmann said. Police gave no motive for the slayings. Thomas Varughese, a neighbor of the couple, said Camerlengo had a history of mental illness and had returned two or three weeks ago from a psychiatric hospital. Mohrmann said she could not confirm the report.

DOC.HEAD: President Yang Shangkun Hospitalized with Appendicitis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd pvs, `The official...' to UPDATE with premier describing Yang's operation as a success. Pickup 4th, `The post...'
DOC.TEXT: President Yang Shangkun, a key power-broker among China's conservative leaders, has been hospitalized with appendicitis, the Foreign Ministry said today. The ministry, in a short statement, said 83-year-old Yang entered a hospital Monday with appendicitis and underwent an operation. It did not say where Yang was hospitalized or what his condition was. The official Xinhua News Agency characterized Yang's illness as ``acute appendicitis.'' Premier Li Peng, in a meeting today with Chad's president, Hadj Hissein Habre, described the operation as ``minor'' and said Yang was ``very well and recovering,'' Xinhua reported. Li said the operation was a success and that he had visited Yang in the hospital on Tuesday. The post of presidency in China is largely ceremonial. Yang, however, is also a member of the party's policy-making Politburo and is vice chairman of the powerful Central Military Commission. Questions about Yang's health were raised after he failed to appear Tuesday to accept a medal given him by the Peruvian government. A welcoming ceremony for President Hissene Habre of Chad scheduled for Tuesday afternoon that Yang was to have presided over was postponed. Vice President Wang Zhen attended the welcoming ceremony in Yang's place today. Yang, a retired People's Liberation Army general, swept into prominence last year when he and Premier Li Peng ordered the imposition of martial law in Beijing to end pro-democracy demonstrations. He is widely regarded as representing the hard-line stance toward the student-led demonstrations that led to the June 1989 bloody military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. Since then, he has elevated supporters such as his brother Yang Baibing into key posts in the military and the government, and has been regarded by China watchers as putting himself in line to succeed 85-year-old Deng Xiaoping as China's senior leader. Deng and Yang are longtime allies, and Yang has supported Deng's economic reforms but is thought to be more politically conservative.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Leaves Capital for Visit to Atlanta
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs Mandela departure; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``We need...
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela departed the capital today assured of some political support and buoyed by a tumultuous rally where he was serenaded, praised and nearly worshipped by more than 19,000 Washingtonians. Mandela left for Atlanta at midmorning, concluding a three-day visit during which he won assurances from President Bush and members of Congress of continuing U.S. economic sanctions against South Africa's white government. The African National Congress leader, accompanied by his wife, Winnie, shook hands with the police officers and posed for photos before boarding a charter flight for the next leg of his U.S. visit. Mandela made no statement, but on Tuesday night he told a cheering crowd, ``We thank you, America. We thank you for being true to your responsibility ... We thank you for responding to our cause.'' The 71-year-old Mandela also called Tuesday for financial assistance to his country once the apartheid system of racial segregation is abolished. ``We need to mobilize the country for peace,'' Mandela told supporters. ``We need to train personnel for economic recovery. ... For all this we shall continue to rely on your firm support.'' The rally in the city's convention center was jammed with spectators, some of whom paid $1,000 to attend a reception before the event. When Mandela entered the stage filled with people including Jesse Jackson and embattled Mayor Marion Barry and his wife, Effi, the crowd jumped from their seats, screaming and cheering. Mandela briefly joined a group of South African dancers, and smiled and waved to the crowd. ``Sisters and brothers, as we enter the third leg of our visit to the United States, our delegation, my wife and I feel more assured of our overwhelming support,'' he said. ``Apartheid must go, and it must go now. The masses of the American people are with us. Both Congress (the House) and the Senate of the United States are with us. President Bush and the administration are with us. Surely apartheid will go,'' he said. Bush, in meeting with Mandela on Monday, assured him that he is not about to lift U.S. economic sanctions. But the president and many in Congress made it clear they were not happy with Mandela's continuing refusal to renounce violence in the struggle against apartheid. Some in Congress also criticized his support for radical leaders such as Libya's Moammar Gadhafi and Cuba's Fidel Castro. Jackson, in introducing Mandela at the rally, apologized for U.S. complicity in his arrest by the South African government 27 years ago. ``Our CIA was a factor in your arrest,'' Jackson said. ``We are ashamed of that,'' he added, as the crowd again erupted into applause and cheers. Earlier Tuesday, in an address to a joint meeting of Congress, Mandela made an impassioned plea for justice, comparing the struggle of South African blacks to that of America's founding fathers. ``Our people demand democracy. Our country, which continues to bleed and suffocate, needs democracy,'' he said. The one-time prisoner was accorded the kind of reception from Congress normally reserved for U.S. presidents. His entrance was greeted with a 2{-minute ovation and there was even longer applause from the packed House chamber when he finished. In an interview published in today's editions of The Washington Post, Mandela said the ANC would agree to the lifting of U.S. economic sanctions once ``mutual confidence'' is achieved between the Pretoria government and the anti-apartheid movement. ``And it may not be necessary for us actually to agree upon a constitution before we can feel that fundamental and irreversible change has taken place,'' he said. ``It's a question that must depend on the progress that we're making, and on how we address the problems that arise, and how mutual confidence is built in the course of our negotiations.''

DOC.HEAD: Criminal Violations Alleged in Blast that Killed Three
DOC.TEXT: Charges of reckless homicide and criminal violations of federal safety law have been filed in a 1988 tunnel explosion that killed three workers. U.S. Attorney John E. Fryatt said the S.A. Healy Co. of McCook, Ill., and project manager Patrick Doig were named in a 12-count indictment charging them with violations of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. In addition to the federal grand jury indictment, Milwaukee County District Attorney E. Michael McCann announced that state charges of reckless homicide were filed against S.A. Healy in two of the deaths. The three men died in a methane explosion Nov. 10, 1988, in a tunnel that is part of a Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage Commission's $2 billion improvement project. Fryatt said the charges involved failures in providing and maintaining a sufficient ventilation system and proper electrical equipment, in safety instruction of employees, and in de-energizing electrical power in the area where high levels of methane gas were detected. Killed in the explosion were Ronald Kohne, 49, of Big Sandy, Tenn., the superintendent; Rick Sochacki, 34, South Holland, Ill., a safety officer; and Tony Bell, 25, of Sturgeon Bay, a shift foreman. McCann, who headed a coroner's inquest into the deaths in December, said the reckless homicide charges were filed in the deaths of Sochacki and Bell. He said each charge carries a maximum $10,000 fine. Inquest testimony indicated that the day the blast occurred, the tunnel had been cleared of workers because of high methane levels, and the victims were returning to check the tunnel when the gas exploded. Attorney David Cannon, representing S.A. Healy, said the company and Doig expect to be vindicated. ``The company doesn't believe that any of its employees committed any reckless acts in the tragedy and as a result expects to vigorously contest all the charges,'' Cannon said. Each misdemeanor count in the federal indictment carries a maximum penalty of six months in jail and fine of $250,000 for an individual and $500,000 for a company. Fryatt said S.A. Healy could face total fines of $6 million and Doig could face three years in prison and fines totaling $1.5 million, if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Moves to Bar Legal Aid Lawyers From Eviction Cases
DOC.NOTE: EDs: RECASTS first 2 grafs; picks up 3rd graf, The resolution...
DOC.TEXT: Three days after legal aid lawyers won a court fight to restrict a Bush administration drug-fighting effort, a presidential panel sought to bar anti-poverty attorneys from taking such cases. Directors of the Legal Services Corp. asked Congress in a resolution approved Monday to enact legislation that would bar legal aid groups receiving federal money from representing suspected drug dealers in public-housing eviction cases. The resolution, approved by voice vote, also urged local legal aid organizations to discourage their attorneys from filing such cases. Last Friday, legal-aid lawyers in Richmond, Va., won a court order that restricted public-housing raids planned by the Department of Housing and Urban Development to evict suspected drug dealers by seizing their leases. The order generally barred eviction of public-housing tenants suspected of dealing drugs unless they were given prior notice and a hearing. Instead, federal marshals on Monday began serving notices informing tenants that their public-housing leases were seized and they would eventually be kicked out. The seizures are authorized by a forfeiture provision of the 1988 Anti-Drug Abuse Act. By late Tuesday, 25 public-housing leases had been seized in Washington, Chicago, Richmond, New York City, Macon, Ga.; New Haven, Conn.; and Columbus, Ohio, the Justice Department said. HUD said it planned to serve seizure notices in 19 cities this week. Legal Services Corp. spokesman David Eisner said the resolution was not adopted as a specific response to the case brought in Richmond by the Central Virginia Legal Aid Society. But Eisner said ``legal services attorneys like those lawyers in the Richmond case are standing in the way of the policy of getting drug dealers out of public housing.'' Board members have been concerned for some time that ``legal services attorneys take simple eviction proceedings and make them drag out for six months or a year,'' Eisner said. At Monday's board meeting, Henry McLaughlin, the executive director of the Central Virginia Legal Aid Society that obtained last week's court order, argued against adoption of the resolution. McLaughlin told board members that seeking due process for public-housing tenants facing eviction was a proper use of federal money. The Richmond organization received $562,652 from the Legal Services Corp., this fiscal year, Eisner said. The resolution had the support of HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, who announced plans for the anti-drug raids last month. ``Kemp's initiative to get the scourge of drugs out of public housing is one of the most important things that we can do,'' Eisner said. Carolyn Stewart, a spokeswoman for the National Legal Aid and Defenders Association, said the board would prohibit innocent relatives of suspected drug dealers the right to challenge their evictions. ``What this implies is guilt by association and trial by family,'' she said. ``If a family member is involved in any sort of drug activity, this action by the board would punish all members of that family by denying them representation under the law.'' Civil libertarians argue that eviction without prior notice and a hearing violates the Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Teams Rescue Seven People Buried in Iranian Quake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `Officials say...' to INSERT differing estimates on death toll. Pickup 5th, `The head...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK2,3
DOC.TEXT: French and Iranian relief teams rescued at least seven people, including a mother and her 12-year-old son, who were buried for five days in the rubble from the earthquake in Iran, the official media said today. In another development, field tribunals were being set up in Rudbar and Manjil to try ``criminals who are abusing the situation'' in the ravaged northwestern area, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. IRNA appeared to be referring either to looters or profiteers operating after Thursday's quake. The agency also said at least 50 aftershocks were recorded Tuesday night and today. More than 400 aftershocks have occurred since the quake struck. Officials say between 36,000 and 50,000 people were killed and 200,000 injured in the temblor, which measured 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale. About a half million people were left homeless. A Western Red Cross official said Tuesday that the death toll eventually could reach 70,000. The head of Iran's Red Crescent societies, Mohammed Parham, said 175 foreign planes carrying tons of aid had landed in Tehran since Sunday and that no additional foreign doctors or relief workers were needed, IRNA reported. The rescued mother and the 12-year-old boy were found critically injured Tuesday in the village of Kelishom, 100 miles northwest of Tehran, IRNA said. Two other people were rescued in village of Vieh, IRNA said. The agency also said a man, a woman and a boy, members of a family, were rescued in the village of Jirandeh the same day. ``Rescue workers had to remove massive piles of rubble and dig for four hours'' to save the family, it said. Bulldozers and cranes removed the dusty debris in many of the 342 cities and remote mountain villages affected by the quake, and relief teams brought tents and food supplies to the homeless. Survivors were being housed in more than 70,000 tents sent to the region, said Parham, whose organization is the Islamic version of the Red Cross. Parham praised the foreign relief effort and said about 500 foreign doctors and relief workers were in the quake-afflicted area. But he said relief operations were approaching the final stages and added there was no need to dispatch additional foreign doctors and relief workers to Iran, IRNA reported. Relief workers, meanwhile, are trying to prepare for the next threats _ a possible outbreak of disease and the fierce winter winds that roar through the stricken region. Pestilence is a danger as rains falling on bodies trapped in rubble wash bacteria into the water supply. Kingsley Seevaratnam of the Geneva-based League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, said Iranian authorities want to move people out of the stricken northwestern provinces quickly to avoid possible epidemics. Christian Brauner, a disaster specialist with the West German Red Cross, said he hoped to persuade West German authorities to send experts in repairing water and sewage systems to help Iran provide a clean water supply. In Manjil, about 135 miles northwest of Tehran, Brauner said tents now being given out for temporary housing will be inadequate when winter comes. ``They will be torn to ribbons,'' he said. In Parliament, hard-line deputies said Tuesday that the foreign aid _ much of it from countries Iran considers enemies _ will not buy closer relations with the West or nullify positions taken by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Those stands include the February 1989 death threat to British author Salman Rushdie for offending some Moslems with his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has pledged several thousand dollars to help survivors of the quake. One deputy, Ayatollah Saddegh Khalkhali, said quake aid from the United States, Iraq and Saudi Arabia was appreciated but Iran ``could not forget our martyrs.'' The high-ranking cleric added: ``We cannot forgive the killing of 300 people on the Airbus or the 400 at Mecca.'' He was referring to the U.S. downing in July 1989 of an Iranian jetliner that killed all 290 aboard. The Navy said the jetliner, shot down over the Persian Gulf, was mistaken for a warplane. More than 400 Moslem pilgrims, most of them Iranians, died when Saudi troops opened fire on a demonstration in Mecca in July 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Government Forces Rounding Tamils Up In South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with gov't saying 400,000 have fled the fighting. Pickup 2nd pvs, `Also today...'
DOC.TEXT: Government security forces detained hundreds of Tamil youths in Colombo today in sweeps for guerrillas believed to have infiltrated the capital. The government, meanwhile, said 400,000 people have fled the 2-week-old upsurge in Sri Lanka's civil war and that many were without food, water or shelter. ``We are starving,'' said one resident in the town of Batticaloa. ``There is no electricity and no transport. Only guns, guns and guns.'' Also today, military officials called on 2,500 Tamil Tiger rebels believed trapped in an eastern jungle to surrender or risk an intensive air attack. The Tigers are ``on the retreat on all fronts. ... They are a spent force now,'' said army commander General Hamilton Wanasinghe. On Monday and Tuesday, government air force planes bombed and strafed rebel positions surrounding a strategic 200-year-old fort in the northern city of Jaffna, the rebel stronghold. A rebel statement claimed ``hundreds'' of buildings had been set on fire by incendiaries and that civilians were killed in the raids. At least 1,626 combatants have died since the civil war flared up anew on June 11. Fighting started after a Tamil man claimed he was manhandled by Sinhalese police and Tamil Tiger guerrillas responded by attacking police stations in the east. Ethnic Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the island's 16 million people and control the army and the government. Tamils comprise 18 percent. Claiming discrimination by the Sinhalese, Tamil Tigers have since 1983 been waging war to carve out a separate Tamil homeland in the north and east. Military officials say they believe Tamil Tiger guerrillas are moving into the south and planning attacks against Sinhalese civilians as retribution for rebel losses in the north and east. In the past, rebel statements have said they kill Sinhalese civilians because government troops kill Tamil civilians. Police and troops today cordoned off Kochchikade town, about a half mile north of Colombo's city center, and went into homes, shops and businesses questioning young Tamils. Residents contacted by telephone said security forces prevented people from leaving or entering the town for more than six hours. A large number of young Tamils who were new to the area were taken away in police vehicles, residents said. Similar operations, according to military and police officials, were being conducted throughout the south, with hundreds of Tamil youths taken into custody. The worst rebel attack on civilians occurred on May 14, 1985 when a marauding gang of Tamil rebels launched a machine-gun and grenade attack on Sinhalese Buddhists worshiping at a shrine in Anuradhapura, an ancient capital, about 100 miles north of Colombo. In all, 157 people were kiled. Military officials say the fighting in the east has Tamil rebels on the run. On Tuesday, air force helicopters dropped thousands of leaflets over a dense jungle asking rebels to surrender. The leaflets were dropped near Kundikudicharu village in the eastern Batticaloa district, where military officials believe 2,500 rebels were trapped. Rebels were asked to leave their weapons behind and come out of the jungle. The leaflets said the rebels would not be harmed.

DOC.HEAD: Government Official Sees Japan's Opinion Reflected in Bush's Tax Statement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with talks at an impasse late today, U.S. official urging Japan for strong commitment to resolving trade imbalances. Pickup 7th pvs, `The U.S. ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan has long been pressing Washington to raise taxes to cut the U.S. federal deficit, and a senior Tokyo official today said that may have helped get President Bush to agree to the idea of tax increases. Misoji Sakamoto, chief Cabinet secretary, said Japanese officials strongly supported U.S. measures to cut the budget deficit in talks with U.S. negotiators in Tokyo this week. The Tokyo talks are aimed at reducing Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States by making structural changes in both nations' economies. The talks went into an extra day today but remained at an impasse, said a senior Bush administration official participating in the negotiations. The official, who requested anonymity, urged Tokyo to match Bush by making a stronger commitment to ending the trade imbalance between the two countries. Bush, in a written statement released Tuesday in Washington, did not say whether he was considering an actual tax increase or higher revenues from the current system. But his willingness to include the word ``tax'' was the strongest indication to date that he might be willing to accept tax increases as part of an effort to lower the deficit. An official from the prime minister's office quoted Sakamoto as saying Bush ``may have paid consideration'' to Japanese opinion on increasing U.S. taxes. The U.S. budget deficit is regarded as a spur to U.S. consumption that increases demand for Japanese imports and thus contributes to the trade imbalance. On Tuesday, Japanese officials at the talks asked U.S. negotiators why the United States dropped a target year of 1993 for eliminating the deficit, estimated at $200 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said later Tuesday they told the Japanese that Washington wants to look beyond eliminating the budget deficit by 1993 and to envision a budget surplus. In addition to working on lowering the budget deficit, the United States has agreed to improve worker training and education and to increase savings, steps designed to increase exports and lower imports. Among other issues, Japan has agreed to increase public works spending, ease restrictions on opening large retail stores, revise land-use policies to curb high land prices and crack down on unfair business practices. The measures are thought likely to increase foreign opportunities for trade and investment in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: First Freely Elected Parliament Holds Opening Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, ``The House...'' with 1 graf to ADD definition of Presidium. Pickup 4th, ``Alexander...''
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's first freely elected Parliament in 44 years convened its opening session today and prepared to elect new leaders. The legislature is dominated by President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum and its Slovak ally which led last year's peaceful revolution against the Communists. The House of Nations and the House of the People, the two chambers of Parliament, met to elect their respective chairmen and were then to convene in joint session to elect a new speaker and the Presidium of Parliament. The Presidium meets between legislative sessions to decide on technical matters. Alexander Dubcek, who was appointed to head the interim parliament in December after the Communists were ousted, was the only candidate for Parliament speaker, Civic Forum spokesman Petr Kucera said. Dubcek represents Public Against Violence, the Civic Forum's sister movement. His deputy was again to be Zdenek Jicinsky, a Civic Forum member, Kucera said. Dubcek, who led the 1968 Prague Spring reforms that were crushed by Soviet-led troops, regained prominence in the heady days of the peaceful revolution as a symbol of reform. Th interim government was to submit its formal resignation later today, but incumbent Premier Marian Calfa is to head the new cabinet. Havel planned to formally announce the new federal government late today on national television. Several ministers appointed to Calfa's interim ``government of national understanding'' in December were expected to retain their posts. The Civic Forum and Public Against Violence won elections two weeks ago, gaining 170 seats in the bicameral house. The Communists, who ruled unchallenged for four decades until the November revolution, won 47 seats. The third strongest group is the Christian Democratic Alliance, which won 40 seats in the June 8-9 elections, the first free balloting since 1946. The composition of the new federal government was forged at turbulent coalition talks which ended Friday after the Christian Democratic Movement reversed an earlier decision and decided to join Civic Forum in governing. The unofficial leader of the Christian Democratic Movement, Jan Carnogursky, was appointed deputy prime minister in the Slovak regional government today after rejecting any post on the federal government. The Slovak government is headed by Public Against Violence member Vladimir Meciar. The Czech regional government, to be put together by the Civic Forum's Petr Pithart, a former activist, was not expected to be announced before Friday. The Civic Forum and Public Against Violence could have formed a minority federal government but would have lacked the necessary three-fifths majority needed to push key constitutional changes through Parliament. Officials from both groups repeatedly said they sought the broadest possible coalition as Czechoslovakia embarks on a difficult transition to a market economy. They refused to include the Communists in the government.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Chafe At Shortages As Economic Merger Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 6th, `Some merchants...' to UPDATE with Siemens investing $600 million in East Germany. Pickup 7th pvs, `The East...'
DOC.TEXT: Sticking to the fast track toward unification, West Germany has drawn up a plan to complete its merger with the East in December. But East Germans are already feeling the pinch of economic union. Five days before the two countries create one economy, East Germans are being forced to search for food and other necessities. ``There's no soap here, no meat,'' said Ines Kroll, a 25-year-old mother of two as she pushed her shopping cart past depleted shelves in the only store in Blankenburg, a small town north of Berlin. Merchants are shutting stores and clearing shelves to make room for the expected deluge of Western goods. Groceries have been canceling their orders with East German suppliers and letting their stocks run out. Experts say many East German companies are keeping their products off the market until next week, when they can sell them for West German marks. Some merchants say they also want to avoid taking in large amounts of East German marks in the days before the nearly worthless currency is replaced by the valuable West German mark. In Munich, a huge West German electronics and household appliance company, Siemens, today announced it will invest $600 million in East Germany and hire up to 30,000 people in the next several years. The announcement represents the biggest single investment program since East Germany shed its Communist government and began moving to a free market. The East German government on Tuesday announced temporary import tariffs to protect industries threatened by the switch to capitalism after 40 years of socialist central planning. Amid criticism that the rapid merger was hurting many East Germans, West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said that quick unification was important because of the unstable situation in the Soviet Union: ``We need to go through the door to unification because it can close shut again,'' he told reporters. Germans fear instability in Eastern Europe if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev should be removed from power in the squeeze between hard-liners upset with his reforms and progressives who think he is moving too slowly. About 380,000 Soviet troops are still on East German soil and Moscow has balked at withdrawing them over objections to NATO's desire that a united Germany be party of the Western military alliance. Suggestions for what a political treaty unifying East and West would look like were released Tuesday by the West German Interior Ministry in the form of a ``discussion paper.'' Under the proposals, East Germany would officially join West Germany the day after elections for a joint German parliament. West and East German politicians have proposed Dec. 9 or Dec. 16 as possible dates for the balloting. West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said in Bonn, West Germany on Tuesday that he expected the East German Cabinet to decide today to begin negotiations on the political treaty. He said a pact should be ready for debate in both parliaments by early September. Last week, the parliaments of both states ratified the treaty outlining the monetary, economic and social union that is to take effect on Sunday. On that day, the West German mark officially replaces the East German mark and 40 years of rigid, socialist economic policy give way to free-market rules. Lines of up to 1,000 people have been snaking down sidewalks in East Berlin as people converge on banks to fill out paperwork necessary for converting savings accounts to West German marks. Depending on age, accounts up to 6,000 marks ($3,600) can be converted at the most favorable rate of one West German mark for each East German mark. In an attempt to protect its ailing industries from the first rush of Western competition, East Germany on Tuesday announced a series of tariffs on Western goods beginning Sunday. An 11 percent tariff is to be imposed through the end of the year, replaced the following quarter by a 6 percent tariff. Food will not be affected, although East Germany's huge farm collectives are expected to be battered by Western agricultural producers. It was uncertain whether the tariffs would remain if the current quick pace of unification continues and the nations fully unify in December. Many stores are already stocking West German goods under agreements made in March that allowed a limited entry of some products into the country. But many staples still were in short supply. Mrs. Kroll said she could find no detergent and rejected the skimpy selection of meat. She also had mixed feelings about the end of the East German mark. ``My husband mints East German coins for a living,'' she said. Some experts say 1 million to 4 million workers will lose their jobs in the first two years of economic unification. Many of the heavy industries that were once the backbone of the former, centrally planned economy are expected to fail as they face leaner, more efficient Western concerns.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Appears Before Iran-Contra Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter appeared today before a federal grand jury that was recently empaneled to continue investigating the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter, who was sentenced June 11 to six months in prison for lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair and obstructing inquiries of congressional committees, testified behind closed doors at the U.S. Courthouse. A prosecutor from the office of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh accompanied Poindexter into the grand jury room. The grand jury, which has already heard testimony from former National Security Council aide Oliver L. North, is continuing to sift evidence about whether other Reagan administration officials participated in efforts to mislead Congress about the Iran-Contra affair, according to sources. The grand jury is expected to try to perform a final assessment of the degree of knowledge that President Reagan and then-Vice President George Bush had of the covert military assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels that was orchestrated by Poindexter and North. North, a retired Marine lieutenant colonel who was ordered to perform 1500 hours of community service, has testified on three occasions since the grand jury was empaneled last month. North worked closely with former State Department official Elliott Abrams and former CIA officer Alan Fiers in connection with the Contras. North also had frequent contact with Donald Gregg, then Bush's aide on national security. matters. Gregg, a former CIA station chief, is now the U.S. ambassador to South Korea. The grand jury is trying to determine whether these officials participated in efforts to cover up the Iran-Contra affair from Congress, according to the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Poindexter's convictions are in connection with the coverup of North's secret Contra resupply network and the concealment of the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Reagan approved letters that Poindexter sent to Congress denying that North was assisting the Contras militarily, Poindexter's lawyers said before his trial. In a videotaped deposition, however, Reagan said he didn't recall the letters. Poindexter didn't testify at his trial, so was unavailable for questioning about his daily meetings with Reagan. Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral who is free pending appeal of his case, was convicted of hiding North's role from Congress and of concealing the fact that Reagan administration officials knew that a CIA-assisted shipment from Israel to Iran contained Hawk missiles. Reagan testified that he didn't recall when he learned of the Hawks shipment.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Miami Welcome Gets Chillier; Splits Ethnic Groups
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's scheduled arrival in Miami tonight has driven another wedge between blacks and Cuban-Americans in this racially divided city. The South African anti-apartheid leader has been greeted as a hero in New York, Boston, and Washington, D.C. But South Florida politicians have refused to honor him, and area Cuban-Americans are calling for mass protests during his address Thursdayvention in Miami Beach. Black leaders, in turn, are calling for counterdemonstrations and have condemned t at a labor conhe politicians for ignoring the message of hope Mandela could bring to U.S. blacks. ``To reject Mandela is to reject us and that is very deep. It's psychologically devastating,'' said Johnnie McMillian, head of the Miami-Dade chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Mandela's visit was welcomed until last week, when he defended Cuban leader Fidel Castro, Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat, and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi for their help in the early years of the African National Congress' struggle against South Africa's racial separation laws. The heavily Cuban city of Miami immediately withdrew a planned proclamation in Mandela's honor. Miami Ms of rioting. In Los Angeles, county supervisors also clashed over Mandela's support for Castro, Arafat and Gadhafi, but they still declared Friday to be Nelson Mandela Day. Supervisor Mike Antonovich argued against honoring Mandela, who is scheduled to arrive in Los Angeles on Friday on the last leg of his U.S. speaking tour. He called for Mandela to renounce his support for Arafat, Gadhafi and Fidel Castro. ``Because Arafat and Gadhafi have been responsible for so much bloodshed in the Middle East and all three have contributed to terrorism, I think we should ask that Mandela repudiate his support for them,'' Antonovich said Tuesday. But Supervisor Kenneth Hahn said Mandela had made it clear he supported Arafat, Castro and Gadhafi because of their opposition to the South African government's policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Murphy to USIA Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he will nominate George F. Murphy Jr. to be inspector general of the United States Information Agency. Since 1988, Murphy has been deputy director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Anthony J. Gabriel.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Defeat Proposal on Equality in School Funding
DOC.TEXT: The courts could be the next stop for the issue of equality in funding for Oklahoma schools, now that voters have defeated a share-the-wealth referendum at a special election. Voters split sharply by region as they defeated the proposal Tuesday. The plan was clobbered in Oklahoma City, the largest municipality, and in most rural areas, especially in western Oklahoma, where oil reserves and utility plants are concentrated. But it won by a hefty margin in Tulsa, in northeastern Oklahoma, the state's second largest city. Andrew Tevington, Gov. Henry Bellmon's chief of staff, said he understood one group was planning a federal lawsuit challenging the disparity in district funding, which ranges from $10,600 to $2,300 in per pupil spending. ``Unfortunately we'll probably end up in federal court and the federal courts will write our funding laws instead of the people of Oklahoma,'' Tevington said. Similiar lawsuits have been successful in such states as Kentucky and Texas. Bellmon blamed voter confusion for the defeat of the proposal and three less controversial issues. The proposals had the support of Bellmon, a Republican, and leaders of the Democratic majority in the Legislature. The other three questions would have changed how state school land money is handled, removed antiquated language from the state Constitution on school attendance and changed the membership of the state school board. The share-the-wealth plan would have redistributed on a statewide basis oil and property tax revenue that now goes to local schools. It would have put into a single pot property taxes collected on utility, railroad and airline property valued at more than $500,000, locally assessed real and personal commercial-industrial property valued in excess of $500,000, gross production revenue on oil, the rural electric cooperative corporation tax and motor vehicle registration taxes and fees now apportioned to schools.

DOC.HEAD: U. of Colorado President Named To Head Ohio State
DOC.TEXT: E. Gordon Gee, president of the University of Colorado, has been elected by Ohio State University's trustees to become the university's 11th president on Sept. 1. Gee, 46, will succeed Edward Jennings, who announced in December he was stepping down to a faculty position. Gee, who will be paid $150,000 a year, said after his selection Tuesday that his top priorities will include fund-raising and seeking federal aid for students. Gee, a native of Vernal, Utah, has a law degree and a doctorate in education, both from Columbia University in New York.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Armored Car Robbery, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0449,0612
DOC.HEAD: FBI, Sheriff Look for Clues in $10.8 Armored-Car Heist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with lie detector tests being given, CORRECT attribution of 7th graf to police, sted company spokesman; MOVES first reference to Clark down to 9th graf. Picks up 10th graf, `To prevent ...'
DOC.TEXT: Investigators questioned two armored-car guards and gave them lie-detector tests after gunmen knocked off their truck for $10.8 million, the biggest such heist in U.S. history, officials said. The armored car was robbed by at least two men with a shotgun Tuesday after its crew stopped at a convenience store for a coffee break, investigators said. The guards were forced to drive to a wooded area a half-mile away, where they were tied up, blindfolded and gagged, officials said. The robbers put the cash, in bags weighing at least 1,500 pounds, into another vehicle and drove off. Neither guard was injured. No suspects have been identified, said sheriff's Capt. Neil Flood. ``There are a lot of questions, obviously, about the manner of the heist,'' Sheriff Andrew P. Meloni said. ``It appeared to be well-planned.'' The sheriff would not say whether the robbery of the Armored Motor Service of America truck could have been an inside job. The two guards, who worked for the company a total of 18 months, were questioned all day and into the evening by FBI and sheriff's officials, said Flood. The guards, whose names were not released, are ``not really'' suspects, the sheriff said. ``They obviously need to be talked to,'' he said. AMSA controller George Clark said the guards agree to submit to lie-detector tests as a condition of employment. To prevent inside jobs, work crews are rotated, Clark said. It was unclear how long Tuesday's crew had worked together. The truck had left the company's offices in the Rochester suburb of Chili for the Federal Reserve Bank branch in Buffalo. During the stop at a store, a gunman shoved the barrel of a shotgun into an opening in the truck's cab and seized the vehicle from the driver, officials said. The other guard was taken hostage when she returned from the store. The guards freed themselves within 15 minutes of the robbery, drove to AMSA and reported the hold-up, Meloni said. Guards carry .38-caliber revolvers. Clark said the coffee-and-sandwiches stop was not against company rules. ``But it is strongly discouraged from a security standpoint,'' he said. ``It's hard to knock off a moving truck.'' Officials are reviewing the company's records and looking for witnesses who might have seen the armored car, Meloni said. The robbery is at least the second-largest theft in U.S. history and the largest involving an armored car. In 1982, about $11 million was reported taken from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Co. office in New York City. But authorities said much of the money may have been previously embezzled. In 1985, $7.9 million was stolen from a Wells Fargo depot in New York by masked gunmen. In 1983, robbers took gold estimated to be worth up to $11 million from a smelting company and jewelry wholesaler in North Miami, Fla. The robbery Tuesday was the second multimillion-dollar robbery of an AMSA truck in 13 months. In 1989, two men drove a one-ton armored truck through a garage door in East Syracuse, pistol-whipped two guards and stole $2.9 million. Two suspects are on trial in federal court in Syracuse. One of the guards pleaded guilty last year to taking part in the robbery.

DOC.HEAD: Court Limits Power of Environmentalists to Use Federal Courts
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today limited the power of environmentalists to use the federal courts to prevent opening of federal lands to commercial development. By a 5-4 vote, the justices overturned a pro-environmentalist ruling that had been challenged by the Bush administration. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, said the National Wildlife Federation failed to provide enough _ or the right kind of _ evidence to justify its suit against the Interior Department. The federation challenged the department's plans to change the status of some 180 million acres of public land in the West and Alaska, more than a fourth of all public lands in the nation. The federation said it was suing to ``protect federal lands against unwise or premature disposition and development,'' including millions of acres to be opened up to mining and mineral leasing. The decision to reclassify the land for development and other uses was made by the Reagan administration in 1985, following a policy instituted by then-Secretary James G. Watt in 1981. The wildlife federation said the Reagan administration violated federal law by opening the land to development without following procedures in the 1976 Federal Land Policy and Management Act (FLPMA). The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here said the federation and its 4.5 million members have legal standing to sue based on affidavits by members that they use some of the land for recreation. For example, federation member Peggy K. Peterson said she uses land in the South Pass-Green Mountain area of Wyoming. Scalia today agreed with the Bush administration that the federation may not base a wholesale challenge to the Interior Department's reclassification on allegations such a change will adversely affect a few people. Challenges must be mounted case by case, Scalia said, unless Congress changes the law to permit a broader attack or federal officials bow to such broader demands by environmentalists. ``The case-by-case approach ... is understandably frustrating to an organization ... which has as its objective across-the-board protection of our nation's wildlife and the streams and forests that support it,'' he said. But, Scalia said, it is not up to the courts to come up with far-reaching solutions when not authorized by law. ``Until confided to us, more sweeping actions are for the other branches'' of government, he said. He was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy. Dissenting were Justices Harry A. Blackmun, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens. Blackmun, in an opinion for all four, said the wildlife federation presented enough evidence in affidavits by two members to warrant a full trial of its suit. He said today's ruling characterized the federal land management program as ``1250 or so individual classification'' decisions. But, Blackmun said, ``The majority offers no argument in support of this conclusory assertion and I am far from certain that the characterization is an accurate one.'' The case is Lujan vs. National Wildlife Federation, 89-640.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Newspaper over Rape Story
DOC.TEXT: A rape victim is suing the Fort Worth Star-Telegram for publishing an account of the attack that she says contained identifying details even though it did not give her name. The woman says the story violated her right to privacy as a victim of sexual assault. She is seeking at least $8,000 in damages for alleged emotional and physical distress. The Star-Telegram did not publish the woman's name or address in reports about the Sept. 24 rape. The lawsuit contends the story included information about the rape and about her, including her age, occupation and the make of her car, that made her identity ``readily apparent'' to people in her community. As a result of the story, the woman has suffered ``extreme and severe embarrassment, humiliation and acute depression,'' the lawsuit alleges. The lawsuit seeks $3,000 in damages to pay for psychological treatment and $5,000 in past and future lost wages. The U.S. Supreme Court last year gave the news media added protection in reporting such crimes. The court ruled that the weekly Florida Star did not have to pay damages to a rape victim whose name it published. The ruling limited states' power to punish the reporting of truthful information that is lawfully obtained. Florida law makes it a crime to publish the names of victims of sexual assault. The Florida Star said the rape victim's name was published inadvertently after it was released by a sheriff's department. Texas law does not prohibit publishing rape victims' names, nor does it prohibit law enforcement agencies from releasing the names, said Star-Telegram Associate Executive Editor Phil Record. ``We were just surprised at this kind of suit because we don't see that it has a great deal of merit in it,'' Record said Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Child Abusers Not Always Due Face-to-Face Confrontation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material throughout to add other cases.
DOC.TEXT: People charged with child abuse are not always entitled to a face-to-face confrontation with their young accusers, the Supreme Court ruled today. In a decision expected to make it easier to prosecute suspected child abusers, the court said the Constitution allows for exceptions to such potentially traumatic confrontations. The decisions were announced as the court ended its 1989-90 term, which included major rulings on abortion, the right to die, flag burning, political patronage, police efforts to stop drunken drivers, and prayer groups in public schools. In a major victory for affirmative action, the court today upheld federal policies that favor minorities in awarding broadcast licenses. By a 5-4 vote, the justices said the Federal Communications Commission policies do not discriminate unlawfully. The child-abuse decision will let states use some techniques to protect minors _ particularly those called to testify against their accused abusers _ from a face-to-face courtroom confrontation. More than half the states have enacted such measures already. By a 5-4 vote, the justices upheld the child-molesting conviction of a Maryland day-care center owner even though four young children were allowed to testify out of her presence. The children testified over one-way, closed-circuit television. But by a separate 5-4 vote, the court refused to reinstate an Idaho woman's child-abuse conviction thrown out by the state's highest court because the child did not testify. Rather, a pediatrician testified at the trial about his interview with the 2-year-old alleged victim. Writing for the court in the Maryland case, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said, ``Where necessary to protect a child witness from trauma that would be caused by testifying in the physical presence of the defendant, at least where such trauma would impair the child's ability to communicate, the (Constitution's) confrontation clause does not prohibit use of a procedure'' other than a face-to-face confrontation. She was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices Antonin Scalia, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens dissented. Writing for the dissenters, Scalia said, ``Seldom has this court failed so conspicuously to sustain a categorical guarantee of the Constitution against the tide of prevailing current opinion.'' The Constitution's Sixth Amendment, in part, says, ``In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right ... to be confronted with the witnesses against him.'' ``Though we reaffirm the importance of face-to-face confrontation with witnesses appearing at trial, we cannot say that such confrontation is an indispensable element of the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of the right to confront one's accusers,'' the majority said. States in recent years increasingly have sought to protect young witnesses, particularly those testifying in child-abuse cases. The number of such cases is growing. More than 2.2 million child-abuse reports were filed in 1988, according to the National Committee for the Prevention of Child Abuse. Testimony by children on closed-circuit TV, on videotape, through one-way mirrors or behind screens has been allowed in some criminal cases. Today's decision in the Maryland case allows those techniques, as long as they ensure ``the reliability of the evidence by subjecting it to rigorous adversarial testing.'' In other action today, the court: _ Limited the power of environmentalists to use the federal courts to prevent opening of federal lands to commercial development. By a 5-4 vote, the justices overturned a pro-environmentalist ruling that had been challenged by the Bush administration. _ Upheld Arizona's death penalty law in a decision that also removes a constitutional shadow from similar laws in Idaho and Montana. The justices, by a 5-4 vote, ruled that the Arizona law is valid even though judges, not juries, decide whether a murder was a crime for which death can be the punishment. _ Ruled that most of the nation's post offices may ban all soliciting on their property. The justices, by a 5-4 vote, said a regulation imposing such a blanket ban does not violate free-speech rights. In a significant ruling on the protections offered by the Constitution's First Amendment, the court reinstated the convictions of two political activists who solicited contributions and distributed literature from the sidewalk outside a post office in Bowie, Md. The justices in 1988 struck down an Iowa man's sexual-assault conviction because two 13-year-old girls were allowed to testify while shielded from his view by a large screen placed in the courtroom between them and the defendant. They cited a Sixth Amendment violation. But the 1988 ruling appeared to leave unanswered whether there may be exceptions to the face-to-face requirement. The Maryland Court of Appeals threw out Sandra Craig's conviction, saying her 7-year-old accuser and three other young witnesses wrongly were allowed, to testify over closed-circuit TV. They testified from a room outside the courtroom with only a prosecutor and one of Mrs. Craig's lawyers present. Mrs. Craig and her other lawyer remained in the courtroom, where they could watch the testimony and talk privately by telephone to the other lawyer. The state court ruled that Mrs. Craig was entitled to a new trial on charges she sexually molested a girl who attended her Clarksville, Md., day-care center. She had been sentenced to 10 years in prison for her 1987 conviction on those charges. Today, the nation's highest court said the Maryland court was wrong. Mrs. Craig also faces charges stemming from the alleged molestation of 12 other children who attended the day-care center. In the Idaho case, Laura Lee Wright of Boise was convicted of lewd conduct committed on her daughters, who were then 5 and 2. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison before the state Supreme Court threw out her conviction. The state court said the trial judge wrongly allowed a pediatrician who had examined the younger girl to testify about what she told him. The girl did not testify, and therefore could not be cross-examined by Mrs. Wright's lawyer. The state court said the pediatrician's testimony lacked ``particularized guarantees of trustworthiness'' because it was not tape-recorded, because he asked leading questions and had a preconceived idea of what facts the child should be disclosing. O'Connor, joined by the four dissenters in the Maryland case, upheld the state court ruling while not agreeing with how that ruling was reached. ``Given the presumption of inadmissibility accorded accusatory hearsay statements ... we agree with the court below that the state has failed to show that the younger daughter's incriminating statements to the pediatrician possessed sufficient particularized guarantees of trustworthiness under the confrontation clause to overcome that presumption,'' O'Connor said. The cases are Maryland vs. Craig, 89-478, and Idaho vs. Wright, 89-260.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Traveling to Cradle of Non-Violent Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Mandela's arrival in Atlanta, details. DELETES outdated grafs, EDITS to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, who refuses to renounce violence for the cause of racial equality, arrived in the birthplace of America's apostle of non-violence today to lay a wreath at the grave of Martin Luther King Jr. Mandela emerged smiling and waving from his chartered jet at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. He was greeted by a marching band and about 200 invited guests, including Gov. Joe Frank Harris, Mayor Maynard Jackson and Coretta Scott King, widow of the slain civil rights leader. About 100 people lined an access road nearby, hoping for a glimpse of Mandela, who came from Washington. Security was heavy. Mandela quickly reminded Atlanta's civil rights leaders, some of whom have gently criticized him for not renouncing violence, that he sees South Africa's black movement as different from the U.S. civil rights struggle. ``Unlike you, we are still under the grip of white supremacy,'' he said in a brief address at the airport. Mandela then spoke briefly to reporters, saying, ``Non-violence is a good policy when conditions permit.'' Mandela was scheduled to lay a wreath at King's tomb and then to address an audience of civil rights activists at Big Bethel AME Church. A later address at Morehouse College was canceled, but Mandela still planned to address a sold-out rally at Grant Field. Mandela's schedule has been trimmed down to give the 71-year-old leader more rest. He has been touring the United States since June 20. The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the King-founded Southern Christian Leadership Conference, hoped Mandela's visit would inspire black Americans to ``see that we can overcome.'' ``We think we have problems. He's overcome and I hope he lights our fire,'' Lowery said. In turn, some civil rights figures hoped a first-hand look at racial progress in the South would lead Mandela to try to avoid violence in his homeland. Others, including King's widow said more attention is paid to Mandela's stance on violence than to the South African government's violence toward blacks. As chairman of the Mandela visit host committee, Mrs. King said she hoped to show the African National Congress leader Atlanta's ``impressive spirit of interracial cooperation.'' Civil rights leaders who worked with King during the 1960s acknowledged that King's staunch policy of non-violence conflicts with Mandela's stand, but they are sympathetic to the black nationalist leader. In general, they say it is more important to free South African blacks than to insist on doing it their way. Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga., a civil rights veteran who has been jailed 40 times, said: ``Without violence, we were able to turn the South into a New South. Maybe being there will give him the will to try, as much as possible, to avert violence.'' ``If our experiences in desegregation can be helpful, we will offer them, Lowery said. ``There are some differences in every revolution, but I have to advocate non-violence. I've seen the results,'' said the Rev. Hosea Williams, King's field lieutenant during the 1960s. ``I would tell Mr. Mandela to please study and evaluate the teachings of Martin Luther King Jr. before deciding that violence is the only way to bring about needed social change.''

DOC.HEAD: East and West Overcome Major Hurdle Toward Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators at East-West talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe agreed today to limit the number of tanks and armored combat vehicles each alliance may have, diplomats said. Agreement on the two weapons categories will speed negotiations for an initial agreement at the talks by the end of this year, they said. ``This is a very major step,'' a Western diplomat told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. ``This is the heart of the treaty. Along with artillery, these are the chief components of ground offensive forces. Limiting this is one of the major steps in which these negotiations will increase stability in Europe. It is certainly one of the key elements.'' The breakthrough proposal on tanks and armored combat vehicles came from the French and the Poles. The French-Polish proposal, which was adopted by the delegates, establishes an overall ceiling for armored combat vehicles of 30,000 on each side and a ceiling of 20,000 tanks for each side. It also sets a minimum weight limit of 16.5 tons for tanks regardless of whether they have tracks or wheels. One of the more contentious issues at the talks has been finding common definitions for tanks and other armaments. The agreement also no longer makes a distinction between armored troop carriers and other armored vehicles, thus removing a further obstacle. NATO and Warsaw Pact delegates referred to the proposal as a ``package'' noting the link between definitions and limits on numbers and weights. They said the future treaty text will include a long list of the arms they would carry, thus classifying all the weapons the two sides currently have.
