Polish chief delegate Wlodzimierz Konarski told reporters earlier this month that this would be unprecedented in East-West relations and that these lists would become the basis for the reductions. According to U.S. estimates, the West has 23,600 tanks against Warsaw Pact's estimated 52,500. NATO has about 34,025 armored combat vehicles and the Warsaw Pact 59,400, according to U.S. estimates last year. The talks on Conventional Forces in Europe are designed to reduce troops and non-nuclear weapons of the two alliances from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural mountains. The 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact countries are participating. Both sides hope to have an agreement ready for signing by December, when leaders from 35 nations, including the 23 involved in the talks, meet in Paris. The other 12 participants are neutral and non-aligned countries in Europe that would also be affected by reducing tensions on the continent. Eastern and Western diplomats said there were still many outstanding issues to be resolved before a final agreement can be signed. They said the issues of ceilings and definitions of aircraft and helicopters as well as terms for verification still remained to be settled. The superpowers have agreed to a ceiling of 195,000 troops each in Central Europe, with the United States permitted to maintain up to 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe. NATO has proposed a maximum of 4,700 combat aircraft for each side, with an additional 500 air defense interceptors, but the East wants a higher ceiling.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Delegation Traveling to Moscow, More Meetings Likely
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of Lithuanian leaders, including the Baltic republic's president and prime minister, left for Moscow today for likely meetings with top Soviet officials, a spokesman said. The parliament of the break-away republic is scheduled on Thursday to begin debating a possible suspension of its March 11 declaration of independence that has put it at loggerheads with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Darius Suziedelis of the Lithuanian parliament's Information Bureau, said in a telephone interview that President Vytautas Landsbergis and Prime Minister Kazimere Prunskiene were leading a six-member delegation to the Soviet capital. The delegation also included Deputy Prime Minister Romualdas Ozolas and legislative leader Egidius Bickauskas. Suziedelis said little was known about their agenda in Moscow. But it was unlikely that the group would travel to the Soviet capital without an understanding that a meeting would be held with top Soviet officials. Landsbergis met with Gorbachev on Tuesday morning, and then returned to Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. He told the Supreme Council parliament upon his return that he received a better understanding of what kind of a compromise might be acceptable to Gorbachev, and that he might return for more talks with the Soviet leader. Mrs. Prunskiene, asking parliament on Tuesday to freeze the declaration of independence, told the republic's lawmakers that early independence is impossible without a compromise with the Kremlin. She said Gorbachev agreed in a telephone call Tuesday after meeting with Landsbergis that he would end a crippling economic embargo and begin negotiations that ``will discuss a different status for Lithuania, including as an independent state.'' But the only official statement from Moscow was much more toughly worded. The Soviet news agency Tass, quoting what it said was an official report on the meeting with Landsbergis, said the Lithuanian president was told talks can only be held ``if Lithuania declares a moratorium and suspends the act of March 11 for a period of talks. They can be held only in the context of an inter-republican dialogue on the preparation of a new union treaty and the formation of a union of sovereign socialists states.''

DOC.HEAD: Khashoggi's Lawyer Asks in Final Argument: `Where is the Proof?'
DOC.TEXT: Adnan Khashoggi's lawyer said today the government's case against his client was built on contrived allegations against the Saudi financier. The lawyer, James Linn, said no evidence exists that Khashoggi ever plotted with former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos and Imelda Marcos to circumvent a U.S. court injunction freezing their assets in 1986. ``Where is the proof? Where is the evidence of them forming a criminal agreement?'' Linn demanded in a closing statement before the jury in U.S. District Court. The case is expected to go to the jury on Thursday following a government rebuttal. Prosecutors, possibly with political ambitions, envisioned a ``case of the century'' when they first brought the indictment in 1988 against former President Marcos, Mrs. Marcos, Khashoggi and several others, Linn said. After Marcos died last September, he said, ``you got a widow, you got a Saudi businessman. It takes a lot out of the case.'' But, he said, the government chose to proceed with the thought: ``Let's see if we can convict this man because of his yachts and airplanes, or Mrs. Marcos because of her shoes and her shopping.'' He asked jurors to consider whether Khashoggi, famous for his business acumen, would agree to illegally take over ownership of four New York buildings secretly owned by the Marcoses _ ``multimillion-dollar buildings that were losing a million dollars a month.'' A day earlier, Mrs. Marcos' attorney urged jurors to acquit the former Philippine first lady of all charges against her, saying that even one verdict of guilty would be ``a stink and a smear on her as though it were fifty.'' In a dramatic four-hour summation that brought Mrs. Marcos to tears at the end, lawyer Gerry Spence ridiculed the government's fraud and racketeering case as a ``fantasy'' spun by questionable witnesses and unsupported by convincing evidence. ``The only thing that matters is the facts, and the facts in this case demand that you free Mrs. Marcos, that she not stand here and undergo this torture for another day,'' said Spence. ``She committed no crime except of loving a man for 35 years, raising his children, taking his lavish gifts and being his ardent supporter.'' Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband embezzle $222 million from their country's treasury to buy four New York buildings, jewelry and art works. She faces up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines if convicted of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Khashoggi, 54, is charged with mail fraud and obstructing justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the properties after a U.S. court order froze their assets. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Wearing her customary black dress of mourning for her husband, who died last September, Mrs. Marcos sat with downcast eyes through most of Spence's oration, occasionally smiling or fighting back tears. At the end, she tearfully embraced the silver-haired lawyer and kissed him on both cheeks.

DOC.HEAD: Slithering Visitors Force Family to Flee Home
DOC.TEXT: Mokbul Kazi thought it wasn't much of a deal when he tried to kill a snake with a spear. The Bangladeshi farmer was used to snakes slithering into his home, especially when the summer monsoons flushed them out of their holes. This one was different. It was wounded by Kazi's attack, but clung tenaciously to the mud and straw ceiling of his hut, the Khabar newspaper reported Wednesday. That night, about fifty snakes invaded Kazi's hut, hissing disapprovingly. Kazi and his family fled. The snakes stayed for a week. They left Saturday, when their wounded comrade died, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiploads of Sheep Pour Into Saudi Arabia for Moslem Ritual
DOC.TEXT: Shiploads of sheep from New Zealand are arriving at Saudi Arabia's ports in preparation for the ritual animaor 45 percent of the total volume through 76 slaughter and ``further processing'' plants. The survey also found that the top eight companies accounted for about 60 percent of the volume in 105 plants, and that the largest 20 firms had 80 percent of the volume in 156 plants. Approximately 75 percent of the slaughter plants surveyed were in the top 10 broiler states, the report said.

Wind erosion eased its grip on the Great Plains this season because of improved moisture conditions in much of the region, according to a final survey by the Agriculture Department. Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said Tuesday that an estimated 7.8 million acres were damaged by wind in the 10 states that make up the Great Plains, down 45 percent from 14.3 million acres in 1988-89. The agency measures wind damage during a seven-month season that runs from Nov. 1 through May 31, when winds are usually the strongest and soils the driest. The survey covers 541 counties in the 10 states. ``Most of this decrease is the result of precipitation in Colorado and Kansas, where land damaged from wind decreased from 6.5 million acres last year to 463,000 acres this year for the two states,'' Scaling said. The greatest damage was in North Dakota, in its third year of severe drought, he said. The state reported 2.9 million acres damaged this season, compared with 2.3 million last year and a record 3.5 million acres in 1987-88. North Dakota accounted for more than one-third of the total wind erosion in the 10-state region. Kansas, after setting a record with 5.1 million acres damaged last year (largely because of a one-day storm that damaged nearly 4.8 million acres), reported only 190,000 acres damaged this season. The least damage was in Nebraska, with 130,000 acres damaged, compared with 192,000 last year. Officials said the record for land damaged by wind in the Great Plains was 15.3 million acres in 1954-55, the year that the agency began annual records. According to the survey, the state-by-state breakdown comparing wind-damaged acres in 1989-90 with damage in 1988-89, included: _ Colorado, 273,731 and 1,403,655. _ Kansas, 189,600 and 5,126,250. _ Montana, 1,249,665 and 1,832,025. _ Nebraska, 130,115 and 191,605. _ New Mexico, 248,500 and 117,950. _ North Dakota, 2,932,687 and 2,297,681. _ Oklahoma, 136,800 and 111,930. _ South Dakota, 601,830 and 678,550. _ Texas, 1,668,000 and 1,979,626. _ Wyoming, 407,550 and 552,680.

An additional $11 million has been reallocated to 46 states for the Agriculture Department's special supplemental food program for women, infants and children. About half the states were running out of money for the program, known as WIC. Higher food costs, especially for dairy and citrus products, were said to be the main factors. Officials said Tuesday the department regularly reallocates unspent and carryover WIC funds to states in need or in danger of running out before the end of the fiscal year. ``Many states have managed their WIC caseloads carefully enough that they aren't having any budgetary problems,'' said Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service. ``Others have had to economize ... by choosing less expensive but nutritious foods,'' she said. Nationally, the reallocated money will allow states to provide an additional 300,000 food packages to participants over the final three months of this fiscal year, Nelsen said. The funds will be available to states July 1 and will supplement more than $2 billion allocated for WIC in the current fiscal year that began last Oct. 1. More than 4.5 million women, infants and children participate.

DOC.HEAD: Model Says She and Mayor Barry Used Drugs At Least 100 Times
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Ex-model Rasheeda Moore testified today that she and Mayor Marion Barry used drugs ``over 100 times'' _ sometimes more than once a day _ during a three-year romance. Moore, who cooperated in the FBI sting operation that led to Barry's arrest, testified that she and the mayor used cocaine at her mother's home and a dozen other locations from 1986 to 1988. The drug use continued after her ``intimate relationship'' with Barry ended, she testified at the mayor's cocaine and perjury trial. She said she ended the affair because ``I was losing myself.'' Barry sat 50 feet away in the courtroom while Moore offered her account. Barry's wife, Effi, sat nearby in a front row seat. Asked how frequently she and Barry used drugs, she responded ``over 100 times. There were times we did it more than once a day, sometimes two to three times.'' ``There was so much drug use over that period of time, and I was losing myself ... losing my character regarding my children,'' Moore testified. ``I wanted to get my life in order.'' Moore helped the government in the FBI sting operation, which resulted in the mayor's arrest Jan. 18 at the Vista Hotel. It was during their meeting in a hotel room that the FBI videotaped the mayor allegedly smoking crack cocaine. It was Moore who persuaded Barry to come to the hotel room. The videotape of their meeting is expected to be played following her testimony. Moore began testifying after assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin told the jury the mayor's ``drug dealings'' with the mayor included powder cocaine, crack, marijuana and opium. Retchin's statement is the first time that opium use by the mayor has been suggested. Prosecutors have said Moore and Barry carried on a ``torrid'' relationship for three years. Barry's wife, Effi, sat in the front row of the courtroom as Moore took the stand. Prosecutors said they want to ask Moore about drugs other than cocaine, even though Barry is charged with crimes only in connection with alleged cocaine possession. Retchin explained that because Barry plans to raise the defense that he was entrapped by overzealous government investigators, Moore should be permitted to testify about the other substances to show he was predisposed to drug use. Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said marijuana use does not suggest ``predisposition or propensity for crack cocaine.'' On Tuesday, tape recordings of Barry's grand jury appearances in January 1989 were played in court. Barry told the grand jury he had no indication that a friend, Charles Lewis, was involved with drugs and that he and Lewis had not given drugs to each other. Those assertions form the basis of the three felony perjury charges against the three-term mayor. Lewis, a convicted drug dealer, testified last week that he and Barry used crack cocaine, powdered cocaine and marijuana repeatedly from 1986 through December 1988. Barry's grand jury appearance came the following month. There was nothing ``unusual or criminal'' about his visits to Lewis' Washington hotel room in December 1988, Barry said in his sworn testimony. He told the grand jury in January 1989 that he gave Lewis money for food on occasion, but not more than $60 in total. Lewis testified that Barry gave him hundreds of dollars for drugs, even sending some money over to Lewis' hotel with one of the mayor's security guards. Barry recalled that his first visit to Lewis' hotel room was on Dec. 17, 1988. Lewis testified last week that the two smoked crack cocaine the night of Dec. 16, 1988. Lewis testified last week that he left his hotel room to buy crack when drug supplies got low on Dec. 19, 1988, while Barry stayed in the room. Barry told the grand jury he didn't recall Lewis leaving the room. Barry said he spent an hour or less in the room on the night of Dec. 19. Lewis testified the mayor was there well past midnight and long after a televised Monday night football game had ended. The mayor told the grand jury that he and a city government attorney, James McWilliams, discussed McWilliams' job problems during the game. McWilliams testified last week that he tried repeatedly to do just that, but that he wasn't successful and at one point found Barry slumped over on a bathroom seat an arm's length from drug paraphernalia.
Here are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision Wednesday holding that people charged with child abuse are not always entitled to a face-to-face confrontation with their accusers:
DOC.HEAD: Maryland v. Sandra Ann Craig, Main Opinion Written by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor:
DOC.TEXT: We have never held, however, that the Confrontation Clause guarantees criminal defendants the absolute right to a face-to-face meeting with witnesses against them at trial... In sum, our precedents establish that ``th Confrontation Clause reflects a preference for face-to-face confrontation at trial,'' ... a preference that ``must occasionally give way to considerations of public policy and the necessities of the case. That the face-to-face confrontation requirement is not absolute does not, of course, mean that it may easily be dispensed with. Our precedents confirm that a defendant's right to confront accusatory witnesses may be satisfied absent a physical, face-to-face confrontation at trial only where denial of such confrontation is necessary to further an important public policy and only where the reliability of the testimony is otherwise assured. We likewise conclude today that a state's interest in the physical and psychological well-being of child abuse victims may be sufficiently important to outweigh, at least in some cases, a defendant's right to face his or her accusers in court. That a significant majority of states has enacted statutes to protect child witnesses from the trauma of giving testimony in child abuse cases attests to the widespread belief in the importance of such a public policy. Thirty-seven states, for example, permit the use of videotaped testimony of sexually abused children, 24 states have authorized the use of one-way circuit television testimony in child abuse cases; and eight states authorize the use of a two-way system in which the child-witness is permitted to see the courtroom and the defendant on a video monitor and in which the jury and judge is permitted to view the child during testimony. Given the state's traditional and ``transcendent interest in protecting the welfare of children,'' and buttressed by the growing body of academic literature documenting the psychological trauma suffered by child abuse victims who must testify in court, we will not second-guess the considered judgment of the Maryland Legislature regarding the importance of its interest in protecting child abuse victims from the emotional trauma of testifying. Accordingly, we hold that, if the State makes an adequate showing of necessity, the state interest in protecting child witnesses from the trauma of testifying in a child abuse case is sufficiently important to justify the use of a special procedure that permits a child witness in such cases to testify at trial against a defendant in the absence of face-to-face confrontation with the defendant. The requisite finding of necessity must of course be a case specific one: the trial court must hear evidence and determine whether use of the one-way closed circuit television procedure is necessary to protect the welfare of the particular child witness who seeks to testify. To be sure, face-to-face confrontation may be said to cause trauma for the very purpose of eliciting truth, but we think that the use of Maryland's special procedure, where necessary to further the important state interest in preventing trauma to child witnesses in child abuse cases, adequately ensures the accuracy of the testimony and preserves the adversary nature of the trial. Indeed, where face-to-face confrontation causes significant emotional distress in a child witness, there is evidence that such confrontation would in fact disserve the Confrontation Clause's truth-seeking goal. In sum, we conclude that where necessary to protect a child witness from trauma that would be caused by testifying in the physical presence of the defendant, at least where such trauma would impair the child's ability to communicate, the Confrontation Clause does not prohibit use of a procedure that, despite the absence of face-to-face confrontation, ensures the reliability of the evidence by subjecting it to rigorous adversarial testing and thereby preserves the essence of effective confrontation.
DOC.HEAD: Dissenting Opinion Written by Justice Antonin Scalia:
DOC.TEXT: Seldom has this Court failed so conspicuously to sustain a categorical guarantee of the Constitution against the tide of prevailing current opinion. ... The purpose of enshrining this protection in the Constitution was to assure that none of the many policy interests from time to time pursued by statutory law could overcome a defendant's right to face his or her accusers in court. This debate is not an appropriate one. I have no need to defend the value of confrontation, because the Court has no authority to question it. It is not within our charge to speculate that, ``where face-to-face confrontation causes significant emotional distress in a child witness,'' confrontation might ``in fact disserve the Confrontation Clause's truth-seeking goal.'' If so, that is a defect in the Constitution which should be amended by the procedures provided for such an eventuality, but cannot be corrected by judicial pronouncement that it is archaic, contrary to ``widespread belief'' and thus null and void. For good or bad, the Sixth Amendment requires confrontation, and we are not at liberty to ignore it. The Court today has applied ``interest-balancing'' analysis where the text of the Constitution simply does not permit it. We are not free to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of clear and explicit constitutional guarantees, and then to adjust their meaning to comport with our findings.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leader Claims Home Attacked
DOC.TEXT: A top union leader and former finance minister said his home was attacked early Wednesday by a group of masked men who used iron bars to smash windows and damage his car. Mahendra Chaudhry, who also is a senior member of the deposed Coalition party, claimed the incident was politically motivated. ``They came to intimidate us,'' said Chaudhry, secretary of the Fiji Trade Union Congress. ``It took only three or four minutes and was well-planned. They acted as if they were on a mission. All we could hear was shattering glass.'' Chaudhry and his wife, Veer, were not hurt in the incident, which was being investigated by police. Chaudhry, an ethnic Indian, was finance minister in the multiracial Coalition government. That government ruled for only a month before being overthrown in a military coups in 1987. As the union leader, he has been at the forefront of opposition to a draft constitution intended to give the minority indigenous Melanesians political dominance over other races. The draft was approved by the country's high chiefs Monday and is expected to take effect soon, despite Coalition claims that it is racist. Last weekend, Chaudhry called on ethnic Indians to seek overseas support, such as trade bans and sanctions, if the draft was enacted.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Agents Uncover Record Alcohol Smuggling Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents seized 5,500 gallons of nearly pure grain alcohol in the biggest such seizure made in Norway, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The Oslo daily Aftenposten said agents Friday found two freight containers filled with cans of 96-percent alcohol that had been smuggled from Spain to Oslo by ship and truck. Three Norwegians were arrested Monday, the newspaper said, without naming them. The suspects could face two years in prison if convicted. Alcohol is heavily taxed in Norway under a policy intended to curb consumption. The newspaper said it was the biggest single seizure of illegal spirits made in Norway.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Consitutional Amendment Was Victim of Canadian Regionalism
DOC.TEXT: Canada as a country is an unnatural union. Less a nation than a grouping of regional entities with vastly differing interests and outlooks, it always has been difficult to govern. Following the failure of the Meech Lake constitutional accord, it may become even harder. ``It's not a natural state, either economically or geographically, and certainly not culturally,'' constitutional expert John D. Whyte said. ``And the one cultural linkage that we did have, living under a British crown, has absolutely disappeared,'' said Whyte, dean of the Queen's University law school. Is Canada impossible to govern? ``We're about to find out,'' said Joseph Jockel, a specialist in Canadian studies at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y. ``Beyond the short-term squabblings and constitutional theory, there is a combat between two visions of what Canada is, and they may be incompatible. ``The majority of Quebecois see Canada as binational, a pact between two nations and two people in which one is Quebec and one the people of Canada,'' Jockel said. ``Meech was to have addressed that. ``Most English Canadians see Canada as a country of 10 provinces and of one people, to which some special characteristics in Quebec have to be accommodated. ``Meech really crashed on the rocks of those two visions,'' he said. Meech Lake was an attempt to gain French-speaking Quebec's signature on Canada's 1982 constitution. The agreement contained five points covering the province's most important concerns, including one clause designating Quebec a ``distinct society'' within Canada. The clause had little practical impact but was a symbol of enormous importance to the 6.5 million Quebecois, who make up about 25 percent of Canada's 26 million people. Other provisions involved a new constitutional amending formula, some powers over immigration, a limit on federal spending authority and a voice in appointing Supreme Court justices. The measure required ratification by the federal government and the legislatures of all 10 provinces. It died when Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells decided not to put it to a vote and when a member of the Manitoba assembly managed to delay debate beyond Saturday's deadline. The failure of the measure angered and embittered many Quebecois, who view it as a rejection by English Canada. The long debate over the amendment and the numerous reservations by other provinces gave rise to increased nationalism in the province. The geography and history of Canada make it difficult to find national consensus, and in the case of constitutional amendments such as Meech Lake, unanimity. Regional interests are nearly impossible to overcome. British Columbia in the far west has much more in common with the northwest United States than it does with Ontario or Quebec. Economically, its gaze is as much oriented toward the Orient as it is eastward to the rest of Canada. In the east, the impoverished maritime provinces of Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick depend to a large extent on fish and on government handouts for economic survival. Newfoundland only joined the Canadian federation in 1949, and many Newfoundlanders still talk about ``going up to Canada.'' Alberta in the west, with its rich resources in oil and gas, feels its political clout is not equivalent to its economic might. That is one reason it fights so hard for reform of the moribund Canadian Senate. The prairie provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba have always been seen as an agricultural vastness and market for central Canada's products. Quebec, with its historical, linguistic and cultural differences, is clearly distinct from the rest of Canada. It long has felt more comfortable in its close relations with the northeastern United States, and more recently with Ontario, than with the rest of Canada. ``Just look at the Quebec license plates, from Boston to Florida,'' one Quebec official said, noting the French province was wholeheartedly behind the U.S.-Canadian free trade agreement of a year ago. A common feeling is resentment of central Canada and opposition to Ottawa. Because 62 percent of Canada's people live in Ontario and Quebec, and because nearly 30 percent of all the people in the country live either in Toronto, Montreal or Vancouver, political power has been unbalanced. And while Meech Lake frequently was portrayed as French vs. English Canada _ which it was to some extent _ it was far more complicated. Special treatment for Quebec was psychologically unacceptable for many English Canadians, and politically unacceptable for others. ``Now Canada is really going to be tested,'' Jockel said. ``We can count on Quebec putting forth a new agenda even more explicity based on the notion of Canada as two people.''

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, Leader in Conservative Branch, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, whose leadership in Conservative Judaism helped pave the way for the ordination of women, has died at age 66. Kelman died Tuesday of cancer at the New York University Medical Center, according to a colleague, Rabbi Julra Harlow. Known as ``a rabbi's rabbi,'' Kelman never led a congregation but was a major force in the Conservative movement. As the executive vice president of the Rabbinical Assembly, he was mentor to hundreds of rabbis, guiding them spiritually and pragmatically. During the 1960s, he was among Jewish leaders who participated in civil rights marches with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the South. Kelman was born in Vienna in 1923 and moved to Canada with his family as a young boy. His father, Rabbi Zvi Yehuda Kelman, died when Wolfe Kelman was 13. Left with six children, his mother stepped into the role of community leader in Toronto, where she offered religious and personal guidance. ``It was her example that made me believe women could function as rabbis,'' Kelman said years later. Women were first ordained in Conservative Judaism in 1985. The standing of rabbis improved markedly over his years at the Rabbinical Assembly. But he refused to take credit for being any more than someone who eased the way for others. Survivors include his wife, the former Jacqueline Levy; a son and two daughters. A funeral service was scheduled for Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says Hubble Photos Not as Good as Expected
DOC.TEXT: Photographs taken from the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope have not been as good as expected, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration says. The problem might be caused by all the lights in the telescope's mirror not focusing at the same point, NASA officials said. They scheduled a news conference later today. The telescope was launched into orbit April 25 aboard the space shuttle Discovery. It is designed to study the far reaches of the universe while free from the distorting effects of earth's atmosphere. ``In assessing the Hubble Space Telescope's optical performance, the orbital verification team conducted a series of focus tests,'' NASA said. ``The anticipated image quality was not achieved,'' it said. ``Computer models of the images indicate the source of this lesser quality image may be what is called spherical aberration. A spherical aberration occurs when all the lights in a mirror do not focus precisely at the same point.'' ``NASA managers are assessing the cause and determining what the scientific implications are,'' the agency said.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

June 25 Philadelphia Daily News on S&L crisis: George Bush thinks the savings and loan disaster is a bad thing. Some of the billions in failed loans, he says, showed ``excesses'' and were ``foolish and ill-advised.'' He does not, however, think the crazed deregulation masterminded by the Reagan and Bush administrations had anything to do with it. In other words, ``It's bad, don't blame me and I don't have any intention of doing anything to prevent it from happening again.''

June 25 Dallas Times Herald on sexist medical research: It's appalling that the researchers who conduct federally funded health studies routinely exclude women from the focus groups. But that's exactly what's happening, congressional investigators say. Incredibly, knowing full well that the disease to be studied affects men and women, researchers sometimes have been given funding by the National Institutes of Health for studies that use only men. What makes the situation even more reprehensible is that the NIH has had a policy in effect since 1986 that requires women to be included in studies unless their presence clearly is scientifically inappropriate. An NIH advisory committee reported in 1987 that less than 14 percent of the institute's budget was devoted to female health issues, according to Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., a leader of the Congressional Caucus for Women. ... We agree with Mrs. Schroeder, who said what these dismal findings reveal simply is that ``it's OK to put women's health at risk.'' ... The good news is that the NIH essentially agrees with Mrs. Schroeder. William Raub, the acting NIH director, said he and his colleagues know that they must correct the situation immediately. The caucus and the General Accounting Office _ the investigative branch of Congress _ must make certain Raub is held accountable.

June 25 The Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, on libel ruling: The Supreme Court clarified libel case law when it ruled in favor of a plaintiff who alleges a newspaper columnist defamed him 15 years ago. The columnist asserted by way of his opinion that a high school wrestling coach and a school superintendent had lied at a hearing. Courts in Ohio found in favor of the columnist, arguing that opinion is absolutely protected by the First Amendment. The decision, written by Chief Justice William Rehnquist, removes opinion from this lofty perch. Rehnquist said that the courts had misconstrued previous libel decisions by the Supreme Court. In a 1974 case, Gertz vs. Welch, the court said that ``under the First Amendment there was no such thing as a false idea.'' Rehnquist noted that the notion of ``idea'' soon became synonomous with opinion. The court, including dissenting justices William Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, said that there is a distinction between ideas and opinions. Moreover, an opinion by implying a fact can defame. Justice Brennan's dissenting opinion disagrees only in the application of the court's principle. He argued that the newspaper columnist did not say anything defamatory, that the column was clearly conjecture and not based on fact. The director of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press said the decision ``ironically is going to encourage irresponsible commentary at the expense of well-reasoned analysis.'' Even in the worst-case scenario this is a dubious assertion. The First Amendment has not disappeared. The court merely removed an artificial distinction.

June 25 The Record of Hackensack, N.J., on a proposed free trade pact with Mexico: American business would gain better access to a market of almost 100 million Mexicans. Mexico, a strategically important neighbor of the United States, would gain needed jobs and prosperity, without a penny in additional aid from Washington. Those are the principal benefits that could materialize from a proposed free trade pact between the United States and Mexico. In a recent meeting in Washington, President Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari, president of Mexico, committed themselves in principle to easing barriers to the flow of capital, goods and services between the two neighbors. Since jobs are being exported away, why not steer them towards Mexico, where a significant percentage of the new wages would be spent on American goods and services? And more prosperity in Mexico might actually ease the already high levels of migration of Mexican workers to the United States. Mr. Bush and Mr. Salinas are realistic about the obstacles ahead. But the idea is worth pursuing.
