DOC.HEAD: Riots Spead Beyond Zambia's Capital; At Least 20 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with five more people reported killed, troops herding protesters into sports stadium. Picks up 8th graf, `By noon...' ^By MELINDA HAM
DOC.TEXT: Riots against increases in food prices and Zambia's one-party government spread from Lusaka to smaller cities today, and troops herded protesters in one town into a sports stadium and held them at gunpoint. Hospital officials said five people died today, raising the toll to at least 20 in the worst rioting in Zambia's history. Health officials conceded there could have been many more fatalities in barricaded suburbs and shanties without transport or telephones. On the third day of protests and looting, the government extended 6 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew to 24 hours. Civilian vigilantes patrolled the streets carrying automatic rifles, military helicopters flew low overhead and suburban storekeepers fired volleys of bullets to defend their wares, wounding an unknown number of looters. Police officials said widespread looting took place throughout the day at the town of Kafue, 25 miles south of Lusaka. Army units later herded scores of looters into a Kafue sports stadium and held them there at gunpoint, the officials said on condition of anonymity. Rioting also reportedly broke out late Tuesday in the mineral-rich Copperbelt province of this south-central African nation, where the government has more than doubled the price of corn meal as part of subsidy-cutting reform. Protesters also demand an end to socialist one-party rule by President Kenneth Kaunda in the country of 7.5 million people. It is the most serious challenge to Kuanda's rule since he came to power in 1964. Police said they had detained more than 550 people. Unconfirmed reports said 12 police officers were illed today when a rampaging mob attacked Chainama police station, east of the city center. The attack, if confirmed, would bring the death toll since Monday to 32. Doctors in Lusaka today said at least 20 people died and 190 were wounded in three days of riots. By noon, mobs or police had thrown up makeshift road blocks using burned out cars or broken masonry in most suburbs. Troop reinforcements in armored personnel carriers positioned themselves at strategic points but did not fire. The windows of most stores in the downtown shopping district have been smashed in, one witness said. Police spokesman Andrew Kaitisha said the arrests in Lusaka were aimed at finding ``ringleaders'' among the thousands of protesters who rampaged through most districts of the capital, looting stores, burning flags and chanting anti-government slogans. ``They were arrested for screening and are being interviewed by a special police team for find out who the agitators are,'' he said. There were no immediate details of the extent of unrest on the Copperbelt but reports said demonstrators clashed with security forces at the mining town of Kitwe, about 225 miles north of Lusaka. The violence was sparked by the June 19 increase in the price of corn meal, the country's staple, from $2.79 per 55-pound bag to $6.56. The increase was announced as part of an economic reform program aimed at reducing government subsidies and making the economy of one of Africa's poorest nations more commercially viable. It had been recommended by financial agencies and donor nations. The unrest took on a further political dimension as demonstrators, mostly from Lusaka's most impoverished townships and shanties, demanded Kaunda's ouster and an end to nearly two decades of socialist-style one-party rule. Earlier this year, Kaunda promised to hold a referendum on the future of Zambia's one-party system but no date has been set for the vote. Residents of the Lusaka suburb of Chilenji said rioters smashed their way into a home occupied by Kaunda, a former school teacher and lay preacher before he led his nation to independence from British colonial rule in 1964. The house, seen in the past as a symbol of Zambia's black nationalist struggle against the British, was extensively damaged, residents said. Student rioters have also burned the flag of Kaunda's ruling United National Independence Party. Kaunda, 67, has made no official comment on the unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Nest Egg Drawing Customer Interest
DOC.TEXT: Keeping a nest egg for a rainy day at the Bank of Boston, Connecticut branch office here is not all it's ``quacked'' up to be. The nest egg, actually an egg nest belonging to Paulette the Duck, has been drawing interest, as in customer interest, since it was built under the drive-through teller window. It took Paulette more than two weeks to build the nest at the bank office, which is next door to her normal habitat, the Meadow Brook Plantation Garden Center. The eggs, which Paulette has been depositing in the nest two at a time, should mature into 13 ducklings in a month or so. Paulette apparently is a very protective mother-to-be and has enlisted relatives to keep curious humans at bay. ``The other day, five ducks came waddling down and stood in front of a car and wouldn't let it pass,'' teller Debbie D'Agostino said Tuesday. ``They were all quacking at the same time.'' For most of the last two weeks, Paulette has sat on her nest all night and left the following morning when the bank opened. But since Monday, she has refused to leave, despite being coaxed and cajoled by bank workers and depositors.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: worth pursuing.
DOC.TEXT: June 23 The Martinsburg (W.Va.) Evening Journal on suspension of PLO talks: How drearily familiar is the criticism being made of President Bush's decision to suspend friendly talks with the terrorist Palestine Liberation Organization. Eighteen months ago U.S. officials announced they would engage in a ``dialogue'' with the PLO to help bring peace to the Middle East. The agreement was conditioned on PLO renunciation of violence. Since then PLO operatives _ under orders of high-ranking PLO officials _ have conducted several terrorist raids. One a few weeks ago was aimed at a U.S. embassy in Israel. It was prevented only by quick-acting Israeli police and troops. Bush, finally tired of PLO duplicity, last week called a halt to the farce. He said he's suspending talks with the PLO until he has some evidence it'll keep its end of the bargain. Almost immediately there was criticism. Opponents of Bush's stance said he may have opened the door to more violence in the Middle East. ...It's time to stop worrying about upsetting the PLO. It's time to demand, as Bush is doing, that PLO leaders keep their word about renouncing violence _ or face increasing enmity from the United States and a step-up in aid to Israel. Certainly, the rabid dog has been angered. He'll probably bite to try to force us to give in to him. But his growls should be met by a kick in the teeth _ not a pat on the head.

June 22 Pasadena (Calif.) Star-News on Iran earthquake: Wouldn't it be going against our Judeo-Christian cultural values in the West to be any less saddened or helpful because of yesterday's devastating earthquake in Iran than we were after the devastating earthquake in Armenia? Yes _ there's no question but that it would. One doesn't have to flip through one's Bible long before running into this admonition from Matthew: ``Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you.'' ...They curse us, they hate us, they use us, they persecute us. They take our embassy and its people captive and ruin hundreds of lives. They control the fates of dozens of innocent hostages in Lebanon. They put out a death sentence on an obscure Anglo-Indian writer in a model case study of radical intolerance. They persecute their own people through a supposedly theocratic people's dictatorship that ironically reminds us in its cruelty of nothing so much as the arrogant fake monarchy it toppled. ...Why shed crocodile tears for them? Because, both soul-searching and logic will tell us, there's no ``them'' there. That is, in the great scheme of things, there are not enough bad guys in Tehran to shake a stick at. Whereas the bereaved peasants in northern Iran today no more invented the image of our country as the Great Satan than they invented high-definition TV... It may not ``work,'' in the sneaky, self-serving sense that's admittedly part of this notion. If we send humanitarian aid, it may not be admitted by the remnants of the Ayatollah Khomeini's kooky regime. It may be considered a trick, or merely propagandistic. But then again, subtly and diplomatically done, such aid has a chance of working to both of our ends: helping out people in distress and showing them that Americans have love in their hearts for the Iranian people, if not for their leaders. Self-serving? Partially. But remember that our government did install the Shah, no swell fellow himself. This could be honest, Judeo-Christian penance. And, cynicism aside, blessing them that curse us isn't such a bad path to follow simply for its own sake.

June 23 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on the constitutionality of roadside checkpoints: The Fourth Amendment protects us from ``unreasonable searches and seizures.'' But what about roadside checkpoints, which stop passing motorists in an effort to identify and apprehend the small minority who are driving under the influence of alcohol? Are these reasonable police procedures, or do they violate the Constitution. This past week, the Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that such checkpoints are ligitimate. This was a sensible ruling: It finally clears up a long-disputed legal issue, and also provides one more weapon in the arsenal of those charged with limiting the highway mayhem caused by drunk drivers. Writing for the majority, Chief Justice William Rehnquist argued that roadside checkpoints ... meet a three-pronged test of constitutionality. First, the problem being targeted is unquestionably important. ... Second, checkpoints constitute an effective mechanism for identifying potentially dangerous drunk drivers. ... Third, checkpoints cause only minor interference with people's liberty. ...

June 22 The Madison (Wis.) Capital Times on Iran earthquake: Human tragedy on the scale that is occurring in Iran transcends national boundaries or past political divisions. It cries out for a worldwide response to help survivors go on with their lives, even as they mourn their dead. The earthquake that shook northern Iran last Thursday turned dozens of communities into piles of rubble that entombed thousands of people. Fortunately, the United States was among those nations that put aside diplomatic differences with Iran to offer humanitarian aid.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: humanitarian aid.
DOC.TEXT: June 26 The Daily Telegraph, London, on aid to the Soviet Union: It does not ... make sense to pour large sums of Western taxpayers' money into the bottomless pit of the Soviet Union. That would not merely be a premature reward for inadequate economic reform; it might actually slow the process. It is natural for the West Germans, flush with the world's largest trade surplus, to wish to use this to political effect. Other Western politicians, too, may wish they could buy Mr. Gorbachev out of economic failure. Unfortunately, this is not an attainable objective. There are forms of assistance to which all should agree. The Bush administration has shown itself encouragingly ready to foster trade, and must now persuade Congress to agree. Subsidized American grain sales are not so different from the kind of food aid urged by some Europeans; a little may be politically useful. But large-scale subsidy would merely stunt the Soviet economy's feeble efforts to generate domestic production. Financial aid which merely reduced the Soviet Union's need to sell gold would be an incentive, not a cure, for domestic mismanagement. Investment, which is what the Soviet Union most needs, will come once a market economy exists.

June 20 Il Messaggero, Rome, on Romania: The recent repression and bloodshed in Bucharest reveal a new kind of post-Communist regime in Eastern Europe. Incorrectly, it is being called ``neo-communism.'' It is in fact something quite different. Neo-communism is the courageous attempt of a Mikhail Gorbachev, who, in the face of an incredibly difficult transition phase, is poised to move the crisis-bound Soviet Union from Stalinism to true democratic socialism. Even if for now it is but a vision, the possibility cannot be excluded that from so many failings, a new, liberal communism can be born. The course of Iliescu in Romania is quite different. Here there is no transition _ only restoration. Remember the words of Elena Ceausescu to her executioners: ``You are all my children.'' That ominous warning, broadcast on televisions around the world, weighs heavily on the heart. Another leopard reigns in the blood of Bucharest.

June 21 Weltwoche, Zurich, Switzerland, on Soviet withdrawal of troops from Germany: Suppose the Soviet Union pulls its troops out of Germany. Not much imagination is needed to predict that on the day the last Soviet soldier has left East Germany, the call will rise in West Germany for the withdrawal of the Western troops. Already now, France and Britain do not dare to voice any reservations, and will not be able to resist such demands. But the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Germany would mean the factual end of NATO, whether it is dissolved or not. Germany, because of its sheer size, thus would get a special status in Europe. One does not need to accuse the West German politicians of seeking such status. But they or their successors, swept to power by the new nationalism and the new sense of greatness, will be inevitably pushed in this direction. ..The German special status will that be of a Europoean superpower and not that of a medium power restricted and limited by an (international) treaty.

June 21 Mainichi Daily News, Tokyo, on the Mideast situation: The Middle East situation is like a mirage. From time to time the hope for lasting peace there appears, but all too soon fades away. At present the situation is going through a disappointing period. Anticipation for peace was strong toward the end of 1988. That was when the Palestine Liberation Organization proclaimed the establishment of an independent Palestine state but, at the same time, gave virtual recognition to the existence of Israel, and announced the abandonment of terrorism. This led to the start of direct dialogue between the U.S. government and the PLO. With the PLO's adoption of a realistic course and the U.S. government's restudy of its policy toward that group, many thought that the bottleneck in the long search for peace had at last been removed. Eighteen months have passed since then, however, instead of the prospect for peace becoming brighter, several events darkening that prospect have taken place. The killing of Palestinian workers in the outskirts of Tel Aviv on May 20 by ``a mentally disturbed man'' led to protests and a general strike by Palestinians. Then on May 30, armed groups believed to be members of a radical PLO wing landed from speedboats at two bathing beaches near Tel Aviv. The raid was checked by Israeli troops, but the question remains as to whether this was a violation of the PLO's pledge ``to abandon terrorism.'' If the U.S. government considers this to be a violation, there is the possibility that the dialogue with the PLO will be halted or interrupted temporarily. This would deliver a big blow to the peace efforts. ... At a time when there is little prospect for improvement of the situation, all those concerned should endeavor not to make the situation worse. Efforts should be made to mitigate mutual distrust. Even the slightest careless action will increase that distrust.

June 25 Le Monde, Paris, on the political repercussions of the Iranian earthquake: This catastrophe could strengthen the arguments of President Rafsanjani and other Iranian leaders who want to end as rapidly as possible the isolation which has forced the country to turn toward moderate Arab countries and the West, It remains to be seen if the door which has opened a crack under these particularly sorrowful circumstances will close again when the emotions provoked by the earthquake have faded. The political-religious rhetoric, today relegated to secondary importance, might surface again in the face of the complex problems which must still be resolved in order to knock down the wall of defiance and mistrust which 10 years of pure, rigid Khomeini-ism has built around the Islamic Republic.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Judge Sentenced In Own Former Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: A judge was sentenced today in his former courtroom to two to five years in prison for bribery and corruption. Cambria County Judge Joseph F. O'Kicki, 59, was stripped of his $80,000-per-year job and forfeits his state pension. Visiting Senior Judge Richard Grifo of Northampton County also imposed a $57,500 fine on O'Kicki. ``You have tainted the entire judiciary with a broad brush,'' Grifo told O'Kicki. ``Every member of the judiciary not only feels pain because of you, but will continue to feel that pain.'' Before being sentenced, O'Kicki delivered a one-hour speech accusing prosecutors of misconduct, criticizing local news media and maintaining his innocence. ``I see conspiracies everywhere,'' O'Kicki said during the speech, in which he quoted Isaac Newton, Latin philosophers and former U.S. Supreme Court justices. Grifo allowed O'Kicki to remain free on bond pending his appeal, which O'Kicki's attorneys said would be filed today. Last fall he was convicted of three counts of bribery and one count each of official oppression, coercion and demanding money for a promotion. O'Kicki faced a maximum sentence of 26 years in prison. Among other offenses, O'Kicki was convicted of bullying aides and clerks into chopping wood, shuttling him to and from work, feeding his dogs and performing other chores on county time. A secretary testified O'Kicki summoned her for dictation into his chambers, where the judge was wearing only bikini underwear. Another testified O'Kicki asked her to have sex with him at her house before work, and treated her badly after she refused.

DOC.HEAD: A New Plan for Play Production on Broadway
DOC.TEXT: More plays and lower ticket prices are the goals of a major new initiative to bring audiences back to Broadway. The plan to stimulate the production of plays in designated, little-used Broadway theaters as well as to reduce ticket prices was announced Tuesday by members of the Broadway theater community. The project, called The Broadway Alliance, was born after months of discussion among theater owners, producers, unions and guilds, said Harvey Sabinson, head of the League of American Theaters and Producers. It involves salary, royalty and manpower reductions and concessions by actors, producers, theater owners, unions and suppliers, ``an equality of sacrifice,'' said Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of Actors Equity Association and committee chairman of the Alliance. Because of these concessions, production costs for the plays must not exceed $400,000, and producers must use certain, underutilized Broadway theaters. That capitalization is less than half of the usual $800,000 to $1 million now required to produce a play on Broadway. In return, ticket prices will be held to a top price of $24 for orchestra seats and $19 and $10 for mezzanine and balcony tickets. The top ticket price for plays on Broadway now ranges from $37.50 for ``The Piano Lesson'' to $50 for ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' and ``The Grapes of Wrath.'' The plan is aimed at one-set plays with small casts and does not apply to musicals. ``The Broadway community can no longer stand by as many of America's finest plays are being produced everywhere but on Broadway,'' said Peter Stone, head of the Dramatists Guild. ``Most of these plays, in the face of growing costs and lacking a big star, a major prize or a lavish production, have been relegated to regional and off-Broadway theaters. ``Such acclaimed works as `Driving Miss Daisy,' `Steel Magnolias,' `Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de lune,' `Other People's Money' and `The Cocktail Hour' have achieved national recognition and large motion picture contracts while Broadway can only watch and remember a time, no more than 10 years ago, when every one of these fine plays would have been lighting up Broadway houses,'' Stone said. Broadway's three major theater owners _ the Shubert, Nederlander and Jujamcyn organizations _ each have provided theaters for the new project. The houses include the Walter Kerr, the Nederlander and either the Belasco or Lyceum theaters. Only the Kerr is currently booked. The theaters would be booked on a rotating basis. The plan will go into effect Sept. 1, and run for 18 months until the end of February 1991, when it will be up for review. Producers wishing to participate would have to apply to the Alliance for approval. All personnel working at reduced wages, including the actors, will participate in a profit-sharing plan after production costs are recouped. The productions also will pay no rent to the theaters until costs are recouped.

DOC.HEAD: Measure To Censor AMA Journal Defeated
With PM-AMA Convention
DOC.TEXT: The American Medical Association's policy-making body defeated a measure to censor editorials in the AMA's medical journal. The Illinois State Medical Society, angered by several editorials in the Journal of the American Medical Association that were critical of doctors, suggested a censorship panel to review such material. But Tuesday, the House of Delegates overwhelmingly agreed that the journal should continue to be editorially independent. ``By following a political agenda over a scientific one, we would lose the respect of our contributors and, most importanly, our readers,'' the journal's editor, Dr. George Lundberg said. Dr. James Andersen, president of the Illinois State Medical Society, said the move to censor was prompted by frustation with editorials that didn't reflect the views of the membership. ``We feel the editor should be responsible in some degree to the journal's publisher and owner,'' Andersen said.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Sentenced For Helping Libya Build Factory
DOC.TEXT: A West German businessman was sentenced to five years in prison on Wednesday for helping Libya build a plant the court said was ``clearly intended'' to produce chemical weapons. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, described by prosecutors as a ``merchant of death,'' was found guilty by a state court in Mannheim of violating West German export laws. He was also found guilty on charges of tax evasion of $11.7 million. That charge was based on his failure to report profits from the plant project. Chief Judge Juergen Henniger said that based on expert witness testimony, the court concluded the plant in Rabta, 60 miles south of Libya's capital of Tripoli, ``was clearly intended for the production of chemical warfare agents.'' He said the plant was capable of producing mustard gas and other poison gases, and that Hippenstiel-Imhausen was aware of its purpose before he signed a contract in 1984 to build it for Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Libya maintains the plant was intended to make pharmaceuticals and insecticides, not chemical weapons. U.S. officials told West German authorities in late 1988 and again in early 1989 that the plant was built to manufacture poison gas, and an investigation against Hippenstiel-Imhausen and others was opened last year. Hippenstiel-Imhausen, 49, confessed on June 13 at his trial to helping design, build and supply the facility, but he did not say that he knew the plant was for poison gas. He apologized for causing ``diplomatic problems'' for West Germany. The case was a major embarrassment for the West German government, which initially denied West German firms were involved in the project. As the verdict was read, the pale Hippenstiel-Imhausen often sat with his head in his hands. Henninger sentenced Hippenstiel-Imhausen to the maximum three years for violation of export laws, and four years for tax evasion, then reduced it to a total of five years. He said he cut the sentence because the defendant had shown remorse and confessed to his part in building the plant and to the tax evasion charges. He will eligible for parole after serving two-thirds of his sentence. Hippenstiel-Imhausen's lawyer, Eberhard Wahle, said he was ``considering an appeal.'' The ruling followed an 11-day hearing and marked one of the most sensational business trials in West German history. Hippenstiel-Imhausen was the director of the Imhausen-Chemie company of Lahr in West Germany's southern Black Forest region. He testified that the Rabta project got its initial start in 1984 when a ``middleman'' contacted him about building a plant to make ``pharmaceuticals and insecticides.'' He said he did not learn until later that the plant would be built in Libya. He said that as head of Imhausen-Chemie he ``participated in construction of the Rabta factory'' by delivering plans and equipment for the project. Although he suspected he was violating laws barring exports to areas of conflict, such as the Middle East, Hippenstiel-Imhausen said he went on with the project because he ``didn't want to lose the business.'' ``The responsibility and overall management were in my hands,'' he told the court. West German authorities are investigating 18 other people in connection with the Rabta plant, but none has been charged. The Rabta plant was damaged by fire under mysterious circumstances earlier this year, and there have been widespread reports another plant in Libya is under construction. On Tuesday, the ARD television network, citing U.S. and West German intelligence sources, said Libya intended to build a second plant using the plans furnished by Hippenstiel-Imhausen for the Rabta project. Libya on Wednesday denied a new chemical weapons plant is being built. However, the Stuttgart prosecutor's office on Wednesday said it was investigating an export company in Stuttgart in connection with the alleged second plant, along with a computer and electronics company in the city of Ulm.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Turner's Slip Sold at Auction for $1,200
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that slip is lavender sted white
DOC.TEXT: Sure, anyone can give someone the slip, but actress Kathleen Turner's slip costs $1,200. The slip, which she has been wearing in the play ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' was one of 29 items sold Tuesday night at a black-tie dinner and auction for Easter Seals. The auction raised $30,000 for the charity that aids people with disabilities. Turner is playing Maggie in the play on Broadway, dressed in a low-cut, lavender, thigh-length, silk slip with lace trim. Advertisements for the play feature Turner in the slip, seated, with her legs crossed, leaning toward the camera but looking away, and have appeared in newspapers, on billboards and posters in buses and trains throughout the region. Bidding for the slip started at $500 and quickly grew after auctioneer Diddi Lynn Worsole informed potential buyers that the slip was not in the room because Turner was wearing it just a few blocks away. ``She's sweating in it right now,'' Worsole said. ``Maybe there will be a little perfume on it.'' The bidding quickly escalated in increments of $100 until Staten Island real estate broker Henry Setaro came in with the top bid of $1,200. ``It's the closest I will ever get to Kathleen Turner,'' Setaro said. ``I hope they don't wash it before I get it.'' Setaro, whose wife sat next to him during the bidding, said he might hang the slip up in his home, but he first wants to see how his wife looks in it. ``I think my wife will look as good in it as Kathleen Turner,'' Setaro said. Sandy Setaro said she approved of the purchase because the money was for a good cause. The slip is actually one of two that were custom-made for Turner to wear in the Tennessee Williams play, in accordance with a union regulation that says producers must provide two sets of each costume.

DOC.HEAD: Yacht That Helped Sink Gary Hart Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Wanted: someone with a sense of history and humor to plunk down a cool $1.225 million for a pleasure craft. Advertised in newspapers around the nation this week, the opulent 83-foot yacht has a built-in Jacuzzi, three rosewood-paneled staterooms and a requires a crew of six that can handle intimate parties of 30-40 people. Elizabeth Taylor, Jack Nicholson, Elton John, Julio Iglesias and James Caan have visited the three-decked Monkey Business at Turnberry Isle, a ritzy resort complex north of Miami. But, of course, its most famous passenger was Gary Hart. The former U.S. senator from Colorado fell from Democratic front-runner for the presidency into infamy in less than a week after his charter trip from Florida to Bimini with model Donna Rice came to light in 1987. Hart and Rice swore there was no hanky-panky inside the swanky master stateroom, which boasts a king-size bed. But Rice's girlfriend, a bikini store owner named Lynn Armandt who was along for the ride, told the media otherwise and collected a hefty fee in the meantime. The rest is tabloid and political history, says yacht broker Bob Offer of Fort Lauderdale, who is selling the boat for Donald Soffer, a millionaire developer with holdings in New York and Miami. ``The boat has a character of its own,'' said Offer. ``When you walk on board, you really want to have a good time.'' In fact, Hart wasn't even planning to leave the dock when he met Rice, Armandt and his friend, William Broadhurst, a Washington, D.C., attorney who had chartered the Monkey Business from Soffer that day, Offer said. ``He went on board and the next thing he knew he was going to the Bahamas,'' he said. Offer said Soffer, who had the Monkey Business custom-built in 1979 and first cast about for buyers last fall, decided to market the boat in earnest because construction on a new 140-foot yacht is almost complete.

DOC.HEAD: Skepticism Greets Debut of New Five-Pence Coin
LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: After the shrunken fiver comes the dime-sized five-pence coin, and as usual when confronted with change, some Britons are reacting with annoyance and suspicion. The tiny coin hit the streets Wednesday, exactly three weeks after a smaller five-pound note was introduced to cries of derision. ``Are you kidding? These are ridiculous,'' said Parry Vaughn when he was shown the new, shiny coins on a London street. ``They're too small, they're too fiddly, and as bad as the five-pound note.'' ``It's horrible. It's too small,'' said Valdo Cesar. But his friend, Louis Leffa disagreed. ``It looks better. It's lighter and easier,'' he said. ``They're small all right, like the old six-pence, but I would get used to them,'' said Roger Brown, referring to the coinage of pre-decimalization days. ``It doesn't surprise me that most people don't like it. This government has a habit of doing things people don't like,'' said Roger Levy. At the Royal Mint, spokesman Joseph Cussen sounded mildly exasperated at the hostility that has greeted the new five-pence. ``The British are resistant to any change, and when it comes to coins they can't bear with them being interfered with or changed,'' Cussen said. ``Nobody asked us,'' complained the tabloid Sun, to which the Royal Mint responded with results of a 1987 survey in which most people said they favored smaller, lighter coins. On the new five-pound note, Queen Elizabeth II has been updated to show her age, 64. But she is unchanged on the new coin. The bust of Her Majesty still turns up heads, and tails reveals the thistle badge of Scotland. The government says the new coins contain less metal, saving about $1.70 million a year. At .1 ounce each, they are nearly 50 percent lighter than their predecessors. The 5 billion larger five-pence coins still in circulation will be phased out by Dec. 31 and recycled into new coins. ``The British don't like a new coin at first, but they get used to it and then they protect it fiercely,'' Cussen said. He said the Royal Mint has never registered a flop like the United States' Susan B. Anthony dollar coin. The closest shave, he said, was the coin that replaced the 10-shilling note in 1960. The shilling note ``was a little brown note which really made you feel like you were spending money, and people were genuinely heartbroken'' when it was phased out, he said. ``There was a move in Parliament to have the coin withdrawn, but it wasn't successful.'' Since then, the pound has also become a coin.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Warn of Assault on Endangered Species Act
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to delete jobs figure and SUBS grafs 12-13 `The preliminary...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY by adding that two jobs figures cited are over different time spans.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists charge that the Bush administration's plans to balance the interests of Northwest loggers against survival of the northern spotted owl are an assault on the Endangered Species Act. The administration Tuesday announced preliminary plans for saving the owl by restricting logging. At the same time, the administration asked for relaxation of the 1973 Endangered Species Act to let policy-makers weigh the economic and social costs against the benefits of saving animals that are listed as threatened. ``They list the owl but now they're going to change the law so they don't have to protect it,'' Larry Tuttle, Oregon director of The Wilderness Society, said Tuesday. Andy Kerr, conservation director of the Oregon Natural Resources Council, said the proposals amounted to a ``Tiananmen Square for American wildlife.'' ``Opening up the Endangered Species Act is not a good idea in the heat of the moment,'' he said. Meanwhile, timber industry supporters were skeptical the government could make good on promises that enough timber would be sold to keep loggers employed and lumber and plywood mills rolling. ``These proposals are a sham. They're smoke and mirrors,'' said Rep. Bob Smith, R-Ore. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said Friday the spotted owl, of which 3,000 to 5,000 pairs remain, would be designated a threatened species on July 23. Under law, that obligates the government to protect the owl, which nests in the oldest and tallest trees of the Northwest _ timber prized by loggers. The preliminary plans to protect the owl were announced by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan. A task force headed by Yeutter is to come up by Sept. 1 with a detailed plan. The preliminary plan will reduce timber cutting on U.S. Bureau of Land Management land in Oregon and Northern California from 950 million board feet annually to about 750 million. Lujan said 1,000 jobs would be lost over the next two year and 450 owls saved. An earlier proposal by government scientists would have resulted in the loss of nearly 28,000 jobs on BLM and Forest Service land over the next 10 years. Lujan said that by careful cutting his proposal would protect 125 more pairs of owls than would the scientists' proposal for BLM land. Yeutter and Lujan also called on Congress to broaden provisions of the Endangered Species Act so that an exemption committee will have more latitude to consider the economic and social impact of protecting wildlife. Lujan said the BLM is determined to have a minimal impact on owl habitat as it seeks maximum timber harvesting. ``We're not going to just go in there and cut willy, nilly. Any contract submitted to us must meet the test of the Fish and Wildlife Service. If we don't meet the test, we don't cut,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Planners OK Preserving Stage Where Malcolm X Was Slain
DOC.TEXT: The City Planning Commission on Wednesday approved the construction of a $25 million biomedical laboratory on the site where Malcolm X was slain, provided a substantial portion of the building is preserved. That includes 40 percent of the Audubon Ballroom, including the stage on which the black nationalist leader was shot o Feb. 21, 1965. In May, the commission had deferred a decision on a plan to demolish the ballroom at Broadway and 165th Street, across from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Followers of Malcolm X objected. Applicants for the research building were Columbia University and the city. It is to get funding from the Municipal Assistance Corp. and state urban development aid. The project still has to be approved by the city's Board of Estimate. Malcolm X headed the Harlem mosque of the Black Muslims but split with Black Muslim leader Elijah Muhammad in 1963. Malcolm X then formed the Organization of Afro-American Unity, which promoted black nationalism but admitted the possibility of interracial brotherhood.
Here are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision Wednesday upholding federal policies that favor minorities in awarding broadcast licenses:
DOC.HEAD: Metro Broadcasting Inc. v. FCC, Main Opinion Written by Justice
DOC.TEXT: William J. Brennan: It is of overriding significance in these cases that the FCC's minority ownership programs have been specifically approved _ indeed, mandated _ by Congress. We hold that benign race-conscious measures mandated by Congress _ even if those measures are not ``remedial'' in the sense of being designed to compensate victims of past governmental or societal discrimination _ are constitutionally permissible to the extent that they serve important governmental objectives within the power of Congress and are substantially related to achievement of those objectives. We hold that the FCC minority ownership policies pass muster... First, we find that they serve the important governmental objective of broadcast diversity. Second, we conclude that they are substantially related to the achievement of that objective. We have long recognized that ``because of the scarcity of (electromagnetic) frequencies, the government is permitted to put restraints on licensees in favor of others whose views should be expressed on this unique medium.'' Just as a ``diverse student body'' contributing to a ``robust exchange of ideas'' is a ``constitutionally permissible goal'' on which a race-conscious university admissions program may be predicated, the diversity of views and information on the airwaves serves important First Amendment values. We do not believe that the minority ownership policies at issue impose impermissible burdens on non-minorities. Although the non-minority challengers in these cases concede that they have not suffered the loss of an already-awarded broadcast license, they claim that they have been handicapped in their ability to obtain one in the first instance. But just as we have determined that ``as part of this nation's dedication to eradicating racial discrimination, innocent persons may be called upon to bear some of the burden of the remedy,'' we similarly find that a congressionally mandated benign race-conscious program that is substantially related to the achievement of an important governmental interest is consistent with equal protection principles so long as it does not impose undue burdens on minorities. In the context of broadcasting licenses, the burden on non-minorities is slight. The FCC's responsibility is to grant licenses in the ``public interest, convenience or necessity'' and the limited number of frequencies on the electromagnetic spectrum means that ``no one has a First Amendment right to a license.'' Applicants have no settled expectation that their applications will be granted without consideration of public interest factors such as minority ownership. The commission's minority ownership policies bear the imprimatur of longstanding congressional support and direction and are substantially related to the achievement of the important governmental objective of broadcast diversity. The judgment is affirmed.
DOC.HEAD: Dissenting Opinion by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor:
DOC.TEXT: At the heart of the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection lies the simple command that the government must treat citizens ``as individuals, not `as simply components of a racial, religious, sexual or national class.''' Social scientists may debate how peoples' thoughts and behavior reflect their background, but the Constitution provides that the government may not allocate benefits and burdens among individuals based on the assumption that race or ethnicity determines how they act or think. To uphold the challenged programs, the Court departs from these fundamental principles and from our traditional requirement that racial classifications are permissible only if necessary and narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling interest. This departure marks a renewed toleration of racial classifications and a repudiation of our recent affirmation that the Constitution's equal protection guarantees extend equally to all citizens. The Court's application of a lessened equal protection standard to congressional action finds no support in our cases or in the Constitution. In both the challenged policies, the FCC provides benefits to some members of our society and denies benefits to others based on race or ethnicity. Except in the narrowest of circumstances, the Constitution bars such racial classifications as a denial to particular individuals, of any race or ethnicity, of the equal protection of the laws. The dangers of such classifications are clear. They endorse race-based reasoning and the conception of a nation divided into racial blocs, thus contributing to an escalation of racial hostility and conflict. We are a nation not of black and white alone, but one teeming with divergent communities knitted together by various traditions and carried forth, above all, by individuals. Upon that basis, we are governed by one Constitution, providing a single guarantee of equal protection, one that extends equally to all citizens. Under the appropriate standard, strict scrutiny, only a compelling interest may support the government's use of racial classifications. Modern equal protection doctrine has recognized only one such interest: remedying the effects of racial discrimination. The interest in increasing the diversity of broadcast viewpoints is clearly not a compelling interest. It is simply too amorphous, too insubstantial, and too unrelated to any legitimate basis for employing racial classifications. The court has determine, in essence, that Congress and all federal agencies are exempted, to some ill-defined but significant, degree, from the Constitution's equal protection requirements. This break with our precedents greatly undermines equal protection guarantees, and permits distinctions among citizens based on race and ethnicity with the Constitution clearly forbids.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested in Juarez in Las Vegas FBI Agent Killing
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban refugee wanted for questioning in the shooting death of an FBI agent has been arrested in Mexico, police said today. Jose Antonio Echevarria, 29, was arrested Tuesday night after authorities tracked him throughout the day, said Las Vegas police Lt. Kyle Edwards. Echevarria was arrested without resistance at the Ciudad Juarez airport by Mexican police, said Terry Kincaid, an FBI agent in El Paso, Texas, just across the U.S. border from Juarez. ``We've got a federal hold on him on a bank robbery charge,'' Edwards said. Echevarria had been sought since Monday, when FBI agent John Bailey was gunned down as he tried to halt a robbery at a Security Pacific Bank branch several blocks east of the Las Vegas Strip. Carlos Guerri Rubio, 27, originally identified by police as Gurry, was arrested on a murder warrant two hours after Bailey died. Police had emphasized Monday and Tuesday that Echevarria was wanted only for questioning and was not a suspect in the killing. Edwards hedged on that statement following Echevarria's arrest. ``We've obtained a lot of information since last night as to the activity of both suspects the day of the robbery,'' Edwards said today. He would not elaborate. Edwards said police received information Tuesday that Echevarria was in Mexico. Bailey, 47, was shot and killed when he happened on the robbery while serving a subpoena at the bank. A motorcycle belonging to Echevarria was found in front of the bank. Echevarria, who fled from Cuba to Florida on an inner tube raft in 1987, was Guerri's roommate. Edwards said Bailey was clutching personal papers belonging to Guerri following Monday's shooting. Police first said Bailey had a robbery suspect on the bank floor, then was knocked against a wall before he was shot. On Tuesday they said Bailey confronted the robber and managed to sit him down in a chair in the lobby. The agent asked a bank teller to get a pair of handcuffs from his car and was in the process of going through the suspect's billfold for identification when the robber reached for a gun and fired, hitting Bailey three times in the body and arms, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Forecasting Gauge Up 0.8 Percent
With AM-Taxes-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge climbed 0.8 percent to a new high in May, the government reported Wednesday in a new sign the nation's longest peacetime expansion will last at least through the end of its seventh year. However, the report also pointed to a sobering new dropoff in consumer confidence, and one analyst said the economy ``could be close to a recession by the end of the year.'' The Commerce Department said its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, rose to 146.2 percent of its 1982 base. The previous record of 146.0 was set in January 1989. But analysts attributed the improvement mainly to overseas demand for U.S. products and said U.S. consumer spending remains weak. Some suggested that because of consumer restraint, economic growth could slow further in the months ahead. Indeed, the largest negative in the report was an index measuring consumer confidence, which fell back from a slim advance in April. It also had been negative in January and February and unchanged in March. Other recent Commerce Department reports and a national survey earlier this month by the Federal Reserve also point to a slowdown in consumer spending which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. ``Consumers are getting to be a lot more cautious than they have been,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``The main reason they're retrenching is they are weighed down by the debt they piled up during the 1980s.'' David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities firm, also said consumers also are beginning to worry about their job outlook and ``a constant barrage'' of unfavorable economic news. But analysts said exports appear to be picking up the slack, stimulating the manufacturing sector which has been sluggish for months. Overall, the economy grew at only a 1.1 percent annual rate in the last quarter of 1989 and just a 1.3 percent rate in the first three months of this year, though that was enough to keep alive the expansion that began in November 1982. ``The May leading indicators show that except for housing and construction, the production side of the economy is beginning to recover,'' said William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Steinberg agreed, but said: ``It's principally the export industries that are doing well right now. And that's principally the high technology companies like computers, and the aircraft industry.'' And Jones questioned whether economic growth could continue without a strong consumer contribution. Without it, he said, ``the economy could be close to a recession by the end of the year.'' A consensus forecast of prominent economists surveyed earlier this month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators of Sedona, Ariz., is for 1990 growth of just 1.9 percent, down from 3 percent last year and 4.4 percent in 1988. Nevertheless, any growth at all would be welcome news for White House and congressional leaders who resumed negotiations Wednesday on reducing the federal deficit in fiscal 1991. A recession would make their task much more difficult since it would mean a loss of jobs and incomes, diminished corporate profits and a drop in tax revenues. At the same time, the government would be called upon to increase spending on various benefits. Seven of the 11 leading indicators were positive in May _ a longer average workweek, an increase in the price of raw materials, a larger amount of orders for consumer goods, higher stock prices, a decrease in the weekly unemployment claims, slower business delivery times and an increase in orders for new plants and equipment. In addition to the drop in consumer confidence, the other negatives were a decrease in the money supply, a smaller number of building permits and a drop in manufacturers' unfilled orders.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Out Psychological Testimony in Central Park Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Wednesday testimony; picks up 4th graf, `During jury...'; subs last 5 grafs to CORRECT witness' name to Malone sted Maloney.
DOC.TEXT: A man who said he escaped a rampaging mob of youths the night a young woman jogger was gang-raped and left for dead in Central Park testified today that he recognized a shirt worn by one of the suspects. It was the first time during the trial of three youths charged in the attack that a witness provided any link to any of the defendants. The three are charged with rape and attempted murder, based in part on admissions they made to police after arrest. On Tuesday the judge said he would not let defense lawyers introduce IQ tests and psychological evidence suggesting that their teen-age clients confessed to crimes they didn't commit. The witness, Gerald Malone, was shown a photograph of several youths on Tuesday by an attorney for defendant Raymond Santana. The picture was taken after the young men were arrested in the case. Malone failed to identify any of the youths by face but under questioning by Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer told jurors he recognized the shirt, which had a large white logo, worn by one of the teen-agers. The shirt was being worn by Keith Richardson, one of three additional defendants in the case who will stand trial later this year. Malone said the shirt was ``similar'' to the one he saw on one of the youths who tried to attack him as he and his fiance were riding a tandem bike through the park. On Tuesday, Justice Thomas Galligan of the state Supreme Court, New York's trial-level court, refused to admit reports from psychologists who examined defendants Antron McCray, 15, Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16. During jury selection, each defense lawyer suggested that his client had succumbed to lies, trickery and intimidation, and one alluded to how prisoners of war confess to things of which they are not guilty. ``Some people have a tendency to act under pressure,'' said Michael Joseph, McCray's lawyer. ``I felt it was important for the jury to know how my client scored on his intelligence tests, his IQ,'' Joseph said. ``On the one end you have an Alan Dershowitz, and on the other end you have my client. He's no Dershowitz.'' Dershowitz is a Harvard law professor and eminent defense attorney. The teen-agers allegedly were part of a larger gang of youths who rampaged through Central Park, randomly assaulting or trying to assault at least eight people they encountered. A witness testified Tuesday that he and his fiancee narrowly escaped that night from a mob of 30 or 40 teen-agers _ the same group prosecutors say attacked the jogger about 30 minutes later. The jogger, an investment banker who was then 28, was gang-raped, beaten, and left for dead in a puddle of mud and blood. She suffered brain damage and cannot recall what happened to her that night, Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer told the jury. Malone, 35, an advertising executive, testified that he and his fiancee, Patricia Dean, were riding a tandem bicycle in the park that night when they spotted the mob. ``They were spread out over the road, and they were making noise. They were making grunting sounds, yelling,'' he said. Malone said he and Dean pedaled quickly through the group and escaped, then called police. Malone said he was unable to recognize any of the gang members. The youths are being tried in an adult court, but if convicted face sentencing as juveniles to up to 10 years in prison. Three other teen-agers face trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Emir of Kuwait Cancels Feast Ceremonies in Sympathy With Iran
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The emir of Kuwait has canceled ceremonies marking the Moslem Eid al-Adha feast in deference to the victims of the Iranian earthquake, an official announcement said Wednesday. ``In sympathy with the plight of the Moslem people of neighboring Iran following the disastrous earthquake which claimed thousand of victims, the Emiri Court announces that the emir will not receive well-wishers as usual for Eid al-Adha,'' said the announcement. Each year, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, like leaders in the rest of the conservative countries on the Arabian Peninsula, marks Eid al-Adha by receiving long lines of well-wishes at his palace. Eid al-Adha, or the Feast of Sacrifice, falls Monday and commemorates the Prophet Abraham's readiness to sacrifice his son to God. Sheik Jaber's gesture follows the improvement in Kuwaiti relations with Iran since the end of the Iran-Iraq war. During the eight-year war, Kuwait was the target of Iranian missile and ship attacks because Iran accused it of supporting Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-liver Transplant Patient Battles Hepatitis
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was in serious condition Wednesday as she battled hepatitis infecting her second transplanted liver. Stormie, 13, of White Settlement, Texas, had been listed in fair condition when she was admitted Saturday to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh for testing. Her condition was downgraded Tuesday when doctors said tests confirmed she had hepatitis. Stormie received injections Wednesday to fight the hepatitis, and doctors slightly reduced her anti-rejection medication to enable her body to combat the infection, said hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo. Ms. Cardillo said doctors were ``fairly optimistic'' they could fight the infection with medication. ``Stormie looks good. She feels good. She doesn't like getting shots, but otherwise she's doing fine,'' she said. Infectious hepatitis, a viral infection that inflames the liver, had damaged her first transplanted liver. It was replaced in February. Last month, Stormie suffered mild liver rejection and returned to Pittsburgh for tests. Doctors then also adjusted the dosage of her anti-rejection medication. On Feb. 14, 1984, Stormie became the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient during an operation at Children's Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: our findings.
DOC.TEXT: In a separate case, the court refused to reinstate an Idaho woman's child-abuse conviction thrown out by the state's highest court because the child did not testify. Rather, a pediatrician testified at the trial about his interview with the 2-year-old alleged victim.
DOC.HEAD: Idaho v. Wright, Main Opinion Written by Justice Sandra Day
DOC.TEXT: O'Connor: We think the Supreme Court of Idaho properly focused on the presumptive unreliability of the out-of-court statements and on the suggestive manner in which (the pediatrician) conducted the interview. Viewing the totality of the circumstances surrounding the younger daughter's responses to (the doctor's) questions, we find no special reason for supposing that the incriminating statements were particularly trustworthy.
DOC.HEAD: ances surrounding
DOC.TEXT: the making of a statement are the best indicators of reliability, I doubt this is so in every instance. And if it were true in a particular case, that does not warrant ignoring other indicators of reliability such as corroborating evidence, absent some other reason for excluding it. In this case, the younger daughter's statements are corroborated (by other evidence). These facts, coupled with the circumstances surrounding the making of the statements acknowledged by the court as suggesting that the statements are reliable, give rise to a legitimate argument that admission of the statements did not violate the Confrontation Clause.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
High Court Rules Post Offices May Ban Soliciting
DOC.TEXT: Prohibiting people from soliciting on Post Office property does not violate their right of free speech, the Supreme Court said Wednesday. The justices voted 5-4 to reinstate the convictions of two political activists who solicited contributions and handed out literature on a sidewalk at the Bowie, Md., post office in 1986. ``We are grateful the Supreme Court has recognized our customers' need for unimpeded access to do business with the Postal Service,'' said post office general counsel Harold Hughes. ``The history of regulation of solicitation in post offices demonstrates the reasonableness of the provision here at issue,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote in the court's main opinion. O'Connor, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia said a sidewalk on post office property is not a traditional public forum where free-speech rights are given enhanced protection. Providing the key fifth vote, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said there was no need to reach that issue because the disputed regulation is a valid one restricting the time, place or manner of speech _ not its content. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens dissented, saying such a sidewalk is a traditional public forum and that the postal regulation is being enforced in a discriminatory way. Marsha Kokinda and Kevin Pearl were arrested outside the Bowie post office Aug. 6, 1986, after they refused to stop their activities from a table they had set up on a sidewalk adjacent to the building. The two are volunteers for the National Democratic Policy Committee, the political arm of an organization headed by political extremist Lyndon LaRouche. They were convicted of violating a federal regulation banning ``soliciting, electioneering, collecting debts, vending and advertising'' on postal property. Although there was no evidence the two had blocked or interfered with people entering or leaving the post office, postal officials had received about 40 complaints before asking Ms. Kokinda and Pearl to leave. The post office in Bowie, like tens of thousands in suburban and rural communities, is a freestanding building with its own sidewalk and parking lot. A municipal sidewalk runs in front of the post office property, separating the parking lot from the street. When the case was argued before the high court in February, a Justice Department lawyer drew a distinction between municipal sidewalks _ where free-speech rights traditionally have broad protections _ and sidewalks on federal property. The court today agreed with that distinction. Justice Department lawyer John Roberts Jr. last February also reported that the regulation is not being enforced against people who hand out leaflets or those who picket, but only against those who solicit immediate contributions. The case is U.S. vs. Kokinda, 88-2031.

DOC.HEAD: China Buys More U.S. Wheat Under Subsidy Program
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 139,400 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said six private exporting companies made the deals under USDA's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for October, he said. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized to be sold to China under EEP on May 2. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 5,050 tons. Dickerson said China has slightly more than 1 million tons remaining in its current allocation. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about els. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $3.21 a bushel, the wheat would have a farm5.1 million bush value of around $16 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $19.82 a ton, or about 54 cents per bushel. DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles and his wife, Diana, will attend the enthronement of Emperor Akihito of Japan in November, Buckingham Palace announced Wednesday. Charles, heir to the British throne, will represent his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, at the Nov. 12 ceremony in Tokyo. The royal couple will be in Japan while Britain is observing Remembrance Sunday, the annual commemoration of the nation's war dead. The royal couple will lay a wreath at the Commonwealth War Graves Cemetery in Yokohama, where more than 1,200 British and other Allied soldiers killed in World War II are buried, the palace said. Charles' father, Prince Philip, attended the funeral of Emperor Hirohito last year. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government resisted demands by British war veterans to boycott the funeral.

The first time Bob Hope entertained in South Carolina, he had to dress in a coal bin. ``I played Orangeburg in 1924,'' Hope said Tuesday from his home in Los Angeles. ``It was one of my very first play dates. I don't remember much about the auditorium, but I remember that coal bin.'' The 87-year-old Hope has made many trips to South Carolina since that first one for a musical more than 65 years ago. His latest will come Tuesday, when he headlines the ``Save the Yorktown'' fund-raiser in Charleston. The Yorktown, a World War II aircraft carrier, is the centerpiece of the Patriots Point Naval and Maritime Museum. A group of retired Navy and Marine Corps officers asked Hope to participate in the fund-raiser because the museum is having financial problems. The carrier, launched in 1943, was in many World War II and Vietnam War battles. It also recovered the crew of Apollo 8, the first manned spacecraft to circle the moon, in 1968. The ship has been docked in Mount Pleasant, a Charleston suburb, since 1975.

``My nose must weigh 50 pounds,'' author Ray Bradbury commented as he stared at a 3,000-pound monument erected in his honor in his hometown. Bradbury, author of such books as ``The Martian Chronicles'' and ``Dandelion Wine,'' was in the Chicago suburb Tuesday for Ray Bradbury Day. A park also was named for Bradbury, 69, who left Waukegan in 1934 when he was 14. The bust of Bradbury is the first planned for the town's ``Walk of Stars.'' Other hometown stars, including the late comedian Jack Benny, Broadway star Jerry Orbach and football great Otto Graham, are to be similarly honored.

Singer Dionne Warwick says AIDS education campaigns must target minorities, and in words that are understandable to those who don't have a high school diploma. The Grammy-winning singer told an international AIDS and ethics forum Tuesday that health officials have reached the educated white, gay male population. ``We must develop new models that are culturally sensitive and community-specific,'' Warwick said in calling for ``bilingual'' AIDS educators who also know the language of the streets. ``Having our health decisions made by Caucasian males, while it has never been satisfactory, is no longer acceptable,'' said Warwick. Warwick and pop music stars Stevie Wonder, Elton John and Gladys Knight raised $2 million for AIDS research with their recording, ``That's What Friends Are For.'' But the singer said she was dissatisfied with how little ended up in the hands of minorities ``because they didn't have a voice.'' She has since established the Warwick Foundation to raise funds for minority AIDS programs.

DOC.HEAD: Rock 'n' Roll Guitarist Changes Name to Rachel
DOC.TEXT: A bass guitarist for a heavy metal band wants to strike a different chord with his name. So ``Skid Row'' band member James Southworth on Tuesday asked a judge to change his name to Rachel Bolan Southworth. Superior Court Judge Francis Piscal said he would approve the name change for the 26-year-old Toms River resident after receiving the necessary papers from county and state authorities. Southworth, who wore rings in each nostril for his day in court, told the judge he wanted to change his name to simplify the use of credit under his stage name of Rachel. He testified that he had no outstanding debts or obligations, and no criminal record. Outside the courtroom, Southworth would not say why a heavy metal musician would want his fans to yell for Rachel. ``This is my personal life,'' he said. ``I'm trying not to make a big deal of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Scorched: Planes Grounded, Crops Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with record electrical use in Los Angeles, reason for planes being unable to take off safely, RECAST lead. Picks up 10th graf: `Phoenix natives. ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PN1, PN2
DOC.TEXT: Little relief was forecast today as America's hottest city got hotter than ever _ 122 degrees _ overheating cars and preventing planes from taking off safely. The same heat wave sent the temperature to 112 Tuesday in Los Angeles, also an all-time record. ``This is going to finish up the strawberries,'' said Ben Hillbrecht, a grower near Escondido, Calif. ``And the boysenberries will cook right on the vine.'' Authorities said they suspected three deaths in Phoenix and one in Los Angeles were heat-related. In Tonto National Forest, 90 miles northeast of Phoenix, six firefighters were killed and five injured Tuesday while fighting a 1,900-acre wildfire. It was not immediately known if the heat played a role in the tragedy. The temperature topped 106 in Payson, 12 miles from the fire area. Electricity use in Los Angeles skyrocketed to an all-time high along with the mercury, as residents attempted to quell the scorching heat with air conditioners, the city's Department of Water and Power reported. The demand topped 5,000-megawatts passing the 4,991-megawatt mark of Sept. 6, 1988. The National Weather Service predicted it would be just about as hot today in the Southwest. Only slight cooling was expected by the weekend as a high-pressure system held fast over New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado and Utah. Tuesday's high in Phoenix broke a day-old record. Monday's high of 120 surpassed the old record of 118, equaled most recently on July 4, 1989. The city's normal high for June 26 is 105. This morning's low fell only to 93 degrees, and the weather service expected the 116-degree record high for this date to be easily broken. During the worst of the heat, jetliners were grounded at Sky Harbor Airport because the manuals that specify takeoff speeds and maximum loads at different temperatures stop at 120 degrees. No one contemplated jetliners encountering higher temperatures at major airports, airport spokesman Rick Martinez said. America West and Southwest airlines, the airport's major carriers, contacted the Boeing Corp. in Seattle for emergency charts to use in takeoffs of Boeing 737-200s, their most widely used airliner, and Boeing engineers worked out the new specifications, he said. Martinez said the heat reduced lift for all aircraft. ``The hotter it is, the tougher it is for a jet to take off,'' Martinez said. Phoenix natives pride themselves on their resistance to heat, but out-of-towners were shocked by the scorching weather. Emery Jones of Castledale, Utah, drove into town with his wife, Suzanne, in an air-conditioned car. When they stepped out, he said, ``it took our breath away.'' ``We're buried,'' said David Wonnacott, general manager of services and installation for Goettl Air Conditioning. ``There are more calls than we can handle.'' Charlie Blackburn, owner of Sun City Auto Service, said his shop was ``super busy'' servicing automobile air conditioners, replacing radiators and making other heat-related repairs. ``Unfortunately when it's the hottest, we have to work the hardest,'' he said. Fire Department spokesman Steven Jensen said the heat was suspected in the deaths of three men _ one whose body was found in his home Tuesday after he called a doctor Monday night to complain of symptoms of heat exhaustion, another found behind a downtown building, and a third found on a street. In Los Angeles today, the downtown early morning low dipped to 84 about 5 a.m. That would tie the all-time record warmest low, set in September 1939, if the temperature remains above 84 through midnight tonight, according to the National Weather Service. Police said a 4-year-old boy died after he got inside a car parked out of the shade with the windows rolled up. Tuesday's 112-degree high in Los Angeles broke the record of 110 degrees set Sept. 4, 1988. Southern Californians streamed to beaches, where temperatures were more than 20 degrees lower than inland. Lifeguards reported nearly 100,000 people at Santa Monica, 150,000 at Hermosa Beach and 40,000 at Zuma Beach. ``This is our season,'' laughed Marilyn Novak, marketing director for Baskin-Robbins ice cream stores. ``These will be record-breaking days for our stores, believe me,'' she said from company headquarters in Glendale, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Warrant Issued for Arrest of Officer Accused of Cover-Up in Jesuit Massacre
DOC.TEXT: An arrest warrant was issued today for an army officer accused of destroying evidence in the November massacre of six Jesuit priests, their cook and her teen-age daughter. The warrant for Lt. Col. Carlos Camilo Hernandez was issued by Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is handling the politically-charged investigation. The charges accuse Camilo Hernandez of destroying the mission logs of troops accused of the shooting. Camilo, now an executive officer of the elite Belloso Battalion in the capital, is the former assistant director of the military college where the troops were stationed. The director of the college, Col. Guilllermo Benavides, three lieutenants and five enlisted men have already been charged with the murders. The massacre took place during a large-scale offensive by leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN. Army positions at the college had come under fire several times. Six priests, their housekeeper and her 15-year-old daughter were roused from their sleep before dawn on Nov. 16 and killed by troops of the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion. Two of three lieutenants leading the death squad said Benavides issued a direct order to kill the priests. The investigation has moved slowly and there have been reports that crucial evidence has been destroyed, that military witnesses have been given assignments abroad to keep them from testifying and that the masterminds of the slayings were being protected. The far right considered the left-leaning Jesuit academics subversive because they blamed social injustice, rather than international Communist expansion, for El Salvador's 10-year-old revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Muscular Dystrophy Treatment Held to be Feasible, Safe
DOC.TEXT: Researchers who injected millions of immature muscle cells into muscular dystrophy patients said Wednesday the experimental treatment has proven safe and feasible. The injections went into the biceps, making the new work the first to show safety and feasibility for treating a large muscle, the Muscular Dystrophy Association said. But Dr. George Karpati of the Montreal Neurological Institute said it will take months to find out whether the experimental therapy succeds in improving muscle strength. Karpati, who led the research team, spoke in a telephone interview before announcing results at a news conference. The experimental procedure is aimed at Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a genetic muscle-destroying disease that disables in childhood and usually kills in young adulthood from destruction of respiratory muscles. In the treatment, immature muscle cells called myoblasts are injected into a patient's muscle. The hope is that the myoblasts will supply muscle fibers with a gene to produce dystrophin, a protein the fibers lack. Loss of this protein leads to the disease. Earlier this month, researchers said the procedure spurred dystrophin production in a patient's big toe. Karpati said the new experiment was on a larger scale, involving 50 to 60 injections into a larger muscle, and delivering 60 million myoblasts throughout each treated bicep. One patient was treated in April and two others later, Karpati said. The boys are ages 6 and 8. The myoblasts were generated from muscle samples, no bigger than a pencil eraser, taken from the boys' fathers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Broadcasters Cheered by Supreme Court Ruling
With AM-Scotus Affirmative Action, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Minority broadcasters said Wednesday's Supreme Court decision upholding the Federal Communications Commission's affirmative action rules will spur efforts to increase minority ownership of radio and TV stations. James L. Winston, executive director of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said the decision ``means the FCC's ability to help promote minority ownership can now go forward without fear of constitutional challenge. ``While this still ... is not at the level we would like to see, we are pleased that the ability of the FCC to utilize policies to increase ownership will be allowed to continue and expand.'' Before the FCC established the rules in 1978, blacks owned about 30 radio stations and one television station, according to the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters. Now, blacks own 182 radio stations and 17 television stations, the group said Wednesday. That represents an increase from 1 percent to about 3.5 percent of the nation's radio and TV stations, the FCC said. Those numbers are likely to grow now that the legal uncertainties have been lifted from the rules, broadcasters said. Eddie Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said the decision ``affirms the FCC's ability to improve the under-representation of minorities in broadcast ownership.'' Lois Wright, vice president and corporate counsel for one of the nation's largest black-owned broadcasting companies, Inner City Broadcasting Corp. in New York City, said the FCC rules have been working effectively and ``I think they'll work more effectively now. ... You're likely to get more deals'' involving minority broadcasters. The rules upheld Wednesday award preference to minorities seeking broadcast licenses. The FCC ``comparative'' licensing process also gives preference to competing applicants based on other factors, such as whether prospective owners plan to operate the station. Female applicants also receive extra points, but the court said it was not ruling on gender preference. The court Wednesday also upheld separate rules, known as the ``distress sale'' policy, that allow a broadcaster faced with the loss of his license to sell to a minority-owned business at 75 percent of a station's market value. ``I'm overjoyed,'' said Kernie Anderson, general manager of WDAS-AM-FM in Philadelphia. ``This reflects a continuation of a policy that has benefited not only African-Americans but women and the entire nation. It has made for greater diversity in our industry,'' Anderson said. ``For the Supreme Court to uphold the righteousness of what indeed was a just action by the commission ... is appreciated by an African-American,'' Anderson said. WDAS was one of the first stations sold under the distress sale policy. FCC policy also allows anyone who sells a radio or TV station or cable system to defer capital gains taxes on the sale if the buyer is a member of a minority. This so-called tax certificate policy was not in question Wednesday at the court.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Tested Explosive on Airliner, TV Documentary Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS semtex to Semtex in grafs 1,3,16,17 and 18. For Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT Wednesday, Time Set By Source
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's internal security agency tested Semtex on a passenger aircraft in 1984 and found that just seven ounces of the explosive could destroy a plane in flight, according to a British television documentary. Semtex has been implicated in the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988, in which 270 people died. The hour-long ``This Week'' documentary for Thames Television, scheduled for broadcast Thursday night, shows spectacular explosions filmed by the former marketing director at the factory that produced Semtex. The tests in October and November of 1984 were an anti-terrorist exercise, said Maj. Zbynek Hybl, identified as a member of the parliamentary ``special operations group'' allied with the Czechoslovak secret police. Hybl said only four other people were involved in the tests, which were conducted on a Soviet-built Ilyushin 18. He said the results were not passed to any terrorist group. Paul Wilkinson, professor of international relations at St. Andrews University in Scotland and an expert on terrorism, said in a telephone interview that Czechoslovakia had no need for an anti-terrorist program. ``There was never a terrorist threat within Czechoslovakia's borders, nor had a Czech aircraft ever been threatened by attack with a sabotage bomb,'' Wilkinson said. Czechoslovakia's previous communist government ``had a reputation for passing on specialized knowledge not only to their own operatives, but on a very selective basis to chosen proxies and clients, which I assume _ and I think most students of the subject assume _ had to be approved at a very high level, with the knowledge and consent of the KGB,'' he said. Semtex is made only in Czechoslovakia, and President Vaclav Havel has confirmed that the previous Communist regime sold nearly 1,000 tons of it to the government of Libya's Col. Moammar Gadhafi. The documentary says Hybl's ``special operations group'' was based in Brezany Castle, near Prague, where the Interior Ministry also had a training program for Third World security agents. ``We wanted to find out what strength of charge you would need to blow a hole through the fuselage of the plane,'' said Hybl, whose remarks were translated by Thames Television. ``That was the most important piece of information we needed. We tried every explosive we could get hold of, everything from military to civilian... ``As far as the Czechoslovakian explosives we had were concerned, we discovered that a charge weighing 200 grams (seven ounces) would be more than enough to blow a hole in the fuselage which would be large enough to cause the plane to decompress in flight.'' Those tests produced jagged holes about the size of a dinner plate in the plane. Scottish police have said Pan Am Flight 103, a Boeing 747, was destroyed by a small amount of explosive hidden in a radio-cassette player.
