The documentary shows 8mm color film taken by Bohumile Sole, who said he retired last year as the Semtex factory's marketing director. ``They said they wanted me to teach them how to work with Semtex because they had not worked with Semtex before,'' Sole said. ``They didn't even know how to design a charge. So, they simply wanted to know how effective Semtex was, what its characteristics were, when it was applied to various parts of the aircraft.'' Wilkinson said much is still unknown about the assistance that Communist governments gave terrorist groups. Hungarian Interior Minister Balazs Horvath said Tuesday that the former Communist leadership had sheltered Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, the terrorist known as Carlos who organized an attack on OPEC headquarters in Vienna in 1975. Former Interior Minister Andras Benkei described the charge as ``nonsense.'' East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel has said former Communist leader Erich Honecker and his security chief made hospitality to West German terrorists a ``personal hobby.'' Information provided by a former high-ranking East German secret police officer recently has led to the arrest of nine suspected members of the Red Army Faction.

DOC.HEAD: Commentators Welcome Bush's Concession, Markets Have Mixed Reaction
With AM-Bush-Taxes Reax, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign commentators on Wednesday welcomed President Bush's concession on tax increases but expressed skepticism that the huge U.S. budget deficit would be reduced substantially. Financial markets had a mixed and slightly nervous reaction. The dollar fell against other major currencies around the globe. Stock prices soared in Tokyo, and European stock markets shrugged off the news. Abandoning his ``read-my-lips: no-new-taxes'' campaign pledge, Bush on Tuesday conceded that higher taxes would be required to get the deficit under control. The White House would not specify any tax increases or program cuts. The U.S. deficit could total more than $200 billion in the next fiscal year. U.S. trading partners for years have clamored for the United States to cut its red ink, which pushes U.S. interest rates higher. That puts upward pressure on foreign interest rates. High rates anywhere slow economic growth. ``At economic summit after economic summit we have consistently called for imbalances to be corrected,'' a British government official said on condition of anonymity. ``I would have thought that he (Bush) would get more accolades from abroad than at home.'' The news was prominently displayed in the foreign press. Under the headline ``Read My Lips (Again),'' The Times of London editorialized: ``Given the stake held by the rest of the world in the orderly cutting of a deficit that is plainly out of control, a sigh of relief is called for.'' Some newspapers couldn't resist a dig. The financial page of Amsterdam's De Volkskrant newspaper cynically wrote the top of its lead story like a fairy tale: ``Once upon a time he told the American people he would resist with all his might any increase in taxes.'' The Milan daily Corriere della Sera's headline said in part: ``To Contain the Deficit, He Has to Eat His Words.'' The dollar fell on the prospect that tax increases would lower U.S. interest rates. Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank in Tokyo, said: ``Japanese investors now think the U.S. monetary policy is moving toward relaxation.'' A trader in Milan said: ``We're seeing small, nervous movements, but no big swings. The Europeans are going to let the United States decide in which direction to send the dollar.'' Ian Francis, a director at Morgan Grenfell and Co. in London, said the foreign exchange market might have overreacted. The U.S. Federal Reserve Board is unlikely to do an about-face on its tight monetary stand on the basis of Bush's turnaround, he said. Meanwhile, the news helped send the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, soaring 740.98 points, or 2.29 percent, to close at 32,312.75. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 26.3 points, or 1.1 percent, at 2,373.5. Traders mostly cited concern about weakness in the stock index futures market. But traders also said there was concern that Bush's statement would lead to a lower dollar, which in turn could hurt the profits of dollar-earning companies. The Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Milan and Paris stock markets showed little reaction. Geoffrey Dennis, chief international economist at James Capel and Co. in London, said he expects the Bush administration to leave income taxes alone, and instead raise tobacco and alcohol duties. But that won't be enough, he said. ``When this comes down to it, we will still be faced with a huge budget cutting task,'' Dennis said. The Times of London concluded that Bush must resist a renewed urge to spend. ``He should do so with all the political strength he has: economic stability across the world depends on it,'' the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Official Says Anti-Gorbachev Tide Unlikely at Congress
With AM-Soviet-Debt, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite the rise of conservative foes, a top official said Wednesday it is unlikely next week's pivotal gathering of Soviet Communists will be postponed or will turn against Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Vadim A. Medvedev, the party's ideology chief and member of its Politburo, also said the platform and rules that the party leadership will propose to the congress have been reworked in response to criticism from both left and right. In the new documents, the party takes a repentant tone about its blame for the country's ills. Medvedev's comments, and the revisions of the main congress documents just four days before the 4,700 delegates converge on Moscow, showed the leadership's deep concern about keeping the party together. Reformers say conservative foes of Gorbachev could dominate the gathering, undermine him as he tries to pull the country out of a deep economic and political crisis, and force progressives to quit the party. The reform-minded president of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin, urged Tuesday that the 28th Communist Party Congress be postponed until autumn to ``stabilize the political situation.'' Medvedev said other Communist officials also want to delay the congress, now scheduled to start Monday, because there have been too many political meetings lately. But he said a delay was unlikely. ``I believe the train has already left the station, and we should stick to the original date,'' he told a news conference. He added that the leadership had contacted delegates across the nation, and most oppose a delay. The issue is expected to come up Friday at a meeting of the party's 249-member policy-making Central Committee. That body will review the timing of the congress and discuss the main congress documents, Medvedev said. Yeltsin has predicted ``a real struggle'' at the Central Committee meeting over the congress timing. A postponement could prevent hard-liners from capitalizing on their successes last week at a meeting of party members from the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic. Some traditional-minded Soviet Communists demand the resignation of Gorbachev, who holds the posts of Soviet president and general secretary of the Communist Party, but occupies a shrinking middle ground in Soviet politics. But Medvedev told reporters he was confident that supporters of Gorbachev's perestroika, or reform program, would gain the upper hand. ``We expect healthy perestroika forces to take care of that. ... I am convinced those forces are in the majority,'' he said. He declined to predict how Gorbachev would fare if his most prominent conservative foe, Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, ran against him for party chief at the congress. Under draft rules that may be changed in a revision to be published Thursday, the congress would be urged to eliminate the position of party general secretary, the post Gorbachev now holds, and replace it with a chairman. It also would elect a new Central Committee and could be called upon to replace the 12-man Politburo with a larger, more representative body. Despite uncertainty surrounding the congress, the Central Committee published a ``program statement'' Wednesday that the congress will be asked to approve. Medvedev said the party's positions, originally published in February, were revised after consultations with representatives of the Democratic Platform and Marxist Platform, progressive and conservative groups, respectively. The program, spread across almost two pages of the Communist Party daily Pravda, pays tribute to Communist idols Marx, Lenin and Engels, but not Marxism-Leninism, the way of thinking long at the basis of Soviet ideology. It emphasizes instead that good ideas should be drawn from all currents of thought. The Soviet Union's main problem, it says, is the previous distortion of socialism. ``False ideas about socialism as a society based on the state monopoly on property, and dictatorship led by the party-state brass in the name of the proletariat, led to tyranny and lawlessness and the alienation of people from property and authority,'' the committee said. The program also: _Says party units should be allowed to remain in the KGB and army, but should be clearly separate from the basic power structure. _Backs many of Gorbachev's reforms already under way, including the transition to a market economy and the party's rejection of its former political monopoly. _Proposes more independence for party organizations in the 15 Soviet republics, and allows for the possibility of various platforms in the party without actually approving full-fledged factions.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Accuses Former Leaders of Sheltering Terrorists
DOC.TEXT: The interior minister on Wednesday accused the former Communist leaders of harboring terrorists, including the mastermind of a 1975 attack on an OPEC meeting in Vienna that killed three people. The Cabinet minister, Balasz Horvath, said three documents from the former Communist government indicated the terrorists used Hungary as a base. Horvath ordered an investigation into the responsibilities of Communist officials in sheltering terrorists. Three former Communist officials named by Horvath _ former Interior Minister Andras Benkei, former President Karoly Nemeth and high-ranking party official Antal Gyenes _ have denied any knowledge of or role in sheltering terrorists. Unlike other Eastern European countries where Communists were removed from power, in Hungary no Communist leader has been arrested or charged in connection with activities during 45 years of Communist rule. Horvath said it was ``obviously a political decision to let these people (terrorists) come and stay in Hungary.'' ``It remains to be proved that they were undergoing training here, but the inventory seems to point in a certain direction,'' he told reporters. He did not elaborate. He said Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, alias Carlos, who masterminded the OPEC attack, was among those who had been in Hungary. Ramirez Sanchez has been blamed for a series of assassinations. In 1975, he headed Interpol's most-wanted list. Horvath said the deputy national police chief, Andras Turos, went to him with the information over the weekend. He said the government documents included a 1979 Interior Ministry report on the arrival of Carlos and his group and a 1980 ministry report saying the terrorists left behind explosives, guns, rockets and rocket launchers. Horvath said it is not known where the group obtained these items. He said a 1980 letter from Carlos to former Communist Party leader Janos Kadar thanked Kadar for allowing the group to use Hungary as a base. Benkei was quoted by the Nepszava newspaper on Wednesday as saying, ``This must be a misunderstanding. I did not deal with such matters. I retired in 1980. Hiding people? Nonsense. Lies.'' Nepszabadsag, which used to be the organ of the Communist Party, stated that according to their information, Carlos and his associates were indeed in Hungary in those years. Citing a ``well-informed'' but unnamed source, the paper stated that ``a very small circle of leaders knew about the authorization, and their stay was ... (safeguarded by) state security organs.'' ``According to the information we have, their stay was not linked to any terrorist action, but was to provide the terrorists rest and recreation,'' Nepszabadsag reported Wednesday. Another Budapest daily, Magyar Hirlap, said Wednesday that there had been a terrorist training camp at Csopak, on the northern shore of Lake Balaton, but provided no further information. Horvath told reporters that there has been no evidence uncovered so far that Carlos and his group were in Csopak.

DOC.HEAD: Death Count Rises to 10 in Loan Office Killings
DOC.TEXT: A worker who was wounded last week when a gunman opened fire in a loan office died Wednesday, raising the death toll to 10. Jewell Belote, 50, a stenographer at the General Motors Acceptance Corp., died from complications at University Medical Center, said Vince Scolaro, a hospital spokesman. The 10 dead include James Edward Pough, who turned the .30-caliber rifle on himself after his June 18 rampage. Four other people were wounded. GMAC repossessed Pough's car in January, then notified him in March that he still owed $6,394, the difference between the car's resell value and the amount of the loan. Pough also killed two people and wounded two others on Jacksonville streets during the weekend preceeding the office shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Fire on Demonstrators; Five Reported Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers shot into a crowd of demonstrators Wednesday who were demanding the president resign, and doctors said five people were critically wounded. The army said the shootings were a ``mistake.'' The troops opened fire when more than 5,000 unarmed civilians tried to march past the main Barclay Training Center army base to President Samuel Doe's residence. They were demanding that Doe resign to end a 6-month-old civil war in which many civilians have died. Lt. Gen. Henry Dubar, commander of Doe's forces, said the soldiers heard gunfire and feared rebels were attacking the president's residence, so they began shooting. Doctors at JFK Hospital in Monrovia said five people were admitted with critical injuries. Dubar called the incident ``a mistake.'' The government also announced the execution of a private convicted of killing a Liberian civilian in April. Doe's troops have been accused of killing hundreds of civilians in their effort to halt rebels who have advanced to within 15 miles of the capital. The government has repeatedly promised to punish soldiers convicted of harming civilians, but this was the first known execution. Reporters who sought shelter in a shantytown near the Barclay Training Center barracks heard numerous commands to cease-fire during the shooting. But the commands were followed by bursts of gunfire from M-16 rifles and screams from protesters and other civilians. Some witnesses, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they saw several demonstrators fall. Some apparently fell into open drains during a stampede to escape. Other witnesses said they saw soldiers beating marchers at the front of the procession with rifle butts. The march, the second in as many days, was organized by the Citizens' Committee for Democracy and Peace, which includes members of student unions, trade unions and civic organizations. Rebels who have captured most of the country since they began fighting in December are demanding Doe's resignation. Protesters have taken up that rallying cry, hoping such a move will end the fighting. Gunshots could be heard all over Monrovia more than an hour after the incident, including in the plush Mamba Point suburb where the U.S. and other embassies are located. A few hundred yards from the U.S. Embassy, soldiers commandeered two cars and drive up and down the street, leaning out of the windows and a sunroof, firing occasional shots into the air. Thousands of people marched down Monrovia's main avenue on Tuesday, demanding Doe's resignation, but soldiers barred them from going near Doe's palace. Tuesday's march, headed by Christian and Moslem leaders, was the first demonstration in Monrovia calling for Doe's resignation. The president has refused rebel demands that he leave office immediately, but he has agreed not to run for re-election next year. The rebels, led by former Doe aide Charles Taylor, accuse the government of corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Unsolicited Advice For Ivana: Split!
DOC.TEXT: Ivana Trump, her family demoted to a $450,000 monthly allowance because of The Donald's financial pickle, should bail out before she goes down with the yacht, says one celebrity divorce lawyer. ``She should proceed to grab the money and run,'' attorney Raoul Felder said Wednesday. ``The real problem is, I don't know if she can grab the money any more. ... She's got to have the board of directors of various banks decide whether to give her the $25 million.'' John Scanlon, a spokesman for Mrs. Trump, said she had no plans to drop her lawsuit demanding half of her debt-ridden, estranged husband's assets. She is contesting a premarital agreement that reportedly would give her $25 million, plus a $7 million mansion. ``It was only a few months ago, when Mr. Trump's marital problems were making news, that the general opinion was that his wife, Ivana, had made a bad deal when she agreed to take only $25 million in case of a divorce,'' observed The New York Times. ``That no longer seems so paltry.'' ``She's painted into a corner; there are a lot of creditors who have to be paid,'' said Felder. ``If I were her adviser, I would tell her, `You have a wonderful world to conquer.' All the glitter has gone out of Trump and now is floating around her.'' In fact, Felder suggests that the timing is right for Mrs. Trump to cash in on her own cachet: for instance, as a spokeswoman for a cosmetics firm. Whether Mrs. Trump gets wind of Felder's advice or not, her accountants should be relieved that it's free. The flamboyant divorce lawyer, who has represented the ex-wives of Mike Tyson, Mel Brooks, Martin Scorsese and Robin Leach, among others, charges $500 an hour. ``She's had a significant number of offers for business opportunities in the licensing field and product endorsements,'' said Scanlon. ``Right now, she's getting her children settled for the summer. She'll look at those in the fall.'' Mrs. Trump's own attorney, Michael Kennedy, doesn't discuss her case with reporters. It's public knowledge, though, that a group of banks will closely monitor Donald Trump's personal and business dealings for years to come as a condition of a $65 million bailout announced Tuesday. The banks crimped the family's monthly allowance to $450,000 and will pare it to $300,000 by 1992. In comparison, Trump reportedly had $583,000 in personal expenses in May _ not counting the $841,000 maintenance on his boat and the $246,000 upkeep on his private plane.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Financed Relief Flight Dispatched to Iran
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-financed plane load of relief supplies worth $470,000 was dispatched Wednesday from Basel, Switzerland, for victims of the Iranian earthquake, U.S. officials said. Included in the cargo, purchased and flown to Iran by the Red Cross, were five electrical generators, 645 tents and $20,000 worth of antibiotics and other medical supplies. The assistance is the second round of American government assistance. Earlier this week, the Red Cross flew to Iran $225,000 worth of U.S.-donated blankets, tents, water jugs and search-and-rescue equipment. Meanwhile, private U.S. humanitarian organizations have dispatched an additional $1.7 million in assistance for victims of the earthquake, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. Ms. Tutwiler said she knew of no direct contacts between U.S. and Iranian officials on the aid. ``We're doing it all through the Red Cross'' and through the Swiss Embassy in Tehran, which represents U.S. interests there, she added. ``My understanding of how all of this is working is that they (the Iranians) are ... making their needs known through the Red Crescent Society to the Red Cross and (that) various countries, including our own, ... are responding based on those needs,'' she said. She said she kne of no additional flights of relief supplies, but added that she ``can't rule out that another request will come in and that we would certainly fill it.'' The Iranian government has agreed to accept assistance from the United States and most other governments but it insists the assistance be channeled through the Red Cross or other private relief groups. The Iranian foreign minister has said his country welcomes help due to the magnitude of the earthquake, in which an estimated 50,000 people died, 200,000 were injured and a half-million have been left homeless. The United States broke relations with Iran in 1980 after the seizure of the U.S. Embassy and the taking of American hostages in November 1979. The last 52 were released in January 1981. Six Americans are now being held hostage in Lebanon by militants believed to be under Iranian influence.

DOC.HEAD: Political Pressure Forces Mandela To Retain Armed Struggle
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite international criticism, Nelson Mandela has not renounced violent struggle against apartheid because of fears of losing black supporters and a major bargaining chip. Mandela's African National Congress says it cannot disavow violence until apartheid is abolished. The ANC says it must keep its armed wing as long as the government and right-wing white groups retain massive military power and unarmed black protesters are being killed. Black leaders caution against comparing the anti-apartheid struggle to the non-violent civil rights movement in the American South in the 1960s. Non-violence is not realistic in a country where the white government has used force for decades to suppress blacks, they say. Civil rights movements in the United States were often aimed at local governments and laws instead of the federal government. Federal courts and troops often acted to protect civil rights activists and restrain local officials and police. Despite controversy in the United States and Europe over Mandela's refusal to renounce violence, the ANC has all but suspended its armed struggle due to several factors. The legalization of the ANC in February, a call for negotiations by President F.W. de Klerk, and reductions in aid from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have led the ANC to stop high-profile attacks. Even before these developments, the ANC's armed struggle never posed a serious threat to the government. Mandela launched the guerrilla campaign in 1961, a year after the ANC was outlawed. But attempts to build an effective military force in South Africa failed because of internal problems and the superiority of security forces. The few attacks blamed on the ANC in recent months have been hit-and-run attacks on police stations or government buildings that caused minor damage. Such attacks appear to be the work of small groups operating independently, and there has been no evidence of the ANC directing any operations. But the armed struggle has had a strong psychological impact on whites and been a major symbol of resistance to many blacks. Young blacks believe the armed struggle has been the one way they have been able to fight apartheid. Mandela risks losing the support of thousands of blacks if he renounces the armed struggle before apartheid is abolished. Such young blacks, hardened by decades of violence and repression, glorify strength and believe only violence can end apartheid. ``Many of the youngsters are not really interested in negotiation. In fact, they have become a little bit angry,'' ANC leader Walter Sisulu said. Radical groups that espouse violence, such as the Pan African Congress, claim they are attracting thousands of former ANC members disillusioned by Mandela's moderate line. The ANC and allied groups are locked in a violent struggle with rival black organizations that has cost thousands of lives. Anti-apartheid leader Archbishop Desmond Tutu and other religious leaders have urged the ANC to at least suspend the armed struggle to help build peace. But the threat of armed struggle is one of the ANC's best bargaining chips in pending negotiations with the government on ending apartheid. The ANC says it cannot renounce violence without similar government concessions. Mandela and other black leaders say the government retains massive military and police power and that blacks are still suffering oppression. Dozens of blacks have been killed by police gunfire in recent months, including at least 11 in one incident. Mandela also points to extreme right-wing groups with thousands of members that are forming paramilitary groups to resist attempts to end white rule. Blacks must be able to defend themselves because the white government will not suppress such groups, he says.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Allows Extradition of Fugitive Greek Banker
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that officials may extradite the Bank of Greece's former chairman, who is accused of embezzling $200 million in a scandal that toppled former Premier Andreas Papandreou. U.S. District Judge Douglas Woodlock upheld a magistrate's ruling that George Koskotas, 35, may be returned to Greece on felony charges brought in the alleged scheme to siphon funds from the bank from 1986 to 1988. Koskotas, who was suspended as chairman Oct. 20, 1988, fled his homeland as the scandal surrounding the Greek socialist government heated up. He was arrested Nov. 23, 1988, at an airfield in Bedford. Woodlock's ruling upheld a magistrate's Aug. 24, 1989, decision that Koskotas could be extradited on felony charges but barred extradition on a misdemeanor travel documents charge. ``It is one more major step ... toward exhausting the legal process in trying to avoid being returned to Greece,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Victor A. Wild said. Koskotas could take his case to the First Circuit Court of Appeals, he said. Koskotas' Washington, D.C.-based attorney, Ron Liebman, was out of town and not immediately available for comment. He has argued that his client would face retribution at home. ``If this court sends Mr. Koskotas back to Greece, he will be murdered,'' Liebman told Magistrate Joyce L. Alexander at last year's extradition hearing. ``The cards are stacked against (him) politically.'' Under the U.S. extradition treaty with Greece, courts can refuse to return people accused of political crimes. But prosecutors have argued that Koskotas' alleged financial scheme does not fit into this category. The ``Koskotas Affair'' paved the way to Papandreou's election defeat last June amid allegations of corruption among officials in the ruling Panhellenic Socialist Movement. The former premier has been accused of authorizing Koskotas' scheme to siphon money from the Bank of Crete. The banker has said he acted with Papandreou's approval and put the money into accounts controlled by the socialist party. A special investigator in Athens has been examining the alleged involvement of Papandreou and four other former government ministers. The Greek parliament last September indicted all five men in the alleged embezzlement scheme. No trial date has been set. Koskotas, who is being held at the Essex County Jail in Salem, also faces a multimillion-dollar civil lawsuit brought by the Bank of Crete in federal court in New York.

DOC.HEAD: California Cigarette Sales Drop Significantly Since Tax Hike
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette sales have dropped 14 percent and state tobacco tax revenues have more than tripled since voters approved a tobacco tax hike in 1988, the American Lung Association announced Wednesday. ``Proposition 99 is doing exactly what the tobacco industry feared most,'' Steve Harmon, the association's state president, said in a statement. ``It is leading to a significant reduction in smoking.'' The state cigarette tax was increased from 10 cents a pack to 35 cents by Proposition 99, which voters approved in November 1988. The sales tax took effect January 1, 1989. Cigarette sales have sinced dropped from $2.54 billion in 1988 to $2.18 billion in 1989, while the state's tobacco tax revenue soared from about $253.8 million in 1988 to $764.4 million in 1989, the association said. Proposition 99 tax revenues are earmarked for anti-smoking programs, medical research, and health care.

DOC.HEAD: County Board Votes Redistricting Plan Ordered in Voting Rights Suit
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors voted 3-2 Wednesday to reshape one of its districts to include a majority of Hispanic voters. The vote came hours before a federal judge's deadline. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon ruled June 4 that supervisors deliberately spread the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries after the 1980 federal census. He said that violated the federal Voting Rights Act, and imposed a deadline for 3 p.m. Wednesday. Supervisor Ed Edelman, whose Third District was restructured, said the new plan ``does great violence to the Hispanic community.'' ``It's not fair to the public, and the court will see that it's unfair,'' he said. ``It's an attempt for the conservative majority to keep control.'' According to Edelman's description of the plan, he would probably face a strong challenge from a Hispanic candidate in future elections. The new, predominantly Hispanic district, which Edelman called ``octopus-shaped,'' includes his own home but transfers much of his liberal political base to the districts of fellow liberal Kenneth Hahn and conservative Deane Dana. Edelman and Hahn had pushed to increase the number of districts to seven to meet Kenyon's demands. The new plan is subject to the judge's approval; he set a July 5 hearing. Kenyon has said that if the plan fails to correct the violations, he will redraw the district in consultation with the plaintiffs. Hispanics make up an estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million residents. But no Hispanic has been elected to the board since 1875. Edelman was re-elected June 5 to a four-year term. Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, which joined the U.S. Justice Department in the lawsuit, said Kenyon's order put the election results in doubt. Kenyon has not said what he plans to do about the June 5 election.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Tests Beetle-Killing Potato Plant
DOC.TEXT: Genetically altered potatoes that could be naturally deadly to beetles are being field tested in the Pacific Northwest, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. The outdoor tests were scheduled to begin this week in Prosser, Wash., said geneticist Charles R. Brown of the department's Agricultural Research Service. ``Ultimately, we want to know whether potato plants could use this genetic weapon to combat Colorado potato beetles with little or no chemical insecticide,'' he said. Brown is based at the agency's vegetable and crop research unit in Prosser and is collaborating with other scientists from the University of Washington, Seattle, and another USDA researcher in Yakima, Wash. The quarter-acre potato plots are at Washington State University's research and extension center in Prosser. Brown said the added gene is from a strain of bacterium, Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bt, that lives in soil naturally and makes a beetle-killing protein. The Prosser tests were said to be the first in the United States involving Bt genes placed in potatoes. Other researchers at private companies and universities, however, have raised tomato, cotton and tobacco plants that use a Bt gene and show pest resistance. Brown said the Colorado potato beetle is ``probably the worst potato insect pest worldwide'' and that it has become resistant to many pesticides.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Officials Offer Plan For Fund to Protect Ozone
DOC.TEXT: Environmental officials proposed a $160 million global fund Wednesday to help developing nations build industries that do not rely on chemicals that damage the Earth's protective ozone layer. They also offered to increase the fund by $80 million if China and India sign a treaty on saving the ozone layer. The two countries have refused to sign the treaty because they fear the high cost of converting to ozone-friendly technology. The unprecedented idea was announced at the start of a conference of environmental ministers and officials from about 100 countries. The fund would be voluntary, but it could become a future model for how to pay for resolving environmental problems. The United States, which until two weeks ago opposed creating such a fund, was posing one of the few obstacles to final agreement. It demanded a permanent seat on the proposed 15-member executive committee that would decide how to use the money. Most delegates favor rotating membership. Richard Smith, who led the U.S. delegation in talks this week that led to the proposal, noted that the United States would contribute about 25 percent of the fund. ``Our position is that any country contributing this much should be (permanently) on the committee,'' he said. Some delegates, speaking privately, said the United States was prepared to compromise and final agreement would be reached by the time the meeting ends Friday. Delegates are representing the 56 countries that signed the Montreal Protocol of 1987. That treaty called for a 50 percent reduction in the manufacture of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, by 1996. The plan for the $160 million global fund was worked out in talks that preceded the formal conference. Dr. Mostafa Tolba, an Egyptian scientist and executive director of the U.N. Environment Program, said delegates proposed increasing the fund by $80 million if China and India signed the Montreal Protocol. ``Far too much is at stake to contemplate failure. We have no option but to succeed and inshallah (God willing) we will succeed,'' he said. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said her government would make an initial contribution of $9 million. ``We need to speed up action and set ourselves higher targets and shorter deadlines for reducing and eventually eliminating CFCs and halons,'' she told delegates. CFCs, used in refrigeration, insulation, cleaning solvents and as aerosol propellents, rise into the stratosphere where they break down in constituent chemical parts. One of these, chlorine, destroys the thin shield of ozone that filters out harmful ultraviolet rays. Scientists say that without the shield, life on Earth would perish. William Reilly, administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, told delegates: ``Scientific research, monitoring, and satellite observations have all left no doubt whatever that the ozone hole is not a theory but a menacing open window to cancers and cataracts, and that that window must be shut.''

DOC.HEAD: Ag Exports To Pacific Rim Rise
DOC.TEXT: U.S. agricultural exports to the major Pacific Rim countries are increasing again this year but the growth is smaller than in 1989, an Agriculture Department report said on Wednesday. Exports to Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan are expected to increase but will not match the 10 percent gain of 1989 or the 28 percent jump in 1988, the department's Economic Research Servce said. Agricultural sales to Canada are expected to rise sharply in the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1 because of a change in the reporting system, the agency said. Sales to Australia and New Zealand probably will increase. ``Economic growth in the developed Pacific Rim slowed for the second straight year in 1989,'' the report said. ``Rising interest and inflation rates, and labor shortages in East Asia are straining the region's economies.'' One factor was a strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen, which possibly dampened demand for American farm products, the report said. Meanwhile, the dollar fell against the currencies of South Korea, Taiwan and Canada, which helped boost export prospects.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Bans New Nuclear Construction in Russian Republic
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin on Wednesday ordered a freeze on new atomic energy projects beginning next year in the Russian republic that comprises three-quarters of the Soviet Union's territory. A directive from the republic's Parliament, signed by Yeltsin as Russian president and distributed by the official news agency Tass, charged that national government ministries are ill-equipped to process and store radioactive wastes. The move highlighted concern about nuclear power in the wake of the 1986 Chernobyl accident, and was the reform-minded Russian president's first direct challenge to the Kremlin since he was elected last month. The directive also called on the Russian republic's government to develop a proposal for banning the burial on Russian territory of radioactive waste from other nations or in the other 14 Soviet republics, also beginning next year. It was not immediately clear whether the order would cause a direct confrontation between Yeltsin's government and national officials over any specific projects. A rising anti-nuclear mood across the entire Soviet Union has forced Soviet officials to delay or cancel several nuclear power plants the last four years. Yeltsin's directive also said the Ministry of the Sea Fleet and the Defense Ministry added to the problem of nuclear waste. The order did not directly say military nuclear projects must be frozen as well, but appeared to include them. The seven-point directive cited increasing stockpiles of radioactive wastes and the ``low technological level of the management approach to solving the problem of gathering, processing and eliminating radioactive wastes.'' It said that combination ``created an unhealthy ecological and social-psychological situation in a series of regions of the Russian republic.'' The directive said the Russian republic would ask that the Kremlin write a program for dealing with radioactive waste that includes a time period for implementation and delineates responsiblity. It called for the program to be worked out before June 1991. The Russian government was instructed to review all existing radioactive waste sites in its jurisdiction and make recommendations about how and whether they should be used. Until a national program is enacted, the directive said it would be considered ``unacceptable to start construction of new atomic energy sites on the territory of the Russian republic from Jan. 1, 1991.'' The Russian Council of Ministers was instructed to ``prepare a proposal to prohibit burial on the territory of the Russian republic the final products of the activity of atomic sites from other republics and countries beginning Jan. 1, 1991.'' Official reports say 31 people were killed when one of four reactors at the Chernobyl plant, in the Ukraine, caught fire and exploded April 26, 1986. Unofficial reports say 250 died. The blast spewed cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia, and also sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world. This April, on the eve of the fourth anniversary of the accident, the Soviet government decided to resettle 200,000 more people living in the area of the Chernobyl plant at a cost of about $26 billion. But Soviets, increasingly concerned about contamination of their environment, also are worried about the safety of nuclear energy used in industry and to power ships such as ice breakers and submarines. The Soviet government has only recently acknowledged other major nuclear accidents. Last June, officials said that in 1957 a tank of radioactive waste exploded at a weapons site in the southern Ural Mountains, showering almost 400 square miles with radioactive waste and forcing evacuation of 10,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Upholds Arizona Death Penalty Law
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court upheld Arizona's death penalty law Wednesday in a decision that also removed a constitutional shadow from similar laws in Idaho and Montana. By a 5-4 vote, the court said the Arizona law is valid even though judges, not juries, decide whether a murderer's sentence should be death or life in prison. Had the justices ruled the other way, new proceedings could have been required for the 88 people on Arizona's death row and perhaps for all or most of the death row inmates in Idaho and Montana. As of last month, Idaho had 19 inmates on death row; Montana had six. No one has been executed in those three states since the Supreme Court allowed states to resume capital punishment in 1976. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which has jurisdiction over nine Western states including Arizona, Idaho and Montana, previously issued a decision in conflict with the Arizona Supreme Court's ruling in Walton's case. The federal appeals court threw out the death sentence of John Harvey Adamson, convicted of murdering Phoenix newspaper reporter Don Bolles in 1976. Wednesday's decision likely means the 9th Circuit court's ruling, on appeal by Arizona before the justices, will be set aside _ perhaps as early as Thursday when some house-cleaning orders are to be issued. ``I think this moves us much closer to executions,'' said Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin. But he added that the first executions might be as long as six months off. ``The issues are the same,'' in the Adamson case, Corbin said. Corbin criticized the 9th Circuit judges for what he said was ``finding some Mickey Mouse reason'' to overturn every death sentence that goes before them. Idaho Attorney General Jim Jones said, ``This removes probably the most serious impediment to moving forward with the death penalty in Idaho.'' In Montana, Assistant Attorney General Pat Schaeffer Jordan said Wednesday's ruling would apply there as well. Writing for the high court, Justice Byron R. White said convicted murderer Jeffrey Alan Walton properly was sentenced to death for robbing and killing Thomas Powell near Tucson four years ago. Powell on March 2, 1986 was robbed in a bar parking lot, and then driven in his own car to a secluded area and shot. A jury heard testimony that Walton put a gun to Powell's head and fired the fatal shot. Walton denied he killed Powell, swearing that a co-defendant was the triggerman. The jury did not specify whether it found Walton guilty of premeditated murder or ``felony murder,'' the taking of a life during the commission of a felony. After the jury convicted Walton, Judge G. Thomas Meehan conducted a hearing, without a jury as Arizona law requires, to consider all aggravating and mitigating factors in the case. He sentenced Walton to die in the state's gas chamber, and the sentence was upheld by the Arizona Supreme Court. White said Arizona's law is not that different from Florida's, which the court already had upheld. In Florida, a jury makes a sentencing recommendation which can be followed or ignored by a judge. White was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens dissented. In a separate ruling, the court also upheld the death sentence of Arizona death row inmate Jimmy Wayne Jeffers, convicted of killing his ex-girlfriend in Tucson 14 years ago. The 9th Circuit had upheld his conviction but struck down the death sentence. The vote in Jeffers' cas was by an identical 5-4 lineup of the justices.

DOC.HEAD: Government Considers Closing Down Small Hawaiian Airline
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: A Transportation Department official said Wednesday he is considering whether to close down Hawaii-based Discovery Airlines for allegedly operating under illegal foreign ownership and control. The three-month-old carrier flies six leased planes on inter-island flights in competition with both Hawaiian and Aloha airlines, who claim Discovery is owned primarily by Japanese interests and run largely by an Italian. Patrick Murphy, the deputy assistant secretary designated to decide the matter, said he would ``give considerable weight'' to the recommendation of an administrative law judge. The judge, Ronnie A. Yoder, declared Tuesday that cancellation of Discovery's temporary permit to operate ``would appear to be a more appropriate action'' than granting it a requested extension. Yoder said the airline and department lawyers imply in a proposed settlement that Discovery does not qualify as a U.S. airline. The judge also said the airline admitted to ``substantial prior misrepresentations'' in seeking authority to operate. The judge said the fact that the proposed settlement includes sale of a share in the airline to qualify it as a U.S. airline is an admission that it ``has operated from its inception as a non-U.S. citizen air carrier in violation of the Federal Aviation Act and that its submissions to the department ... were false and constituted misrepresentation in violation of federal law.'' Such actions should not be rewarded with an extension of the airline's operating permit, as proposed by the department's lawyers, Yoder said. The law requires that U.S. airlines have no more than 25 percent foreign ownership and that they not be controlled by foreigners Discovery is 75 percent owned by Philip Ho, who other airlines claim got his funds from Nansay Corp. of Japan. Ho is president of Nansay's operations in Hawaii. The judge recommended against the proposed settlement of the issue by Discovery and department lawyers. The proposal would have allowed Ho to sell most of his stock in Discovery and had the airline pay a $50,000 fine for making misstatements. The administrative law judge also cited evidence that Franco Mancassola, an Italian citizen, is effectively Discovery's executive vice president, earning twice as much as its president. ``We are disappointed that the administrative law judge did not concur with the consent order,'' said Discovery President Don Straight. ``However, we are gratified that he saw fit to forward the consent order to the decision maker for an expedited review. We continue to be hopeful of a prompt and fair decision.'' Transportation Department lawyers said problems with Discovery's application were not intentional and would not warrant criminal prosecution. Hawaiian Airlines, however, said it would ask the Justice Department to investigate Discovery's actions in starting up its passenger service. Hawaiian, in business for 61 years, on Tuesday announced a $9.9 million suit against the new airline, claiming lost revenue because of Discovery's allegedly fraudulent actions. A. Maurice Myers, Aloha Airlines president, said the law judge ``has seen through the thinly veiled sham created by the Nansay Corporation and Discovery.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Pulling Volunteers Out of Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Corps is pulling its volunteers out of the Philippines to make sure they are not killed or kidnapped by Communist rebels, the agency said Wednesday. ``All of the volunteers are safe, and this is strictly a precautionary measure,'' Peace Corps Director Paul Coverdell said in a statement. The agency suspended its program after learning that ``Peace Corps volunteers may be among those targeted by the armed wing of the Communist Party,'' Coverdell said. He said the White House and the State Department were involved in the decision to recall the 261 volunteers, most of whom were working in remote rural areas with poor security. For a month, Americans have been cautioned by the State Department to be careful traveling in the Philippines. But they have not been told to stay away, or to leave. ``We see no reason, at the moment, to change the advisory,'' said Philip Covington, a department spokesman. The travel advisory, posted May 28 with the onset of negotiations over the use of the U.S.-run Clark Air Base and naval facilities at Subic Bay, specified that ``serious problems'' exist in urban areas. ``We have advised Americans that a threat exists against U.S. government personnel and facilities, and the threat is heightened with the bases negotiations,'' Covington said. The Peace Corps volunteers are scheduled to leave Thursday after a special send-off from Philippine President Corazon Aquino. They will fly to Hawaii to finish their service or discuss other assignments. Coverdell stressed that the Philippines program is being suspended, not cancelled, and said the agency's office in Manila would remain open. ``It is my desire that Peace Corps volunteers will soon return to the Philippines,'' Coverdell said. ``This program is too valuable ... to leave it in a state of suspension for any longer than is absolutely necessary.'' The State Department made clear that none of the present volunteers are likely to be returning to their posts in the Philippines. Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that after they arrive in Hawaii, the volunteers will attend a ``close-of-service conference'' at the University of Hawaii. ``Some of the volunteers will go on to work in other countries,'' she said. ``Others will be ending their Peace Corps service early.'' A senior U.S. official in Manila said the move does not imply a lack of support for the Aquino government. Concern that it might be viewed that way ``has to be balanced against the greater downside of having a Peace Corps volunteer kidnapped or killed,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Philippine military said last week that rebels in Manila planned to target Americans and other foreigners for assassination and kidnapping in the next six months. The U.S. Embassy recalled all Peace Corps volunteers to Manila over the weekend after receiving a report that they had been added to the target list. The rebels have made no specific public threats against the volunteers but have charged that U.S. and Japanese aid workers secretly assist the Philippine government in its counterinsurgency operations. Both the U.S. and Japanese governments deny the charges. The Communist New People's Army has been fighting for 21 years to establish a Marxist government in the Philippines. The rebels are believed to have killed eight Americans in the Philippines since April 1989. They claimed responsibility for the deaths of two U.S. airmen last month near Clark Air Base, and threatened to kill more until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. Some U.S. officials have complained privately that the Aquino government has not been aggressive in guaranteeing the safety of the estimated 140,000 Americans in the Philippines. Senior embassy officials, however, have expressed satisfaction with security arrangements. Peace Corps volunteers had been involved in education, environment, agriculture and community development projects throughout the main Philippine island, Luzon, and the central Visayas chain. They were recalled from the southern island of Mindanao in 1985 because of lawlessness and never returned. Coverdell said more than 7,500 volunteers had served in the Philippines since 1961 when the Peace Corps was founded, making it one of the agency's oldest and most successful programs.

DOC.HEAD: Savimbi Asks U.S., Soviets for Joint Relief Effort
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the U.S.-armed rebels in Angola is urging President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to undertake a joint emergency airlift of food and medicine to starving Angolans, the rebel group said Wednesday. In letters to the two leaders, Jonas Savimbi also called for a cease-fire in Angola's 15-year civil war and the creation of protected land corridors to allow safe passage of relief supplies. Savimbi, who heads the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, also wrote Angola's President Jose Eduardo dos Santos urging him to accept the plan, the organization said. Bush and Gorbachev agreed earlier this month to mount a joint airlift of food for starving Ethiopians with U.S. food flown on Soviet planes. Bush and Gorbachev also discussed joint sponsorship of peace talks between Savimbi and the Soviet-backed government of Dos Santos. In the first signs of possible peace progress, UNITA and government officials held two rounds of talks in Portugal in recent weeks but they are divided on how to proceed. The UNITA announcement said hundreds of thousands of people face starvation in regions controlled by its forces, as a result of drought in recent years. Dos Santos, in a letter to the House of Representatives' Select Committee on Hunger, estimated that 1.55 million Angolans ``run the risk of death from hunger.'' The letter, dated June 7 and made available to The Associated Press, said more than 500 Angolans have already died because of the drought. Dos Santos, responding to a letter from the committee that urged him and Savimbi to support international relief organizations like the Red Cross, promised to cooperate. But he suggested such aid would have to be distributed by Angolan government agencies, a move Savimbi is likely to reject. Savimbi's proposal for ``corridors of peace'' would establish agreed routes into each side's territory for the safe passage of international relief convoys. The rebel chief said a similar approach worked successfully in rebel and government-held territories in Sudan. The United States secretly gives Savimbi more than $40 million of weapons annually. U.S. officials say the Soviets give Dos Santos at least $600 million annually.

DOC.HEAD: `I Got It Back Now' _ Doctors Save Man's Arm
DOC.TEXT: Bill Price remembers falling from the scaffold, clawing helplessly at the air. And he remembers looking in horror at his right shoulder. His arm was gone, torn off by a wrought-iron fence spike. ``When I was laying there on the ground I looked over and I seen it wasn't there,'' Price said Wednesday. He spoke at a news conference to announce the improbable: He plans to go home Saturday, his arm reattached by surgeons at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital. How much sensitivity and strength will return to his arm and hand can't be immediately known, and recovery depends on years of physical therapy, his surgeon said. ``I just hope I don't wake up tomorrow and it's gone,'' said Price, 32, his voice breaking. ``I got it back now.'' On June 18, Price was pointing stone on a building in Scranton when a balcony gave way and he fell three floors into an open stairway. His arm caught on the fence and was severed about 4 inches below the shoulder. Dr. John Taras, the orthopedic surgeon who led the five-hour effort to reattach the arm, praised fast-acting emergency workers who packed the arm in ice, helping to keep the muscle alive. Price was taken to Scranton's Community Medical Center, which alerted Thomas Jefferson. In Philadelphia, 2{ hours after the accident, Taras and Dr. Richard Uhl were working on the arm, sorting out blood vessels and nerves. Price was in the operating room within another hour. And within hour after that, blood was flowing to the arm. ``Blood flow is essential to keep the muscle living,'' Taras said. Surgeons spent five hours reconnecting the large artery that brings blood from the heart to the limb, reattaching the bone with a metal insert and reconnecting three large veins and three major nerves. ``Reattached, replanted arms generally are functioning usefully,'' Taras said. ``We've seen professional musicians have their fingers amputated and go back to playing as a professional musician.'' The biggest factor in Price's recovery, he said, ``is his resolve to get better and to accomplish what he wants.'' Price was perched on a scaffold set up on a balcony at the Throop Memorial Building, adjacent to St. Luke's Church in the northeastern Pennsylvania city. The masonry balcony gave way and he plunged to the ground. ``I was trying to stop myself but there was no way of stopping. I knew I was falling and that was it,'' said Price, of Luzerne, who is married and the father of a 10-year-old boy and 6-year-old girl. When he saw his injury, he was ``in shock, panic _ I was in something, I don't know what.'' ``I thought it was gone. I thought it was completely gone,'' he said. Price was asked what he would do if the injury kept him from construction work or his favorate pastime, dirt-track car racing. ``I don't know. That's all I ever did,'' he said. His current state of mind, he said, is ``total confusion, just total confusion right now.''

DOC.HEAD: Cyclist Recalls Being Nearly Ripped from Her Bike by Park Gang
DOC.TEXT: A woman testified Wednesday that a gang of youths terrified her and tried to pull her off a bicycle in Central Park on the night a female jogger was gang-raped and beaten nearly to death in the same area of the park. Patricia Dean said she and her fiance, Gerald Malone, were riding through the park on a tandem bicycle when 30 youths attacked them. Dean told Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer the teen-agers saw her and Malone coming, and several moved into the roadway, pulling hoods over their heads and ``making animal noises, grunting.'' ``At that point I was terrified. Jerry aimed the bike at them. As we came through them, they were pulling at us.'' She said one youth pulled on her leg and shoulder. ``Three on the right were pushing and the whole bike was swerving.'' ``We just kept going as fast as we could,'' drove out of the park, found a telephone and called police, Dean said. Dean testified at the trial in Manhattan's state court of three teen-agers charged with the rape and attempted murder of a female runner the night of April 19, 1989. The jogger, an investment banker who was then 28, was gang-raped, beaten, and left naked and near death in a puddle of mud and blood. She survived, but suffered brain damage and has no recollection of what happened to her that night, Lederer said. Antron McCray, 15, Raymond Santana, 16, and Yusef Salaam, 16, are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in connection with the attack on the jogger and on two men who were less seriously injured. Three other youths, Kevin Richardson, 15, Stephen Lopez, 16, and Kharey Wise, 17, are to stand trial on the same charges later this year. Malone, an advertising executive, testified that he could not identify any of the youths in a photograph taken by police of suspects in the attacks. But he said a shirt worn in the photo by Richardson was similar to one worn by one of the youths who tried to attack him and Dean. It was the first time anyone other than a participant in the rampage had drawn any link between the defendants and the attacks in the park. In other testimony, banker David Lewis, 31, said he suffered a deep and painful bruise when he was hit by a member of a gang of teen-agers he encountered on the north side of the jogging path around the Central Park reservoir. Able to run a six-minute mile, Lewis said he believes he escaped serious injury by outrunning the youths.

DOC.HEAD: Life in the Boiling Lane
With AM-Heat Wave, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: How hot is it? Well, when your house has no air conditioning and your car doesn't either, 112 degrees is well past the boiling point for life in general. Sleep is elusive. Your brain short-circuits. In the middle of the night, laying in a puddle of your own sweat, the heat dragons begin to romp. Questions such as, ``At what point will the gas in my engine begin to boil?'', take on profound proportions. How long does it take for dehydration to set in? Will my tires melt in gridlock? Will the greenhouse effect make us all end up like that ``Twilight Zone'' episode in which the Earth is literally burning up? Or, spontaneous combustion _ fact or fiction? It has never been 112 degrees in Los Angeles before. And they say there's no such thing as global warming. Sure, L.A. has sweltered now and then. Malibu usually catches on fire in weather like this. Earthquakes occur. But there's something different about this heat wave. This is surreal. No, this is absurd. Hot winds are blasting a static electricity that makes the hair on your arms hurt. It was 106 degrees at 8 o'clock Tuesday night. Something bad is going to happen. Everywhere you go, every person you meet, the topic of conversation is heat. Callers from the East Coast laugh at your complaints. ``You should be stuck in a subway train with your face pushed into someone's armpit when it's 99 degrees and the humidity is 100 percent,'' they say. ``Now that's hot.'' No, that's disgusting. Hot is being stuck in bumper-to-bumper traffic on the Santa Monica Freeway at 8 a.m. with no air conditioning, and it's already 100 degrees. Hot is when the bowl of M&Ms on your coffee table melts. Hot is being awakened by an editor who, after you've finally fallen into sweat-induced slumber, tells you to write a story about how hot it is. It's so hot you need gloves to touch the steering wheel of your car. It's so hot the little man selling oranges in the median of La Cienega Boulevard was nowhere to be found Wednesday morning. It's so hot that a morning disc-jockey team warned listeners to be on the lookout for freeway shooters. People are grumpy. People are dying of heat prostration. The asphalt in Glendale shimmers like Highway 190 in Death Valley. Sweat trickles down the back of your shirt and collects in your waistband. In our upstairs sweatbox of an apartment, my roommate has come up with some highfalutin' concept that entails closing all but one window and placing a fan in front of it, blowing out. It doesn't help. Filling the bathtub with cold water and the contents of four ice trays does, however. If you could sleep there without drowning, life would be tolerable.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Official Says WIC Not an Emergency
DOC.TEXT: A money shortage that could force 240,000 low-income women and children out of a government nutrition program is not an emergency, an administration official said on Wednesday. Meanwhile, a bill that will help states get more money for the supplemental food program for women, infants and children, or WIC, was moving quickly through the House. The House education and labor committee approved a measure by Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, to let states borrow a greater amount of next year's WIC appropriation to cover current shortages. Hall introduced the bill Monday and a vote on the House floor could occur Thursday, officials said. House members criticized the Department of Agriculture, which administers WIC, for not seeking more money for the program, which has been battered in at least 20 states by food price increases and rebate reductions. ``It's an absolute outrage,'' said Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas. ``Why isn't the administration up here urging an emergency supplemental appropriations bill?'' ``This program faces a dire crisis,'' said Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., who chaired a hearing on WIC by the House budget committee's task force on human resources. Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the USDA's Food and Nutrition Service, said $11 million was being reallocated this week to make up for spending or budget shortfalls in some states. ``It will clearly not be enough,'' Ms. Nelsen said. But, when pressed by task force members, she refused to call the funding shortage an emergency. ``I would characterize it as a very difficult situation,'' Ms. Nelsen said. ``I would save severe crisis or emergency for when we can't serve women and children with medically related nutritional risks.'' The National Association of WIC Directors said Tuesday that $72 million is needed to keep about 240,000 women and children from being dropped. Congress has appropriated $2.1 billion this year for WIC, which provides milk, cheese, juice, cereal, peanut butter and other food to 4.5 million participants. The states hardest hit by potential cutbacks include California, New York, Texas and Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposes Loan Help for Latin America, Hemispheric Free Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds; Adds details, Brady comments, throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday offered to forgive a portion of $12 billion owed the government by Latin American and Caribbean countries and proposed a free trade zone for the entire Western Hemisphere. The president also proposed ``debt-for-nature'' swaps to encourage third-world countries to protect natural resources. Bush, in a major speech on U.S. trade and investment policies toward the region, offered new proposals centered around trade, investment and the Latin nations' debt to the U.S. government. It marked the first time the administration had shown a willingness to write off a portion of the government debt _ which would still leave the $48.3 billion the Latin nations owe U.S. banks. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said $7 billion in low-interest loans among the $12 billion was eligible to be forgiven, but the process could take several years. ``Obviously it's going to take a lot of consultation with the Congress,'' to work out the bilateral debt agreements with each nation, he said. The debt forgiveness would be contingent on economic and investment reforms the debtor nations would work out with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The president, speaking to administration officials and Latin ambassadors in the White House East Room, said he wants to eliminate trade and tariff barriers between the United States and the Latin and Caribbean nations, ``particularly with groups of countries that have associated for the purposes of trade liberalization.'' The Central American nations recently agreed to form a common economic unit known as the Central American Economic Community, and there have been several other attempts by Latin American countries to cooperate on trade and economic matters in the past. The United States already has an open trade policy with Canada and is discussing a similar arrangement with Mexico. In his remarks, Bush proposed ``that we begin the process of creating a hemisphere-wide free trade zone; to increase investment, that we adopt measures to create a new flow of capital into the region, and to further ease the burden of debt, a new approach to debt in the region _ with important benefits for our environment.'' Bush said he was proposing a ``major new initiative to reduce Latin America and the Caribbean's official debt to the U.S., for countries that adopt strong economic and investment reform programs with the support of international institutions.'' Brady told reporters that the proposals were designed to address problems that cannot be rectified under the ``Brady plan'' that the Bush administration put forward last year to deal with foreign debt to commercial banks. That plan called for the banks to forgive part of the loans. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank would lend money to the borrowing countries to buy back old debt at a discount. Bush also said the United States wants the International Development Bank to create a new lending program for countries ``that take significant steps to remove impediments to international investment.'' Such impediments include bureaucratic and logistical blockades to potential investors, he indicated. The United States, Bush said, is prepared in addition to contribute $100 million to a proposed IDB-administered ``investment fund for the Americas.'' He said he will seek matching contributions from Japan and Europe, to bring the fund to $300 million that would be used for grants to countries that make broad investment reforms. On the environmental front, Bush recommended creation of environmental trusts into which loan interest payments on U.S. loans can be paid. The money would be used to finance environmental programs in the debtor countries, he said. ``These innovative agreements offer a powerful new tool for preserving the natural wonders of this hemisphere we share,'' he said. In response to a reporter's question, Brady conceded that the administration's debt forgiveness plan for Latin America could set a precedent for other parts of the world. The new government of Poland has been lobbying the United States and other Western countries to forgive its $39 billion in official loans and saying such a write-down is critical to its economic reforms. Besides the debts owed to the U.S. government, the Latin countries owe $48.3 billion to U.S. banks. Brazil's $19.1 billion is the largest portion. John Reed, chairman of Citicorp, said after hearing Bush's speech that it was ``the first time I've heard the United States government focus on economic development in Latin America in a regional sense and giving it the priority the president gave it.'' Reed said Citicorp is owed about $8 billion by Latin American countries, but he said, ``We're not uncomfortable with our existing exposure.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservative PAC Plans Anti-Duke Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A conservative fund-raising group on Wednesday announced plans to launch an ad campaign attacking U.S. Senate candidate David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader running as a Republican in Louisiana. Floyd Brown, founder of the Republican Challengers Committee, said the political action committee had targeted Duke because he was ``a racist pretending to be a Republican out of convenience.'' ``He is trying to establish himself as the leader of the conservative movement and we have to stop that,'' Brown said. Duke is running against Democratic incumbent Sen. J. Bennett Johnston and Republican state Sen. Ben Bagert. The three will meet in an Oct. 6 open primary. Bagert is the GOP's endorsed candidate but polls have shown Duke running second behind Johnston. If no candidate gets more than 50 percent of the vote, the top two vote-getters will face off in November. Brown said his group hopes to spend $1 million to defeat Duke. However, the group had just $8,900 on hand as of May 31 and debts of nearly $80,000, according to Federal Election Commission records. Brown said he had $30,000 in new pledges for the anti-Duke effort and was confident he could raise plenty more. Brown and his partners at the Republican Challengers Committee earlier worked with another PAC that spent $10 million attacking 1988 Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis for granting furloughs to convicted murderer Willie Horton, who raped a Maryland woman while on furlough. Duke, in a telephone interview, criticized Brown's plans but said he was not concerned. ``If they were truly concerned and truly interested in Republicanism they would be spending their money against the liberal Democrat J. Bennett Johnston,'' said Duke, a member of the state House. ``I have a perfect voting record on conservative principles.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Hitler's Art, Photographs Worth $6.8 Million
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge set at $6.8 million the value of an art cache seized by the U.S. government that includes four watercolors painted by a young Adolf Hitler and photographic archives of pre-war Europe and Nazi Germany. U.S. District Judge Lynn N. Hughes also ruled Tuesday that the items could have produced more than $1.1 million in income through the sale of reproductions during the years of legal wrangling over their ownership. Billy F. Price of Houston, who helped locate the articles in the early 1980s, had sought to have them valued at more than $30 million. The latest findings open the way for Price to seek monetary damages based on the income he has not received since the government seized the paintings, said Larry A. Campagna, one of Price's attorneys. The U.S. government, which can not appeal any of Hughes' decisions in the suit until a final judgment is issued, has argued that Price is not entitled to any money. The paintings and photographs were seized by the U.S. Army in 1945 in Germany. The family of Heinrich Hoffman, who operated a photographic business in Europe before and during World War II and who was given the paintings by Hitler, claimed they owned the items. Price, a Houston businessman and collector of Hitler's work who helped the Hoffmans locate the articles and bought an interest from the family, has been battling the U.S. government for their possession. The judge last year ruled that the government had no right to the items, in what may have been the first decision favoring a U.S. citizen claiming articles captured in a war by the Army. In his findings, the judge said the value of the watercolors lay in the fact they were painted by Hitler rather than by ``an obscure early twentieth-century German watercolor artist.'' Hitler's watercolors portray street scenes and war landscapes painted before and during World War I. The photographs include one depicting Rudolf Hess with his family, Mickey Mouse painted on a Nazi aircraft and Nazis ``engaged in horse play.''

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Town Dominates ``Mibster'' Tournament
DOC.TEXT: It's enough to leave the town glassy-eyed with pride: not only does Ridgeley have the nation's best marbles player, it has the second best, too. The town of 990 was also home to the girls' champions in 1987 and 1988. Carl Whitacre, 12, last week won the National Marble Tournament boys' division, and Mickey Lantz, 13, was runner-up. The two beat out about 58 other boys during the competition in Wildwood, N.J., including 22 other West Virginians. They ended up facing each other for the championship. During the 15-game title set, Lantz led 7-4, but Whitacre won the last four games without giving Lantz a chance to shoot. ``I bawled because I lost. That's 2,000 bucks down the drain,'' said Lantz, referring to a $2,000 scholarship Whitacre won along with the title. But no hard feelings. `He's going to win it next year,'' said Whitacre. Whitacre won't be eligible because of his win this year. But he'll be back in Wildwood as a referee, he said, and he wants to coach other ``mibsters,'' as marbles players are called. Whitacre's aunt won the girls' championship in 1987 and Lantz' sister won in 1988. Youths in the eastern West Virginia town must fight their way through two local tournaments to get a shot at the national tournament. ``It gets as exciting as a football game in the (local) finals,'' said Tonyia Dickel, Whitacre's grandmother.

DOC.HEAD: Samson's Letter to Delilah Reported Found Among Dead Sea Scrolls
DOC.TEXT: A scholar said Wednesday that a portion of a letter from the biblical strongman Samson, possibly a love note to the temptress Delilah, had been found among the Dead Sea Scrolls. John Strugnell, head of a 22-member team of scholars with exclusive access to most of the unpublished scrolls, said he recently stumbled on a fragment containing nine words and three lines of the letter. ``It has to be a copy of a letter sent by Samson ... (but was it) to Delilah? Unfortunately, we don't know,'' he said, adding he had deciphered little about what Samson wrote at this point but would publish more details soon. Strugnell, the world's leading expert on the Dead Sea Scrolls, said it was clear from the first few words of the letter, what he called the ``address,'' that it was without question from Samson. He suggested that it may be a love letter because it fit into the context of ``erotic and sapient literature'' that developed in the early Jewish period. The letter was not signed, he said. No other information was made available about the letter. Samson, whose story is told in the Book of Judges, was known for feats of enormous strength, such as slaying 1,000 Philistines with the jawbone of a mule. But he was stopped by Delilah, who was sent by the Philistines. She seduced him, learned that the secret to his strength was his hair and cut it off while he was sleeping. Strugnell, a Harvard University professor, announced the existence of the letter as an example of discoveries that are expected in the near future from the scroll research. He and other scholars on a five-member oversight committee that controls access to the scrolls defended the slow pace of publishing manuscripts from the ancient library found at Qumran on the Dead Sea from 1947-52. They also responded to criticism that they unfairly prevented other scholars from looking at scroll fragments during a news conference held in conjunction with the Second International Conference on Biblical Archaeology. Shmaryahu Talmon, a Hebrew University scholar on the Israeli oversight committee, told reporters measures had been introduced the past three years to expand access, to set timetables for publication and to compile a catalogue of manuscripts and published scroll studies. ``The pace has been speeded up without lowering standards of scholarship,'' Talmon said. ``We will try to open up as far as possible the material we have.'' Talmon said scrolls have already been published and 50 plates of fragments that have not been assigned to scholars on the team will be open for inspection by researchers. However, he said access would not be granted to material held by the research team because scholars had invested whole careers in piecing together fragments and they should have the right to publish the material first. ``It would not be fair to rob them of the fruit of their labor,'' Talmon said. Robert Eisenman, head of the religion department at California State University at Long Beach and a leading critic of the system, said the changes represented some progress but that after 40 years scholars should have ``absolutely open access.'' ``They drop new bombshells every now and then to deflect people from the basic problem,'' he said, referring to Strugnell's announcement. ``Control of the manuscripts is control of interpretation and control of the field.'' Eisenman, reached by telephone in California, said he and other ``opposition voices'' had not been invited to address the conference. He accused the Israel Antiquities Authority of acquiescing to the ``clubism'' that froze out more than 500 qualified experts from studying the original manuscripts. Magen Broshi, curator of the Shrine of the Book where some scrolls are on public display, disputed critics' claims that less than half the documents had been made public. He estimated about 70 to 80 percent of the 90,000 words of biblical texts, letters, and other documents from the Qumran library had been deciphered and published. Amir Drori, head of the Antiquities Authority which has final say over the manuscripts, said a general deadline of 1997 had been set for completing study of the scrolls and the year 2000 for publication. He said some material might be reassigned if deadlines were not met. Officials also announced plans to begin carbon-dating portions of the Dead Sea scrolls. Based on handwriting styles, the earliest manuscripts were estimated to date to 200 B.C. and be the work of a Jewish sect. But some scholars suggest unpublished scrolls may be the work of early Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Drive Launched to Repeal Sanctions for Hiring Illegal Aliens
DOC.TEXT: Senators of both parties on Wednesday launched a drive to repeal federal sanctions against employers who hire illegal aliens, saying the penalties cause discrimination in hiring. ``In my view, employer sanctions simply are not worth the price in increased employment discrimination and increased burdens on business,'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, told a news conference. He was joined in unveiling legislation that would repeal the sanctions by Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; and Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M. ``I support reasonable measures to achieve the goal of these sanctions,'' Kennedy said. ``In this case, however, Congress made the wrong move. We aimed at illegal aliens _ but we hit law-abiding Americans and it is time to rectify the mistake.''
