The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act, designed to curb an influx of illegal aliens over the southern border, calls for the sanctions, which range from $250 fines to six months in jail depending on the circumstances. The General Accounting Office reported to Congress in March that the sanctions have caused ``widespread'' hiring discrimination against those with ethnic names or who appear foreign in the eyes of employers wary lest they make an error and incur a fine. The repeal measure also includes provisions that would bolster the Border Patrol with additional agents and $50 million in new funds and toughening penalties for transporting and harboring illegal aliens. ``Reducing illegal immigration should be placed back onto the shoulders of law enforcement,'' DeConcini said. Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., at a later news conference renewed his criticism of the GAO report, saying it was impossible to determine whether employer sanctions were soley responsible for discrimination. He said sponsors of the repeal measure are ``now using the GAO report as a hook to achieve their obsessive original agenda and goal which was to kill employer sanctions.'' ``They today are making a last frantic and exasperated gasp and grasp at achieving their objective during this Congress,'' Simpson said. He said that if the sanctions are repealed ``illegal immigration will increase, more illegal aliens will be exploited and some employers will return to the practice of paying these people peanuts and profiting from their misery and their labor.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: parabolic mirror.
DOC.TEXT: ``We suspect that in the technique used to measure and polish the mirror, there was an error made in the primary or secondary and it resulted in the mirrors being made to the wrong number,'' he said. By ``wrong number,'' he meant manufactured to the wrong curvature. The two mirrors were tested individually on the ground, said Oliver, and passed all tests. He said they were not tested in combination on the ground because this would have required a test arrangement that would have cost ``hundreds of millions of dollars.'' Before it was launched, NASA said the Hubble, operating from 281-mile orbit, far above the obscuring effects of the Earth's atmosphere, would capture views of the universe never before possible. The five instruments on the craft, the agency said, would detect objects 25 times fainter than the dimmest seen from Earth, and would expand the size of the observable universe by 250 times. Objects in the farthest reaches of the universe, some 14 billion light years or 82 billion trillion miles away, would be visible to the Hubble, the space agency said. Since the universe is thought to be 15 to 20 billion years old, the telescope would be seeing objects only a short time after the so-called big bang that astronomers believe is the origin of the universe. In addition to power, the agency said the Hubble also would have an unprecedented clarity, about 10 times that of telescopes on Earth, and would be able to hold steady for many minutes on extremely faint objects. Instead, Weiler said, the flawed telescope now is able to gather only a fraction of the light that NASA had expected. He said the telescope is designed to capture about 70 percent of the visible light from a distant star, but with the focusing flaw it can now gather only about 20 percent of the light. ``We're a factor of three and a half off,'' he said. Despite this, NASA chief scientist Lennard Fisk said the flawed Hubble still will be a valuable observatory. ``You'll find many fundamental discoveries from Hubble as it works today,'' Fisk said at the news conferecne. ``I think you'll be very pleased with the investment even as it is today.''

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Rattle Region, Relief Worker Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of helicopter crash, relief plane from Iraq arrives, four rescued, edits to trim. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON7, LaserColor XTEH3
DOC.TEXT: Aftershocks rumbled through northern Iran on Wednesday, shaking buildings and killing a relief worker who was trying to dig out bodies buried under debris by last week's earthquake. Bad weather hampered rescue efforts and was blamed for the crash of a relief helicopter with 14 people on board that hit a mountain in Gilan province. One person died and six others were reported seriously injured. Tens of thousands of people took shelter in tent cities set up with the help of foreign volunteers. About a half-million people were left homeless by Thursday's quake, which registered 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale. Officials at the Red Crescent, the Moslem equivalent of the Red Cross, said they counted 40,000 dead and 60,000 injured. Government officials earlier said 50,000 people died and 200,000 were injured. A Red Cross official said Tuesday the death toll could reach 70,000. More than 205 people hurt in the quake died of their injuries Wednesday in hospitals in Zanjan province, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. IRNA said Mohammad Hossein Eftekhari, a Parliament deputy from Rudbar, a city in Gilan, was killed in the crash of the Chinook helicopter near Kelishom, 100 miles northwest of Tehran. The pilot suffered severe burns, a passenger broke his back and four others suffered serious injuries, IRNA said. In Jirandeh, a man and a woman were rescued on Tuesday, and two other people were found alive in Vieh the same day, IRNA reported Wednesday. Meanwhile, IRNA said a 19-year-old volunteer died Wednesday in Rudbar. A wall collapsed on Iraj Amjadian, a student at the police academy, when a mild quake shook the city as he and other volunteers were trying to pull bodies from the debris of a collapsed building. Fifty aftershocks struck Tuesday and Wednesday in Gilan province, on the Caspian Sea, and Zanjan, just south, according to Tehran University's Geophysics Center. More than 400 aftershocks have hit since Thursday. Two field tribunals were being set up in northwestern Iran to try ``criminals who are abusing the situation in the area,'' IRNA said. The agency did not elaborate, but appeared to refer either to looters or profiteers operating after the quake. The agency said the courts would be set up in Rudbar and Manjil. At a news conference in Tehran, the managing director of Iran's Red Crescent societies said survivors were being housed in more than 70,000 tents sent to the region, IRNA reported. Mohammad Parham said 175 foreign planes airlifted thousands of tons of supplies, including medical aid, tents and other items. He praised the foreign relief effort and said 500 foreign doctors and relief workers were in the area. He said relief operations were approaching the final stages and that there was no need for additional foreign doctors and relief workers, IRNA reported. ``The need for foreign doctors and rescuers was acute only in the first 72 hours. Now, the need is for medicines and shelter equipment,'' said Seyfollah Vahid Dastjerdi, the Red Crescent chief. The first plane carrying Iraqi relief supplies arrived Wednesday. Iran and Iraq fought an eight-year war, which was halted by a cease-fire in 1988. Foreign aid has come from more than 26 countries, including sworn enemies like the United States, Britain, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. That has prompted a bitter debate among Iranian leaders. Radicals say the donations should not lead to improved relations with the West, and others who say they should. Radical members of parliament oppose ties with the West. President Hashemi Rafsanjani supports better ties with the outside world. Some Western diplomats say the quake and resulting international aid effort could lead to better diplomatic ties. ``Of course the goodwill gesture being shown by France and other countries will have favorable effects in future relations of these countries with Iran,'' French Minister for Humanitarian Action Bernard Kouchner said in an interview published Wednesday in the Tehran Times.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush Headed To Court With Owl Plans
DOC.TEXT: Three congressmen said Wednesday that the Bush administration's scaled-down plan to protect the northern spotted owl will force a court battle that will paralyze logging in the Pacific Northwest. ``The president is leading us right down the road and into a legal disaster,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn. and chairman of the House Interior Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands. ``The administration is putting us right back in court _ right back into paralysis in that area,'' he said. Echoed Rep Ron Wyden, D-Ore., ``I think there are serious questions as to whether BLM can scientifically justify its position. I sense BLM is wide open to a lawsuit.'' And Rep. Jim McDermott, D-Wash., said the administration was ``flying in the face of the scientific evidence. All they are going to do is precipitate lawsuits.'' At issue is the administration's plan, announced Tuesday, to save the owl, placed on the endangered species list last week, with far milder reductions in the timber harvest than environmentalists had said were needed. The administration says it can protect the shy, two-foot-tall owl by reducing timber harvest levels from federal Bureau of Land Management forests from 950 million board feet annually to 750 million board feet. The administration's plan, announced by BLM Director Cy Jamison, will cost an estimated 1,000 jobs over two years, compared with the government's prediction of an 8,000-job loss this decade under an earlier plan by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas. Congressional and environmentalist critics of the plan charged the administration was ignoring evidence that current forest management practices are inadequate to reverse shrinking-habitat and declining-population trends jeopardizing the owl's survival. Environmentalists say Northwest timber harvests must be cut nearly in half to ensure that the owl will survive. Vento said he was also angry about Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's decision to postpone a more complete plan for protecting the owl until a newly formed task force can present to President Bush, by Sept. 1, a comprehensive proposal for protecting the bird while pursuing maximum timber harvests on Forest Service lands. ``The president ought to get off the fence instead of passing the buck to another blue-ribbon committee,'' Vento said. Wyden said Bush has avoided a detailed response because he wants to please both environmentalists and the timber industry. ``At some point you cannot pretend to have it all ways. You look at this and you get the feeling the administration is taking the position like somebody at a smorgasbord that just wants to eat it all. You can't. You have to make some tough choices,'' Wyden said. Environmentalists said the BLM's proposal is illegal because it does not adhere to the most modern, comprehensive scientific information, as required by the Endangered Species Act. ``This is voodoo biology,'' said Andy Kerr, conservation director for the Oregon Natural Resources Council. Even before Tuesday's announcement, environmental groups said they would likely challenge in court any action short of what they were proposing.

DOC.HEAD: Announces U.S. Dance Tour
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Baryshnikov will dance in the United States for the first time this year during an 18-city tour starting Oct. 24, it was announced Wednesday. The tour will be called the White Oak Dance Project. Dances, including two new ones, will be by modern dance choreographer Mark Morris. During his tenure as artistic director of American Ballet Theatre, Baryshnikov invited Morris to create the ballet ``Drink to Me Only with Thine Eyes,'' to music by Virgil Thomson. Baryshnikov danced in it. After he left Ballet Theatre last fall, Baryshnikov went to Brussels where the Mark Morris Dance Group has its headquarters to dance in Morris' ``Wonderland,'' to music by Arnold Schoenberg. Ron Besserer, who danced in that and has danced with Martha Clarke and Lar Lubovitch, will be on the tour. Other dancers on the tour will be Peggy Baker and Nancy Colahan from the Lubovitch company, Jamie Bishton of Ballet Theatre, Kate Johnson from the Paul Taylor Dance Company and William Pizzuto and Denise Pons of the Boston Ballet. The troupe will perform between Oct. 24 and Nov. 18 in Boston, Minneapolis, Madison, Wis., Toledo, Columbus, Youngstown and Dayton, Ohio, Charleston and Savannah, S.C., Jacksonville, Daytona Beach, Miami and Tampa, Fla., East Lansing and Detroit, Mich., Louisville, Ky., and two cities to be announced. The sponsor will be Baryshnikov Productions and the Howard Gilman Foundation. The dancers will be in a new dance center on the grounds of Gilman's White Oak Plantation during July and August rehearsals.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sentenced in His Old Courtroom for Corruption
DOC.TEXT: A former judge was sentenced Wednesday in his old courtroom to two to five years in prison for corruption charges that included bullying court employees into feeding his dogs and chopping wood. During a rambling, one-hour speech at the Cambria County Courthouse, Joseph O'Kicki maintained his innocence, quoting Isaac Newton, Roman and Buddhist philosophers, a former U.S. Supreme Court justice and a state penitentiary inmate. He did not apologize for the crimes he was convicted of Dec. 16, 1989. ``You violated a sacred trust,'' visiting Senior Judge Richard Grifo of Northampton County told him. ``You have tainted the entire judiciary with a broad brush.'' O'Kicki was convicted on six counts. They included improperly soliciting a lawyer for a $500 loan that never was repaid, asking for $500 from an aide who was promised a promotion never granted, and making court aides, clerks and secretaries perform personal chores. Two secretaries told investigators O'Kicki summoned them to his chambers, where they found him wearing only underwear _ once bikini briefs, the other time yellow briefs. O'Kicki, 59, was removed from his $80,000-a-year post and denied a state judicial pension. Grifo also fined O'Kicki $57,500 and ordered him to reimburse the state about $140,000 in salary he received since being suspended from the bench Oct. 11, 1988. Grifo allowed the former judge to remain free on $10,000 bond pending an appeal, which O'Kicki's attorney said would be filed. Preate spokesman Mike Moyle said O'Kicki will be eligible for parole after serving two years.

DOC.HEAD: For Lip Readers, Bush's Turnabout Flops _ Even in Peoria
DOC.TEXT: Read my lips? Yo, George, read this. President Bush's flip-flop on his hallmark campaign pledge of ``no new taxes'' is generating more heat than a summer hot spell in Death Valley. Taxes and the hot air of broken political promises provided a combustible mix for people in the street, radio talk show callers, headline writers and late night comics. ``I think all politicians have some little white lies in them,'' said Peter Sienkowski, 52, a Dallas Republican. WABC Talk Radio in New York City played Bush's oft-repeated campaign pledge with his Tuesday statement that reducing the federal deficit would need ``tax revenue increases.'' The about-face prompted a torrent of calls. ``How many times have we heard that phrase, `read my lips?''' wondered Paulette Pettit of WABC. ``There wasn't passion or anger among callers. It was more a feeling of, `I can't believe I fell for that line.''' Ted O'Brien of WRKO in Boston, home of defeated Democratic presidential candidate Michael Dukakis, said the phone lines sizzled Wednesday. ``It was THE topic,'' O'Brien said. ``There is a sense of disappointment among his supporters. Those on the other side had a sense of let him twist slowly in the wind. And there were those who said the Duke would have done it 14 months earlier.'' Headline writers had a field day. ``Read My Lips...I Lied!'' said the New York Post on its front page. Inside was this line: ``Read His Forked Tongue.'' The New York Daily News offered: ``Bush's Lips Say The `T' Word.'' The Times-Picayune in New Orleans had this: ``Re-Read My Lips, Bush Says: Taxes Must Increase After All.'' ``Late Night'' comic David Letterman on Wednesday's show listed the top 10 other campaign promises Bush has broken. His list included a birthday joyride on the stealth bomber for every U.S. citizen, going 10 rounds with Dukakis at Trump Plaza, adding a mechanical shark to the White House tour and, number one, the nude Elvis postage stamp. Bush's new pitch flopped in Peoria, where the president was pilloried. ``I think it stinks,'' said Marsha Barnes of that Illinois community. ``He's just like all the rest. They promise you something, then they get in office and break their word. I won't believe him in the future.'' ``He's a liar,'' said Susan Russell, a resident of the Illinois city. ``I never did believe that `read my lips' stuff and now I think all that publicity about his loving family was a lot of baloney.'' Robert Miller, a Peoria Republican who voted for Bush, said the president's change of heart was predictable if not well-received. ``Don't they all break their promises once they get in office?'' he said. Indeed, Bush's turnabout didn't come as that much of a surprise. In a May 30 Gallup Poll, 74 percent of the respondents said Bush would not be able to keep his pledge of no new taxes. An ABC News-Washington Post poll of May 14 showed 49 percent of the respondents said Bush should drop his promise and consider raising taxes to reduce the federal deficit. Thirty-eight percent said he should keep his word. And who pays will have a big impact on how any tax increase is received. An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll last month said 68 percent of the respondents favor high taxes for the rich. Pollsters say Bush's credibility hinges on whether the public sees the switch as a change of direction or the cold reality that taxes are needed to cut the deficit. ``How people read the economy is the important context on how this decision will be read,'' said Andy Kohut of Princeton Survey Research. ``Our surveys show a willingness to pay more in targeted areas, such as health care, the war on drugs, the environment.'' Some of Bush's supporters grudgingly said he had no choice. ``He wouldn't have done it unless his back was up against the wall. When he said no new taxes, I think he was sincere at the time,'' said Laurie Ashcraft, 45, a Chicago marketing research manager. ``I think the guy's got some savvy for being able to recognize the situation and having guts to go against what he said earlier,'' said Jon Simon, 29, of Boston. ``I applaud him for it. He finally took a stand and wasn't afraid to contradict himself.'' But no reasonings appeased Chago Saldana, 67, the owner of a tire shop in Rio Hondo, Texas, a community of 2,000 residents near the Mexican border. Said Saldana, ``It's a bunch of bull.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislator Warns Israel on Expansion of Settlements
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 1-2 to CORRECT to subcommittee sted committee, UPDATE with final passage; picks up 3rd graf pvs bg'ng, Rep. David Obey, ...,
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House foreign aid subcommittee said Wednesday he will support cuts in aid to Israel next year if its government persists in expanding settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The blunt warning came as the House, approving a $15.7 billion foreign aid bill, narrowly voted to preserve President Bush's policy of not sending U.S. aid to international family planning groups linked to abortion and agreed to keep money flowing to Cambodia's non-communist resistance. The vote on final passage was 308 to 117. Rep. David Obey, treading on a subject seldom mentioned openly in Washington, said he meant the comments as ``a very friendly warning'' intended to ``avoid long-term tragedy and a mountain of death'' in the increasingly unstable region. ``If Israel expands their settlements in any way, or if they add a single new settlement, I will make a flat commitment to support any request made by the administration to reduce aid to Israel in next year's bill,'' the Wisconsin Democrat said. He was opening debate on a $15.8 billion foreign aid bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Obey's statement set him on a collision course with the newly installed right-wing Israeli government, which has promised to expand settlements in the territories seized in the 1967 six-day war. Obey said the amount of any aid cuts would be based on how much is spent on creating new settlements or expanding present ones. ``Israel is a sovereign nation and has the right to do anything they want. But the U.S. government has no obligation to fund, either directly or indirectly, settlements which we believe to be an impediment to the peace process,'' he said. The bill before the House included $3 billion in military and economic aid to Israel, which traditionally has been the largest single foreign recipient of U.S. largesse. A separate measure passed earlier this year included an additional $400 million in loan guarantees to build housing in Israel for Soviet Jewish emigres. Ariel Sharon, the housing minister of the new Israeli government, has said Israel will not settle any of the Soviet emigres in the West Bank or Gaza, and Obey welcomed that promise as a positive step. But his threat to cut aid applied to any settlement, whether by emigres or others. On the population issue, the House voted 224 to 198 to send $3 million through private groups for family planning and other health projects in Romania, whose people have for decades been subject to a government policy against contraception. But the amendment, offered by Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., specifically excluded from participation two groups _ the United Nations Population Fund and the International Planned Parenthood Federation _ which participate in abortion counseling, referral or services. Smith's opponents argued that those two groups are the only ones which now operate in Romania, so barring them would make any aid program for that country ineffective. But Smith and allies countered that Bush would veto any bill that included funding for the two abortion-linked agencies. The lawmakers also adopted, 260 to 162, an amendment by Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., to provide $7 million in non-lethal aid to the coalition opposing Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government. That replaced language in the bill barring any aid to the resistance, a prohibition supported by members who feared the dominance of the Khmer Rouge in the coalition. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia in the 1970s and were responsible for the deaths of more than 1 million people in what have come to be known as ``the killing fields.'' They are the strongest military faction in a coalition which also receives millions of dollars in covert U.S. military aid. Solarz argued that the money is needed to keep pressure on the government to reach a peaceful settlement, and House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., said it would maintain ``at least the figment, if not the reality, of a third force'' in the country. The bill is the principal vehicle for U.S. military, economic and development aid to friends and allies around the globe. This year's version begins what Obey has called a planned 5-year transition away from a past emphasis on military aid and toward economic support. Citing reduced East-West tensions and an end to the Cold War, the House Appropriations Committee included new money for emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, refugee and children's programs, and development in Africa and Latin America. To pay for the increases, the panel cut nearly $400 million from President Bush's military aid request. The Bush administration agreed to support the bill on the House floor, with the understanding that it would work when the measure goes to the Senate to soften the military aid cut and other provisions it objects to. High on the list of White House objections is language halving military aid to El Salvador, expected to be about $85 million next year, and applying conditions intended to keep the warring government and leftist FMLN rebels at the peace table. Negotiations on a new bipartisan policy toward El Salvador are being conducted separately between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and a team of House Democrats and Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: Abortions Getting Harder to Find in Rural Areas, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Abortion services are getting harder to find in rural parts of the country and in some areas women have to travel hundreds of miles to a provider, a report by the Alan Guttmacher Institute said Wednesday. Nearly all of the nearly 1.6 million abortions performed in 1988 were performed in metropolitan areas. About 1.7 percent _ a total of 27,000 _ took place in rural areas, according to the survey by the independent, non-profit research group. In 1979, when 1.5 million abortions were performed in this country, about 4.5 percent of them, around 67,000, were in rural facilities. As the concentration of abortion services has continued to shift from hospitals to specialized clinics, women in rural areas have been hit hardest. Those women usually have had to rely on hospitals for abortion services, since small clinics often are not economical in rural areas, the report said. ``Our findings clearly show that access to abortion, which was already a tremendous problem for women living outside of the metropolitan areas of our country, is getting worse, even without additional state restrictions that may result from any new legislative activity,'' Stanley Henshaw, author of the report, said in a statement released with it. In South Dakota, for example, women living in the western and central parts of the state have to travel as far as 200 miles to the nearest abortion provider, the report said. It said that because of the long distances, rural women are more likely to have their abortion later in pregnancy when the health risks are greater.

DOC.HEAD: Warrant Issued for Arrest of Officer Accused of Cover-Up in Jesuit Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details on arrest warrant, defense attorney's comments, Cristiani's comments on peace talks, CORRECTS spelling of Guillermo, trims to edit. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A judge Wednesday issued an arrest warrant for an army officer accused of destroying evidence in the November massacre of six Jesuit priests, their cook and her teen-age daughter. The warrant comes after widespread criticism of the investigation by a U.S. congressional committee and leaders of El Salvador's Roman Catholic Church. The charges accuse Lt. Col. Carlos Camilo Hernandez of destroying the mission logs of troops accused in the shootings at Central American University. Hernandez, an executive officer of the elite Belloso Battalion in San Salvador, is the former assistant director of the military college where the troops were stationed. The warrant was issued by Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is handling the politically charged investigation. It asks military officials to arrest Hernandez and hand him over to the civilian court for prosecution. Neither the armed forces press office nor the U.S. Embassy would comment on the latest development in the Jesuit case. Defense attorney Joaquin Barahona said the judge based his warrant on the testimony of several witnesses as well as statements by Hernandez himself. Hernandez is the tenth person charged in the case. The director of the military college, Col. Guillermo Benavides; three lieutenants; and five enlisted men have been charged with the slayings. No Salvadoran officer has ever been prosecuted for a human rights crime, despite the deaths of tens of thousands of people at the hands of death squads linked to the armed forcesor President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist Republican Nationalist Alliance. To date, the only evidence presented against Benavides has been that of other defendants, which is not admissible in Salvadoran courts. However, a key military witness appeared before the judge Wednesday in a closed hearing. Col. Carlos Armando Aviles, who reportedly blew the case open by telling a U.S. military adviser who was responsible for the slayings, arrived Wednesday in El Salvador from Taiwan, where he had been sent for ``military training'' after the Jesuit massacre. ``Aviles is a key witness,'' a defense lawyer, requesting anonymity, told The Associated Press. ``If he testifies to what he has said unofficially, it will be overwhelming evidence against the defendants.'' Asked about the latest developments in the Jesuit case at a news conference Wednesday, Cristiani would only comment: ``If the judge thinks he has proof he should proceed according to the law.'' The massacre took place amid a huge offensive by leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, who have waged a decade-long insurgency. Army positions at the college had come under fire several times. The six priests and educators, their housekeeper and her 15-year-old daughter were roused from their sleep before dawn Nov. 16 and killed by troops of the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion. Two of three lieutenants leading the death squad said Benavides issued an order to kill the priests. The investigation has moved slowly and there have been reports that crucial evidence has been destroyed, that military witnesses have been given assignments abroad to keep them from testifying, and that the true masterminds of the slayings were being protected. The far-right considered the left-leaning Jesuit academics subversive because they blamed social injustice, rather than international communist expansion, for El Salvador's revolution. The Rev. Ignacio Ellacuria, rector of Central American University and one of the region's most respected educators, was one of those slain. The murders provoked an international outcry and calls from some quarters in the U.S. Congress for sharp cuts in aid to El Salvador, the largest recipient of U.S. aid in the hemisphere. Washington currently sends El Salvador about $1 million a day in economic and military aid. The money keeps this small nation and its powerful military afloat. Cristiani has taken pains to assure U.S. officials there will be a good-faith investigation and punishment of those responsible. At least 72,000 people have died in the civil war, most of them civilians. The government is also under pressure from the rebels to resolve the Jesuit case. The rebels demanded army officers be made accountable for rights abuses at the latest round of peace talks that ended this week in Mexico. At his news conference, Cristiani said the talks, which produced no substantive accords, were ``positive in the sense that there were advances in the process of pacification.''

DOC.HEAD: Records Set, Both High and Low; Usual Summer Thunderstorms Hit Some Sectors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CLARIFY that Phoenix reading is from Luke Air Force Base; official Phoenix reading, used in AM-Heat Wave, Bjt, comes from Sky Harbor airport
DOC.TEXT: Record breaking temperatures, both high and low, were set Wednesday, and thunderstorms hit various parts of the nation. Miami cooled to 71 degrees during the morning and tied its record low for for the date, set in 1968. San Diego and Scottsbluff, Neb., reached 68 degrees, breaking the record for the warmest low temperature for the date. On Wednesday afternoon in Southern California, highs ranged from about 80 degrees at the beaches, to near 110 degrees at the Los Angeles Civic Center, to 114 degrees in the inland valleys, and as high as 122 across the lower deserts. The heat wave was expected to continue through Thursday across western Texas and through Sunday in Southern California. The National Weather Service predicted that the heat wave will move eastward, slowly, and temperatures will rise across much of the nation during the weekend. Among the cities setting record highs for the date Wednesday: Cheyenne, Wyo., where the 94-degree reading surpassed by one degree the 1970 record; and Denver, which broke its record set in the same year by six degrees, registering 102. That reading at Denver also tied the city's record high for June; it was last reached in 1954. The usual summer thunderstorms grew during the morning. Storms produced hail three-quarters of an inch in diamater near Elkhorn, Wis., and Waseca, Minn., where winds gusted to 60 mph. By early afternoon, the showers and thunderstorms extended from parts of Lower Michigan across northeast Illinois and southeast Wisconsin, and from southeast Minnesota into north-central Iowa. They also struck parts of the Dakotas, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana, Mississippi, and the lower Texas Gulf Coast. Rainshowers and thunderstorms extended along the Florida Panhandle coast, and central and southern Florida. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered in parts of Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, New York state and across western New England. Wednesday morning's low for the nation was 36 degrees at Truckee, Calif. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 46 degrees at Grand Marais, Minn., to 115 at Luke Air Force Base, west of Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Criminal Division Resigning from Justice for Philadelphia Firm
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Justice Department's criminal division, Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., is resigning to join a Philadelphia law firm, officials said Wednesday night. Dennis' resignation, expected to be announced Thursday, creates another vacancy in the top echelons of the Justice Department, which has been plagued by personnel difficulties in the last year. But officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Dennis's resignation as an assistant attorney general is unrelated to recent turmoil on the staff of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Dennis, who has spent most of his career as a Justice Department prosecutor, will become a senior partner at the prestigious Philadelphia firm of Morgan, Lewis and Bockius, said one official. ``This is for his personal and professional benefit,'' the official said. Without disputing that, two sources familiar with the situation said Dennis had grown frustrated with Thornburgh's close-to-the-vest management style that centralized decision-making in the attorney general's office. These sources spoke on condition that they not be identified. Dennis, the first black to head the Justice Department's criminal division, will join the national litigation section at the firm Morgan, Lewis and Bockius has more than 600 lawyers in several cities, including Washington. As a holdover from the Reagan administration, Dennis long had plans to return to Philadelphia, where he was U.S. attorney for five years before he became assistant attorney general in 1988, officials said. He commutes daily by train from his home near Media, Pa., a suburb southwest of Philadelphia. Last year, Dennis served as acting deputy attorney general as well as head of the criminal division. As such he was the highest-ranking black ever to serve in the department. Dennis, who officials said would remain on the job through August, is the second top Justice Department official to resign in the last two months. In May, Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer, the department's No. 2 official, resigned amid great acrimony, later accusing Thornburgh of mishandling an internal investigation of an unauthorized news leak. Sources said Ayer was also frustrated because he had been frozen out of policy-making decisions by the attorney general's top aides, who worked for Thornburgh when he was governor of Pennsylvania. Several days after Ayer's resignation, Thornburgh resassigned two top aides, spokesman David Runkel and chief of staff Robert S. Ross Jr. in an attempt to counteract criticism that he was isolated from the department and surrounded by political loyalists. The president nominated William P. Barr, assistant attorney general in charge of the Office of Legal Counsel, to succeed Ayer as deputy. Barr told the Senate Judiciary Committee at his confirmation hearing Wednesday that he was asked by Thornburgh to restore the traditional lines of authority in the department. Barr said that post of executive assistant to the attorney general, which had been Ross's job, was abolished. Barr said he now reports directly to Thornburgh. The 40-year-old Barr, who is acting deputy attorney general, told senators that all the Justice Department components now report to the attorney general through him. When Ayer was deputy, some divisions and agencies reported to Thornburgh, Barr said. Barr told lawmakers that Thornburgh's staff assumed more responsiblities than the attorney general had intended because he had difficulty recruiting top people in the waning days of the Reagan administration. Personnel difficulties continued after Thornburgh was asked to stay on as attorney general in the Bush administration. His first choice for deputy attorney general, Robert Fiske, was rejected by conservatives because of involvement in the American Bar Association's judicial screening committee. Barr told the committee that Thornburgh's staff continued to retain many responsibilities because of the difficulty finding a deputy. Beside's Barr's appointment, other nominations for vacant Justice Department positions are pending in the Senate. The Senate is also considering the nomination of Michael Luttig to succeed Barr as the department's legal counsel. Late last year, Carol Crawford, assistant attorney general in charge of legislative affairs, resigned following a series of bureaucratic turf wars. Lee Rawls has been nominated to head the office.

DOC.HEAD: Over 1,000 Calls, No Strong Leads in Search for Killer
DOC.TEXT: More than a thousand callers have flooded a police hotline with reports they saw or spoke to the ``Zodiac gunman,'' but none has produced a firm lead, police said Wednesday. Mayor David N. Dinkins has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the gunman, who has promised a death for each sign of the zodiac and already has killed one man and wounded three others since March 8. Investigators on the Zodiac Task Force are using a sophisticated computer system to keep track of the hotline calls. ``The computerized system enables us to do is make sure we capture all the tips, all the information that comes in, and gives us a chance to pull it up rapidly,'' said Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown. ``You don't know which call you get or what piece of information you get will be that which you need to bring resolution to the cases,'' he added. The calls are checked and assigned a priority by supervisors and ``if there's a sign that something is really hot, that will be dealt with immediately,'' Brown said. The most credible sounding tipsters are interviewed by detectives. Investigators interviewed 18 callers on Wednesday, but believed their reports were unfounded, said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. Police and news organizations have received six notes from someone claiming responsibility for the shootings. In one of the notes, the writer threatened to kill 12 people _ one for each astrological sign. Police have said they do not believe the gunman is connected to the killer dubbed the ``zodiac'' who claimed responsibility for as many as 40 killings in a series of notes sent to San Francisco-area newspapers from 1968 to 1987. The latest shooting victim, Larry Parham, said he was questioned about his birth date by a stranger a few days before he was shot in Central Park. Parham's astrological sign _ Cancer _ was referred to a letter left at the scene. However, another of the four victims said Wednesday that the gunman, who was wearing a mask, said nothing to him before he opened fire. This victim, whose spoke to WNBC-TV on condition of anonymity, said he did not think the man knew his astrological sign. The police task force has grown to more than 50 investigators, and they are consulting with ``people who have a knowledge of astrology,'' Brown said. Brown was Atlanta's public safety commissioner and headed the investigation of a series of child killings there in 1979 to 1981.

DOC.HEAD: President Havel Swears in New Chechoslovak Government
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel on Wednesday swore in Czechoslovakia's first democratically elected government in more than four decades. Also Wednesday, the new Parliament elected as speaker of the house Alexander Dubcek, leader of the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms that were crushed by Soviet-led troops. He had been appointed interim speaker in December. The new 16-member government, headed by incumbent Premier Marian Calfa, was formed in talks involving Havel's Civic Forum, its Slovak ally Public Against Violence and the Christian Democratic Movement. Civic Forum and Public Against Violence spearheaded November's peaceful revolution that deposed the Communists who had ruled for four decades. The two groups together won a majority in the 300-seat Parlament in June 8-9 elections. At the ceremony at Hradcany Castle, the seat of the president, Calfa pledged to help lead Czechoslovakia out of the debris of the Communist legacy, recalling the democratic tradition that prevailed before Communist rule. ``We have a great past and we are in the ruins of the present. Our task is to step over these ruins and lead Czechoslovakia on the road to Europe, on the road toward prosperity,'' Calfa said. Havel reminded the new government of its responsibility. ``After long decades, you are the first government that has emerged from free elections, a government born of the true will of the people,'' Havel said. Several members of the interim Cabinet remained in the new government. They included Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier, economic reformer Vladimir Dlouhy and Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek. Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus and Labor Minister Petr Miller also retained their ministries. Dlouhy and Pavel Hoffmann, a Slovak economist, are to head new ministries that will oversee planned radical economic reforms. A third economist, Vaclav Vales, retained his post as deputy Prime Minister and is to coordinate the transformation to a market economy. One of the Parliament's first tasks will be to elect a new President for a two-year term. Havel has been nominated for the post but has said he would accept only if the government wins Parliamentary support. In the new 300-seat legislature, Civic Forum and Public Against Violence have 170 members. The Communists won 47 seats and the third-strongest group, the Christian Democratic alliance, won 40 places. The House of Nations and the House of the People, the two chambers of Parliament, met in joint session to elect a speaker and presidium. Dubcek, who was chosen speaker, became a symbol of reform during the November revolution. After initial resistance, the Christian Democratic Movement agreed to join the government coalition. A government comprising only the Civic Forum and Public Against Violence would have lacked the three-fifths majority needed to push through constitutional changes. Officials from both groups repeatedly stated they sought the broadest possible coalition, but ruled out governing with the Communists. The Slovak government, which was also appointed Wednesday, is headed by Vladimir Meciar, a member of Public Against Violence.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian-Backed Hezbollah Criticizes Saudi Royal Family
DOC.TEXT: The Iranian-backed Hezbollah called Wednesday for stripping the Saudi Arabian royal family of its role as custodian of Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina. The call came in a statement issued in Beirut to mark the third anniversary of clashes in Mecca between Iranian pilgrims and Saudi security forces in which more than 400 people were killed. Most of the victims were Iranian pilgrims staging anti-U.S. demonstrations during pilgrimage rituals around the Kaaba, Islam's most sacred shrine. Saudi Arabia has since introduced a quota system, curtailing the number of pilgrims to Mecca. Tehran rejected the move and ordered a boycott of the pilgrimage, which is considered a sacred duty that all Moslems must perform at least once in their lifetimes. The Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God, is Iran's main ally in Lebanon, the only country where the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's brand of Shiite fundamentalism has taken strong roots. ``On the third anniversary of Mecca's bloody massacre committed by the Wahhabi rulers ... we stress that they must be stripped of custodianship on the two most sacred shrines,'' Hezbollah's statement said. The Saudi dynasty belongs to the Bedouin Wahhabi community, an offshoot of the Sunni Moslem sect. The ruling family of Al-Saud traditionally holds trusteeship over the Kaaba and the tomb of the Prophet Mohammed in Medina.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Armored Car Robbery, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0762,0543
DOC.HEAD: Possibility of Inside Job Investigated in Record Heist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Both employees...' and ADDS 1 graf to UPDATE with comment from second AMSA official that company has no policy prohibiting stops; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: ``Skeptical'' authorities on Wednesday were investigating whether robbers who stole $10.8 million from an armored truck may have had inside help. FBI agents and Monroe County sheriff's officials also said they had found a van believed to have been used in Tuesday's robbery, the biggest theft from an armored car in U.S. history. At least two gunmen held up the truck when the driver and guard stopped to buy coffee and sandwiches shortly after leaving Armored Motor Service of America's offices in the Rochester suburb of Chili. The truck was on its way to the Federal Reserve Bank branch in Buffalo with surplus cash from area banks. Lloyd's of London insurance companies are offering a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the robbers and recovery of the stolen money. The driver and guard, whose names have not been released, told authorities they were bound, gagged and blindfolded while the robbers transferred the cash to another vehicle. Both employees have been given lie-detector tests, the results of which weren't released. One company official said their stop at the convenience store violated company policy, but another official denied there was such a policy. Sheriff Andrew P. Meloni said a gray van was found Wednesday afternoon as the result of a telephone tip. ``We are certain it was used in the robbery,'' Meloni said at a news conference. He would not say where the van was discovered or what evidence connected it with the theft. One of the gunmen was wearing brown clothing ``similar to the uniforms worn by the company that operated the truck,'' said FBI Special Agent G. Robert Langford. ``We don't know if that means he was an employee or if the uniform was used to gain access to the truck or to prevent him from attracting a lot of attention.'' The two employees, who were not injured, were questioned by authorities for more than eight hours Tuesday, sheriff's department spokesman Tom Ryan said. Ryan said authorities were ``skeptical'' about some of the details of the story told by the driver and the guard. Meloni said ``we haven't ruled anybody in or out'' as a suspect. Teams of FBI agents and sheriff's officials interviewed current and former AMSA employees Wednesday and searched for witnesses, sheriff's Capt. Neil Flood said. ``Somebody's sitting on 1,500 pounds of money out there somewhere,'' Flood said. Sheriff's deputies and FBI agents questioned customers and passers-by outside the convenience store where the truck was held up. Keith Frank, manager of the store, said the truck had stopped there before _ sometimes as often as two or three times a week. Michael Bucci, executive vice president of AMSA, said the stop was a violation of company policy. ``You don't stop,'' Bucci said. ``Absolutely not.'' But George Clark, the company's controller, said Wednesday there is no rule that absolutely prohibits stops.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Grows to 15,000 Acres after Killing 6 Firefighters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to add fresh quotes, survivor's comments, details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A blaze that killed six firefighters when it flared like ``a big blowtorch'' spread Wednesday across 15,000 acres of Arizona's most verdant pine forest. A photographer who escaped the fatal firestorm Tuesday described how he and others fled for their lives into a burned-out clearing. ``There wasn't much time for thinking, just survival,'' said Chad Surmick. ``All of a sudden the trees around us started bursting into flames. It was like Roman candles going up all over the place.'' The firefighters were killed and five others injured when a ``dry thunderstorm'' struck the area Tuesday, driving the fire along the Mogollon Rim in all directions and trapping several crews, said Jim Paxon, fire-information officer for the Gila National Forest in New Mexico. ``It's just like a big furnace, a big blowtorch kind of effect,'' Paxon said. ``It built its own thunderhead from the fire. That was a 40,000-foot vertical column, five to six miles across.'' The fire had destroyed about 50 houses and forced evacuation of 700 others by Wednesday. The dead firefighters were five inmates from the Perryville state prison west of Phoenix and an administrative assistant to the warden at the prison's San Pedro Unit, said corrections spokesman Michael Arra. Four of the five injured firefighters also were Perryville prisoners, while the fifth was from a Tucson fire department. The inmates were participating in a 5-year-old volunteer firefighting program which had never had a casualty, Arra said. Surmick, a photographer for the Mesa Tribune, was with six other journalists and a number of firefighters ``when we started noticing the fire getting closer and closer and the smoke was getting really bad.'' While he and others ran to a previously burned clearing, the fire jumped the road behind them. ``As we were running up the hill, some of the TV guys were trying to film,'' Surmick said. ``The firefighters were screaming at them, `This is not the time to be filming; we are going to die if you don't get up that hill.''' Surmick and the others were trapped in the clearing for about three hours. Tanker planes and helicopters backed up as many as 1,500 firefighters and support personnel fighting the blaze in Tonto and Coconino National Forests, which was ignited Monday by lightning. Firefighters also had to contend with a heat wave that sent temperatures soaring to an all-time record high of 106 degrees at Payson, 13 miles to the southwest. Smoke billowing from 30-foot-high flames was so thick that command stations repeatedly lost touch with firefighter crews. Payson was choked with smoke, and the smoke and ash reached as far away as Show Low, 90 miles to the east. Tonto National Forest fire information officer Bob Celaya estimated that nearly all of Bonita Creek Estates, a subdivision of 57 summer homes, had been destroyed. The subdivision was evacuated Monday evening, and the residents of about 700 other threatened homes were told to evacuate Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks Resume in Aftermath of Bush Turnaround on Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 new grafs for lede with plan to raise Social Security tax; SUBS 7th graf pvs: ``Sen. James,'' now 8th graf, with details
DOC.TEXT: Democrats responding to President Bush's endorsement of possible tax increases offered a plan Wednesday to cut billions of dollars in benefit programs such as Social Security and to raise taxes paid by some people covered by the retirement program. Republican congressional leaders, meanwhile, faced a budding rebellion over Bush's tax turnabout. White House and congressional negotiators searching for ways to cut the 1991 federal deficit began discussing proposals in earnest, a day after Bush said ``tax revenue increases'' are needed as part of a plan to cut the deficit. Democrats, citing Bush's concession, offered a plan that one participant, speaking on condition of anonymity, said totaled $5.6 billion in savings. Negotiators are seeking $45 billion to $60 billion in new taxes and spending cuts for fiscal year 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Another official, also requesting anonymity, said the options came to $10 billion. The official said one element was a three-month delay in cost-of-living increases for benefit programs for which people qualify automatically, such as Social Security pensions for retired workers. Under that plan, the annual cost-of-living boosts would be delayed from Jan. 1 to April 1 for a savings of $3 billion. The official said the suggestion for delaying cost-of-living adjustments ran into objections from Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Rostenkowski said the political consequences of such a delay would be ``death,'' the official said. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., said the Democratic package included reductions in Medicare and federal employee benefit programs. Sasser also said the plan would increase from 50 percent to 85 percent the amount of Social Security benefits subject to federal taxes for couples whose incomes exceed $32,000 annually. The tax boost would raise $3.1 billion next year. ``We're trying to be even-handed about it, tit-for-tat,'' said Sasser. ``They're talking about taxes, and we're talking about reducing entitlements,'' the bureaucratic term for benefit programs. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said the negotiators generally agreed that their goal should be to achieve a balanced budget by 1995. The Gramm-Rudman law requires the deficit to be eliminated by 1993, a goal that virtually everyone in Washington believes cannot be achieved. ``It's fair to assume ... the targets are going to be changed,'' Domenici said of the series of declining annual deficit goals set by Gramm-Rudman. In seven weeks of meetings, only one proposal had been advanced, a $51 billion deficit-reduction package offered last week by White House budget director Richard Darman. It was quickly dismissed by Democrats as insufficient. But Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., said after emerging from the Wednesday morning session of closed-door bargaining, ``The whole tenor has changed. It is very determined. It doesn't seem to be as acrimonious. It's, `How do we get there?''' Some other Republicans, not part of the negotiations, didn't feel that way. ``The president may well go into a back room somewhere and sign off on this deal, but Republicans haven't,'' said Rep. Bob Walker, R-Pa., who led a letter-writing campaign in the House against any tax increase. Negotiators said there was no attempt during Wednesday morning's meeting to learn what taxes Bush was referring to. But outside the Capitol meeting room where negotiators met, Democrats and Republicans grappled for political advantage over Bush's statement. The president said Tuesday that spending cuts, changes in the budget process and a cut in the capital gains tax rate _ which everyone agrees would increase revenues, atleast initially _ were also required to shrink a budget gap that could surpass $200 billion next year. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp told reporters that revenues can come from many sources, including a growing economy, new federal fees or taxes on tobacco. ``It certainly didn't violate, in my view, any pledge,'' Kemp said. But many rank-and-file Republicans, counting on the subject of taxes as a campaign issue against Democrats, were pained by Bush's retreat from his promise of ``no new taxes.'' Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., collected the signatures of 12 of the Senate's 45 Republicans on a letter saying the deficit must be controlled ``through spending reductions and economic growth, not through tax increases.'' On Tuesday, 90 of the 176 House Republicans signed a similar note. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, one of the administration's budget negotiators, turned aside questions about Republican anger over the president's announcement. ``All of us in the budget process have a very strong commitment to the fact that sniping and private opinions from the sidelines to gain political advantage are not going to help this process,'' Brady said. ``I feel the president's actions yesterday were an exercise in leadership. That is why the American people elected him and I am sure they are going to look at it that way,'' Brady told reporters at the White House. Democratic leaders said they remained unconcerned about the petitions, saying unhappy lawmakers might change their minds if tax increases were part of a solid deficit-reduction package that included spending cuts. ``I'm not going to write it off today,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said of the prospects for passage of a budget deal. The Democratic Study Group, a liberal research arm of the House's Democrats, released a letter to Foley insisting any tax increases be levied on people with annual incomes greater than $200,000 annually. The petition, circulated last month, was signed by 134 House Democrats. ``Working and middle-class families have fought for a decade against declining wages while their tax burden has gone up,'' the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopters Carrying 24 Reporters Collide in Nicaragua
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two helicopters carrying journalists collided Wednesday afternoon as they were returning from a Contra demobilization ceremony in the countryside. A witness said several were badly injured. ``In all the years I've covered the war, I've never felt so close to death,'' said Ernesto Mejia, an Associated Press photographer aboard one of the helicopters. ``It seemed unreal, to end the war almost dying.'' There were unofficial reports at least 14 people had been hospitalized. A spokesman for the presidential press office said authorities were still compiling a list of the injured several hours after the crash. Mejia said 24 journalists were on board the two helicopters when they collided at 2:15 p.m. as they were taking off from San Pedro de Lovago, a village where Contra commanders had turned over their weapons to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in a ceremony marking the end of the civil war. The journalists were evacuated to Managua, about 100 miles away, in helicopters from the United Nations-Organization of American States force overseeing the Contra demobilization. ``When we reached an altitude of about 15 meters (yards), the nose of our helicopter dropped and we hit the other MI-17 as it was taking off,'' Mejia said. ``We felt a terrible impact and then we were on the ground, some of our comrades crying. ``After getting out as best we could, we saw that the other helicopter had fallen about 200 meters (yards) away,'' he said. Mejia said he and eight other reporters were in one helicopter and 15 were in the second. ``We could see that Barricada reporter Guillermo Cortes was unconscious and we told the OAS people, who got him out. Seconds later, the helicopter caught on fire and burned to a crisp.'' Mejia said there were three reporters from Nicaraguan national television on his helicopter along with freelance photographer Arturo Robles, two reporters for Barricada, the Sandinista party newspaper, and two photographers from the presidential press office. Mejia said the other helicopter, which was carrying 15 journalists, did not burn but most of its occupants appeared injured. Mejia said Agence France Press reporter Lidia Hunter, a Nicaraguan, and AFP photographer Bruno Martina, an Italian, appeared badly injured and were taken to the military hospital in Managua. A Univision cameraman appeared to have suffered serious injuries in both legs and was unable to move, Mejia said. Peter Northall, a photographer for Agence France Press, said he suffered only minor injuries in the crash. A third helicopter carrying journalists made the flight to Managua safely, Mejia said.

DOC.HEAD: Roemer Believes Abortion Bill Veto Likely To Be Sustained
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with final passage of abortion bill, picks up 9th graf pvs, `Louisiana legislative...; SUBS last graf to conform
DOC.TEXT: The Legislature gave final approval Wednesday night to the strictest state abortion bill in the nation and passed it along to Gov. Buddy Roemer, who has promised a veto. The bill calls for prison terms of up to 10 years hard labor for doctors who perform abortions, and offers no exceptions for women who wish to abort fetuses that are the product of rape or incest. The bill's sponsors hope to use it to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion rights. Roemer has 10 days to act, and the legislative session ends in 12 days. Roemer and abortion rights advocates predicted Wednesday that the Legislature would sustain Roemer's promised veto The House passed the final version by a 80-23 vote Wednesday night, accepting amendments the Senate had added to clarify that abortion would be allowed to save the life of the mother. The Senate Tuesday passed the bill by 24-15, two votes shy of the two-thirds majority needed to override a veto. ``I believe the vote yesterday in the Senate showed that there will be sufficient votes to sustain the veto. But that will be their decision,'' Roemer said at a news conference. ``We have the votes to sustain both in the Senate and in the House,'' said Robin Rothrock, leader of a coalition of state abortion-rights groups. ``I'm feeling great.'' Rep. Woody Jenkins, the bill's author, met with Roemer privately for more than an hour Wednesday, but they failed to reach a compromise, Jenkins said. Wedndesday's House vote, and a 74-27 vote on a version of the bill last week, provided margins large enough for an override. But anti-abortion lawmakers have conceded privately that they might not be able to carry all those votes to override. Louisiana legislative historians say there is no record of a veto being overridden this century. At his news conference, Roemer reiterated his opposition to abortion on demand and criticized groups who have threatened economic boycotts of the state if an anti-abortion law is adopted. In California Tuesday, the president of the Los Angeles chapter of the National Organization for Women said the chapter is drafting a resolution calling for a boycott of all tourism and conventions in Louisiana, to be considered at NOW's annual meeting beginning Friday in San Francisco. ``These same women criticize others for having narrow fundamental views and then I see these kinds of threats. I don't like it,'' Roemer said. But the governor said Louisiana abortion law must have rape and incest exceptions. ``If we cannot give some credence and faith and hope and constructive opportunity to the victims of those crimes then I don't think that this bill should be signed by me and will be vetoed,'' he said. Jenkins said the exceptions could easily be used by women falsely claiming to be rape victims to get a legal abortion. He also said such exceptions would contradict past Louisiana abortion law, a 19th century measure that included no exceptions. Such inconsistency would weaken the state's case should the bill reach the Supreme Court, Jenkins said. ``That's just absolute self-serving foolishness,'' responded Roemer, who said he used to oppose exceptions but changed his mind. Although several states have adopted strict anti-abortion laws in the past year since the Supreme Court upheld a restrictive Missouri abortion law, none has attempted to outlaw all abortions. Idaho's legislature passed a bill outlawing abortion except in some cases of rape, incest, fetal deformity or a threat to the life or health of the woman. But that measure was vetoed by Gov. Cecil Andrus in March. Also in March, the U.S. territory of Guam approved a law that makes it a felony for a doctor to perform an abortion and a misdemeanor for a woman to have an abortion; it makes an exception in cases in which the woman's life is threatened. That law is on hold while it is challenged in court. The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday upheld Minnesota and Ohio laws requiring minors to notify their parents or a judge before having an abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Slugger to Become Baseball's First $5 Million Man
DOC.TEXT: Oakland A's slugger Jose Canseco became baseball's first $5 million man and its highest paid player Wednesday when he agreed to a 5-year deal worth $23.5 million. The contract moved him ahead of the Yankees' Don Mattingly, who in April signed a 5-year, $19.6 million deal. ``I don't think it's what I'm worth,'' Canseco said at Wednesday's news conference. ``It's what the market holds, what the organizations are willing to pay a player. ``The popularity I have, whether it's controversial or positive, people want to come out and see Jose Canseco play.'' The A's, shooting for a third straight trip to the World Series, will pay Canseco $5.1 million in 1995, the final year of his new deal. He will collect a $3.5 million signing bonus, $2.8 million in 1991, $3.6 million in 1992, $4.1 million in 1993, and $4.4 million in 1994. There are incentives, too. If Canseco is named the American League's Most Valuable Player, he'll collect $100,000. An MVP in the playoffs and World Series is each worth another $50,000. The 25-year-old Canseco will earn $2 million in salary for this season. Oakland general manager Sandy Alderson said signing Canseco was necessary if the team was sincere about ``retaining the competitiveness and identity of the Oakland A's into the 1990s.'' He also said ``There's no question that our payroll is reaching the point of some limitation.'' Although he has missed 14 games because of back problems and another two due to a sore right wrist, Canseco has hit 20 home runs with 50 RBIs and a .307 average in 55 games this season. Canseco was voted the AL's MVP in 1988, when he became the first player to better the 40-home run and 40-steal plateau in the same year. He earned $325,000 that year.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Alleges Sexual Abuse by Father Lasted 16 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Additional comments from daughter throughout and Munno's scheduled arraignment
DOC.TEXT: A University of Maryland nuclear engineering professor Wednesday denied allegations that he sexually abused his daughter for more than 16 years. Frank J. Munno, 54, was indicted Tuesday by a Prince George's County grand jury on felony charges after Angela Mattson told authorities her father sexually abused her from the third grade through graduate school. ``I'm pleading not guilty because I'm not guilty,'' Munno said in a telephone interview from his College Park home. ``Shocked and outraged would be the words to describe the feelings I'm trying to keep inside,'' he said. ``My family is supportive and very disappointed.'' Mattson, 28, an engineer with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said she spoke out because she hoped to help other victims of abuse. ``I've learned it's sometimes easier to explain what happened than to keep it a dark secret,'' she told The Washington Post in Wednesday's editions. ``What I'm hoping is that there's a potential abuser out there who's going to see this and realize that his daughter's going to grow up to do something, press charges,'' she said. ``And maybe, he won't go into her bedroom.'' Munno, a tenured, $89,000-a-year professor, heads the nuclear engineering program on the College Park campus, the largest in the University of Maryland system. He has been at College Park for 32 years. He said he would not take a leave from his teaching position. ``Why would I be any worse a teacher because I was accused?'' Munno said. The grand jury charged Munno with incest, child abuse, unlawful carnal knowledge, and unnatural and perverted sex practices. He faces a maximum of 15 yers in prison, if convicted on all the charges. Munno is scheduled for arraignment July 13 on the child abuse charge, authorities said. Mattson said in an interview with WRC-TV that sending her father to prison is not her goal. ``I wanted to have my day in court and to have other people in my position to realize that they can get better, that there is help out there,'' she said. Her father's manipulation prevented her from pressing charges sooner, she said Wednesday. ``I couldn't even get up the courage to leave the house,'' she said. ``Even when I stopped the abuse my father was still able to make me feel guilty enough to stay at home. And in the last few years, it's been a slowly evolving process _ one of my own strength, my own independence.'' When asked if she loved her father, Mattson haltingly replied, ``I wish I had a father. I have come to the point where I need to feel that I don't have a father. A father couldn't have done what he did and continue treating me the way he is.'' In a statement, university officials said they cannot take action against Munno solely on the basis of indictments. Officials will assess the situation when the facts become available. ``I think the statement says they're waiting for the facts, which is refreshing in this society,'' Munno said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Model Details Drug Use With Barry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 22nd graf: ``The bishop,'' with stmnt from bishop
DOC.TEXT: Ex-model Rasheeda Moore testified Wednesday that she used cocaine, marijuana and opium with Marion Barry ``over 100 times'' and that the mayor once told her he was addicted to cocaine. Testifying in Barry's drug and perjury trial, the woman who cooperated with the FBI in the mayor's arrest said they had a sexual relationship and shared drugs between 1986 and 1988. She said Barry once slapped her to the floor after using drugs. ``It was an intimate relationship, and we used drugs together,'' said Moore. Barry watched the 39-year-old Moore with a stony stare as she described their relationship. Barry's wife, Effi, smiled as Moore took the witness stand but wore a grim expression as the witness detailed allegations of sex and drug use. Moore said Barry was an experienced drug user who baked powdered cocaine into crack. ``After he baked it, we smoked it,'' Moore testified. And she said that after smoking crack cocaine in one session, Barry ``said he was addicted to cocaine. He said he wanted to quit.'' Prosecutors were expected to use her testimony to introduce as evidence an FBI videotape of the Jan. 18 night when Barry allegedly smoked crack cocaine while visiting Moore at a Washington hotel room. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. One possession charge stems from the sting in which the three-term mayor was arrested. Moore described an affair that ranged from sex and violence to talks of spirituality, but which always included drugs. She told the court she and Barry used drugs ``at least over 100 times.'' ``There were times we would do it more than once a day, sometimes two or three times a week,'' she continued. ``Sometimes he would stop by before work, sometimes after hours,'' Moore said. Speaking in a low and even voice, Moore described how she and the mayor used drugs, including cocaine powder, crack cocaine, marijuana and opium, at a dozen places around Washington. She said Barry became violent after one session at a Washington hotel in which they smoked crack cocaine through a homemade pipe Barry assembled from aluminum foil and a large spoon. The mayor accused her of having a relationship with another man and ``slapped me,'' Moore said. She returned the slap, she said, but ``ended up on the floor'' when Barry slapped her again. ``I haven't hit a woman in 20 years,'' she said Barry told her. ``You bring the worst out in a man.'' She said they also used drugs at: _Barry's home. Moore testified she and Barry cooked cocaine powder and smoked it while Barry's wife and son were away from the house. _Moore's mother's home. She said she and Barry smoked crack cocaine there several times, including Dec. 22, 1988, the day Barry's visits to the hotel room of convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis were made public. Barry once smoked so much cocaine in the house, ``I had to hold him up. Afterward, he said, `That was a really great hit.''' _The Virginia home of Bishop H.H. Brookins, the leader of more than 300 African Methodist-Episcopal congregations in the region. She said she began to pass out there after smoking crack cocaine and cried out, ``Marion, Marion.'' But, she said, the mayor turned off the bathroom light and left, telling her later, ``I couldn't do anything, there was nothing I could do.'' ``I could have died,'' she told the court. The bishop said in statement he had never met Ms. Moore as far as he knew and if what she described actually happened, ``it would be a violation of the sanctity of my home, of my trust and of my friendship.'' After another crack-smoking episode, Barry said he was addicted to cocaine and ``talked to me for the first time about developing his spiritual side. He was tired, he wanted to get his life together, he talked about starting to go to church,'' said Moore. They were smoking together one Sunday in 1987, Moore testified, when ``I told him, this is Mother's Day, aren't you going to spend time with your family? He told me, `I am, but I have some time after church.''' Moore said Barry often become paranoid, and once sent her out to see if someone was watching them from a van parked outside the townhouse where they were using cocaine. Barry had a series of hiding places where he stashed the drug, including a vacuum cleaner bag, Moore added. Moore testified she first tried to hide her use of crack cocaine from the mayor because she ``didn't want the burden of guilt of introducing it to him.'' But, she said, Barry told her he was experienced with ``freebasing'' _ or smoking cocaine _ when he found a crack pipe in her apartment. ``Before the night was out, we had freebased, we had done crack,'' she said. At the time, Moore ran a youth modeling program for the city, and she testified that Barry helped her get the contract for the program. She estimated the contract was worth $180,000. Moore said she ended her sexual relationship with Barry in June 1988 ``because there was so much drug use over that period of time.'' But ``once we stopped the intimate relationship, we continued using drugs,'' Moore testified. At a bench conference, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin said Moore has been in the government's witness protection program since Jan. 29 because of death threats. Retchin claimed that there is a $100,000 contract out on Moore's life, but that there is no evidence Barry had anything to do with the threat.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to include quotes from manufacturer who says Hubble problem could be result of ``human error'' in ground testing; selection of Lew Allen to head NASA investigation; picks up 7th graf pvs, ``NASA scientist Ed Weiler,'' major consolidations and cuts in second half of story to trim
DOC.HEAD: Flaw Found In Focus Of $1.5 Billion Hubble Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: A focusing flaw that cannot be repaired from the ground has been found in the Hubble Space Telescope, leaving some instruments unworkable until a repair shuttle mission can be flown, NASA announced Wednesday. Many of the spectacular views of the universe that scientists hoped to get with the $1.5 billion Hubble instrument will not be possible now until a maintenance mission scheduled for 1993 is completed, officials said. NASA said it would try to fly the repair mission earlier. Engineers discovered the flaw when they attempted to fine-tune the focus between the primary and the secondary mirrors aboard the orbiting telescope. Hubble deputy project manager Jean Olivier said ``there was no single one point...with a crisp, clean image.'' Further study determined that there was a fundamental flaw that may have been built in when the mirrors were manufactured, Olivier said during a news conference. Jack Rehnberg, the chief of the space science program at Hughes Danbury Optical of Danbury Conn., manufacturer of the flawed mirrors, said the cause may have been human error during an extensive testing program while the mirrors were being made. ``We don't know the cause, but its probably something inherently, fundamentally not done right,'' he said. ``It could have been a human error.'' The mistake, he said, could have come with equipment that checked the polished mirror surface. NASA has said that tests showed that Hubble's 94-inch primary mirror is the smoothest large mirror ever made. ``We could have erred in the assembly of some of the test equipment and it didn't get picked up even though we've had lots of reviews, and checks and rechecks,'' said Rehnberg. The space agency has named Lew Allen, director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, to head a team investigating the Hubble problem. Rehnberg said he has selected a team of engineers from his company to help. NASA scientist Ed Weiler said the problem degrades the focus possible with several instruments aboard the orbiting telescope, particularly two cameras designed to take pictures in visible light of very faint and distant stars. He said a faint object camera, provided to the Hubble project by the European Space Agency, will not be able to take pictures of a quality any better than a ground-based telescope. A wide field camera, which was used to take the first photos from the Hubble released to the public, will be virtually useless until the telescope can be repaired. ``There is no real science we can do with it at this time,'' he said. Three instruments that can study stars by gathering ultraviolet and infrared radiation will not be as seriously affected, Weiler said. But he noted that one of these instruments, the high speed photometer, will be about to collect ``about half of the science'' that had been planned. The Hubble was placed in a 281-mile high orbit by space shuttle Discovery on April 25. Engineers have spent the time since trying to fine-tune the telescope and test its instruments, and have repeatedly reported problems. Engineers first discovered that a cable not installed properly was blocking the rotation of an antenna. This was corrected by limiting the antenna movement. Later, they found that incorrect computer software was causing the telescope to point at the wrong places in the sky. The software was changed. The experts also discovered that the 25,500-pound satellite developed a vibration that lasted for some minutes each time it went from sunrise to sunset and back again in its orbit. Engineers planned to compensate for the vibration with another computer program. But there is no way to fix the focusing flaw from the ground, said Weiler. Instead, he said NASA plans to try to move up a scheduled space shuttle maintenance flight to the telescope. Weiler said a replacement wide-field camera that had already been scheduled for the Hubble may be built with special optics that would correct the focusing distortion caused by the telescope mirrors. ``We are pretty optimistic that we can take out all of the aberration,'' said Weiler. Hubble maintenance flights by the space shuttle were originally planned for 1993, 1996 and 1997, and Weiler said those may be flown earlier if replacement instruments that correct the focusing flaw can be prepared. ``We are not losing science,'' he said. ``We are deferring science.'' Olivier, who has been a leader in checking out the telescope, said that engineers saw a pattern in their tests that had ``the classical characteristic you would expect for a spherical aberration,'' where light does not focus at a point as intended, but over a small volume. The two mirrors were tested individually on the ground, said Olivier, and passed all tests.
