DOC.HEAD: What It Takes for the Government to Concede We're In Recession
With BC-Unofficial Recession I
DOC.TEXT: The official definition of a recession was established by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a forecasting concern in Cambridge, Mass. that has been associated with presidential advisers Arthur Burns and Martin Feldstein and other influential economists. It measures recessions through the gross national product, the total value at retail prices of all goods and services produced by the economy in a given time period, adjusted for inflation. The GNP, compiled quarterly by the Commerce Department, is considered the broadest measure of economic health. Generally speaking, there must be at least two consecutive quarters of declines in GNP for the government to acknowledge a recession has occurred. That hasn't happened since the 1981-82 recession. The most recent GNP figure was issued June 21, when the Commerce Department said growth in the first quarter of this year totaled 1.9 percent on an annual basis, compared with 1.1 percent in the final three months of 1989.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 1

DOC.TEXT: President Bush, who won the White House with a ``read-my-lips'' pledge of no new taxes, conceded that tax increases must be part of any deficit-reduction plan. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. and chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, called Bush's statement Tuesday ``an important step in the right direction,'' while the White House said it marked the turning point in sluggish negotiations with Congress.

President Bush blocked new oil drilling off the coasts of much of California, Florida, Washington, Oregon and New England until the year 2000. Also Tuesday, he permanently blocked any drilling in a proposed marine sanctuary in California's Monterey Bay, and ordered a moratorium on new leases until 1996 for one section off southern California where drilling already is under way. The president called for more environmental studies to settle the question of whether leases might be offered after 2000.

Donald Trump secured urgently needed money from seven key banks to avoid defaulting on debts after his bankers agreed to a long-term $65 million financial rescue plan. The banks agreed in principle Tuesday to lend another $20 million to tide Trump over while finishing touches are placed on a restructuring to keep his sprawling real estate and casino empire solvent. Trump said he was happy with the deal, which will force him to cede some control over his holdings. In return, the banks agreed to spread out payments on more than $2 billion in outstanding loans over the five years.

The Soviet Union is having trouble paying $2 billion in foreign bills and needs more Western credits to help make the transition to a market economy, a government spokesman said. ``If we have credits, it will be easier for us to have economic reform,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told reporters Tuesday. Gerasimov said the Soviet Union has a current deficit _ the difference between cash on hand and outstanding bills _ of $2 billion. This is due to several factors, including the disruption involved in the transition from central planning to a market economy, he said.

The National, the daily sports newspaper that made its debut in its fourth city earlier this week, plans to have 16 printing sites in 13 markets by the end of March 1991, it publisher said. Publisher Peter Price said Tuesday the newspaper's owners, headed by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga, are committing more than $50 million to production of the heavy-grade, four-color newspaper.

A dramatic increase in smoking worldwide has been fostered by U.S. trade policies that ignore the health problems associated with tobacco, according to a report. ``Globally, increasing tobacco use is responsible for almost 2.5 million excessive or premature deaths per year _ almost 5 percent of all deaths,'' the report in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association said. U.S. trade policy perpetuates the problem by trying to develop overseas markets _ especially in Asia, the report said. It recommends changes in tobacco trade policies and the imposition of foreign-language health warning labels on cigarette packages bound for export.

Motorola Inc. said it plans to build a satellite-based cellular phone system that will connect users with telephones anywhere in the world. The system could supplement conventional phone service in nations where it is poor, such as in Eastern Europe, and provide mobile phone service in rural areas, Motorola said Tuesday. The system, called Iridium, would use a network of 77 satellites to receive calls from hand-held telephones resembling today's cellular phones. Prices for the phones would start at $3,000 _ compared with about $400 for today's cheapest cellular phones, Motorola said.

Chrysler Corp. agreed to acquire Dollar Rent A Car, a deal that boosts the No. 3 automaker's presence in the rental market and creates the opportunity for more auto sales. Terms of the agreement were not released Tuesday, but Chrysler said the purchase by subsidiary Pentastar Transportation Group Inc. was expected to be completed by August 15. Pentastar is the holding company for Thrifty and Snappy car rental systems, which Chrysler purchased in June 1989.

The Bush administration announced partial plans to save the rare northern spotted owl at a cost of at least 1,000 logging jobs in the Northwest, 27,000 fewer than government scientists had estimated earlier. ``Today we have set into motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said.

The stock market declined Tuesday, losing ground after rallying on optimism the federal budget deficit would decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished down 2.72 points at 2,842.33. Bond prices rallied after President Bush indicated he would consider tax hikes as part of a deficit-reduction package. The dollar fell and gold prices were lower. Corn and soybean futures prices fell modestly as fears of an extended Midwestern heat wave faded. Cocoa futures surged; energy futures retreated; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Developer Saved From Insolvency by $65 Million Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The threat of bankruptcy stalking Donald Trump has receded now that bankers have come to his rescue with a $65 million long-term loan and debt restructuring deal. The bailout appears to have come at a high cost to Trump, once considered by many to be financially invincible and given great leeway by his lenders. In exchange for providing the fresh credit, Trump's rescuers have gained some control over his holdings and will closely monitor his personal and business dealings for years to come. The breakthrough in prolonged negotiations over the loan and restructuring plan came Tuesday when lawyers decided they didn't need the approval of the lone bank that continued to balk at the deal after some 65 to 70 decided to go along. Because paperwork on the complex deal was not complete, Trump's major lenders decided to forward him a $20 million, 30-day loan so he could make overdue payments on bonds sold to finance his Trump's Castle hotel and casino in Atlantic City, N.J. Earlier this month, Trump missed a $43 million interest and principal payment on the Castle bonds and got behind on a $30 million bank loan. After Trump missed the initial due date on the bonds June 15, a 10-day grace period went into effect. Had Trump failed to make the payments by midnight Tuesday, he would have been in formal default and the assets backing those debts could have been seized by creditors. The negotiations yielded a new five-year commitment from Trump's bankers that will spread out payment on more than $2 billion in outstanding loans over the term of the pact. A clearly relieved Trump said in an interview that he was happy with the outcome and confirmed that the agreement limits his household and personal spending to $450,000 a month for the rest of this year. ``There are certain restrictions ... I can live with them,'' he said. In addition, there were reports that Trump must stick to a business plan, adopt a system of accounting controls and change accounting firms. A spokeswoman for Trump, Norma Foerderer, said she could not confirm the reports. One source involved in the negotiations, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it could take up to two months to prepare the final documents on the financial rescue. The large number of banks and attorneys involved will make the task time-consuming, the source said. The financial foundation of Trump's property portfolio, much of it amassed with borrowed money, has looked increasingly vulnerable in recent weeks. A slump in the New York real estate market and disappointing results from his Atlantic City casinos had put a cash squeeze on Trump, endangering his ability to remain current on his debts. The long-term $65 million bailout and debt restructuring package contains numerous requirements, including one that Trump sell assets to raise cash, according to the source. It was not believed that the agreement specifies which properties Trump must sell. The lone holdout to the deal, Dresdner Bank AG of West Germany, continued to withhold its consent to the deal, but attorneys decided that Dresdner's endorsement wasn't essential, a banking source said. Dresdner, whose $15 million loan to Trump is secured by the first lien on Fifth Avenue's Trump Tower skyscraper, has opposed placing a second lien on the building. It was considered possible that Dresdner might have second thoughts and eventually agree to the deal during the time it takes to complete the paperwork.

DOC.HEAD: The National Plans $50 Million Commitment to Developing Print Sites
DOC.TEXT: The daily sports newspaper, The National, plans to expand to 13 markets from its current roster of four by April 1991. Publisher Peter Price said Tuesday the newspaper will commit more than $50 million toward equipping nine more printing sites. The newspaper has been trying to find the right balance between national and local sports coverage that will attract a loyal readership. In addition, he said the newspaper plans to begin taking classified advertising next month and will begin a late edition in New York and Chicago in July to include late sports scores. Price's comments came amid continuing uncertainty about prospects for the newspaper, which has been publishing editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles since its launch Jan. 31 and started a San Diego edition on Monday. It plans to add editions in six more markets by the end of the year and another three in the first three months of 1991. Critics say they doubt there is a large enough audience for 40 to 48 pages of sports coverage that The National has been providing every day. But Price said the paper is meeting its targets on circulation and is ahead of schedule on advertising despite a generally weak newspaper ad market. He said the owners of the newspaper, headed by Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga, are commiting more than $50 million to equip nine more printing sites by the end of March 1991 to handle production of the four-color paper. That is in addition to the $25 million spent on launching the newspaper in its first three cities. The National now is printed at seven sites. Executives of the paper have said the Azcarraga group is prepared to spend at least $100 million over five years to make The National profitable. Price said the paper also plans to test home delivery in one or two cities in September. The paper has been sold almost entirely at newsstands, convenience stores and in vending machines. The newspaper's circulation has been a topic of some conjecture. Price said Tuesday that The National is selling close to 200,000 copies daily on average, and expects circulation to approach 400,000 by the end of the year. But audited figures have not yet been made available. Some industry executives have reportedly estimated the paper was selling as few as 115,000 copies on average. ``We will feel better when they supply us with some good circulation information,'' said Richard Weigand, senior vice president and media director for Saatchi & Saatchi DFS-Pacific in Torrance, Calif. A Saatchi client, Toyota Motor Sales, is one of the charter advertisers in the newspaper. Price said the paper has been selling 5 to 5{ pages of ads a day on average, more than the 4 pages expected, and that no advertisers have reduced or cancelled their orders. The newspaper's expansion plans to new cities have been scaled back since it was launched. Price said initial plans called for the addition of two cities a month in late 1990 but said that plan proved too ambitious, mainly because printing sites capable of handling the job were not readily available. The expansion schedule through the end of the year now calls for editions in San Francisco in July, Dallas in August, Detroit in September, Boston in October, the Miami-Fort Lauderdale market in November and the Baltimore-Washington, D.C., market in December, Price said. The three sites for early 1991 have not been announced, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Citibank, MCI Challenge AT&T Card
DOC.TEXT: Citibank, the nation's largest credit-card issuer, is taking on long-distance telephone king AT&T in the telephone credit-card market. Citibank has enlisted MCI Communications Corp., the second-largest long-distance telephone company, to help it launch a competitor to American Telephone & Telegraph's Universal card. The cards allow users to charge long-distance telephone calls on their Visa or Mastercards. Citibank began notifiying customers earlier this month of the service. Mastercard holders will be eligible for the service later this summer, Richard Srednicki, Citibank's business manager for Visa and Mastercard, said. AT&T began offering Visa and Mastercard services in March to those of its 70 million long-distance customers who are credit worthy. The move represented a vast new entry into a highly competitive and profitable industry. ``I don't think (Citibank) would have done it if it hadn't been for AT&T,'' said Spencer Nilson, publisher of an industry newsletter called the Nilson Report. Citibank's offer is part of a service called VisaPhone that Visa is testing for banks, said Visa spokesman Gregory Holmes. There are 124 million Visa cards in the United States. ``It's another example of how we're trying to open new markets where bank cards are not being used to charge purchases,'' Holmes said. He said 150 banks have expressed interest in the service, but he didn't know which besides Citibank already are involved. Since its introduction, the AT&T Universal Card has attracted just over 1 million customers, said AT&T spokesman Bruce Reid. ``I don't think we're going to react immediately to something like (the Citibank card.) We're concentrating on trying to get a new product out on the market right now,'' he said. Nilson said he doesn't expect Citibank's new service to interfere with AT&T's expansion into the $423 billion credit card market. But he said Citibank can expect to find willing customers. A recent study by Nilson's newsletter predicted that within two years, 14 percent of the 200 million Visa cards and Mastercards in circulation will double as phone charge cards. In December, US Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance company, began issuing a Visa card that also acts as a phone charge card. ``There's virtually no room for expansion in the number of people (carrying credit cards), but there is room for expansion in the number of cards people carry,'' Nilson said. ``The history of the credit card market is that people are inclined to carry new cards that offer different services.'' American Express began offering similar service with MCI in the early 1980s, said spokeswoman Nancy Muller. ``We offer American Express card members who have MCI residential service the opportunity to consolidate their billing on their American Express card bill,'' Ms. Muller said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Increases Holdings in Rental Car Business
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s has agreed to buy Dollar Rent A Car, its third rental company, as part of an effort to boost sales by showing off its cars and securing a position in the rental market. ``The rentals showcase the vehicles to potential buyers and the potential for fleet orders gives us a more solid production base, keeping the plants operating smoothly,'' said Tom Jakobowski, Chrysler spokesman. Chrysler subsidiary Pentastar Transportation Group Inc. on Tuesday announced the deal. Chrysler used Pentastar to buy the Thrifty and Snappy rental car systems in June 1989 for $236 million. Terms of the deal to buy Dollar were not disclosed. Chrysler plans to complete the purchase by Aug. 15. Pentastar spokeswoman Meloyde Blancett-Scott, in Tulsa, Okla., said the car maker was looking to Dollar as a way to boost sales and get a ``feel for the market.'' Chrysler's car sales through mid-June lag 18 percent behind last year. A New York-based stock analyst also said increasing Chrysler's share in the rental market could make up for a slipping retail share. ``Hypothetically, if you have a smaller share of the retail market but a larger share of the rental market, then you end up with a larger share altogether,'' said Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. ``Through rentals, Chrysler can show off the cars. It gets them on the roads and into the hands of executives who don't have the time to test drive a car,'' Brady said. ``But they'll try a new car if it's going to get them from one meeting to the next.'' Dollar, the fourth largest car rental system worldwide, has about 1,000 locations and an average rental fleet of 80,000 vehicles, 51,000 of them in North America. For fiscal 1989, Dollar and its franchises reported revenues of more than $600 million. Dollar also operates in Europe, Latin America, the Caribbean, Australia and New Zealand, and is opening franchises in Africa and the Middle East. Thrifty has more than 750 locations 45,000 vehicles, 37,000 in North America. Snappy has 20,000 vehicles at 250 locations. Jakobowski said Dollar, like Thrifty and Snappy, would continue operating independently through its franchises and under the Dollar and EuroDollar names. Last October, Chrysler embarked on a program to slice $1.5 billion from its $26-billion annual budget. The company reported $71 million in earnings for the first quarter, down 80 percent from a year ago but more than most analysts expected. William E. Lobeck Jr., chairman of Pentastar, said Dollar's owner and founder, Henry J. Caruso, will be retained as a consultant.

DOC.HEAD: Police Readying for Showdown With Shareholding Racketeers
DOC.TEXT: As hundreds of companies prepare for shareholder meetings Thursday, Japan's ``sokaiya'' racketeers are gearing up for action again, seeking hush money to leave the sessions undisturbed. And this year may bring a new group of racketeers, backed by Japan's largest underworld syndicate as it seeks to establish a foothold in the nation's capital, police say. ``Several sokaiya groups that are apparently backed by the Yamaguchi-gumi have been increasingly active in western Japan, and some of these are also believed to be opening new operations in the Tokyo area,'' said a National Police Agency report. The 20,000-plus-member Yamaguchi-gumi syndicate has kept away from Tokyo in the past but recently has been extending its forces nationwide. Sokaiya racketeers often pose as analysts or consultants and extort money from companies by threatening to make embarrassing comments or otherwise disrupt their annual shareholders meetings. The National Police Agency report said there are 1,307 sokaiya in Japan. Another 123 gangsters are involved in sokaiya activities but are not considered full-time racketeers, it said. Tokyo, as Japan's financial center, is home to about 900 such racketeers, said Yoshihiro Kondo, head of the Metropolitan Police Department's organized crime division. Kondo said 2,600 officers will be called out Thursday to discourage disturbances at the 780 general shareholders meetings scheduled in Tokyo. A special sokaiya task force is set up in the organized crime division each summer. In the early 1980s, police estimated there were 6,000 sokaiya nationwide who hauled in about $390 million a year through blackmail schemes. In one year alone, 243 sokaiya were arrested, some for extortion and others for income tax evasion. Sokaiya activity appeared to taper off after a 1982 law made it illegal to pay off sokaiya and increased the number of shares required to attend shareholders meetings. ``But the sokaiya managed to bounce back,'' Kondo said. The decreased numbers of sokaiya in the police agency report, which was released Monday, may reflect merely a greater difficulty in identifying sokaiya, he said. Sokaiya groups recently have been moving away from general meetings to concentrate on ``backstage'' activities, which include coercing companies into subscribing to their publications as a form of hush money, he said. Such publications generally contain material, often gleaned from company employees, that could create a scandal for the company if released widely, Kondo said. Businesses have banded together to fight the sokaiya by holding their meetings on the same day. On Thursday, 1,666 companies nationwide will hold shareholders meetings. Among them is Koito Manufacturing Co., which is waging a highly publicized battle with American investor T. Boone Pickens. Pickens owns a 26 percent share in the auto parts maker and has demanded a seat on its board of directors. Last year, Pickens' calls for increased shareholders' rights were echoed by a number of questioners from the floor _ tough-looking men in flashy suits who badgered Koito management for about 90 minutes. Afterward, Pickens said they had asked some good questions, but he said of the tactic, ``That's an interesting way to ask for an income statement.'' This year's Koito meeting, with its second round in the high-profile Pickens conflict, will be a likely target for sokaiya, Kondo said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sharply Limits Offshore Oil Drilling; Mixed Response
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists praised President Bush's moratorium on offshore drilling but said it doesn't go far enough. An industry group called it a mistake, and Democrats accused the White House of playing politics. ``If the president really wants to protect the California coast, he should make it permanent, not make it look as though he's just delaying oil drilling off our coast until after the 1990 governor's race and his own re-election campaign in 1992,'' Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy, a Democrat, said Tuesday. Bush suspended until at least the year 2000 new leases for drilling off much of California, Oregon, Washington, southern Florida and New England. He ordered further environmental studies to determine if drilling leases might be offered after that. Bush's decision is ``a major step in the right direction,'' said Lisa Speer, senior staff scientist for the Natural Resources Defense Council. But she complained that Bush did not address some areas where lease sales are upcoming, including the mid-Atlantic coast, Alaska's Bristol Bay and northern Florida. The moratorium also doesn't stop drilling under way in the Gulf of Mexico, off Alaska and off California. Nevertheless, the ban was a major shift in a U.S. policy to decrease reliance on foreign oil. The nation imports half its oil. The Reagan administration had favored opening the entire continental shelf to oil and gas drilling. ``Locking up these energy-rich lands at a time when our dependency on foreign energy is escalating is a serious mistake,'' the American Petroleum Institute said in a statement. Oil companies acknowledged public worry over oil drilling, however. ``President Bush has recognized that most Americans are not prepared at this time to develop certain environmentally sensitive offshore areas,'' Los Angeles-based ARCO said in a statement. ``ARCO supports the president under these circumstances.'' Democrats speculated that Bush wanted to help Republican gubernatorial candidates in California and Florida who oppose offshore oil drilling and could have been hurt politically by new drilling after oil spills like the Exxon Valdez and Mega Borg. Some observers also said Bush may be thinking about his own re-election prospects. ``The President's decision to delay leasing and development for 10 years off most of California's coast is an important concession to the political reality, but it merely postpones the controversy instead of solving it,'' said Ann Notthoff of the Natural Resources Defense Council in San Francisco. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson faces former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein in the gubernatorial race. Both oppose offshore drilling. Feinstein could have made a decision to allow drilling into ``a first-rate campaign issue,'' but Wilson could have used it to show his independence, said pollster Mervin Field, whose polls show Californians opposed to offshore drilling 74 percent to 21 percent. Another California pollster, Steve Teichner, said the real political implications would be for Bush. Bush carried only 51.1 percent of the California vote in 1988. ``It would have been a big problem for him in 1992 if he had not protected the coast,'' Teichner said. In Florida, Republican Gov. Martinez opposes offshore drilling, as do his leading Democratic opponents _ former Sen. Lawton Chiles and Rep. Bill Nelson, who face each other in a Sept. 4 primary. Martinez was pleased with the moratorium, but not with Bush's proposal that the state help buy back 73 leases sold to oil firms for drilling off the Keys. Florida officials estimated the buyback could cost $100 million to $200 million. ``The people of Florida should not be asked to bear what is rightly a federal responsibility,'' Martinez said. Along the New England coast, Bush's ban affects Georges Bank, a vital fishing ground east of Massachusetts' Cape Cod. ``Anybody who knows or cares about Georges Bank should be delighted,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass. ``He's not even going to be president by the year 2000. He's done all that he can for Georges Bank on his watch.'' California Assemblyman Tom Hayden, a Democrat, called Bush's actions ``a major victory for environmentalists.'' ``We have won time, up to 10 years,'' Hayden said. ``So I'm thankful for the actions in Washington, whatever the motives are.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against most major foreign currencies today in nervous European trading as dealers reacted to President Bush's surprise statement that tax increases will be necessary. ``The initial reaction to the tax news has been negative, but the key factor is how hard U.S. corporations might be hit. The market is still waiting to decide,'' said an analyst in Milan. Dealers said European markets were waiting for U.S. trading to open before making any large moves. ``We're seeing small, nervous movements, but no big swings,'' said a Milan trader. ``The Europeans are going to let the United States decide in which direction to send the dollar.'' Traders said beliefs that the economic merger between East and West Germany will lead to higher German interest rates added to the dollar's slump. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.88 yen to a closing 154.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted lower at 154.20 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6630 West German marks, down from 1.6690; 1.4055 Swiss francs, up from 1.4025; 5.5840 French francs, down from 5.6035; 1.8710 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8790; 1,218.50 Italian lire, down from 1,222.25; and 1.1725 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1730. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.7445, compared with $1.7360 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $349.95 a troy ounce, up from $349.50 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $350.30. In Zurich, the bid price was $350, unchanged from late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.37 to close at a bid $352.11. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.82 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.79.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Sharply Higher, Dollar Falls
DOC.TEXT: Remarks by President Bush about higher tax revenues helped send the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index soaring and the dollar falling against the Japanese yen today, traders said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 740.98 points, or 2.29 percent, closing at 32,312.75. The index rose 447.58 points Tuesday. Many Japanese investors saw Bush's statement as indicating lower U.S. interest rates, said Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. Lower interest rates encourage stock investment but make a country's currency less attractive. In a written statement issued in Washington Tuesday, Bush said tax revenue increases must be included in any U.S. deficit-reduction package, but he did not outline concrete steps. The Nikkei gained more than 400 points in the morning and continued rising in the afternoon. Hasunuma said investors were buying actively because of the start today of July stock trading and because of shareholders meetings scheduled Thursday by many Japanese companies. Nomura Securities analyst Yoshiro Inoue said the yen's strength also helped reassure market players and prompt active buying. Trading was moderate, with first section volume estimated at 600 million shares, up from Tuesday's 400 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 154.35 yen, down 0.88 yen from Tuesday's 155.23-yen finish. It opened at 154.33 yen and ranged between 154.00 yen and 154.45 yen. Dealers said the dollar's decline in Tokyo came after investors sold dollars on overseas markets overnight in expectation of lower U.S. interest rates following Bush's remarks. In Tokyo, Japanese institutional investors, mainly life insurance companies, were buying yen against the dollar, said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. ``Japanese investors now think the U.S. monetary policy is moving toward relaxation,'' he said. About $12.16 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from Tuesday's $9.37 billion. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 87.05 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Tuesday's 87.12-point finish. The yield stood at 7.175 percent, up from the previous day's 7.160 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Decision Leaves 73 Oil Leases in Limbo
DOC.NOTE: EDs: To include Bush announcement on buying back leases, INSERTs 2 grafs after 5th pvs, What happens.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's decision to postpone oil drilling off southern Florida leaves in limbo 73 oil leases already bought from the government and is likely to prompt a court battle over how much the leases are worth. Bush on Tuesday imposed a 10-year moratorium on oil development in environmentally sensitive areas off southern Florida, as well as off the coasts of California, Washington and New England. Unlike in California, where the leases under consideration have yet to be put up for sale, a group of oil companies already own 73 leases off Florida within the 13 million acres under presidential review. The leases were purchased in 1983 and 1984 for $108 million. Exploratory drilling would have begun immediately in two of the sites if Bush had given the go-ahead. What happens to the leases now that Bush put a hold on further oil activity there? On Tuesday, Bush announced his administration would begin negotiations with the state of Florida to work out a joint effort to purchase the leases from the oil companies that bought them for $108 million. Federal officials have said they want Florida to bear a substantial portion of the cost. But the state has indicated buying the leases should be left to Washington, since the federal government sold the leases. ``The people of Florida should not be asked to bear what is rightly a federal responsibility,'' Gov. Bob Martinez said Tuesday. The oil companies could hold onto them, but most industry experts doubt they will choose to do so. They cite the opposition of environmentalists that they say is all but certain to intensify the longer drilling is delayed. ``We're kind of in unchartered territory here,'' says Mike Kimmit, a spokesman for Mobil Oil Co., which owns 22 of the leases. He said the leases were acquired with the expectation that drilling could be pursued, oil would be discovered and a profit could be made. Mobil has been ready to begin exploratory drilling for some time on one of the leases 60 miles west of the Florida Keys, but was prevented from doing so because of state opposition, a congressional moratorium and the review by Bush. Industry experts agree that if the leases are sold back to the government the asking price will be much more than the $108 million the companies paid the Interior Department for them. They may demand $200 million or even more, suggest Interior officials. In addition to the original sale price, there are exploratory and administration costs, various fees, interest on the money paid to the government and possibly the value of any known resources, says Rupert Turner, manager of government relations for Shell Oil Co. Shell owns 16 of the leases. Other lease holders include Mobil, Amoco, City Services, Chevron, Union Oil, Tenneco and Texaco. The Interior Department, which handles oil lease sales on the Outer Continental Shelf, is likely to contest any claim by oil companies that they be paid for the loss of oil reserves in the lease areas. ``I don't believe there's a lot of oil in that area,'' said Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan when asked about the 73 leases in a recent interview. Lujan said if the oil companies seek payment for the loss of potential oil discoveries ``we would be talking about hundreds of millions or even billions of dollars.'' The outcome likely will be settled in court, government officials and industry representatives say. According to the law, the Interior Department could take back the leases, but Lujan has ruled out unilateral action. ``I would not want to be the one to cancel those leases. ... I would lose credibility for (the sale of) future leases,'' he said. Lujan has suggested the state of Florida might purchase the leases, but so far no agreement has been reached. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez told federal officials the state would pay no more than $10 million as its share, while Lujan has said the federal government wants to put in no more than $40 million. ``It's really the federal government's responsibility. They're the ones who made the profits, who sold the leases and who should pay the lion's share (in any buyback),'' says Estes Whitfield, Martinez' director of environmental affairs. Whitfield maintains that the oil companies bought the leases knowing there were environmental concerns that might prevent drilling. Oil companies abandon many oil leases as a normal course of exploring for oil, he said.

Stock prices hovered uncertainly today as the market absorbed the jolt of unwelcome earnings news from American Telephone & Telegraph. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 6.44 to 2,835.89 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers held a slim edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 472 up, 464 down and 503 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.86 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. AT&T stock was by far the day's most active issue, tumbling 3] to 37~ on volume of more than 2.7 million shares. The selloff came after the company said it expects its earnings for the second quarter to fall short of the 65 cents a share it earned in the April-June period last year. AT&T cited weaker-than-expected sales of some of its products, which it attributed to sluggish economic activity and market conditions. The drop in AT&T, which is the nation's most widely held stock with more than 2.6 million shareowners, accounted for virtually all the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. Elsewhere, Caterpillar, which has fallen sharply since early this week on an earnings disappointment, lost another | to 51~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .17 to 192.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .46 at 356.34. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.72 points to 2,842.33. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advances on the NYSE, with 706 up, 752 down and 529 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 141.42 million shares, against 133.10 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Puette Named President of Apple's USA Division
DOC.TEXT: In a move that completed a tumultuous, six-month shakeup of top management, Apple Computer Inc. hired Robert Puette, a longtime Hewlett-Packard Co. executive, to lead the company's domestic division. As president of Apple USA, Puette will be responsible for all sales, marketing and support activities in this country. Puette, whose appointment was announced Tuesday, worked 24 years at Hewlett-Packard, where he led the launch, development and expansion of its worldwide personal computer business. Most recently, he was general manager of Hewlett-Packard's Personal Computer Group. ``Bob Puette's arrival marks a major milestone in the development of Apple's USA business,'' said Michael Spindler, Apple's chief operating officer. ``He has a proven ability to effectively manage large, complex organizations. He's demonstrated exceptional business and technical expertise in the global personal computer market. And he's known for his strong and thoughtful leadership.'' Puette, 48, joins Apple on July 1. He fills a vacancy left by the sudden resignation in January of Allen Loren. Puette will report to Spindler, who was promoted to his position after Loren resigned. Apple, ranked No. 2 behind Hewlett-Packard in the personal computer market, badly needs help in the domestic market. The job of Apple USA's president is considered so tough that several leading candidates turned it down, industry sources said. High prices for its computers have lost the company sales in homes, schools and small businesses. In addition, morale in Apple's U.S. operations has been shaken by layoffs and employee unrest over various corporate issues, including high salaries paid to key managers, analysts said. ``I think that this is the turning point for Apple USA,'' Puette said. ``I think the turmoil is going to pretty well disappear and you're going to see some strong marketing messages from the company.'' New, low-cost machines expected to be announced later this year will have a significant impact on the market, Puette predicted.

DOC.HEAD: Unisys and Mitsui Sign Stock Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. announced that Mitsui & Co. Ltd., a Japanese trading company, will buy $150 million worth of Unisys convertible preferred stock and loan the computer maker $50 million. ``This transaction with our long-standing business partner in Japan, Mitsui, is a significant step in our program to strengthen the Unisys capital structure during this rebuilding year,'' James A. Unrun, Unisys' president and chief executive officer, said Tuesday. Mitsui and Unisys have a long-standing relationship that started in 1958. Each company owns one-third of Nihon Unisys Limited, a $2 billion computer company in Japan, and each participates in commercial ventures in other international markets, said J. Peter Hynes, a Unisys spokesman. The agreement benefits both companies because Mitsui strengthens its ties with its joint marketing programs worldwide, and the $200 million goes into Unisys' funds for general purposes, Unisys said. The preferred stock, in two series, will be convertible into Unisys common stock at Mitsui's option. It will have a conversion price of $20 per share for the $50 million in Series B stock, and $21 per share for the $100 million in Series C stock. Both series of stock will pay quarterly dividends at 8~ percent per year for the first five years and 9{ percent per year for the next two years. The five-year loan is unsecured and will bear interest at the rate of 11] percent per year, payable quarterly. The sale of the shares and the transfer of funds is expected to be completed this week.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING FOR ALL NEEDING
Insurance Industry Still Wary Of Proposed Futures Contracts
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade has a selling job to do even if federal regulators approve the exchange's request to trade insurance risk alongside soybeans and Treasury bonds. Some people in the insurance industry expressed skepticism Tuesday about the proposal to trade reinsurance futures. The exchange argued that the innovative products would allow insurers to stabilize underwriting risks, resulting in lower insurance costs for consumers. ``My general feeling would be a wait-and-see attitude,'' said Dan Kummer, vice president of administration and finance in the business insurance division of Allstate Insurance Co. ``From my point of view, I'm not sure I would see this as a replacement for some kinds of reinsurance,'' Kummer said in a telephone interview from Allstate's headquarters in suburban Northbrook. But Burton Gutterman, a Board of Trade director, told a news conference the insurance industry will embrace the products once it learns how to use them, just as once-skeptical banks have become regular traders of the exchange's interest-rate futures. ``There are a lot of questions that have to be answered,'' he said. ``That's a process the Board of Trade is committed to pursuing.'' Gutterman said the exchange on Monday submitted proposals for two reinsurance contracts to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for approval. The contracts would offer insurers a new way to reduce their risk on auto and health insurance policies while creating new markets for speculators. Reinsurance is the practice among insurance companies of selling policies to other insurers _ reinsurers _ to spread the risk around. The proposed futures contracts would be agreements for future deliveries of reinsurance certificates based on pools of auto and health insurance policies. The value of a contract would represent the difference between the premiums collected and claims paid on the pool of policies. In an unusual twist, the Board of Trade would employ a `central custodian' to inspect and qualify all policies. The custodian also would act as a clearinghouse for information about premiums and claims, theoretically providing all market participants with ``a level playing field,'' the exchange said in a statement. The Board of Trade said that by buying and selling the contracts, insurers could effectively reinsure some of their policies through the exchange. ``The insurance markets represent a huge financial sector that currently has very limited ways by which to manage its considerable risk,'' Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann said in a statement. Gutterman said that pending CFTC approval of the contracts, the Board of Trade would lobby state insurance commissioners to allow insurers in their states to use the contracts for reinsurance. Kevin Hennosy, a spokesman for the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, said he had not seen the Board of Trade proposals. ``We certainly would have an interest in how this would impact the consumer and how such a proposal would be regulated,'' Hennosy said from his office in Kansas City, Mo.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush Softens Edge of Tax Issue
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 3 grafs talks under way; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Bush said...
DOC.TEXT: Democrats must agree to major spending cuts as the price for President Bush's concession that taxes will have to be raised to attack the budget deficit, a leading Senate Republican said today. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., made the remark on CBS-TV's ``CBS This Morning'' as negotiators from the White House and Congress resumed their deficit-reduction negotiations. ``It's time to summit or get off the pot,'' Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas, a Republican bargainer, told reporters as the closed-door talks got under way. Bush said Tuesday that a budget pact will require ``tax revenue increases,'' which Democrats hailed as an abandonment of his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. Domenici, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said the key question is not whether GOP lawmakers will back the president's new position. ``It's whether Democrats will now restrain spending enough to make a package that is indeed right for America,'' he said. On the same program, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said increased excise taxes will have to be part of any deficit-reduction package. ``Excise taxes are going to be necessary in the equation because you raise revenues immediately,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. The government levies excise taxes on fuels, cigarettes, liquor and other items. Rostenkowski did not specify which tax increases he favors, but in the past has advocated boosts in gasoline, cigarette and alcohol levies. House Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois today gave a cautious reading of Bush's statement. Appearing on NBC's ``Today'' show, Michel said ``the president didn't tell us yesterday, `The first thing I want you to do is go down there and raise taxes.''' But House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, appearing on the same program, said that Bush, by his statement, ``has said publicly and clearly that he believes new taxes are necessary.'' ``There are going to be some hard hits,'' Michel said. ``The president is taking a hit for the moment, I think temporarily.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told reporters today that continued stiff opposition among congressional Republicans to a tax increase ``may make it difficult to pass'' whatever agreement is reached by negotiators. He added that any agreement, including a tax increase, will have to be acceptable to a majority of members of both parties in both houses. The search by White House and congressional negotiators for a way to cut the mounting deficit was resuming today. The 1991 shortfall could exceed $200 billion _ well above the $74 billion limit set by the Gramm-Rudman law. Bush did not specify which taxes he would consider boosting, and White House officials insisted that would be up to negotiators. Nonetheless, lawakers agreed that the president's comments will help the talks, which have dragged on fruitlessly since mid-May. ``It opens the door to serious negotiations at the summit,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. Many Democrats said Bush had done them a political favor as well. They said he blurred an issue the GOP has used successfully against Democrats across the country since President Reagan's campaigns. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee and a former head of his state's Democratic Party, said it would be ``implausible'' for Republicans to use the issue in campaigns. ``What are they going to say when the president comes to their district to campaign for them?'' Sasser said. ``Or will he come?'' ``He's not only neutralized the issue for 1990, but perhaps stewed up in the Republican Party a question about a lack of identity,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill. Bush's statement also called for cuts in defense, domestic programs, budget process changes and ``growth incentives,'' often used to describe the capital gains tax reduction that Bush wants. But it was his support for tax increases that outraged conservative Republicans. By Tuesday evening, 90 of the 176 House Republicans had signed a letter to Bush saying they were ``stunned by your announcement'' and calling such an increase unacceptable. ``Tax increases at the present time would undermine the economy and substantially weaken it,'' said Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., who circulated the message. Other Republicans insisted that in an effort to boost the stalled budget talks, the president had merely restated his longstanding promise to consider all options for saving money. ``I don't see how it's a change in anything,'' said Sen. Domenici. Rep. Guy Vander Jagt, R-Mich., chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said Bush's remarks did nothing to eliminate the tax issue. His Senate counterpart, Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., said the president's statement ``may cloud the issue a little bit.'' But Nickles, who heads the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said most Republicans still would use the tax issue. ``Most of our challengers are more opposed to taxes than the incumbents are,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise In Pre-Report Positioning
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices rose moderately in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing most of the previous session's losses in the corn and soybean markets. Wheat futures extended Tuesday's modest gains following the Agriculture Department's acceptance of China's bid to buy about 140,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Some analysts predicted quiet trading today and Thursday ahead of the USDA's first report on planted acreage for corn and soybeans. The report is scheduled for release after Thursday's close. It is expected to show that heavy springtime rains in the Midwest prevented farmers from planting as much corn as the USDA had projected in March. A survey of analysts yielded an average corn-planting estimate of 73.9 million acres compared with the USDA's March projection of 74.8 million and last year's 72.3 million. Analysts estimated soybean plantings at 59.6 million acres compared with the USDA March projection of 59.4 million and last year's total of 60.7 million. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.35\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2} cents higher with July at $2.87} a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 1} cents higher with July at $1.38} a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4{ cents higher with July at $6.11 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after a mixed performance Tuesday. DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; inserts 6 grafs after 6th graf pvs, Today's ruling, to elaborate on 3rd graf pvs, The court; subs 17th graf pvs, Justice William, to change reference to Brennan.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today upheld federal policies that favor minorities in awarding broadcast licenses, a majo victory for affirmative action. By a 5-4 vote, the justices said the Federal Communications Comission policies do not discriminate unlawfully against whites. The court did not address the issue of women's rights, but FCC affirmative action policies treat women and minorities almost identically. In a case from Florida, the court allowed the commission to give special, favorable consideration to minorities in awarding a television station license. In a case from Connecticut, the court upheld the commission's so-called distress-sale policy, which allows a broadcaster faced with the loss of its license to sell to a minority-owned business at 75 percent of market value. Today's ruling, which came in a consolidation of the two cases, is a surprising victory for affirmative action from a conservative Supreme Court. Throughout the history of the case, the FCC has argued women's rights were at issue. The Associated Press initially reported that the ruling affected both women and minorities. But in a footnote in his 50-page majority opinion, Justice William J. Brennan said the court did not address gender preferences. The footnote, referring to a broad FCC policy statement, says, ``The FCC also announced in its 1978 statement a tax certificate policy and other minority preferences ... which are not at issue today. Similarly, the commission's gender preference policy ... is not before us today.'' Legal experts said they are confident the ruling also will permit the FCC to continue its policy of giving prefential treatment as well to women seeking broadcast licenses, although the court did not specifically address that issue. Andrew Jay Schwartzman, a communications lawyer, said he was delighted with the ruling and said preferential treatment for women applicants appears to be on safe ground. ``A similar policy for women, I believe, would also be upheld,'' he said. In its most important previous ruling on preferential minority treatment by the federal government, a more liberal high court in 1980 upheld a public works program that set aside a percentage of federal funds for minority contracts. More recently, however, the court has trimmed affirmative action programs. Last year the justices struck down a Richmond, Va., program that set aside a percentage of local public works contracts for minority-owned businesses. That ruling cast doubt on the validity of numerous similar plans of states and cities but had no bearing on federal programs. Today's ruling came as Congress and the Bush administration continue negotiations to settle differences on the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990 _ a bill aimed at erasing the effects of the earlier Supreme Court decisions weakening affirmative action programs. Administration officials say they're concerned that provisions of the bill permitting suits by individuals alleging hiring discrimination are so strong in terms of potential damages that they would, if enacted, lead businesses to reinstitute hiring quotas. The bill as now written goes beyond the traditional discrimination remedies of restoration of job and back pay. Today, the justices said they owe special deference to federal programs that give preferential treatment to minorities. Brennan, writing for the court, said: ``It is of overriding significance in these cases that the FCC's minority ownership programs have been specifically approved _ indeed mandated _ by Congress. ``We hold that benign race-conscious measures mandated by Congress _ even if those measures are not remedial in the sense of being designed to compensate victims of past governmental or societal discrimination _ are constitutionally permissible to the extent that they serve important governmental objectives within the power of Congress and are substantially related to achievement of those objectives.'' Brennan was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. The dissenters were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. O'Connor, in an opinion joined by the other dissenters, said the ruling violates ``fundamental principles'' requiring the government to treat all Americans equally. ``The court departs from these fundamental principles and from our traditional requirement that racial classifications are permissible only if necessary and narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling interest,'' she said. The FCC said its policies, adopted in 1978, are intended to promote diversity over the nation's airwaves by letting ``missing voices'' be heard on radio and television. But the commission has not always supported affirmative action wholeheartedly. When Ronald Reagan was president, the FCC considered scrapping the policies. The current commission has called for broadening minority representation in the broadcast industry, but the Bush administration's Justice Department has disagreed with the FCC's policies. Justice Department lawyers told the court that the affirmative action policies are invalid because Congress did not initiate them and design them narrowly to correct past bias. But Congress expressed itself on the issue in 1987 by passing an appropriations bill that barred the FCC from spending any money to review or scrap its affirmative action policies. The FCC's support for affirmative action has had limited success. The commission said minorities control 3.5 percent of the nation's radio and TV stations, compared to less than 1 percent in 1978. Other federal affirmative action programs have been adopted by the Transportation and Defense departments and by the Small Business Administration. In the Florida case, the FCC awarded Hispanic-owned Rainbow Broadcasting Co. a new TV license in Orlando. A three-judge federal appeals court panel in the District of Columbia _ upheld by the high court _ ruled that a rival, Metro Broadcasting Inc., was not denied the license unfairly. In the Connecticut case, a different panel of the same appeals court struck down the FCC's distress-sale policy and ordered Hispanic-led Astroline Communications Co. to surrender its license for WHCT-TV in Hartford. The appeals court _ reversed by the justices _ ruled for rival broadcaster Alan Shurberg, who is white. James L. Winston, executive director of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said the court's decision ``means the FCC's ability to help promote minority ownership can now go forward without fear of constitutional challenge. ``The polices have been effective over the past 12 years in increasing the number of minority-owned stations in general, and particularly the ownership by African-Americans from 30 radio stations and one television station to the point where we now have 182 radio stations and 17 television stations. Said Kernie Anderson, general manager of black-owned WDAS-FM-AM in Philadelphia, one of the first stations sold under the distress sale policy: ``This reflects a continuation of a policy that has benefited not only African-Americans but women and the entire nation. It has made for greater diversity in our industry. For the Supreme Court to uphold the righteousness of what indeed was a just action by the commission ... is appreciated by an African-American.'' The cases acted upon today are Metro Broadcasting vs. FCC, 89-453, and Astroline Communications vs. Shurberg Broadcasting, 89-700.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Giant Sees Lower Second-Quarter Income
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with stock price down, analyst comments, background. Adds byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: AT&T today said its profit in the second quarter likely will be lower than last year's in part because sales of various products have fallen short of expectations. The softness will make it more difficult for American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to meet its objective of achieving 10 percent to 12 percent growth in earnings this year, the company said in a statement. But AT&T said it stands by its earlier projection that net income for all of 1990 would rise to a record level. This year's profit is expected to surpass the 1989 earnings of $2.7 billion, or $2.50 a share. The news sent the company's stock price sliding. In midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange, AT&T shares were selling for $38.62{, off $2.62{ from Tuesday's close. Earlier this morning, the shares were off as much as $3.50. The company blamed market conditions and a sluggish economy for weakening its product sales in the quarter that will end June 30. AT&T spokesman Dick Gray said results from April and May indicate sales to small and large U.S. businesses of telephone equipment, including such things as electronic switchboards, have been unexpectedly low. Sales of network telecommunications products, such as switching equipment, cable and transmissions systems, also have been below anticipated levels, Gray said. There has been some weakness in sales to the federal government, he added. AT&T also said sales in its computer division have lagged. Meanwhile, heavy demand for AT&T's Universal Card has caused expenses associated with processing card applications to rise in the second quarter, the company said. AT&T called the demand for the new credit card, introduced in March, unprecendented and twice the level expected. Analysts called AT&T's announcement disappointing, but said they believed the company's profit for the entire year would rise, as AT&T promised. George Kelly, of Morgan Stanley & Co., said this was the first time AT&T announced its quarterly earnings would be below analysts' expectations in the six years since it spun off its regional phone operating companies. ``This has come as a real surprise to analysts who follow the company,'' Kelly said. He attributed the slowdown in purchases of corporate phone systems in part to the nationwide commercial real estate slump. As fewer companies move to new quarters, fewer phone systems are sold, he said. In addition, AT&T has faced increased competitor in the office phone market from Rolm, which is owned by International Business Machines Corp. and Siemens AG of West Germany, Kelly said. In the market for central-office switches, which are the nerve center of phone companies, AT&T has seen increased competitor from LM Ericsson of Sweden, Kelly said. ``AT&T has always had a cost-structure problem in their equipment business, and they have done a good job of controlling that,'' he said. ``But we haven't really witnessed a downturn in demand.'' Stuart Crane, an analyst at Gruntal & Co., said demand for central-office switches has softened as the regional phone operating companies have completed a cycle of buying new equipment. In last year's second quarter, AT&T earned $699 million, or 65 cents a share, on revenue of $9.26 billion. In light of AT&T's statement today, Kelly estimated earnings this quarter will be 63 cents a share, while Crane put the figure at 62 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner Gets 66 Percent Raise
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner's total pay increased 66 percent to $729,952 last year, boosted in part by an incentive plan adopted by his company's board of directors in 1989, according to a Turner Broadcasting System Inc. proxy statement. The TBS chairman, who owns about $1.5 billion worth of Turner Broadcasting's outstanding stock, earned a $197,513 bonus in 1989. That brought his total cash compensation to $729,952, compared with total cash compensation of $440,649 in 1988, according to the proxy statement released Tuesday. The cable television company, which owns Superstation WTBS in Atlanta and produces the Cable News Network, CNN Headline News and Turner Network Television, lost $70.6 million in 1989 as its revenue exceeded $1 billion for the first time. Also in the proxy statement, Turner Broadcasting said it will ask shareholders on July 23 to approve a plan that would increase the number of authorized shares of common stock. The company proposed to triple the number of authorized shares of its Class A common stock from 25 million shares to 75 million shares and double Class B shares from 150 million to 300 million. The moves would not dilute Turner's majority voting control in the company. He currently owns 39.7 percent of the company's outstanding common equity and 62.9 percent of the voting power.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Report Breakthrough In Trade Talks; Bush, Kaifu Confer
DOC.TEXT: Talks between Japan and the United States on structural trade reforms progressed late Wednesday night with a last-minute breakthrough on the issue of increasing Japan's public works spending, officials said. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu conveyed Japan's final offer on the issue to President George Bush in a telephone conversation late Wednesday night Bush said he would hear details of the talks from U.S. officials and expressed appreciation for Kaifu's efforts, according to a high-ranking Foreign Ministry official. ``This represents a breakthrough,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Without an agreement on public works spending tonight, I doubt we could finish the talks by tomorrow.'' Foreign Ministry officials said they could not confirm reports that Japanese and U.S. officials had agreed on a final figure of $2.77 trillion in public works spending over the next 10 years. Local media, citing unidentified government sources, said Kaifu and other top Japanese officials, meeting in a last-ditch move to salvage the talks, had agreed to increase their original proposal of $2.68 trillion by $96.77 billion. U.S. officials accepted the proposal, Kyodo News Service reported. The United States claims that Japan needs to offset its high savings rate, which gives Japanese businesses a relatively cheaper source of capital than their U.S. counterparts, with more government spending, which can boost such capital costs as interest rates. Washington had requested that Tokyo commit itself to spending at least $3.22 trillion over the next decade. Japanese officials expressed concern that such a large increase would stimulate inflation. Earlier Wednesday night, U.S. officials had said the talks were at an impasse due to conflicts over public works spending and other issues, despite a decision by Bush to take stronger action to cut the U.S. budget deficit. A senior U.S. official participating in the talks complained that Japan had failed to show ``political will'' to match Bush's decision on Tuesday to accept tax increases to help cut the U.S. deficit. ``It took more political courage to raise (tax) revenues than it would to increase public spending,'' the official said on condition he not be named. ``The president made an important decision. We hope our Japanese friends realize that.'' Doing more to cut its budget deficit is one of Washington's key commitments in the current round of trade talks, called the Structural Impediments Initiative. The talks are intended to attack Japan's $49 billion surplus in trade with the United States by taking steps to remedy fundamental problems in both countries _ such as the U.S. budget deficit and Japan's tough-to-crack business systems _ seen as hindering trade and competitiveness. This week's talks were to prepare a final version of an interim report issued in April. Officials said they expected to work through the night in order to complete the report by midday Thursday. Prior commitments on both sides required that the current talks end then or resume sometime next week, they said. The meetings originally were scheduled to end Tuesday but have dragged on as officials haggled over the many topics under discussion. The U.S. official said progress had been made on opening Japan's products distribution system and improving land use and customs facilities and operations. There also was progress on measures by Washington to curb demand for imports, improve competitiveness of U.S. products and slash the federal budget deficit. But he said negotiators were still split on issues related to exclusionary business practices and the speed of processing patent applications, and over the private right to take legal action over unfair business practices. Japanese officials were dissatisfied with U.S. proposals on easing export controls for oil and strategically sensitive products, he said. Both sides say they are anxious to reach agreement before the July 9 summit of the seven major industrialized democracies in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Koito Says Only 2 Percent of Stockholders Support Pickens
DOC.TEXT: Koito Manufacturing Co. said Wednesday it has overwhelming support from most of its shareholders to reject the demand by T. Boone Pickens Jr. for a voice in running the company. Pickens and 52 other Americans own 26 percent of the total shares in the Japanese auto parts maker. For its general sareholders meeting Thursday, Koito said, it has received proxies representing 83 percent of the other shares supporting its position against Pickens. Proxies representing 2 percent of those other shares support Pickens, it stated. Pickens and his allies are in Japan for the meeting, where they plan to renew demands for four seats on Koito's 20-member board of directors. ``We are gratified at the overwhelming support that management has received from our shareholders,'' Tomoatsu Aoyama, a Koito director, was saying in the company's statement. ``After corporate raider Boone Pickens' lengthy and highly visible campaign to attack Koito, disrupt our business, and create controversy to further his greenmail scheme, it is revealing that he can obtain the support of fewer than 2 percent of the other shareholders,'' he said. Mark Helmke, a representative of Pickens, said he was not surprised at the small showing overall for the Texas oilman. But, he said, Pickens' Boone Co. had received support from more than half of the 4 million or so ``average Japanese investors.'' ``Our support is from the average investor,'' Helmke said. ``Koito's support is from the keiretsu.'' Keiretsu are corporate networks bound by mutual shareholdings, financial or personnel ties. In Koito's case, Toyota Motor Corp., Japan's biggest automaker, owns about 20 percent of the company's stock and buys about half the auto lighting equipment it sells. Pickens says keiretsu tend to exclude outsiders, especially foreigners. He says Koito's status as a subcontractor in Toyota's keiretsu squeezes Koito profits, depriving him of a fair return as a stockholder. ``By losing the vote tomorrow, we will show that the keiretsu system is stacked against the small investor in Japan as it is against the United States,'' said Helmke. Koito has maintained that Pickens is really interested in having the company buy back his shares at a premium _ a charge he denies _ and has rejected his demands for a greater say in running the company.
