DOC.HEAD: State Sues Accountant Who Backed Lincoln Junk Bond Claims
DOC.TEXT: The state of California today sued Lincoln Savings and Loan chief Charles H. Keating Jr. for alleged fraud in the sale of $250 million in now-worthless junk bonds. The accounting company that backed claims about the bonds' safety was also named as a defendant. Attorney General John Van de Kamp said the defendants include Jack Atchison, the employee of the Arthur Young & Co. accounting firm who handled the account of American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent company. The high-risk, high-interest rate bonds, sold mainly to elderly southern Californians at Lincoln branches, were issued by American Continental. Federal regulators say the failure of Lincoln may cost taxpayers $2 billion. ``Charles Keating and his associates at American Continental Corporation were running a huge financial con game, and sucking the assets out of Lincoln Savings to sustain their operations,'' Van de Kamp said. Atchison was later hired by American Continental for $900,000 a year, four times what he was making at Arthur Young. ``It takes no great insight to understand why he was worth that princely sum to ACC,'' Van de Kamp said. The suit, filed in state court in Orange County, seeks restitution of the $250 million in bonds from Keating, other American Continental officers and directors, Atchison, and Arthur Young, which is now doing business as Ernst & Young. Van de Kamp said he will seek civil penalties that could range from $50 million to $100 million. A Keating attorney, James Ham, said today that many of the legal actions against Keating, including a $2.1 billion lawsuit by the Resolution Trust Corp. in Phoenix, Ariz., were ``grandstanding'' because his client is broke. Van de Kamp agreed in part, saying: ``There's little hope that any (American Continental) assets will be left over to repay the bond holders. That is why we have taken the time and expense to thoroughly investigate the liability of others who might be responsible.'' A call for comment from Ernst & Young was not immediately returned by the firm's spokeswoman, Elizabeth Coleman.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mixed, Erasing Corn and Bean Gains
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a late wave of profit-taking erased strong midday gains in the corn and soybean markets. Susan Leighty, a grain analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the net outcome _ little change in prices _ reflected traders' reluctance to establish new market positions ahead of Thursday's Agriculture Department report on planted acreage and grain stocks. ``It's not surprising it came down,'' she said. Corn and soybeans rallied strongly at midday amid new forecasts for extremely hot, dry weather due in the western Corn Belt from the Southwest. An extended Midwest heat wave could harm the young crops. At the close, wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with July at $3.33 a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $2.86} a bushel; oat futures were 1\ cents lower to 3 cents higher with July at $1.35} a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 1{ cents higher with July at $6.07{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Severance Package for Ousted Chairman About $10 Million
DOC.TEXT: Peter A. Cohen, who was ousted as chairman of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. earlier this year, will receive a severance package worth about $10 million, individuals familiar with the pact said Wednesday. Cohen was ousted by American Express Co.'s chairman, James D. Robinson III, as part of an overhaul designed to stem mounting losses and morale problems at the nation's second largest securities firm. The severance package completes the much publicized separation as the firm continues a major restructuring that includes returning to its old Shearson Lehman Brothers name. Cohen will receive $2.6 million in severance pay plus stock and options amassed during a 20-year career that values the total package at about $10 million, according to people familiar with the package, who asked not to be named. The individuals said the severance pay was calculated at about one month's pay for each year of service, or about $130,000 a month. Shearson, though, technically doesn't sever all ties with Cohen under the package. The firm agreed to retain Cohen as a consultant until March 1991 and pay for an office and secretary outside Shearson's headquarters. That will allow Cohen to receive some benefits to which he is entitled. ``We believe it is a fair and equitable settlement that recognizes Mr. Cohen's significant contributions to Shearson Lehman Hutton over 20 years of dedicated service,'' Gary Beller, American Express executive vice president and general counsel, said in a statement. ``We wish him well in his future endeavors,'' the statement said. Other American Express and Shearson officials declined to comment. Cohen, 43, was ousted from the firm in January and replaced by a top American Express executive, Howard L. Clark Jr. Cohen was instrumental in Shearson's expansion into the investment banking field in 1984 with the acquisition of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. He also led the January 1988 acquisition of defunct brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. for $962 million. The latter deal along with Shearson's failed role in the RJR Nabisco Inc. takeover have been blamed for many of Shearson's current problems. Shearson lost $915 million in the first quarter of 1990, the largest loss ever on Wall Street. Most of the loss was to pay for a restructuring that included thousands of layoffs and the elimination or reduction of several businesses. American Express plans to acquire all the Shearson stock it does not own. Shearson earlier this month said it was grouping into two divisions from four: Shearson Lehman Brothers for individual investing and asset management, and Lehman Brothers for investment banking and capital markets activities. The full firm will be known as Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The severance agreement with Cohen was presented by American Express' board to Cohen about two months ago. As part of the package, Cohen must repay an oustanding loan to Shearson taken to purchase company stock about two years ago, about equal to the $2.6 million in severance pay. Additionally, Cohen is prevented from suing directors and officers of Shearson, American Express and members of their families.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Puts Freeze Toll at $175 Million
DOC.TEXT: Last winter's bitter cold spell cost Florida's commercial foliage industry about $175 million, industry officials say. Dade County alone suffered damages of about $100 million to tender tropical plants, trees and shrubs, said the Florida Nurserymen and Growers Association, based in Orlando. ``The numbers aren't quite as large as we had anticipated right after the freeze, but they still have to be considered conservative,'' said Earl Wells, executive vice president of the association. Foliage prices rose an average 15 percent because of shortages of plants, particularly palms and other tropical trees, Wells said Tuesday. Florida is the nation's leading foliage producer, with about 5,800 commercial nurseries and $1 billion a year in revenues, according to the state Division of Plant Industry.

DOC.HEAD: Says Underwriting Profit Dropped By 45 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Insurance market Lloyd's of London announced a 45 percent drop in underwriting profit Wednesday for its most recent reporting year, largely because of asbestos and pollution claims in the United States. Lloyd's said underwriting profit totaled 411.7 million pounds or $716 million in 1987 compared with 744.5 million pounds a year earlier. Lloyd's announces earnings figures three years late to give it time to get a more accurate idea of the claims that will fall due on policies written during those years. The company said pretax profit dropped 22 percent to 509.1 million pounds or $886 million, from 649.4 million pounds a year earlier. Total net premium income, an insurance industry version of revenues, rose 13.5 percent to 4.2 billion pounds or $7.3 billion, from 3.7 billion pounds in 1986. Chairman Murray Lawrence said the insurance market faces even leaner times over the next two reporting years. When the 1988 claims are tallied, he said, it ``appears as though it will be profitable but it will reflect the impact of overcapacity throughout the industry which became evident that year.'' For 1989, he predicted an overall loss for the market. Lawrence cited an unusual number of major claims which were particularly damaging since the disasters occurred at a time of ``keenly competitive'' premium rates. Lawrence said that although the 1987 results showed a reasonable overall profit, there was some variance between markets. While aviation and motor markets produced impressive profits and marine showed results in line with 1986, non-marine insurance underwriting results were disappointing, Lawrence said. The drop in non-marine underwriting results came from asbestos claims and pollution problems on U.S. business, he said. Lloyd's reports profits once a year. The figures were converted at the current exchange rate of $1.74 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: More Yields Fall
DOC.TEXT: Yields on four-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level since last December. The average yield was 8.50 percent, down from 8.589 percent at the last auction on March 28. It was the lowest rate since four-year notes averaged 7.65 percent on Dec. 20. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8{ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $10,000. A total of $8.31 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $44.78 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell, Gruner and Jahr Sign Deal to Acquire East German Publisher
DOC.TEXT: British media baron Robert Maxwell and the West German publishing house Gruner and Jahr AG have agreed to jointly acquire East Germany's largest publisher, Berliner Verlag, for an undisclosed price. Maxwell's Mirror Group Newspapers said in a statement Wednesday that Maxwell had signed an agreement with Gerd Schulte-Hillen, chief executive of Gruner and Jahr, to acquire Berliner Verlag in a 50-50 deal. Berliner Verlag, formerly owned by the East German Communist Party, produces various publications, including the daily Berliner Zeitung, and the weeklies Neue Berliner Illustrierte, FF dabei, Eulenspiegel, and Wochenpost. Gruner and Jahr will be the managing partner, and Maxwell will be the chairman of the advisory board of the company, the statement said. The partners have agreed that Berliner Verlag will be independent of party politics, the statement said. A spokesman for Maxwell declined to offer additional details.

Stock prices turned upward today, pulling out of a week-long slump despite some unwelcome earnings news from American Telephone & Telegraph. AT&T stock came under pressure after the company said it expects its earnings for the second quarter to fall short of the 65 cents a share it earned in the April-June period last year. AT&T cited weaker-than-expected sales of some of its products, which it attributed to sluggish economic activity and market conditions. The drop in AT&T was widely felt, given its status as the nation's most widely held stock with more than 2.6 million shareowners. But analysts said buyers moved cautiously into some other stocks after it became evident that the AT&T setback wasn't starting a general rush to sell.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Owner Enters Innocent Pleas
DOC.TEXT: Former Vernon Savings & Loan owner Don Dixon pleaded innocent Wednesday to 38 federal charges in the collapse of his thrift three years ago. The charges include allegations that he illegally raised money for national political figures. A trial date of Aug. 20 was set by U.S. District Judge Joe Fish. Dixon remained free on personal recognizance. Dixon was indicted June 13 in the $1.3 billion collapse of Vernon Savings and Loan in 1987. Federal regulators at the time called Vernon a prime example of the abuses in the savings and loan industry. Dixon, 50, has maintained he is a scapegoat for the government's sloppy handling of the S&L crisis. The indictment alleged that Dixon used thousands of dollars from Vernon Savings on pleasure trips, prostitutes and illegal contributions to politicians, including former House Speaker Jim Wright and Jack Kemp, a former Republican congressman from New York who is now Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Prosecutors have said the recipients did not know that the funds came from illegal sources. Five other Vernon officials have pleaded guilty to various crimes and one, former President Patrick G. King, was sentenced last year to five years in prison. Former chairman Woody F. Lemons was sentenced in April to 30 years in prison. A consultant and two Vernon borrowers also have pleaded guilty in thrift-connected cases.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Contracts Rise In May Due To Public Works, Dodge Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source until 6:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Three public works projects totaling $300 million helped boost the value of new construction contracts in May by 6 percent from the month before, the F.W. Dodge Division of McGraw-Hill said Wednesday. The Dodge Index of construction contracting, which uses 1982 as its base of 100, rebounded to 155 in May, compared with April's four-year low of 147. The seasonally adjusted indicator of future construction activity represents the value of newly started projects of all kinds. In May, contracting for public works and utility projects grew 12 percent to its best level this year. The projects included three lock-dam structures being built by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers along waterways in Oregon, West Virginia and Pennsylvania, Dodge said. Though these projects gave the May figures a lift, the level of general building activity also rose, Dodge said. Non-residential building contracting advanced 6 percent, while residential building rose 4 percent. Despite May's increase, year-to-date contracting activity was 7 percent below the activity in the same five months of 1989, Dodge said. The largest shortfall was in the Northeast, where the value of newly started work was off its year-ago pace by 24 percent. Construction in the North Central region was ahead 5 percent so far this year, the West remained even and the South was down 10 percent, Dodge said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Price Slump Continues
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices continued their downward drift Wednesday led by a steep slide in wholesale gasoline prices. Trading picked up to about average volume after recent sluggish sessions on the New York Mercantile Exchange, energy analysts said. The contract for July delivery of wholesale unleaded gasoline tumbled 1.83 cents to settle at 59.49 cents a gallon, expanding on Tuesday's loss of 0.95 cent. Contracts for later delivery also finished significantly lower. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, the July home heating oil contract slid 0.56 to 47.93 cents a gallon after falling 0.43 cent Tuesday. Contracts for delivery during August through October posted similar declines. The August contract of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, shed another 46 cents to close at $16.68 a 42-gallon barrel. That was wider than Tuesday's drop of 24 cents. Other nearby crude contracts fell. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.500 per 1,000 cubic feet. It was the lowest settlement for the near-month contract since the New York Merc began trading natural gas in early April. It was down from the closing level of $1.507 Tuesday. Jim Fiedler, an energy specialist for E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said the selloff in gasoline was the catalyst for the market's overall weakness. He said brokers are puzzled because gas demand is still lagging despite the start of the peak summer driving season. Weekly statistics released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute indicated gas demand is running about 5 percent behind last year. Crude, meanwhile, has been under pressure because there is a glut of oil available, which hasn't shown signs of abating, Fiedler said.

DOC.HEAD: News That Quarterly Profit Will Fall Sends AT&T's Stock Sliding
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `In late ...,' to UPDATE with closing stock price. SUBS 18th graf pvs, `Gray said ...,' to DELETE erroneous attribution to AT&T spokesman.
DOC.TEXT: News that AT&T's second-quarter profit will be lower than a year ago _ and below analysts' expectations _ sent the price of the nation's most widely held stock sliding Wednesday. The announcement by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. was the first time since the 1984 breakup of the former Bell System that the nation's largest phone company has given advance warning of a lower profit. The company blamed the expected earnings slide in the quarter ending Saturday partly on lower-than-expected sales of telephone equipment. AT&T would not predict how much the drop would be. It said it would release second-quarter results in mid-July. Analysts said the news was surprising, but they did not doubt AT&T's forecast that profit for the entire year would be at a record high. ``All this suggests to me is a temporary (profit) margin squeeze, with a reversal over the next six months,'' said Stuart Crane, who follows AT&T for the investment firm Gruntal & Co. ``The fundamentals of AT&T are strong,'' he said. ``I don't agree with throwing out the stock.'' In nationwide New York Stock Exchange trading, AT&T shares closed at $39.12{, down $2.12{ from Tuesday's close. Earlier, the shares were down as much as $3.50. About 11.5 million shares changed hands Wednesday, nearly nine times the average daily volume. AT&T estimates it has 2.5 million shareholders, more than any other U.S. company. About 40 percent of the shares are held by individuals. AT&T spokesman Dick Gray said results from April and May indicate sales to U.S. businesses of equipment such as electronic switchboards and private phone systems have been unexpectedly low. Sales of products to telephone operating companies, such as switching equipment, also have been less than anticipated, Gray said, as have been sales to the federal government. AT&T also said sales in its computer division have lagged. The company said the lower equipment sales were due to market conditions and a sluggish economy. AT&T does not disclose how much of its profit it derives from individual business segments. Meanwhile, heavy demand for AT&T's new Universal Card has caused expenses associated with processing applications for the credit card to rise, the company said. AT&T called demand for the card twice the level expected. The card, which combines a phone charge card with a MasterCard or Visa, was introduced in March. The company said the expected decline in second-quarter earnings will make it more difficult to meet its objective of 10 percent to 12 percent profit growth this year. But it stands by its earlier projection that net income for all of 1990 will break last year's record high. In 1989, AT&T earned $2.7 billion, or $2.50 a share, on revenue of $36 billion. For several years, AT&T has been cutting costs by reducing employment levels. In April, AT&T reached agreement with its unions to offer early retirement to about 34,000 workers. The program follows one offered last year to managers, under which about 12,000 opted for early retirement. AT&T has about 315,000 employees. AT&T also plans to continue to move workers into sales and marketing jobs to increase revenue, Gray said. George Kelly, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Co., attributed the slowdown in sales of corporate phone systems partly to the nationwide commercial real estate slump. As fewer companies move to new quarters, fewer phone systems are sold, he said. AT&T also faces increased competition in the office phone market from Rolm, which is owned by International Business Machines Corp. and Siemens AG of West Germany, Kelly said. In the market for central-office switches, the nerve center of phone companies, AT&T has seen increased competition from LM Ericsson of Sweden, Kelly said. Gruntal's Crane said demand for central-office switches has softened as the regional phone operating companies have completed a cycle of buying new equipment. But he predicted an upturn in two to three years as AT&T comes out with new optical-based central switches. The company is several years ahead of competitors in this advanced technology, he said. In last year's second quarter, AT&T earned $699 million, or 65 cents a share, on revenue of $9.26 billion. In light of AT&T's statement, Kelly estimated earnings this quarter would be 63 cents a share, while Crane put the figure at 62 cents. Gregory Sawers, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., estimated 60 cents.

DOC.HEAD: BFI Agrees to Supply Alcoa with Recycled Aluminum
DOC.TEXT: Browning Ferris Industries announced on Wednesday an agreement to sell more than 1 billion used aluminum cans yearly to Alcoa Recycling Co. ``Our agreement with Alcoa is a major milestone to boost aluminum can recycling nationwide,'' said BFI Chairman William D. Ruckelshaus, the former head of the federal Environmental Protection Agency. Houston-based BFI, one of the world's largest waste handling companies, collects cans through organized recycling efforts in 170 programs nationwide involving 1.4 million households. Last year, the programs brought in about 1 billion cans, or 2 percent of the recycled cans. Until now, each of the programs has been selling the aluminum individually. ``This assures us a market, long-term, for the cans, and it assures Alcoa a source of supply, long-term, for the cans,'' said BFI spokesman Peter Block. As part of the agreement, the two companies also will work to expand the collection programs. ``Municipal curbside recycling programs represent a major new source of aluminum available for recovery,'' said Alcoa Recycling President George Cobb, calling recycling an ``above-ground aluminum mine.'' Alcoa Recycling paid $232 million for 17.1 billion cans in 1989, spokesman Al Posti said from the company's Pittsburgh headquarters. About half of the sheet aluminum Alcoa sells for cans comes from recycling, he said. Alcoa will pay BFI market price for the cans. The deal with Alcoa is the third agreement BFI has reached to get rid of the waste it collects. Last year Wellman Inc. agreed to take recyclable plastics. In June, Weyerhaeuser Paper Co. agreed to take 10,000 tons of paper a month in the western United States.

DOC.HEAD: Apparel Maker Stumbles After Acquisition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 13 `The pessimism ...' to UPDATE with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: Apparel manufacturer Salant Corp. sought refuge in bankruptcy court Wednesday after struggling unsuccessfully with debts incurred in buying a larger rival two years ago. It was the second filing under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code for the New York-based clothing company, whose nationally known brands include Dr. Denton sleepwear, John Henry shirts and Lady Manhattan sportswear. Salant attributed its troubles to weakness in the retail business at a time of year that is always the slowest for the company. The fate of Salant furnished another example of what can happen when companies fail to generate enough cash to pay for takeovers financed with borrowed money. The retail industry, on which Salant relies for its business, has had its share of victims, including Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied department store divisions and Ames Department Stores Inc. Ray W. Williams, Salant's chairman and chief executive, said in a news release that ``continued softness in the retail apparel market during the traditional low point of our seasonal business has made it impossible for us to satisfy our obligations to our lenders on a timely basis.'' The bankruptcy filing was foreshadowed in mid-June when Salant diclosed discussions with lenders about refinancing its debts. That news came as Salant revealed it was in default on $10.8 million in principal and interest on bank loans and couldn't cover $1.9 million due on certain bonds. The company said then that it was looking into alternatives, including a second bankruptcy filing. Salant emerged from its first bankruptcy case three years ago. Shortly thereafter it began building a stake in Manhattan Industries Inc., a much bigger competitor that it eventually bought for $105 million in the spring of 1988. Retail analysts said there has been a perception within the trade that Salant undertook too big a task when it bought Manhattan in an effort to broaden its line of national brands. Until the takeover, Salant mainly made private label clothing for retailers such as Sears, Roebuck and Co. and J.C. Penney Co. It also has the Thomson Trouser Co. In buying Manhattan, Salant gained ownership of various Perry Ellis lines, Manhattan shirts, Lady Manhattan sportswear and the Vera label of scarves and other items. The pessimism about Salant's prospects have been reflected in the company's stock price. It closed at $2.87{ a share in composite New York Stock Exchange trading Wednesday, off 25 cents from Tuesday and down from a high of $26.87{ in the last 52 weeks. Salant's first-quarter loss widened to $2.3 million from the $427,000 loss a year earlier. Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service of Prescott Ball & Turben Inc. in New York, said Salant's chairman overreached in buying Manhattan and, in retrospect, paid too high a price. ``His appetite was a little too strong,'' Johnson said. Still, he believes Williams stands a decent chance of turning Salant around. He noted that Williams proved himself an able manager as president of the Farah Manufacturing Co. ``He's a capable man,'' said Johnson. In the news release, Williams said the company believes it can continue operating effectively while negotiating with its creditors and attempting a court-supervised reorganization. Salant's Denton Mills Inc. subsidiary was included in the bankruptcy filing. He said The CIT Group-Factoring has agreed to forward $100 million in working capital to Salant, an arrangement which must be approved by the bankruptcy court. CIT is a company that acts as a financial middleman in transactions between apparel manufacturers and retailers. Alan Millstein, publisher of the New York newsletter Fashion Network Report, said Salant has had a history of missteps, with the Manhattan takeover only the latest misbegotten maneuver. ``It was a case of a minnow swallowing a whale and nearly choking to death on it,'' Millstein said. ``The acquisition of Manhattan Industries was almost a total disaster. The Perry Ellis name was very costly.'' Salant unloaded money-losing portions of Perry Ellis since the 1988 acquisition and only retained the profitable licenses. Millstein said in the 1960s Salant had a shot at becoming as powerful a force in men's wear as Levi Strauss & Co. became with blue jeans. Sales volumes of the two companies were running neck and neck. Salant missed its chance by not plunging deeply into denim as Levi did, Millstein said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices pulled out of their recent slump with a rally Wednesday, shrugging off unwelcome earnings news from American Telephone & Telegraph. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 59.40 points over the past three sessions, climbed 19.80 to 2,862.13. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 851 up, 597 down and 529 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 146.62 million shares, against 141.42 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 172.73 million shares. AT&T stock was by far the day's most active issue, falling 2[ to 39[ on turnover of more than 11.5 million shares. The selloff came after the company said it expects its earnings for the second quarter to fall short of the 65 cents a share it earned in the April-June period last year. AT&T cited weaker-than-expected sales of some of its products, which it attributed to sluggish economic activity and market conditions. The drop in AT&T, which is the nation's most widely held stock with more than 2.6 million shareowners, weighed down the Dow Jones industrial average by close to 4\ points. But analysts said buyers moved cautiously into some other stocks after it became evident that the AT&T setback wasn't starting a general rush to sell. Recent recession fears also seemed to be abated by the Commerce Department's report that the index of leading economic indicators rose 0.8 percent in May. The increase in the index, which is designed to function as a kind of economic crystal ball, came in toward the high end of advance estimates. Elsewhere, Caterpillar, which has fallen sharply since early this week on an earnings disappointment, lost another \ to 52\ in active trading. Pharmaceutical issues were strong, bolstered by bright appraisals from many analysts of the industry's profit outlook even in a sluggish economy. Eli Lilly gained 1| to 81; Bristol-Myers Squibb 1~ to 63\; Abbott Laboratories | to 40~, and Pfizer 1 to 63]. Other gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1\ at 118; Exxon, up 1 at 48; Procter & Gamble, up 1{ at 83}, and General Electric, up [ at 69[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $20.96 billion, or 0.62 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.40 to 193.87. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.53 to 413.78, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 3.08 at 355.14. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 1.51 to 456.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 357.05, up .25.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drifts Higher, Gold Prices Firm
DOC.TEXT: The dollar drifted higher in quiet trading Wednesday as the markets ignored a report that showed the economy may be strengthening, traders said. Gold prices firmed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery closed at $351.40 a troy ounce, up $1. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $350.10, unchanged, as of 4 p.m. EDT. Currency traders said that there was little activity in the market, and that the dollar moved in a tight range. The market had little reaction to the Commerce Department's report that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, rose to 0.8 percent in May to a record high. News of increasing economic activity normally is good for the dollar, but ``a market that's bearish on the dollar ignores good news,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. President Bush's comment Tuesday that he may accept a tax increase to reach a budget accord set the tone for the market, McCarthy said. An accord that cuts the federal deficit could lead to lower interest rates, which tend to devalue the dollar relative to other currencies. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.35 Japanese yen, down from 155.23. In London, the dollar also traded at 154.35. In New York, one dollar bought 154.40 yen, down from 154.55 late Tuesday. In London, one British pound cost $1.7430, more expensive for buyers than Tuesday's $1.7360. In New York, the pound traded at $1.7428, cheaper than $1.7430 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 1.6637 West German marks, up from 1.6618; 1.4095 Swiss francs, up from 1.3975; 5.5910 French francs, up from 5.5770; 1,221.50 Italian lire, up from 1,217.50; and 1.1695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1719. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6635 West German marks, down from 1.6690; 1.4075 Swiss francs, up from 1.4025; 5.5885 French francs, down from 5.6035; 1.8700 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8790; 1,219.50 Italian lire, down from 1,222.25; and 1.1705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1730. Gold traded in a narrow range in Europe. Dealers said there was no investor interest and most participants were squaring up their positions for end-of-the-month accounting. Gold closed in London at a bid price of $350.05 a troy ounce, up from $349.50 late Tuesday, and in Zurich at $349.90 bid, down from $350. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $350.55 bid, down from $353.25. Silver bullion closed in London at a bid $4.84 a troy ounce, up from $4.79. In New York trading, silver for June delivery closed at $4.794 a troy ounce on the Comex, down from $4.820 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Futures Surge On Production Deficit Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Sugar futures prices bounced sharply higher Wednesday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after the Agriculture Department predicted world sugar consumption would outstrip production for the sixth straight year. On other commodity markets, oil futures fell; grains and soybeans were mixed; livestock and meat were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. Sugar futures settled .20 cent to .28 cent higher in New York with the contract for delivery in July at 12.66 cents a pound. The surge followed the release Wednesday morning of a USDA report pegging world sugar production at 107.2 million metric tons and consumption at 109.5 million metric tons for the marketing year beginning Sept. 1. Harry Schwartz, a sugar analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said the heavy buying of sugar futures may have had less to do with the USDA report than with the market's 23 percent decline from prices near 16 cents a pound over the past two months. ``Sugar is on sale,'' he said. ``This is a limited-time-only, get-it-while-it's-cheap type of sugar sale.'' Sugar futures generally have been sinking since early May, following forecasts by private trade houses for shrinking consumption and rising production. The recent decline was helped by statements from the Soviet Union indicating it could not afford to buy more sugar, cocoa and other commodities on the world market. But with the recent sharp drop in sugar prices, speculation is mounting that the Soviets might find the money to make some purchases, Schwartz said. Energy futures prices continued their downward drift on the New York Mercantile Exchange, led by a steep slide in wholesale gasoline prices. Weekly statistics released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute indicated gas demand is running about 5 percent behind last year. Jim Fiedler, an energy specialist for E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said the selloff in gasoline was the catalyst for the market's overall weakness. He said brokers are puzzled because gas demand is still lagging despite the start of the peak summer driving season. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents to 46 cents lower with August at $16.68 a barrel; heating oil was .04 cent to .56 cent lower with July at 47.93 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .70 cent 1.83 cents lower with July at 59.49 cents a gallon. Near-term pork belly futures soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, largely in reaction to a weekly exchange report that showed an unexpectedly large drop of 4 million pounds in supplies of bellies stored in warehouses outside Chicago. Hog futures were supported by stronger cash markets; cattle futures ended mixed. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .23 cent higher with August at 73.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .35 cent lower with August at 84.20 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .35 cent higher with August at 58.92 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.42 cents to 2 cents higher with July at 59.15 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade after a late wave of profit-taking erased strong midday gains in the corn and soybean markets. Susan Leighty, a grain analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the net outcome _ little change in prices _ reflected traders' reluctance to establish new positions ahead of Thursday's Agriculture Department report on planted acreage and grain stocks. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to { cent higher with July at $3.33\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with July at $2.87 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1\ cents lower with July at $1.36\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1{ cents higher with July at $6.08 a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 20 cents to $1 higher with June at $351.40 a troy ounce; silver was 2.6 cents to 3 cents lower with July at $4.795 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Merger Activity Continues To Fall in First Half
DOC.TEXT: Merger activity fell sharply in the first half of the year as the takeover business continued to contract because of the scarcity of financing, according to statistics released Wednesday. Securities Data Corp., a financial research firm, reported 2,110 transactions involving U.S. firms worth a total of $88.2 billion during the first six months to date, down 50 percent in value from the 2,420 deals worth $193 billion in the first half of 1989. The figures reflect not only less activity, but also lower prices for companies. Since the collapse of the junk bond market last fall, money to finance deals has been harder to come by, and prices for businesses have consequently declined. The first-half total includes Philip Morris Cos.' planned purchase of the Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard for $3.8 billion. Securities Data reported that global merger activity was also down during the first half. The company reported 3,736 transactions with a total value of $187.7 billion, down 39 percent from 4,330 deals worth $305.4 billion a year earlier. There was, however, a slight increase in cross-border transactions _ those involving a foreign company and a U.S. company. Securities Data said cross-border deals rose by 2 percent to $29 billion from $28.5 billion. In compiling its figures, Securities Data considered transactions including mergers, acquisitions, spinoffs, share repurchases and self-tenders, minority stake purchases and leveraged recapitalizations.

DOC.HEAD: Government Accepts Private Bid for Bankrupt Mine
DOC.TEXT: The government has accepted a bid from a consortium of Mexican, West German and Canadian investors to buy the bankrupt Cananea copper mine for $468 million, barely half the original asking price. The consortium, Cuprifera Cananea, submitted the only qualified bid Monday for the mine and mill in Cananea, Sonora, about 100 miles southeast of Tuscon, Ariz. The open pit mine, operated since 1760, is the largest in Mexico producing 45 percent of the country's output. Mexico is the third largest copper producer in the world, accounting for 3 percent of global production. The consortium's offer was just above the government-mandated minimum of $450 million and was just over half the $910 million value that the government placed on the mine when it first attempted to sell it in 1988. In addition to the purchase price, the consortium will assume the mine's $700 million in debts. Bankruptcy judge Sergio Higueras disqualified a $600 million bid from the Mexican company Sintemex because the company's representative showed up three minutes after bidding closed and did not present the required letter of credit or $45 million security deposit. The judge must decide whether Cuprifera's bid is qualified within 10 days before the government can turn over its shares to the consortium, which is led by Mexican tycoon Bernardo Quintana. The government took over the mine from Anaconda Copper Mining Co. under the Mining Law of 1961, which nationalized the industry. It first put the mine on the selling block two years ago as part of a move to privatize state industries. When 3,000 union miners threatened to strike last August over contract demands, the government declared bankruptcy and sent in army troops to close down the mine. Two months later, the union accepted a new contract that eliminated 200 union jobs and reopened the mine. The partners of Cuprifera Cananea are the West German metal company Metallgesellschaft and the German bank West Deutsche Landesbank Girozentrale; Teck Corp., a Canadian energy and mining company, and the Mexican development company Ingenieros Civiles Asociados, or Grupo ICA. Quintana is chairman of ICA.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Form Task Force To Ensure Recovery From Drexel Of S&L Money
DOC.TEXT: Regulators formed a legal task force Wednesday to seek compensation for taxpayers from bankrupt Drexel Burnham Lambert Group for junk bond losses suffered by failed savings and loans. Alfred Byrne, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said the agency has preliminary information linking Drexel and its former junk bond chief, Michael Milken, to millions of dollars lost by a number of failed thrifts in junk bonds. The FDIC, which insures bank and thrift deposits, and the Resolution Trust Corp., responsible for closing or merging hundreds of failed thrifts, may be Drexel's largest creditors, he said. ``We intend to recover the maximum amount possible for our insurance funds and, ultimately, for the American taxpayer,'' Byrne said. He declined to estimate the amount of the losses and the number of S&Ls involved. The task force, headed by FDIC deputy general counsel Jack Smith, will consist of 10 to 12 attorneys from the FDIC and RTC. It is aiming for a share of the $350 million set aside by the Securities and Exchange Commission for claimants of Drexel and the $400 million set aside for claimants of Milken. Drexel, which sold investors billions of dollars worth of the risky, high-interest debt securities known as junk bonds, sought bankruptcy protection in federal court in New York in February. A judge scheduled Nov. 15 as the deadline for bringing claims against the firm. Smith said regulators may bring one consolidated claim on behalf of the insurance fund or coordinate the filing of separate claims for each insolvent institution involved. The FDIC-RTC legal group also will be considering possible criminal referrals to the Justice Department concerning Milken and Drexel. For at least two years, federal banking regulators have been investigating deals between Drexel's junk bond operation in Beverly Hills, Calif., and a ``daisy chain'' of thrifts that traded the bonds among themselves in an alleged scheme to inflate their assets. Among the institutions involved are Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Irvine, Calif., perhaps the nation's costliest thrift failure with an estimated bailout expense of $2 billion, and Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver, where President Bush's son, Neil, served on the board of directors. The failures of Lincoln and other institutions since early last year has left the RTC with a $4 billion portfolio of junk bonds to sell. Ken Lerer, a spokesman for Milken, had no comment on the FDIC announcement. Steven Anreder, a spokesman for Drexel, said: ``As with any other party, (the regulators) will have to present a provable claim. It will be up to the courts to determine its validity.'' Meanwhile, a group of Democratic House members proposed creation of a special House committee to investigate the scandal. ``When Congress appropriates money, it expects the executive branch to manage the programs so that taxpayers' money will be...not lost through incompetence or stolen by crooks,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. However, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said he didn't see the need to gear up another bureaucracy on Capitol Hill. ``I think the committees of Congress presently authorized can make the necessary inquiries,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bell Atlantic, Spain's Telefonica Win Phone Bids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version ran on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bell Atlantic Corp. and Telefonica of Spain reportedly submitted winning bids for control of Argentina's state telephone company. The sales are critical to Argentina's attempt to sell many of its money-losing state companies, which employ tens of thousands of workers but are criticized for chronic inefficiences. The sales also have been designed to pare the country's foreign debt. Argentina is the third most-indebted country in the developing world behind Mexico and Brazil. Bids for ENTel, notorious for its poor telephone service and money-losing operations, were opened by the government Monday and will be announced formally on Thursday. The company is being auctioned off in two sections, serving the northern and southern parts of the country. The Public Works Ministry on Tuesday confirmed newspaper reports that Telefonica, Spain's state-controlled telecommunications monopoly, submitted the highest bids for both sections of ENTel. But the bidding rules do not allow one company to control both sections, and Telefonica chose the southern section. Philadephia-based Bell Atlantic reportedly was allowed to raise its bid slightly and won control of the northern section. Both sections split the Buenos Aires metropolitan area, home to nearly one-third of Argentina's 32 million residents. President Carlos Menem, in power since last July, has endorsed privatizations as a way to prove Argentina is serious about righting its economic situation. But his powerful labor-based Peronist party has balked at the moves, saying too many state workers would lose their jobs. Telefonica director Enrique Used Aznar was quoted as telling the newspaper La Nacion that his company chose the southern sector because ``we think it has greater potential to develop our plans of investment and expansion.'' Bell Atlantic's representative in Argentina, Carlos Joost Newbery, was quoted by La Nacion as saying his company increased its offer for the northern section above Telefonica's to win the bid. Bell Atlantic's initial offer exceeded that of another bidder, STET of Italy. In all, ownership of 60 percent of ENTel (Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones) was sold for $214 million in cash and $379 million to be paid over six years. The winning bidders also will buy $5 billion in Argentina's long-term bank debt and overdue interest payments, erasing a sizable chunk of the country's $62 billion debt burden. Argentina's debt has been trading at a fraction of its face value on the open market. The cost to Bell Atlantic and Telefonica of retiring the debt has been estimated at somewhat over $500 million. Ten percent of the new companies will be sold to employees and the remaining 30 percent will be sold to the public via the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange. Public Works Minister Jose Dromi said the companies are to be privatized formally on Oct. 8.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Proposal Erupts Into S&L Fairness Debate
DOC.TEXT: A debate on the alleged unfairness of the savings and loan bailout toward taxpayers in the Northeast erupted on the Senate floor Wednesday. The clash was the first of what some senators warned could become an increasingly ugly, regional conflict that could spread from the thrift bailout to such other issues as housing, agriculture or defense spending. In the midst of a seemingly unrelated debate on housing legislation, northeastern lawmakers sparred with Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, over reports that states like Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts will bear the heaviest burden in cleaning up the financial mess in the Southwest. Gramm touched off the debate with an amendment to change the formula for community development block grants in favor of Sunbelt states where population is growing rapidly. The proposal immediately was challenged by lawmakers who brandished the S&L collapse as evidence that the Northeast already is carrying too much baggage for Texas and other southern states. ``This amendment has the possibilities of creating enormous regional animosities, of tearing us apart at a time when we need to be coming together,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. The Senate voted to kill Gramm's proposal, but not before it triggered a strong reaction from Northern senators of both parties. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., proposed a counter-amendment that would ensure recipients of bailout money such as Texas would lose a proportional amount of block grant funding. D'Amato said Congress approved the bailout of the collapsed savings and loan industry last year even though most of the money would go to a few southwestern states _ most prominently Texas. But with Gramm's housing amendment, he said, the rules have changed. ``The citizens of New York will pay taxes to clean up the problems elsewhere and be deprived of the economic use of those funds,'' D'Amato said. ``Worse still, the empty office space and cheap homes built with S&L money can be used to lure businesses away from New York, away from Connecticut.'' Gramm shot back that the S&L bailout money wasn't being poured into the coffers of the state of Texas or its citizens _ it was paying back insured depositors, many of them high-roller investors from the Northeast. He called the idea of using ``trumped up amendments based on the S&L bailout'' a ``cute and clever'' tactic. ``To in any way equate the S&L bailout with a formula for allocating community development block grant funds, a formula that in its current incarnation is absolutely unfair, is just outrageous,'' Gramm said. ``I'm not trying to beat a regional horse here.'' D'Amato admitted his amendment was more of a symbolic gesture than a serious effort at legislation. But D'Amato and others said the idea of penalizing the Southwest reflected a genuine outrage over the S&L burden it was placing on the rest of the country. Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., cited statistics showing the extent to which northeastern and midwestern taxpayers will be funneling money to the Southwest. ``Texas, Texas, Texas,'' Dixon bellowed. ``The big winner.'' Kerry spoke ominously of a farm bill, about to come to the Senate floor, ``with goodies galore'' for western and southern farm states. If Gramm and others move to tilt other federal programs in favor of the Sunbelt, Kerry said, ``the repercussions are going to play out as we debate the farm bill.'' Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., threatened to block a water resources development bill containing a substantial amount of money for Texas. Moynihan chairs a Senate subcommittee handling the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Urge Foreign Investment, Last Borders to Fall
With AM-Germany-Money, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The West German economics minister on Wednesday urged foreign companies to invest in East Germany, saying they would find a stable market and a ``bridge to East Europe.'' Helmut Haussmann made his statements at a meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce in Hamburg as the giant West German electronics firm, Siemens, announced it would invest $600 million in East Germany over the next three years. Meanwhile, West Germany said the last of the borders between the two Germanies would fall Sunday, the day the two countries merge their economies and East Germany sheds 40 years of socialism for free-market rules. Full political union is now expected after all-German elections, suggested for early December. The Germanys, after completing the treaty on economic merger, are now working on one that would iron out the consitutional issues. Some experts say up to 4 million people could lose their jobs in East Germany as industries once supported by the state fail in the open market. More than one-third of businesses are expected to close. An influx of Western industry and goods could help offset the falling standard of living, experts have said. Haussmann said he hoped the United States, Japan and all of Europe would discover East Germany, which he said offered secure market conditions and a stable currency. Western companies have been reluctant to invest in East Germany during the current political upheaval and transition to a market economy. East German Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl, also at the Hamburg meeting, said that of the 2,000 joint venture agreements East Germany had signed so far with Western companies, less than 5 percent were with non-West German companies. In arguing for investment in East Germany, Haussmann said the country would be a member of both the European Economic Community and Comecon, East Europe's economic equivalent. ``East Germany is the bridge between the EC and Comecon,'' Haussmann said. ``Make use of that bridge. If you come too late, you will miss out.'' Much of Eastern Europe has opened to new investment following last year's rejection of repressive Communist rule and subsequent democratic reforms. The announcement by Siemens would represent the biggest single investment since East Germany implemented its reforms. The company said it would have up to 30,000 employees in what is now East Germany within several years. Siemens manufacturers computers, telecommunications equipment, household appliances and other products. The company said its East German projects would be in communications, data processing, energy and transportation technology, plant automation, medical technology and environmental protection. The investment includes previously announced joint ventures with 11 former government enterprises and a contract to upgrade East Germany's poor telephone system in six major cities. Siemens spokesman Eberhard Posner said most new employees would be East Germans _ half newly hired and the rest from existing East German companies. In another step toward unification, the Bonn government said that on Sunday for the first time Germans would be able to travel from East to West without border controls. In Bonn, government spokesman Hans Klein said West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and his East German counterpart Peter-Michael Diestel would meet along the border between East Germany and Bavaria on Sunday to sign an agreement eliminating all frontier controls.

DOC.HEAD: Government Aims At Higher Economic Growth Rate
DOC.TEXT: South Korea has boosted its economic growth target for this year to 8 percent to 9 percent, up sharply from 6.5 percent previously, a government plan said Wednesday. The new target compares with actual growth of 6.7 percent last year when exports, the engine of South Korea's economic growth, were sluggish. The country's economy grew at an annual average rate of 12.7 percent between 1986 and 1988, when exports jumped by more than 20 percent annually. The new goal was contained in the economic plan for the second half of this year that was adopted Tuesday in a meeting of economic ministers. Officials at the Economic Planning Board said the upward revision was prompted by a better-than-expected economic performance in the first half and an anticipated export recovery in the latter half. The plan said the gross national product was estimated to have grown at a rate of 9.2 percent in the first half, mainly spurred by strong private consumption and booming construction business. According to the plan, South Korea is expected to post a current account deficit of $1 billion this year, its first shortfall in five years. The government previously had projected a surplus of $2 billion for the year. Officials said the economic management plan calls for holding down annual price inflation to 9 percent by cooling down overheated domestic consumption and curbing hotel, leisure and other unnecessary construction projects. Korean consumer prices have gone up an estimated 7 percent so far this year, fueled by excessive demands for construction materials connected with a boom in real estate and excessive private consumption. The annual inflation rate stood at 5.7 percent last year and averagd 3.8 percent in the preceding seven years. A government think tank predicted two weeks ago that prices would rise 13 percent this year. The government plans to peg this year's total money supply growth at 19 percent to contain inflation, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Executive Accused of Conflict of Interest
DOC.TEXT: A former vice president of the failed Midwest Federal Savings and Loan was charged Wednesday with violating federal regulations in arranging a loan to the co-owner of a Miami resort. The indictment accuses Susan Greenwood Olson, who also is the daughter of Midwest Federal's chairman, of concealing the nature of her relationship with the co-owner of the beachfront Jockey Club when she arranged loans for him and the club. The indictment did not describe the nature of the alleged relationship with Howard M. Lorber and prosecutors refused to comment beyond the indictment. The new charges coincided with the appearance of former Chairman Harold W. Greenwood Jr. in federal court to face separate charges in the thrift's 1989 collapse. Greenwood and three former top executives were charged Tuesday with hiding the thrift's losses. The cost to the government of selling or liquidating Midwest Federal is expected to be about $1 billion. Ms. Olson was indicted in March on fraud charges involving $15 million in loans to the Jockey Club. Prosecutors amended that indictment Wednesday to charge Ms. Olson with concealing ``the true nature of her relationship with Howard M. Lorber during the same time frame she arranged for Midwest Federal to make over $5.4 million in unsafe and unsecured loans to the Jockey Club in which Howard M. Lorber owned a sizeable interest.'' ``I do not know what the language of that count means,'' said Olson's attorney, Mark Erickson. ``It's just another count. Why they put it in now, I don't know.'' The March indictment charged that Ms. Olson obtained an inflated appraisal of the Jockey Club to justify excess loans. The club, which owed Midwest Federal $23.5 million in February 1989, was sold a year ago for about $2.8 million. The revised indictment adds Robert A. Mampel, Greenwood's former executive assistant, as a co-defendant. The indictment said Ms. Olson also arranged a $400,000 unsecured personal loan for Lorber and an unsecured credit line of $50,000. She was charged with hiding the ``clear and direct conflict of interest.'' Lorber could not be reached immediately for comment. Ms. Olson said she is innocent and will fight the charges. ``I don't have anything to be ashamed of,'' she said. ``I'm a very typical middle-class person and I've abided by the laws. ``I'm not a criminal,'' she said. ``I'm going to fight it out. I'm doing OK. He's (Greenwood) prepared to fight it out as well.'' Mampel also was charged Tuesday with Greenwood. Mampel's lawyer, Earl Gray, said he did not know why prosecutors decided to charge Mampel in separate indictments. Assistant U.S. Attorney Hank Shea declined to elaborate on the charges against Mampel. Greenwood and former Managing Officer Charlotte E. Masica appeared briefly before U.S. Magistrate J. Earl Cudd. Mampel appeared in an adjacent room before U.S. Magistrate Floyd Boline. Their next court appearances were set for July 3. A summons has been issued for a fourth former executive, Donald J. Snede, the thrift's former chief financial officer. Snede is scheduled to make his first court appearance July 11. Gray said Snede may be cooperating with prosecutors in an attempt to work out a plea bargain. Shea did not comment and Snede did not return a message left on his answering machine at his home. Neither Greenwood nor Ms. Masica talked openly during brief court appearances. Greenwood fidgeted with his hands and occasionally whispered to his attorney. No pleas were entered. Greenwood is accused of withdrawing $2.5 million from his personal accounts at Midwest Federal within two weeks of the government takeover. Federal deposit insurance covers only the first $100,000 in personal accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Truckers Call for Shutdown in United States and Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf, `But he ...' to UPDATE with plans for Canadian protest; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Johns said.'
DOC.TEXT: A new truck drivers group is asking other truckers to stay off the roads in the United States and Canada from July 1 through July 4 to protest poor pay and working conditions, organizers of the proposed shutdown said Wednesday. If the ``truckers' holiday'' is successful, food products will be in short supply at grocery stores by July 5, said Herman Johns, president of the United Truckers Alliance. And if their demands for better pay and working conditions are ignored, the Belleville-based group wants truckers to stay out until they are met. ``We are losing our professional drivers because they can't afford to keep driving. They must work 90 to 100 hours a week,'' said Cecilia ``CeCe'' Nebgen, vice president of UTA, which was formed in February. The group, which says it represents 3,000 truckers, said that 1 million of the estimated 2.7 million over-the-road truck drivers are expected to join the effort. That figure was scoffed at by Don Tepper, spokesman for the National Private Truck Council in Alexandria, Va. The council represents shippers, producers and truck carrier companies nationwide. ``If they expect 1 million drivers to join them, then Santa Claus would be leading the way,'' Tepper said, noting that similar calls by other groups in the early 1980s were unsuccessful. But he conceded that a successful four-day stoppage could leave store shelves understocked or bare. Meanwhile, in a separate action, Canadian truck drivers were preparing to park their rigs at border crossings at midnight Thursday to protest government policies in their country that they believe are unfair to Canadian truckers. Wayne Whitney, a Windsor, Ont., driver who heads a group called Canadian Truckers Fighting Back, said Wednesday in the Canadian capital of Ottawa that his group is asking drivers not to cross the border. Several border points in Ontario and Quebec were shutdown earlier this month by drivers who say they are being forced out of business by U.S. trucking companies. Johns said members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents about 15 percent of truck drivers, were expected to join next week's protest. Teamsters officials in Washington did not return repeated phone calls for comment. Half the membership of the UTA, formed in February, is comprised of independent drivers and the other half work for shipping or other companies, Johns said. Tepper said about 150,000 of the nation's truck drivers are independent, or so-called owner-operators. Johns said truckers are being driven out of the industry by increases in operation costs and decreasing paychecks. ``Truckers haven't had a pay raise in 10 years, since deregulation took effect,'' he said, referring to congressional action that eased restrictions on the trucking industry in 1980. Tepper conceded pay is low for some drivers. ``Some owner-operators are making a nice living and there are other operators who are earning very little. But it's a measurable minority,'' he said. Johns said the alliance wants all truck carriers and companies that ship goods by truck to: _Pay company drivers 32 cents per mile and $16 per hour for all time spent driving, fueling, loading, unloading and working around the truck. Company drivers are now paid about 20 cents per mile and no hourly wage, Johns said. Tepper said they make between 20 and 25 cents per mile. _Pay independent drivers $1 per mile for the use of their tractor, an additional 20 cents per mile if the trailer is supplied by the owner-operator and $16 per hour labor. Johns said independents currently make about 80 cents per mile. Tepper doubted truckers would win their demands. ``With the competition in the marketplace and with the number of drivers that there are, those wage and compensation levels couldn't be justified,'' Tepper said. ``There are people willing to work for less.'' Several drivers a truck stop in Troy, in Southern Illinois, said they planned to join the stoppage. ``Yeah, I plan to stay home'' Greenville, Pa., driver Dennis Bowman said. ``When you look at a paycheck of $500 and you're working 110 hours a week, it doesn't make much sense.'' But Chicago trucker Ronald Thomas said, ``I don't believe in shutdowns. I don't think it does any good.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Blood Pressure Drug
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A New York drug company Wednesday began recalling a generic drug used to treat high blood pressure after the Food and Drug Administration alleged the company submitted false information to the agency. Interpharm Inc. of Plainview, N.Y., agreed to recall all three strengths of clonidine hydrochloride tablets from distributors and pharmacies and to conduct an audit of its 24 other products, the FDA said. The drug comes in small, round, blue tablets marked ``IP 47.'' Routine testing by the FDA found that ``samples of clonidine hydrochloride 0.3 milligram tablets submitted for bioequivalence testing by Interpharm were not the same as the product on the market,'' the agency said. The tablets Interpharm was marketing were blue, and in its application for approval the company told the FDA its tablets were blue. But the pills that were tested for bioequivalence before the drug was approved were peach-colored, the FDA said. The agency said it found no manufacturing or production data that indicated the company had ever made any peach-colored pills. The FDA said it had no evidence of a safety problem with the drug Interpharm was marketing, but questions whether the product is therapeutically equivalent to the brand name drug, Catapres, made by Boehringer Ingelheim. FDA officials advised patients who use the product to consult with their physician about switching to another product. Interpharm was one of 20 generic drug companies selected for intensified inspections last year in the wake of allegations that several companies had falsified documents and cheated on tests needed to win FDA approval. The investigation that resulted has produced more than a dozen criminal convictions. More than 100 drugs have been recalled or withdrawn.

DOC.HEAD: State Sues Accountant Who Backed Lincoln Junk Bond Claims
DOC.TEXT: The state of California sued deposed S&L boss Charles H. Keating Jr. and his accounting firm Wednesday in an effort to recover $250 million lost on junk bonds sold through Keating's Lincoln Savings & Loan. Attorney General John Van de Kamp contended that Arthur Young & Co.'s audit of Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., deceived the public about the safety of the company. Phoenix-based American Continental issued the high-yield, high-risk bonds, which were sold primarily to elderly investors at branches of Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln. ``If investors had known the truth, no one would have invested a dime in those bonds. Keating and company would have been laughed out of the market,'' Van de Kamp said at a news conference. ``But with Arthur Young standing behind them, their bonds sold easily.'' The bonds became worthless when American Continental filed for bankruptcy protection in April 1989. Federal regulators seized Lincoln the next day. They say it may cost taxpayers $2 billion to cover the thrift's losses. Van de Kamp's unfair business practices suit contends Arthur Young and its former partner who audited American Continental, Jack Atchison, should have known the company was losing huge sums of money. Instead, Van de Kamp said, the accountants vouched for a ``glowing prospectus'' that said American Continental was profitable and a good risk. The state's lawsuit follows the lead of class-action suits already filed on behalf of the more than 20,000 bondholders, which name as defendants accountants and lawyers for American Continental and Keating. ``You go after the people who were paid by Keating,'' said John D.K. Brunner, the chairman of a committee of the bondholders. ``Keating has very skillfully planned to hide behind his Chapter 11 (bankruptcy filing), but for those people who profited very heavily by him and did his bid and calling _ the lawyers, accountants and all those _ that's the only chance us bondholders will ever have of getting our money back.'' California's lawsuit, filed in state court in Orange County, seeks to recover $250 million from Arthur Young, Atchison, Keating, American Continental and other company officials. It also seeks penalties of more than $50 million and an injunction to stop Arthur Young from engaging in alleged deceptive audits of thrifts. Atchison could not be located for comment. Earlier this year he invoked his Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination and declined to testify in a hearing on Keating's lawsuit attempting to reclaim control of Lincoln. Arthur Young now does business as Ernst & Young. Its associate general counsel, Eugene Erbstoesser, said he had not seen the lawsuit. But he denied any wrongdoing and said the firm had conformed to all applicable accounting standards. Keating's attorney, James Ham, accused Van de Kamp of wasting money on lawsuits that can recover no money from his client, who he said is broke. Van de Kamp said Arthur Young should have detected what he said were American Continental's fraudulent misrepresentations. Last August, regulators who seized Lincoln released a report by an outside accounting firm, Kenneth Leventhal & Co., whom they had hired to assess Keating's accounting practices. Leventhal concluded American Continental used accounting ``gimmickry'' to inflate its profits. Keating's activities are the targets of several criminal probes and federal investigations, and a securities fraud suit by California's Department of Corporations. Van de Kamp said Keating and his associates at American Continental ``were running a huge financial con game, and sucking the assets out of Lincoln Savings to sustain their operations.'' Atchison was later hired by American Continental at a salary of $900,000 a year _ four times what he was making at Arthur Young. ``It takes no great insight to understand why he was worth that princely sum to ACC,'' Van de Kamp said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Edges Higher, Share Prices Lose Moderately in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar edged higher against the Japanese yen in early trading Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined moderately. The dollar started trading at 154.57 yen, up 0.22 yen from Wednesday's close. It finished at 154.40 yen in New York overnight, down from 154.55 yen late Tuesday. Kouhei Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar's firmness followed dollar buying in the Sydney market, which opened earlier than Tokyo's. ``But the dollar will not move in a one-sided direction today because of a lack of fresh incentives'' to affect exchange rates, Kuroda said. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 177.41 points, or 0.54 percent, to move to 32,135.34 in the first 15 minutes of trading. The index gained 740.98 points Wednesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 87.03, down from Wednesday's close of 87.05. The yield stood at 7.18 percent, up from the previous day's 7.175 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Revamps Housing Programs, Raises Price of FHA Mortgages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Senate passage of bill and later debate. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday approved overhauling federal housing policies and requiring first-time home buyers to pay more for FHA-backed mortgages. The bill, which had languished on the Senate floor for nearly two weeks, was approved on a 96-1 vote after Democrats and Republicans announced agreement on key provisions with the Bush administration. The only no vote was cast by Sen. William Roth, R-Del. As passed, the legislation would authorize $18.1 billion in federal spending on housing in fiscal 1991, $19.5 billion in 1992 and $21 billion in 1993, compared with the $14.5 billion being spent this year. The issue now movesto the House, where a competing version would cost far more money and take a different approach to restructuring often scandal-prone federal housing programs that have basically gone unchanged since 1968. ``Many problems still face us dealing with the conference'' with House members over their bill, said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. But he called the compromise and Senate vote ``an important breakthrough that could assure passage of a major housing bill this year.'' Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp joined Senate sponsors, including D'Amato and Cranston, in announcing agreement on key elements of the bill. The administration agreed to authorize spending some $3 billion more on federal housing programs next year than President Bush sought in his proposed budget for fiscal 1991. In return, the administration's so-called Homeownership Opportunity for People Everywhere (HOPE) program to encourage eventual tenant purchase of public housing units, was included with $1.9 billion over three years. Senate Democrats also agreed to accept Kemp's proposals to make home buyers using FHA mortgages ante up more of their own money at the point of sale as a measure for shoring up the financially imperiled program. Under the changes, new home buyers with FHA-backed loans would have to make at least a 5 percent down payment on the purchase price and cover at least two-thirds of the closing costs out of their own pockets without financing. Loans with low down payments, deemed most at risk to default, would also be subject to an added annual fee. The administration, in turn, gave Senate Democrats the Housing Opportunity Program (HOP) which would consolidate 10 existing housing programs for sending money to local governments to renovate or build new housing for low-income families. Democrats agreed to accept provisions that would allow a portion of the money to be spent on vouchers for the poor to use for rental housing, despite the Senate's rejection of a similar proposal last week. The Senate passed the bill after spending much of the day using it as a vehicle to argue about which regions of the country were having to spend the most on the savings and loan bailout. The final hour was spent on debating an amendment by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., directing negotiators working on a deficit reduction package to cut a wide variety of federal programs and subsidies before raising taxes. President Bush on Tuesday said a tax increase is needed in addition to spending cuts. Helms' amendment was later accepted on a voice vote after it was watered down to say that the negotiators should consider the most feasible budget reduction proposals from a wide variety of groups before considering new or increased taxes. Earlier, rancorous debate centered on a proposal by Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, to shift community development subsidies in the housing bill from the Northeast to Texas and 35 other states, many in the Sun Belt. His amendment would have changed distribution formula for the $3 billion in block grants to one based solely on population. The Senate voted to table, or kill, Gramm's proposal on a 63-35 vote after it triggered a strong reaction from northern senators who charged Texas and the Southwest have benefited most from the massive federal spending on covering S&L losses. ``The people of New York are going to pay $17 billion for the savings and loan bailout,'' said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``The state of Texas gets 59 percent of that. ... Why should every man, woman and child have to pony up money to pay for that?'' D'Amato said. He retaliated with an amendment that would reduce community development grants to states with savings and loans institutions that have been taken over by the federal government. It died with Gramm's amendment. Gramm's proposal would have replaced a complex formula now in use that places greater emphasis on the age of existing housing, population crowding, the number of people in poverty and the rate of growth. ``I'm trying to right a terrible wrong in the allocation of money,'' Gramm said. ``I don't think New York has any room to cry ... about the allocation of funds. Texas gets cheated by the current formula,'' he said. According to Gramm's figures, New York would suffer a 95 percent cut in its community development money, from $302 million to $207 million. Other states that would lose money would be Hawaii, Illinois, Iowa, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. Texas, Florida and California would be among the biggest gainers, each getting an increase of more than $20 million. Three senators did not vote on final passage of the bill. They were Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass.; William Armstrong, R-Colo.; and Claiborne Pell, D-R.I.
